questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to nausea, vomiting, and right upper quadrant abdominal pain for the past day. The patient drinks one liter of vodka per day and her last drink was about 36 hours ago. Temperature is 37.7 ºC (99.9 ºF), pulse is 122/min, blood pressure is 162/101 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is diaphoretic, agitated, and tremulous. During the examination, it appears as though the patient is speaking to someone else in the room, although no one else is present. Serum alcohol level is negative. CBC, CMP, and PT/INR are drawn and the patient’s Maddrey discriminant function is 30 and MELD score is 16, respectively. Which of the following medications should be administered at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient with alcohol use disorder presents with RUQ abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and an elevated Maddrey discriminant function (MDF) and MELD score, indicating alcohol-induced hepatitis. This patient is agitated, tachycardic, tremulous, and having hallucinations indicating severe alcohol withdrawal.

After diagnosing alcohol-induced hepatitis, the next step is to calculate the Maddrey discriminant function (MDF) which uses total bilirubin and prothrombin time (PT). The MELD (model for end-stage liver disease) score can also be calculated using sodium, creatinine, total bilirubin, and INR. Patients with DF >32 or MELD >20 should receive treatment with (methyl)prednisolone or pentoxifylline, if steroids are contraindicated. Patients, like this one, with DF ≤32 or MELD ≤20 should receive supportive care without pharmacologic treatment of the hepatitis. All patients should have the underlying alcohol use disorder addressed and treated with alcohol cessation counseling and potential medications such as oral naltrexone.

This patient also has severe alcohol withdrawal which should be treated. Severe alcohol withdrawal can have life-threatening consequences such as delirium tremens and seizures. Patients should receive benzodiazepine therapy to help treat symptoms and prevent seizures. Most severe complications occur within 48-72 hours of the patient’s last drink, but this is not always the case. Lorazepam and diazepam are both frequently used, with oral or IV routes depending upon the severity of the symptoms.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous lorazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis; however since the Maddrey discriminant function is <32 and the MELD score is <20, no treatment is indicated.  
❌ Intravenous naltrexone:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate for an opioid overdose which would cause the patient to be lethargic, not hyperactive and anxious.  
❌ Oral prednisolone:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis; however, since the Maddrey discriminant function is <32 and the MELD score is <20, no treatment is indicated.  
❌ Oral pentoxifylline:
Incorrect: This patient likely has alcohol-induced hepatitis; however since the Maddrey discriminant function is <32 and the MELD score is <20, no treatment is indicated. Steroids are preferred over pentoxifylline unless there is a contraindication to steroid use.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of myocardial infarction presents to his primary care physician’s office for a follow-up visit after an incidental imaging finding on CT angiography showed 75% occlusion of the celiac artery and 70% occlusion of the superior mesenteric artery. He has not experienced abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or weight loss. He states he has his usual good appetite. He currently smokes 1 pack per day of cigarettes. His medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, lisinopril, and metoprolol. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg, pulse is 62/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, his abdomen is nontender and without rebound or guarding. Which of the following is appropriate management at this time?
questions.solution:
This patient has significant stenosis of 2 mesenteric vessels, which can lead to acute or chronic mesenteric ischemia (CMI). He does not exhibit symptoms of chronic mesenteric ischemia which include postprandial abdominal pain, nausea, diarrhea, weight loss and food aversion. Some patients with stenosis of mesenteric vessels can be asymptomatic due to collateral blood flow.

In most instances of significant CMI (≥ 70% stenosis of 2 or more mesenteric vessels) with symptoms, treatment is aimed at improving blood flow to the intestines in an effort to reduce symptoms and improve quality of life. Revascularization techniques may include angioplasty and stent placement or bypass graft. However, when stenosis is found incidentally and/or the patient does not have symptoms related to CMI, conservative therapy can be utilized to minimize progression of the disease. This includes antiplatelet therapy (e.g., aspirin), as well as management of potential contributing conditions (e.g., hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes).  Additionally, smoking cessation counseling should be provided, if relevant. Duplex ultrasound monitoring is also important for tracking disease progression.

Option Analysis

✅ Smoking cessation counseling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rivaroxaban:
Incorrect: Anticoagulation is generally not warranted for asymptomatic mesenteric vessel occlusion.  
❌ Surgical consultation for stent placement:
Incorrect: Revascularization is warranted for symptomatic chronic mesenteric ischemia. However, in asymptomatic or incidental cases of mesenteric vessel occlusion, conservative management is appropriate.  
❌ Surgical consultation for bypass:
Incorrect: Revascularization is warranted for symptomatic chronic mesenteric ischemia. However, in asymptomatic or incidental cases of mesenteric vessel occlusion, conservative management is appropriate.  
❌ Watchful waiting:
Incorrect: While this patient may not have concerning symptoms, it is still important to manage risk factors for the progression of his vascular stenosis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to constipation. For the past two months the patient has only been having bowel movements every 5-6 days. The patient’s stool is very firm and difficult to pass, and frequently causes anal pain after defecation. Sometimes there is a small amount of bright red blood on the toilet paper after the patient wipes. The patient’s appetite has been poor lately due to bloating and mild lower quadrant abdominal pain. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, the patient’s abdomen is slightly distended and mildly firm and tender to palpation in the lower quadrants. On the digital rectal exam, there is a firm stool in the rectal vault as well as a 1 cm mucosal tear at the posterior anus. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with decreased frequency of bowel movements and stools that are difficult to pass which are the characteristics of constipation. The patient has pain after defecation and has developed a small anal fissure which can cause small amounts of bright red blood when wiping. In addition, physical exam findings of slightly distended, firm, and tender lower abdominal quadrants, and digital rectal exam with hard stool in the rectal vault and an anal fissure all support the diagnosis of constipation. The next step in management should be reviewing the patient’s medication list as medications are frequently the cause of constipation. If there are no obvious culprit medications, other organic etiologies can be pursued before a diagnosis of functional constipation can be made. Patients should also be asked about fluid intake, diet (especially fiber), physical activity, and habits around bowel movements.
 

Medication-induced constipation is a common cause of constipation. Opioids are the most common medication that can cause opioid-induced constipation. Opioid medications are a frequent cause of constipation in patients with chronic pain or cancer-related pain. Several other medications such as calcium channel blockers (e.g. amlodipine), antidepressants, and agents with anticholinergic properties (e.g., diphenhydramine, oxybutynin) may cause non-opioid-related constipation. If feasible, the culprit medication should be discontinued and swapped out for a different type of medication or even a lower dose of the medication if possible. Lifestyle modifications should be reinforced and other medications (such as osmotic or stimulant laxatives) may need to be added.  

Option Analysis

✅ Review medication list:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform a colonoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient’s small amount of bright red blood can be explained by the difficulty passing stool and the resultant anal fissure. Colonoscopy is not necessary at this point.  
❌ Perform a flexible sigmoidoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient’s small amount of bright red blood can be explained by the difficulty passing stool and the resultant anal fissure. Colonoscopy is not necessary at this point.  
❌ Recommend twice-daily fiber supplement:
Incorrect: While this may be necessary to help with regulating bowel movements, a medication reconciliation should be performed first, in case the constipation is a medication side effect.  
❌ Prescribe sennosides-docusate:
Incorrect: While this may be necessary to help with regulating bowel movements, a medication reconciliation should first be performed, in case this is a medication side effect.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for routine follow-up. The patient developed chronic pancreatitis 5 years ago. The patient previously had heavy alcohol use but has been in recovery for the past year. She smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. Current medications include naproxen (as needed) and pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy. Laboratory studies today are notable for fasting blood glucose of 190 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c of 8.5%. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed diabetes mellitus (type 3c) as a result of chronic pancreatitis, as evidenced by a high fasting blood sugar and hemoglobin A1c. This can occur as a result of islet cell loss during the course of pancreatic inflammation and fibrosis. The duration of chronic pancreatitis appears to be the most important risk factor for the development of endocrine insufficiency.

Management of diabetes mellitus related to chronic pancreatitis usually involves insulin. Metformin is sometimes an option for cases with hyperglycemia, but its use is often limited because of gastrointestinal side effects. Because chronic pancreatitis results in the destruction of all types of cells within the pancreas, regulatory hormone production (such as glucagon) is also diminished. This places patients at an increased risk for hypoglycemia, so tight glucose control is typically avoided.

Patients with chronic pancreatitis should also have their pain controlled with medications or procedures. Patients with exocrine insufficiency should be started on pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy. Treating the underlying cause of chronic pancreatitis may involve lifestyle modifications for alcohol use disorder, corticosteroids for autoimmune disease, and endoscopic management for ductal obstruction. All patients with chronic pancreatitis should have periodic screening for diabetes mellitus, fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies, and osteoporosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Empagliflozin:
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitors, such as empagliflozin, are associated with an increased risk of pancreatitis. Additionally, due to the loss of endocrine function by the pancreas, insulinotropic medications are generally avoided in patients with chronic pancreatitis.  
❌ Sitagliptin:
Incorrect: Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 inhibitors, such as sitagliptin, are associated with an increased risk of pancreatitis. Additionally, due to the loss of endocrine function, insulinotropic medications are generally avoided in patients with chronic pancreatitis.  
❌ Glipizide:
Incorrect: Due to the loss of endocrine function, insulinotropic medications, such as glipizide, are generally avoided in patients with chronic pancreatitis.  
❌ Low glycemic diet:
Incorrect: This patient has developed endocrine insufficiency as a result of chronic pancreatitis. Since the patient’s pancreas is not producing sufficient insulin on its own, insulin therapy is necessary to manage this patient’s glucose levels in addition to initiating a low glycemic diet.  
✅ Insulin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is brought by her husband to the emergency department for altered mental status. Her husband reports that the patient has had a fever and runny nose for the past 3 days and has mostly been in bed. She started complaining of polyuria, polydipsia, and abdominal pain 8 hours prior to presentation. Past medical history is significant for diabetes mellitus type 1. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), blood pressure is 102/66 mmHg, pulse rate is 130/min, and respiratory rate is 28/min. The patient is oriented to person only. Physical examination is significant for dry mucous membranes and decreased skin turgor. Abdominal examination is significant for diffuse abdominal pain. Blood work is obtained, and the results are shown below. The patient is started on IV 0.9% normal saline and IV insulin is ordered. Which of the following should be administered next?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of diabetes mellitus type 1 presents with altered mental status, polyuria, polydipsia, abdominal pain, tachypnea, and signs of dehydration. This clinical presentation, history, and laboratory findings of high-anion gap metabolic acidosis, positive urine ketones, and elevated glucose levels are consistent with the diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis triggered by an upper respiratory tract infection. IV fluids, IV insulin, and IV potassium replacement therapy should be initiated promptly.

Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) is an acute syndrome characterized by a constellation of symptoms secondary to uncontrolled hyperglycemia, high-anion gap metabolic acidosis, and increased total body ketone concentration. It presents with signs of hyperglycemia such as polyuria and polydipsia in addition to fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain, and potentially altered mental status. Physical examination may show signs of severe dehydration such as dry mucous membrane and decreased skin turgor, Kussmaul breathing (deep rapid labored breathing pattern), and fruity odor of the breath.

The acute management of an adult with Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) begins with stabilizing the patient and promptly starting intravenous fluid resuscitation, typically with 0.9% normal saline, to correct the dehydration caused by osmotic diuresis. Then regular IV insulin administration is initiated to rectify hyperglycemia and cease ketone production, thereby reversing the metabolic acidosis. Concurrently, even with normal or high serum potassium levels, potassium replacement is mandatory if potassium levels are below 5.3 given the total body potassium deficit due to osmotic diuresis. Bicarbonate therapy is generally reserved for severe cases with pH ≤ 6.9. As therapy proceeds and glucose levels decrease to about 200 mg/dL, dextrose may be added to avoid hypoglycemia while continuing the insulin infusion until the resolution of ketoacidosis. Once the patient is able to eat and the high-anion gap metabolic acidosis is resolved (anion gap <12 mEq/L, serum bicarbonate ≥18 mEq/L), IV insulin can be switched to SQ insulin. Close monitoring is required to assess response to treatment and identify any complications.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous potassium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metformin:
Incorrect: Oral diabetes medications like metformin are not used in the management of DKA, a condition that requires urgent correction of hyperglycemia with IV insulin.  
❌ Intravenous sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: While this patient does have a significant metabolic acidosis, bicarbonate therapy in DKA is indicated when the pH is ≤ 6.9.  
❌ Glyburide:
Incorrect: Oral diabetes medications like glyburide are not used in the management of DKA, a condition that requires urgent correction of hyperglycemia with IV insulin.  
❌ Intravenous 5% dextrose:
Incorrect: The addition of dextrose is not indicated until glucose levels decrease to ~200 mg/dL during treatment.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man patient presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right knee pain and swelling for the past 3 days. The patient has been unable to ambulate secondary to the pain. Past medical history includes hypertension, gout, diabetes, osteoarthritis managed with NSAIDs, and obesity. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, pulse is 101/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is a palpable effusion, warmth, and marked swelling of the right knee when compared to the left knee. The patient is unable to flex and extend the knee without significant pain. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: CT without contrast of right knee
PA and lateral radiographs of right knee

questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of unilateral knee swelling and pain in a native (non-prosthetic) joint. Given this patient's fever, effusion, limited range of motion, inability to bear weight, and significant pain with range of motion, septic arthritis is likely. The best next step in management is to obtain synovial fluid for analysis by performing an arthrocentesis.
 

Septic arthritis refers to joint inflammation that occurs when a pathogen invades the joint space. Once within the synovial cavity, pathogens trigger the immune system and stimulate the production of cytokines that can eventually result in joint damage. Septic arthritis can arise from infection in the adjacent bone, such as in osteomyelitis. It can also reach the joint through hematogenous spread from a distant infectious site in the body, or by direct inoculation which can occur as a complication of orthopedic surgery. Septic arthritis is usually monoarticular, affecting one large joint, and the diagnosis typically relies on synovial fluid aspiration and analysis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Arthrocentesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of intra-articular kenalog:
Incorrect: Administration of intra-articular kenalog is often part of the treatment of osteoarthritic pain. This patient has clinical examination findings that are concerning for septic arthritis, including fever and significant pain with range of motion, requiring arthrocentesis for diagnosis.  
❌ Administration of colchicine:
Incorrect: Colchicine is often used for the treatment of acute gouty arthritis. This patient has clinical examination findings that are concerning for septic arthritis, including fever and significant pain with range of motion, requiring arthrocentesis for diagnosis.  
❌ CT without contrast of right knee:
Incorrect: A CT scan of the knee without contrast is unlikely to provide useful diagnostic information for this patient who has symptoms and findings consistent with septic arthritis.  
❌ PA and lateral radiographs of right knee:
Incorrect: Plain radiographs of the knee should be performed in cases of septic arthritis to evaluate for bone involvement and to provide a baseline, however when there is concern for septic arthritis, the diagnosis should first be made with arthrocentesis.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of palpitations and shortness of breath. The symptoms started early in the morning and have been intermittent throughout the day. Past medical history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, chronic hypoxemic respiratory failure for which he is on 4 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula, and pulmonary hypertension. Medications include albuterol, fluticasone, salmeterol, and umeclidinium. Temperature is 36.8 ºC (98.2 ºF), pulse is 120/min and irregular, blood pressure is 132/81 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min and SpO2 is 88% of 4 liters of oxygen via nasal cannula. Electrocardiogram is obtained and is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
 

Reproduced fromWikicommons
questions.solution:
This patient with severe pulmonary disease presents with multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT), which occurs when multiple foci in the atria produce electrical impulses, causing ≥3 different P wave morphologies and an irregular rhythm. If this arrhythmia occurs with a heart rate <100/min it is called wandering atrial pacemaker (WAP). WAP and MAT are seen mostly in patients with severe underlying pulmonary disease. Treatment centers around addressing hypoxemia and treating the underlying pulmonary disease.

Among the irregular rhythms with narrow QRS complexes, atrial fibrillation will not have visible P waves, whereas multifocal atrial tachycardia will have ≥3 distinct P wave morphologies. Ventricular tachycardias, whether monomorphic or polymorphic, have complete AV dissociation (P waves may occur, but have no correlation to QRS complexes).

When regular rhythms with narrow QRS complexes (supraventricular tachycardia) are present, the P wave morphology can help determine the specific SVT. In sinus tachycardia, there is a P wave before every QRS complex, and the P waves all have the same morphology and are upright in leads I and II. Atrial tachycardias will have consistent P waves of a single morphology, but will not appear to be in sinus pattern. AV nodal reentrant tachycardia typically has P waves buried in QRS complexes, whereas AV reentrant tachycardia will have P waves following the QRS complex.  

Option Analysis

✅ Multifocal atrial tachycardia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wandering atrial pacemaker:
Incorrect: With a wandering atrial pacemaker the heart rate is < 100/min.  
❌ Atrial fibrillation:
Incorrect: This patient’s electrocardiogram shows multiple visible P waves of different morphologies. The ECG in atrial fibrillation would not have visible P waves.  
❌ Atrial flutter with 2:1 block:
Incorrect: This electrocardiogram shows ≥3 P wave morphologies which would not be seen in atrial flutter. Sawtooth “flutter” waves are usually seen in atrial flutter (especially in inferior leads) which are not present on this electrocardiogram.  
❌ Atrial flutter with variable block:
Incorrect: This electrocardiogram shows ≥3 P wave morphologies which would not be seen in an atrial flutter with variable block.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of fatigue, lightheadedness, and recurrent episodes of palpitations. The patient has not had chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. He does not recall any specific situations that bring on the symptoms. There is no recent history of tick bites, rash, or fever. Past medical history is significant for hypertension controlled with hydrochlorothiazide. The patient is physically active and walks three times per week. The patient does not smoke. Temperature is 37.1°C (97.9°F), blood pressure is 128/84 mmHg, pulse is 47/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination is unremarkable. A 12-lead ECG reveals sinus bradycardia. Initial laboratory evaluation, including CBC, electrolytes, and TSH, are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional episodes of tachycardia in the absence of chest pain, shortness of breath, or syncope. The patient has sinus bradycardia on ECG and a normal initial laboratory evaluation. These findings are suggestive of the diagnosis tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome also known as sick sinus syndrome. The most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis is to order a 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitor also known as a Holter monitor.

When formulating a differential diagnosis for an adult with bradycardia, several causes should be considered, including physiological sinus bradycardia, SA node block, tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome, neurally-mediated bradycardia, electrolyte imbalances, hypothyroidism, infections (e.g. Lyme carditis), structural heart disease, medication-induced bradycardia, and atrioventricular (AV) block.

Additional testing is guided by the patient's history and ECG findings. These tests may include a complete blood count (CBC), electrolytes, thyroid function tests, and Lyme serology. A 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitor (Holter monitor) may be employed to identify transient arrhythmias, periods of sinus arrest, or tachycardia-bradycardia syndrome. An echocardiogram can be used to evaluate for structural heart disease that may contribute to bradycardia. An exercise stress test can also be used to assess for chronotropic incompetence. In cases where syncope is a significant symptom, a tilt table test can be helpful to evaluate for orthostatic or vasovagal syncope. Lastly, an electrophysiology (EP) study may be considered for evaluation in cases of significant or symptomatic arrhythmias if noninvasive evaluation is inconclusive or for risk stratification when a pacemaker is considered for management.  

Option Analysis

✅ 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Tilt table test:
Incorrect: A tilt table test is used for assessing syncope when the initial evaluation is inconclusive and to confirm a diagnosis of vasovagal or orthostatic syncope. Vasovagal syncope is typically brought on by stress or prolonged standing and patients have prodromal symptoms, while orthostatic syncope occurs with changes in position.  
❌ Lyme serology:
Incorrect: Lyme carditis can present with bradycardia. However, it typically results in atrioventricular (AV) block, and not sinus bradycardia, preceded by a tick bite and a bull’s eye rash. The absence of these findings makes the diagnosis of Lyme carditis less likely.  
❌ Electrophysiology (EP) study:
Incorrect: An EP study is an invasive procedure, indicated for the evaluation of syncope, sudden cardiac death, wide complex tachyarrhythmia, or atrioventricular conduction disease if noninvasive evaluation is inconclusive. It is not the best next step in the evaluation of this patient.  
❌ Echocardiogram:
Incorrect: An echocardiogram is useful in identifying structural heart disease that may cause bradycardia. But 24-hour ambulatory ECG monitoring should be performed first to identify the arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic due to sudden-onset severe pain, swelling, and redness in his left big toe. He reports that the pain started 8 hours ago and has progressively worsened. He has no fevers or chills. His past medical history is significant for hypertension for which he is taking hydrochlorothiazide. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 37.4°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 133/79 mmHg, pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination is significant for tenderness, swelling, and erythema of the first metatarsophalangeal joint of the left foot. There is limitation to both passive and active range of motion. Laboratory results are significant for mild leukocytosis and a serum uric acid level of 9.5 mg/dL. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Perform joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hyperuricemia and acute-onset pain, redness, and swelling in his left big toe consistent with the diagnosis of podagra or acute gout of the big toe.

The first step in treating an acute gout attack includes management of inflammation and pain with anti-inflammatory medications including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) which are considered first-line therapy. NSAIDs, such as indomethacin, naproxen, or ibuprofen, should be started within the first 24 hours of symptoms and continued for 7-10 days. Colchicine and oral or intra-articular glucocorticoids are alternatives for patients who cannot tolerate or have contraindications to NSAIDs such as those with a history renal disease, heart failure, peptic ulcer disease, NSAID hypersensitivity, or patients taking anticoagulation. All patients with gout should be counseled regarding lifestyle modifications, such as maintaining a healthy weight, maintaining adequate hydration, and modifying dietary habits (limiting high-purine foods, sugary beverages, and alcohol).

Urate-lowering therapy (ULT) with xanthine oxidase inhibitors, such as allopurinol or febuxostat, is indicated for patients with recurrent gout attacks, tophi, urate nephrolithiasis, stage 2 or worse chronic kidney disease, or evidence joint damage on imaging (e.g., punched out extra-articular erosions, soft tissue gouty tophi). These medications reduce the production of uric aci, and prevent future attacks. They should not be started during an acute gout attack as they can precipitate or worsen a flare due to mobilization of stored uric acid. To prevent this, patients should take low-dose anti-inflammatories for 2 to 4 weeks prior to the initiation of ULT.

Serum urate levels should be checked one month after initiating therapy with ULT. If the serum urate level is < 6 mg/dL, this indicates adequate response to treatment. In such cases, the patient should continue gout flare prophylaxis with low-dose colchicine (preferably) or an NSAID for up to six months. If the serum urate level is ≥ 6 mg/dL, adjustments to the treatment regimen may be needed while continuing gout flare prophylaxis. Adjustments include increasing the dose of the current xanthine oxidase inhibitor, switching to a different xanthine oxidase inhibitor, or adding a uricosuric agent such as probenecid. Once serum urate levels remain below target for six months, gout flare prophylaxis should be discontinued, and serum urate level should be followed annually.  

Option Analysis

✅ Prescribe indomethacin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prescribe allopurinol:
Incorrect: Allopurinol is a urate-lowering medication used for long-term prophylactic management of gout in patients with a history of recurrent gout attacks, chronic kidney disease, physical findings of tophi, or imaging findings of joint damage. It is not indicated in the acute management of a gout flare as it can worsen the flare.  
❌ Perform joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis:
Incorrect: While joint aspiration and synovial fluid analysis can assist in making the diagnosis of gout, it is not required in patients with classic findings of podagra and risk factors for gout like the use of hydrochlorothiazide, as seen in this patient. Treatment with NSAIDs is indicated without need for further diagnostic testing.  
❌ Administer intra-articular glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Intra-articular glucocorticoids may be used in the management of acute gout when other treatments are contraindicated or not tolerated. This patient has no contraindications to the use of NSAIDs.  
❌ Increase the dose of hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, can contribute to hyperuricemia and exacerbate gout. As such it is advisable to discontinue or decrease rather than increase the dose of hydrochlorothiazide in patients with gout.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance due to lethargy. His past medical history is significant for type 1 diabetes mellitus and hypertension, and his chronic medications include insulin glargine, insulin lispro, and lisinopril. The patient had a wisdom tooth extracted four days ago and has been taking hydrocodone-acetaminophen 5 mg two times per day since then. His appetite and oral intake have been very poor due to tooth pain, and he is currently constipated. Temperature is 36.6 ºC (97.9 ºF), pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 112/65 mmHg, respiratory rate is 12/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient is lethargic but awakens easily and is fully oriented. Pupils are sluggish, normal size, and symmetrically reactive. There are no skin lacerations or needle marks. The patient’s skin is slightly diaphoretic. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Patients with severe hypoglycemia, which is likely the case in this patient, can present similarly to patients with opioid intoxication/overdose. This patient was taking two doses per day of low-dose hydrocodone which is unlikely to cause significant intoxication or overdose in an adult. This patient’s pupils are not miotic (constricted), pointing away from opioid intoxication. In addition, the patient is slightly diaphoretic, which is common in opioid withdrawal but not intoxication or overdose. The patient’s poor oral intake likely led to bigger drops in blood glucose when using the same dose of insulin. Therefore severe hypoglycemia is more likely in this case, and the first step is to check a point-of-care glucose level.
 

Patients with opioid intoxication may initially experience euphoria, apathy, or dysphoria. On presentation, patients have decreased mentation, and they may have slurred speech or severe lethargy. Pupils can be sluggish and miotic (constricted) but are generally not fixed. Respiratory drive is preserved. Patients using IV drugs may have needle marks. Patients with an opioid overdose may present similarly, but they are generally very lethargic. Unlike opioid intoxication, patients with an overdose will have significant hypotension and/or respiratory depression (often SpO2 <90%).  

Option Analysis

✅ Check a point-of-care glucose level:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV naloxone:
Incorrect: This would be the next step for opioid overdose. This patient’s presentation could be opioid intoxication, but is more concerning for hypoglycemia (he does not have constricted pupils or signs of respiratory depression on examination). A point-of-care glucose should be performed before considering further management.  
❌ Check a urine drug screen:
Incorrect: While this may be of clinical utility, diagnosing and treating the patient acutely is more important than ordering a urine drug screen. After the acute management is in place, then a urine drug screen can be obtained.  
❌ Perform endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect: This would be indicated for respiratory distress, severe respiratory depression, or an inability to protect the airway (e.g. significantly altered mental status). This patient has no respiratory distress and has adequate oxygenation..  
❌ Administer subcutaneous methylnaltrexone:
Incorrect: Methylnaltrexone is a peripherally-acting mu-opioid receptor antagonist. It is used for opioid-induced constipation. Though the patient is suffering from constipation, this would not be the first step in management.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman presents to the office for evaluation of bilateral hand pain and morning stiffness for 6 months. The stiffness lasts for 60 minutes each morning, making it challenging for her to button her shirt and get ready. It gradually improves throughout the morning and is not as noticeable throughout the rest of the day. She also has fatigue which started 5 months ago, but she does not have fever, chills, weight loss, rashes, or hair loss. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 82/minute, respiratory rate is 18/minute, and blood pressure is 126/74 mmHg. Physical examination of the hands shows tenderness and swelling with a “boggy” feel on palpation of the bilateral proximal interphalangeal (PIP) and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints of the hands. There is no warmth on palpation of the joints. Laboratory results are shown below.  Which of the following tests should be ordered next to help make the diagnosis?  

Laboratory value   
Result
Leukocyte count  
9,000/mm3   
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  
35 mm/hr  
Rheumatoid factor  
1:40
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 6-month history of bilateral joint pain in the hands associated with prolonged morning stiffness, and swelling and tenderness of the PIP and MCP joints. The patient’s findings are consistent with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. The diagnosis of RA can be made clinically. Serologic testing for rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies can help support a diagnosis of RA. In this patient who has clinical findings consistent with RA but a normal RF, anti-cyclic citrullinated antibodies should be ordered next. If positive they will support the RA diagnosis; however, they may not be positive in early disease and are not positive in all patients with RA. Serologic testing can help classify patients as having seronegative or seropositive disease and can help with prognosis. Patients with higher titers have more severe disease and a worse prognosis with a higher likelihood of developing erosive disease.
 

Other tests that are typically ordered when making the diagnosis of RA include ESR and CRP which are typically elevated in active disease and can help support the diagnosis and then be followed over time to assess response to treatment. Antinuclear antibody testing can be done to rule out SLE and other rheumatic diseases, though a portion of patients with RA will have a positive ANA. CBC can reveal anemia of chronic disease, and thrombocytopenia. X-ray can be performed to support the diagnosis, establish a baseline, and monitor disease over time. They can demonstrate ulnar deviation of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and other deformities, periarticular soft tissue swelling, osteopenia, and erosions. Synovial fluid analysis can be helpful in ruling out other causes of arthritis such as septic arthritis or crystalline arthritis when the diagnosis is in doubt.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Anti-double-stranded DNA antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-double stranded DNA antibody is an antinuclear antibody that is highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). This patient does not present with other features consistent with SLE like malar rash and alopecia and has joint involvement that is more typical of RA.  
❌ Uric acid level:
Incorrect: Uric acid level would be obtained in a patient suspected of having gout, which typically presents with monoarticular or polyarticular inflammatory arthritis that is not symmetrical. And joints are typically erythematous and warm on palpation. This patient’s symptoms and physical examination are more consistent with a diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Anti-Ro antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-Ro antibody can be positive in a number of autoimmune disorders but is most commonly seen in patients with SLE and Sjorgren syndrome.  
❌ Anti-Smith antibody:
Incorrect: Anti-smith antibody is an antinuclear antibody that is highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus. This patient’s lack of rash and alopecia and bilateral symmetric polyarticular arthritis is more consistent with RA.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman is brought by ambulance to the emergency department because of confusion. The patient is a professor at the local university and appeared confused during a lecture, prompting students to call an ambulance. Past medical history is significant for hypertension for which the patient takes amlodipine. The patient had two teeth extracted four days ago and has been taking oxycodone 5 mg orally every six hours for pain control. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient appears confused. She has no focal neurologic deficits. Pupils are miotic but reactive. The lower abdomen is distended without tenderness to palpation. Rectal exam reveals hard, firm stool in the rectal vault. Which of the following findings would be most consistent with a diagnosis of delirium?

choices.text: Inability to spell the word ‘WORLD’ backwards
History of increasing difficulty remembering words in her lectures for the past year
Normal immediate recall of events just prior to the lecture
Lack of interest in usually pleasurable activities for the past 3 months
One-year history of telling family and friends that a government agency is spying on her

questions.solution:
This patient who was prescribed opioid medication presents with confusion, miotic pupils, and a  rectal exam that suggests constipation. These findings are consistent with opioid use and opioid intoxication causing delirium. Attention span, thought processes, and level of consciousness can all be altered in delirium. This patient's mental status should be assessed, and focus should be on determining the patient’s ability to sustain and shift attention appropriately. Being able to spell the word ‘WORLD’ backward (or serial 7s in non-English speakers) requires focused attention. Attention should also be assessed globally, which can be done while taking the history.

Delerium can often be missed in patients in the hospital. A widely used and validated scale to screen patients for delirium is the Confusion Assessment Method (CAM), which includes 4 fundamental features of delirium: (1) acute onset and fluctuating course, (2) inattention, and either (3) disorganized thinking, or (4) altered level of consciousness.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Inability to spell the word ‘WORLD’ backwards:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ History of increasing difficulty remembering words in her lectures for the past year:
Incorrect: This would be more of an indication of dementia rather than delirium. Delirium has an acute and fluctuating course and develops over the course of hours to days. Dementia has a more chronic and progressive course.  
❌ Normal immediate recall of events just prior to the lecture:
Incorrect: Patients with dementia often have good immediate recall, while immediate recall is often impaired in patients with delirium.  
❌ Lack of interest in usually pleasurable activities for the past 3 months:
Incorrect: This is more indicative of depression rather than delirium.  
❌ One-year history of telling family and friends that a government agency is spying on her:
Incorrect: Patients with delirium may have delusions, but these typically exist for hours to days. Having ongoing delusion over months to years is more consistent with dementia or psychosis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by family members due to confusion. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Current medications include aspirin, insulin glargine, lisinopril, metformin, and sitagliptin. Temperature is 38.3 ºC (101.0 ºF), pulse is 108/min, blood pressure is 112/78 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 91% on room air. Chest radiograph shows a dense left lower lobe infiltrate. WBC is 19,000 cells/mm<sup>3</sup>. The patient is admitted to the medical service, and later that evening he becomes restless and attempts to get out of bed with his IV still attached. The night-time nurse notes that he is confused and is not able to pay attention to answer her questions, but he is easily redirected by staff and is brought back to bed. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing delirium due to infection. Infection is a common cause of delirium in older patients and typically resolves with treatment of the underlying infection. He is easily redirected back to bed by the nursing staff and has not interfered with his care, nor has he become a threat to others. At this time, if staffing is available, he can be assigned a one-to-one sitter to prevent complications from delirium and help reorient him as needed.

Management of delirium involves avoiding factors that can trigger or worsen it. Patients should have adequate hydration, and be reorientated frequently, sensory impairment should be avoided along with unnecessary nighttime awakenings (e.g. routine vital sign checks). Having family present can help reduce or prevent delirium. Identifying and treating the underlying acute illness and providing supportive care may be all that is needed to manage patients with delirium. However, if patients exhibit hyperactive delirium and become combative and disruptive, posing a threat to others or themselves, then pharmacologic management with low doses of short-acting agents (preferentially typical and atypical antipsychotics) used in the short-term is appropriate.

Typical (first-generation) or atypical (second generation) antipsychotic agents may be used to control symptoms of agitation. Low-dose haloperidol is typically preferred because of the lower risk of side effects than with other antipsychotic medications. However, it is contraindicated in patients with prolonged QT intervals, in patients on medications that can prolong the QT interval, and in patients with neurologic conditions like Parkinson’s disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ One-to-one sitter:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral diazepam:
Incorrect: Oral diazepam is not recommended for the treatment of delirium. Although benzodiazepines have a rapid onset of action, they can worsen confusion and sedation in patients with delirium. They should be reserved for treatment of agitation in delirium when typical and atypical antipsychotic medications are contraindicated (e.g. Parkinson’s disease), or in cases of drug or alcohol withdrawal.  
❌ Intravenous lorazepam:
Incorrect: Benzodiazepines can worsen delirium and should be reserved for treatment of agitation in delirium when typical and atypical antipsychotic medications are contraindicated (e.g. Parkinson’s disease), or in cases of drug or alcohol withdrawal.  
❌ Physical restraints:
Incorrect: Physical restraints should be used only as a last resort in the management of delirium. They should only be used when the patient poses an immediate threat to himself or others and cannot be managed with non-pharmacological or pharmacologic measures.  
❌ Intramuscular haloperidol:
Incorrect: Typical antipsychotics (e.g. haloperidol) and atypical antipsychotics can be used in the management of agitation from delirium when nonpharmacologic measures don’t work and a patient is a threat to himself or others. This patient can be easily redirected and is not a threat to himself or others, therefore nonpharmacologic management with a one-to-one sitter is more appropriate.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of heart failure and hypertension presents to the emergency department with increasing dyspnea and a nonproductive cough over the past week. She has required the use of two additional pillows to sleep at night. The symptoms started when she was unable to refill her prescription for furosemide. Temperature is 37.4 °C (99.3 ℉), pulse is 98/min, blood pressure is 148/88 mmHg, respiratory rate is 14/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 91% on room air. On physical examination, rales are noted throughout the lung fields, except at the right lung base where there are diminished breath sounds. Dullness to percussion is also noted at the right base. Her chest X-ray demonstrates cardiomegaly, bat wing opacities, Kerley B lines, as well as a uniformly white opacity of the right lung base that obscures the outline of the diaphragm and results in a meniscus sign. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of heart failure, symptoms (dyspnea, orthopnea, nonproductive cough), and examination findings (rales) are consistent with decompensated heart failure. This is supported by her chest x-ray (bat wing opacities, Kerley B lines, cardiomegaly), which also demonstrates a right pleural effusion (meniscus sign). Heart failure is a frequent cause of pleural effusions, due to increased hydrostatic pressure within the pulmonary capillaries. IV furosemide should be prescribed at this time.

Management of pleural effusions involves 2 processes: removal of the fluid within the pleural space and treatment of the underlying etiology. In the case of heart failure, both are typically accomplished through diuresis with loop diuretics (e.g., furosemide). Additional treatments when there are other underlying causes of pleural effusion may include antibiotics for pneumonia and chemotherapy for malignancy, and immunomodulators for autoimmune conditions (e.g., SLE, rheumatoid arthritis). Patients with heart failure and treated with IV diuretics should be monitored for improvement. If there is an inadequate response to diuresis and the patient remains symptomatic, then a therapeutic thoracentesis can be performed. In rare cases (typically when the underlying etiology is difficult to treat quickly, such as a malignancy), recurrence of the effusion can occur. For these patients, pleural catheter or video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATs) may be warranted.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV furosemide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Therapeutic thoracentesis:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with decompensated heart failure and a right pleural effusion. Therapeutic thoracentesis is generally not performed unless there is an inadequate response to diuretics.  
❌ Pleurodesis:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with decompensated heart failure and a right pleural effusion. This is typically managed with diuresis. Pleurodesis would only be indicated for recurrent pleural effusions that are refractory to standard initial treatment.  
❌ Diagnostic thoracentesis:
Incorrect: This patient is presenting with decompensated heart failure and a right pleural effusion. A diagnostic thoracentesis would only be performed if the underlying cause of the effusion was unclear (e.g., the patient’s effusion does not respond to typical diuretic therapy).  
❌ IV ceftriaxone and azithromycin:
Incorrect: IV antibiotics would only be indicated if the patient had pneumonia with a parapneumonic effusion. However, this patient’s presentation and x-ray findings are more consistent with decompensated heart failure with an accompanying pleural effusion.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man presents to the urgent care for evaluation of fever, sore throat, and painful swallowing for 3 days. The symptoms started with a mild sore throat that has progressively gotten worse. He denies coughing and nasal congestion. Temperature was 38.3°C (100.9°F) at home. He has been taking acetaminophen twice daily and doing salt-water gargles with minimal relief. He does not have any known medical history. He is a college student currently living in a dormitory and one of his roommates was recently sick with a fever and sore throat. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.6°F), pulse is 102/minute, respiratory rate is 12/minute, blood pressure is 116/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, he appears comfortable and is not in acute distress. Oropharyngeal examination reveals the findings seen below. Lymph node examination reveals tender cervical lymphadenopathy bilaterally. Cardiac examination is unremarkable and lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptoms of pharyngitis (fever, sore throat, and painful swallowing), without associated cough or nasal congestion. Examination is notable for findings of tender cervical adenopathy, enlarged and erythematous tonsils, and tonsillar exudates. The patient has 4 components of the Centor Criteria: absence of cough, fever > 100.4(38°C), tender anterior cervical adenopathy, and tonsillar exudates. Therefore, Group A strep pharyngitis can be clinically diagnosed and the patient should be treated with penicillin and symptomatic treatment.

Patients with upper respiratory infections will often present with fatigue, runny nose, sore throat, and fever. Pharyngitis should be suspected in patients who have a primary symptom of sore throat. In patients presenting with nasal congestion, discharge, and decreased or absent sense of smell, acute rhinosinusitis should be considered. For those patients whose primary symptoms are nasal congestion, sneezing, and headache, an unspecified URI is the more likely diagnosis.

The Centor Criteria can be used in patients with a sore throat to determine the likelihood of Group A Strep pharyngitis. In patients with 0 or 1 point, no further testing is required as they likely have viral pharyngitis. Patients who have 2 or 3 points should undergo rapid streptococcal antigen testing and throat culture swab. If the rapid swab is negative, unspecified pharyngitis is diagnosed and treated symptomatically. If the rapid swab is positive, the patient is diagnosed with Group A Strep pharyngitis and treated most often with penicillin or amoxicillin.  Patients with a score of 4 or more, can be clinically diagnosed with Group A Strep pharyngitis and treated with antibiotics along with symptomatic management. Antibiotic treatment for Group A Strep pharyngitis is important to decrease the risk of complications such as acute rheumatic fever, peritonsillar abscess and decrease the risk of transmission.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of penicillin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Throat culture:
Incorrect: While throat culture can be used to confirm the diagnosis of bacterial pharyngitis, this patient’s symptoms and physical examination findings provide sufficient evidence for a clinical diagnosis of Strep A pharyngitis. The patient can be treated with antibiotics without additional testing.  
❌ Rapid influenza viral swab:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms of fever, and sore throat for 3 days, which can be seen in influenza. However, the presence of enlarged erythematous tonsils with exudates, fever, and cervical adenopathy makes the diagnosis of bacterial pharyngitis more likely.  
❌ Streptococcal rapid antigen detection test:
Incorrect: A rapid antigen detection test would be the first line to evaluate for and diagnose streptococcal pharyngitis. However, this patient meets more than 4 Centor criteria, which makes the possibility of streptococcal pharyngitis high; therefore diagnosis can be made clinically, and antibiotic treatment can be initiated without additional testing.  
❌ Symptomatic treatment:
Incorrect: Symptomatic treatment to manage the patient’s sore throat and fever is important; however, it would not be sufficient management for this patient who meets the Centor criteria for streptococcal pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to flu-like symptoms. Yesterday morning the patient developed a headache, fevers, nasal congestion, and myalgias. This morning the patient noticed shortness of breath and a dry cough. The patient lives at home with her parents who are in their eighties. Her father has a  history of coronary artery disease and her mother has diabetes mellitus type 2. Temperature is 38.3 ºC (101.0 ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 19/min, blood pressure is 115/77 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears fatigued. Both lungs are clear to auscultation. The patient tests positive for influenza virus. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Prescribe oseltamivir and recommend infection control precautions
Prescribe oseltamivir without infection control precautions
Prescribe doxycycline and recommend infection control precautions
Recommend symptomatic treatment and infection control precautions
Recommend symptomatic treatment and no infection control precautions needed

questions.solution:
This patient presents with flu-like symptoms and mild shortness of breath concerning influenza (“the flu”). Although this patient has no high-risk features, she lives with elderly parents with chronic diseases who are considered high-risk household contacts. Therefore testing for influenza is recommended, and given her positive test result and presentation within 48 hours of symptom onset, treatment with oseltamivir and infection control precautions should be initiated.

Influenza is a viral infection that can affect both the upper and lower respiratory tracts. It is highly transmissible and isolation precautions should always be taken. Patients may present with “flu-like symptoms” (e.g., fevers, headache, malaise, myalgias), upper respiratory symptoms (e.g., rhinorrhea, nasal congestion), and lower respiratory symptoms (e.g., cough, shortness of breath). Patients with suspected influenza should be evaluated for high-risk features. If no high-risk features are present, then testing should be performed only if the results of testing will affect management. For example, if the diagnosis of influenza is in question, community transmission is low, or the patient has high-risk household contacts.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Prescribe oseltamivir and recommend infection control precautions:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Prescribe oseltamivir without infection control precautions:
Incorrect: This patient is within the 48-hour window since symptom onset and should be treated with a neuraminidase inhibitor; however, all patients with influenza should take appropriate precautions to help control the infection and prevent spread.  
❌ Prescribe doxycycline and recommend infection control precautions:
Incorrect: While this patient should observe infection control precautions, doxycycline would not be an appropriate treatment for viral influenza in a patient with high-risk household contacts.  
❌ Recommend symptomatic treatment and infection control precautions:
Incorrect: While infection control precautions should be taken, this patient is within the 48-hour window since symptom onset and has high-risk household contacts. Therefore she should be treated with a neuraminidase inhibitor.  
❌ Recommend symptomatic treatment and no infection control precautions needed:
Incorrect: This patient is within the 48-hour window since symptom onset and should be treated with a neuraminidase inhibitor given that she lives with high-risk household contacts. Infection control precautions should be observed for all patients with positive nasal swabs.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man presents to the office for evaluation of fatigue that he has been experiencing for the past 8 months. He used to walk 2 miles a day but now becomes tired after less than half a mile and experiences shortness of breath while walking up one flight of stairs. His medical history is significant for hypertension and osteoarthritis. His medications include lisinopril, tylenol as needed for pain, and aspirin. He has no weight loss, bright red blood in his stools or urine, and no dark stools. His last colonoscopy was 8 years ago, with findings of benign polyps that were removed. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), pulse is 110/minute, respiratory rate is 16/minute, and blood pressure is 132/87 mmHg. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor, pale nail beds, and dry skin. Cardiac examination shows tachycardia and a regular rhythm. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Laboratory tests are shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

 Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  8.5 g/dL 
 Hematocrit    32 % 
 MCV  72 fL 
 Fecal occult blood test  Negative 
 Iron  38 μg/dL 
 Ferritin  12 ng/mL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with microcytic anemia secondary to iron deficiency. In elderly patients with iron deficiency anemia and no overt bleeding, occult gastrointestinal bleeding is the most likely cause. The first step in the evaluation is to perform a colonoscopy to rule out colorectal cancer.    

The evaluation of iron deficiency anemia includes obtaining the following laboratory tests: complete blood count (CBC), serum iron, serum ferritin, transferrin saturation (TSAT), total iron binding capacity (TIBC), serum transferrin, and peripheral blood smear.      

In patients with iron deficiency anemia, CBC would show decreased hemoglobin, hematocrit, mean corpuscular volume (MCV), mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), and reticulocyte count. Red cell distribution width (RDW) would be increased. Serum iron, ferritin, and transferrin saturation (TSAT) would all be decreased, and total iron binding capacity TIBC and serum transferrin levels would be increased as a compensatory measure as the body attempts to capture available iron. Ferritin reflects iron stores and is the most accurate test to diagnose iron deficiency anemia.    

A peripheral blood smear will show microcytic, hypochromic red blood cells indicating reduced hemoglobin synthesis. Anisocytosis (variation in the size of red blood cells) and poikilocytosis (variation in the shape of red blood cells) can be seen as well.    

Additional diagnostic workup is based on patient history. Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and colonoscopy are necessary to identify gastrointestinal blood loss. In physiologically female patients, a workup for gynecological conditions should be considered.   

Option Analysis

✅ Colonoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CT scan abdomen :
Incorrect: This patient has microcytic anemia secondary to iron deficiency. In elderly patients presenting with anemia, colorectal malignancy should be ruled out. CT scan of the abdomen is not adequate for detection of colorectal cancer. 
❌ Capsule endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient presents with microcytic anemia secondary to iron deficiency with concern for gastrointestinal bleeding given his age. Colonoscopy is indicated first for further evaluation.  
❌ IV iron supplementation :
Incorrect: This patient has microcytic anemia secondary to iron deficiency and it is important to identify the underlying cause before initiating treatment. Also, oral iron replacement would be offered before parenteral replacement.
❌ Packed red blood cell transfusion:
Incorrect: This patient’s hemoglobin is above the recommended range of transfusion (7 g/dL), and he does not have an indication, such as acute coronary syndrome, that calls for transfusing at a higher threshold.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with end-stage renal disease presents to the emergency department with progressive swelling, dyspnea, and muscle weakness in both legs. He has also had episodes of palpitations and paresthesias today. He has missed several dialysis appointments this week due to a lack of transportation. Temperature is 37 ℃ (98.6 ℉), heart rate is 80/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure 152/92 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. On examination, rales are heard throughout the bilateral lung fields. 2+ pitting edema is noted in both lower extremities and there is decreased strength in the bilateral lower extremities. Laboratory studies are notable for a creatinine of 13 mg/dL and potassium of 7.5 mEq/L. An ECG taken during triage is shown below. Which of the following medications should be immediately administered?  


Wikimediacommons
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of leg weakness, palpitations, and paresthesias in the setting of missed hemodialysis is concerning for hyperkalemia. In addition to a potassium level of 7.5 mEq/L, the ECG demonstrates tall, peaked T waves and small (and in some leads, indiscernible) P waves, indicating an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmia. IV calcium gluconate should be administered immediately to stabilize the myocardium.  

Hyperkalemia is defined as a serum potassium concentration ≥ 5.5 mEq/L. Patients with mild hyperkalemia may be asymptomatic. However, patients with severe hyperkalemia (> 7 mEq/L) can present with palpitations, paresthesias, muscle weakness, and even ascending paralysis. Cardiac conduction abnormalities or arrhythmias can also occur, and ECG findings may include tall, peaked T waves, ST segment depression, PR prolongation, loss of P waves, and QRS widening. These ECG changes can progress to a sine wave pattern and asystole.  

There are 3 main goals in the management of hyperkalemia: stabilize the myocardium, shift potassium into cells quickly, and remove potassium from the body. Calcium gluconate stabilizes cardiac cell membranes, so it is given immediately to patients with ECG changes, cardiac arrhythmias, or in the case of severe hyperkalemia. Insulin, albuterol, and/or sodium bicarbonate are used to shift potassium into cells to reduce serum potassium levels. These are temporizing measures and are useful in cases like this while awaiting definitive treatment with dialysis. Other treatments that remove potassium from the body include diuretics (e.g. furosemide), and potassium binders (e.g. oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate).  

Option Analysis

✅ IV calcium gluconate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ IV regular insulin:
Incorrect: IV regular insulin (plus dextrose) is utilized for the treatment of hyperkalemia and acts by shifting potassium into cells. Given the ECG changes, IV calcium gluconate should be given immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia, then insulin and dextrose can be given.
❌ Nebulized albuterol:
Incorrect: Nebulized albuterol can be used to treat hyperkalemia, and acts by shifting potassium into cells. However, given the ECG changes, calcium gluconate should be given immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia, then nebulized albuterol can be given.  
❌ IV sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: IV sodium bicarbonate can be used to treat hyperkalemia, and acts by shifting potassium into cells. Given the ECG changes, calcium gluconate should be given immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia, then IV sodium bicarbonate can be given if necessary.  
❌ Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate:
Incorrect: Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate is a potassium binder that increases fecal excretion of potassium. In this case, dialysis would be the preferred way to remove potassium from the body. Given the ECG changes, calcium gluconate should be administered immediately to stabilize the cardiac cell membrane and reduce the chance of arrhythmia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of abdominal pain. The patient states the pain is located near the upper mid-abdomen and that he has never experienced similar pain before. An upper endoscopy is performed which reveals a single, shallow, 1 cm ulcer in the first part of the duodenum. Biopsies do not reveal Helicobacter pylori, and stool testing for H pylori is negative as well. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient was evaluated in the emergency department two weeks ago for a transient ischemic attack, and he was started on a COX-1 and COX-2 inhibitor. This patient’s current presentation is a result of an adverse effect of which of the following medications?
questions.solution:
This patient’s duodenal ulcer in the setting of a negative Helicobacter pylori test is most likely an adverse effect of aspirin therapy. Aspirin works by irreversibly inhibiting both COX-1 and COX-2 (via acetylation). At low doses, it predominantly inhibits COX-1; thereby, preventing platelet synthesis of thromboxane A2 and platelet aggregation. Inhibition of COX-1 in the stomach leads to a decrease in the concentration of cytoprotective prostaglandins, increased production of gastric acid, and decreased mucosal bicarbonate production. Together, these effects increase the risk of developing gastritis, gastric/duodenal ulcers or bleeding.  

Chronic aspirin use is associated with acute renal failure, interstitial nephritis and increased bleeding time. Additional side effects include hypersensitivity reactions such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis, and anaphylactic reactions. People with nasal polyps and asthma are also more prone to experience aspirin hypersensitivity–referred to as aspirin exacerbated respiratory disease.  Aspirin should not be provided to reduce fever in children with underlying viral infections, as it may lead to Reye’s syndrome–a condition characterized by liver damage and progressive encephalopathy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Warfarin:
Incorrect:  Warfarin is a vitamin K epoxide reductase inhibitor that is used for chronic anticoagulation in patients with underlying atrial fibrillation or transient ischemic attack/stroke. Although it increases the risk of bleeding, it is not associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.
❌ Heparin:
Incorrect: Heparin can be used temporarily for anticoagulation in patients with transient ischemic attack/stroke. This medication is not associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.  
✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Celecoxib:
Incorrect: Celecoxib is a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor which helps decrease inflammation. It does not inhibit COX-1, thereby minimizing gastroduodenal toxicity.  
❌ Colchicine:
Incorrect: Colchicine inhibits microtubule formation by binding to tubulin. It is not indicated in the management of transient ischemic attack/stroke, nor is it associated with the development of gastric or duodenal ulcers.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man comes to the office because of several months of low back and buttock pain. The patient reports that the pain is most severe early in the morning and gradually becomes better as the day progresses. The patient has no recent history of trauma. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for osteoarthritis in the patient’s parent. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows marked tenderness in the lower lumbar spine. Neurologic examination of the extremities is unremarkable. Plain x-ray of the spine is shown. The patient is initiated on a non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitor for his pain. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following conditions?  


Reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic back pain and radiography demonstrating “bamboo spine” consistent with ankylosing spondylitis. Reversible nonselective COX inhibitors (naproxen and ibuprofen) are the first line treatment for these patients.  

Reversible nonselective COX inhibitors reduce gastric mucosal protection via inhibition of COX-1 in the gastric mucosa and subsequently induce gastrointestinal side effects (including gastric ulcers and gastrointestinal bleeding). The risk of ulcers can be reduced by combining reversible nonselective COX inhibitors with a second medication like proton pump inhibitors to reduce gastric acid secretion.



Option Analysis

❌ Megaloblastic anemia:
Incorrect: Common risk factors for megaloblastic anemia include folate and vitamin B12 deficiency. Patients with ankylosing spondylitis receiving treatment with non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors are not at increased risk of developing megaloblastic anemia.  
❌ Gastric cancer:
Incorrect: Although non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors have shown to increase the risk of gastric ulceration and bleeding, they do not increase the risk of developing gastric cancer.  
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect:  Non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors have not been shown to affect lipid levels.  
✅ Peptic ulcer :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recurrent nephrolithiasis:
Incorrect: Use of non-selective cyclooxygenase inhibitors does not increase the risk of developing nephrolithiasis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man comes to the office because of knee pain for the past four months. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is associated with swelling at the knee following strenuous exertion. The pain is not associated with fever, rash or malaise. The patient was recently diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease but did not follow up with his gastroenterologist. He does not take any medications. BMI is 36.3 kg/m2. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a small effusion, tenderness and decreased range of motion of the left knee. Plain x-ray of the left knee joint shows narrowing of the joint space and osteophytes. The patient fails to demonstrate improvement in pain following initiation of a supervised exercise program. Which of the following is the most appropriate medication to administer for the management of this patient’s pain?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis. In addition to a supervised exercise program, the patient should begin taking a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor (celecoxib), given his history of peptic ulcer disease.  

Celecoxib reversibly inhibits COX-2 and can treat pain and inflammation like other NSAIDs. It differs in that it does not affect COX-1, as it lacks the antiplatelet effects seen in aspirin and other non-selective COX inhibitors. Moreover, it does not compete with aspirin for COX-1, so it may be combined with aspirin without decreasing its antiplatelet effect.  

Reversible nonselective COX inhibitors reduce gastric mucosal protection via inhibition of COX-1, thus selective COX-2 inhibitors like celecoxib cause the least gastrointestinal side effects. They are recommended for use in patients at risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as prior peptic ulcer disease.  



Option Analysis

❌ Naproxen:
Incorrect: Naproxen reversibly inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. This medication should be avoided in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease, as the inhibition of COX-1 reduces gastric mucosal protection.   
✅ Celecoxib:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin reversibly inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2. This medication should be avoided in patients with a history of peptic ulcer disease, as the inhibition of COX-1 reduces gastric mucosal protection.   
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD), and serves as pharmacotherapy for patients with rheumatoid arthritis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis.  
❌ Sulfasalazine :
Incorrect: Sulfasalazine is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD), and serves as pharmacotherapy for patients with rheumatoid arthritis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right foot pain. The patient woke up this morning with pain associated with swelling and redness but no fever. The patient does not report any history of recent trauma. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 37.8°C (100°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows redness, warmth and a small effusion of the right great toe. A sample of synovial fluid shows needle-shaped negatively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy. The physician starts the patient on valdecoxib. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following clinical findings?

choices.text: Flank pain radiating to the groin
Chest pain radiating to the left arm
Overgrowth of gum tissue around the teeth

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an acute gout flare, which occurs due to monosodium urate deposition in joint spaces. The patient is started on valdecoxib, a selective cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) inhibitor.   

Highly selective COX-2 inhibitors increase the risk of arterial thrombosis, which can lead to myocardial infarction and/or stroke. The increased risk of arterial thrombosis is believed to be due to the COX-2 inhibitors having a greater inhibitory effect on endothelial prostacyclin (PGI2) formation than on platelet TXA2 formation. Prostacyclin promotes vasodilation and inhibits platelet aggregation, whereas TXA2 carries the opposite effects.  

These medications do not affect COX-1 and thus lack the antiplatelet effect seen in aspirin and other non-selective COX inhibitors. Moreover, selective COX-2 inhibitors do not compete with aspirin for COX-1, so they may be combined with aspirin without decreasing its antiplatelet effect.  

Option Analysis

❌ Epigastric pain and tenderness:
Incorrect: Peptic ulcer disease usually presents with epigastric pain and tenderness. Gastrointestinal toxicity is less common with selective COX-2 inhibitors (e.g. valdecoxib) and is unlikely to develop in this patient.  
❌ Flank pain radiating to the groin:
Incorrect: Although selective COX-2 inhibitors have been associated with increased risk of acute renal failure and acute interstitial nephritis, it does not increase the risk of nephrolithiasis.   
✅ Chest pain radiating to the left arm:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ringing in ears:
Incorrect: Tinnitus (ringing in ears) is a common complication of salicylate overdose.   
❌ Overgrowth of gum tissue around the teeth:
Incorrect: Gingival hyperplasia is a common complication of anti-epileptic drugs such as phenytoin or sodium valproate.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual physical checkup. The patient is asymptomatic. Her past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies, for which she takes loratadine. She had an uncomplicated cholecystectomy 25 years ago. Last menstrual period was 12 years ago. Family history is significant for breast cancer in the patient’s grandmother. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. The patient is given the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and shingles vaccine. A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan reveals a T-score of -2.7. The patient is started on denosumab. This medication inhibits osteoclast formation and activity by binding to which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient’s DEXA scan is suggestive of osteoporosis. Denosumab can be administered for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis.  

Denosumab is a human monoclonal antibody that binds the RANK ligand (RANKL) and inhibits its binding to RANK receptors on the surface of osteoclasts and their precursors. These effects prevent the activation and maturation of osteoclasts, which ultimately limits bone breakdown.    

In addition to treating postmenopausal osteoporosis, denosumab can be administered to prevent skeletal-related events (e.g., bone pain, fractures) in patients with bone metastases.  

Common side effects include hypocalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and infections. Rarely can the medication cause osteonecrosis of the jaw.  



Option Analysis

❌ Calcium-sensing receptors:
Incorrect: Cinacalcet lowers parathyroid hormone levels by activating the calcium-sensing receptors in the parathyroid glands. It is effective in treating hypercalcemia in parathyroid cancer and secondary hyperparathyroidism in chronic kidney disease.  
❌ Hydroxyapatite crystal:
