Incorrect: Bisphosphonates (e.g. alendronate) reduce both the resorption and formation by binding to hydroxyapatite, which is the mineralized form of calcium found in bones. When osteoclasts break down bones, they also take in the bisphosphonates. The medication interferes with osteoclast function and promotes osteoclast apoptosis, thereby suppressing bone turnover. Denosumab is not a bisphosphonate and works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ RANK ligand:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calcitonin receptors:
Incorrect: Calcitonin binds to calcitonin receptors and inhibits bone resorption. In contrast, denosumab’s mechanism of action does not involve calcitonin receptors.  
❌ Parathyroid hormone receptors:
Incorrect: Teriparatide is a parathyroid hormone (PTH) analog that acts through PTH receptors. When administered in a pulsatile fashion, the medication can promote osteoblastic activity and bone formation. In contrast, denosumab does not bind PTH receptors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of nausea, headaches, and forgetfulness. The symptoms developed several months ago and have worsened in severity. Past medical history is notable for small cell carcinoma of the lung, diagnosed a year ago and associated syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 128/75 mmHg, and pulse is 80/min. Physical examination is unremarkable. There is no significant soft tissue swelling. The patient is oriented to person, place, and time. Strength and sensation are intact in the upper and lower extremities. Laboratory testing reveals a serum sodium of 124 mmol/L. In addition to fluid restriction, the physician decides to give the patient a medication that directly antagonizes the antidiuretic hormone V2 receptors. Which of the following adverse effects is most commonly associated with this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of nausea, headache, and forgetfulness are likely due to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH), a common paraneoplastic disorder associated with small cell lung cancer. The cancerous cells produce antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which leads to excessive free water retention and hyponatremia.

Vaptans (e.g., conivaptan, tolvaptan) are direct ADH receptor antagonists that are used in the treatment of SIADH due to their efficacy in correcting hyponatremia. These drugs block V2 receptors in the renal collecting ducts, resulting in excessive loss of free water with minimal loss of electrolytes. These changes help normalize serum sodium levels.

Vaptans should be used cautiously to avoid rapid correction of serum sodium, which can result in a form of devastating central nervous system injury known as osmotic demyelination syndrome. Vaptans are otherwise relatively safe drugs, with side effects including excessive thirst, dry mouth, and increased urinary frequency.

Demeclocycline is a tetracycline derivative that can also be used in SIADH treatment due its ability to induce nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. The mechanism of action is not well understood, but the medication appears to inhibit the binding of ADH to its receptor. However, it is not frequently used in the treatment of SIADH due to its severe nephrotoxic side effects.  

Option Analysis

✅ Excessive thirst:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neurotoxicity:
Incorrect: Antidiuretic hormone V2 antagonists (e.g., conivaptan, tolvaptan) are not known to cause neurotoxicity.  
❌ Hypothyroidism:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism is a common side effect of lithium therapy. Although lithium can induce nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by preventing ADH from binding to its receptor, it is not used in the treatment of SIADH due to its severe toxicity.  
❌ Ototoxicity:
Incorrect: Furosemide is sometimes used in the management of SIADH by inducing diuresis and fluid loss. It can lead to ototoxicity; however, furosemide is not an ADH receptor antagonist.  
❌ Tachyphylaxis:
Incorrect: Tachyphylaxis means decreased response to a drug after repeated or continuous use. ADH receptor antagonists (e.g., conivaptan, tolvaptan) have not been shown to cause tachyphylaxis even with long-term use.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the physician due to persistent diarrhea for the past 4-months. The patient’s stools are watery and tea-colored. The patient denies blood in the stool. The diarrhea persists during sleep and the patient has soiled her clothing on several occasions. In addition, the patient has felt weak and experiences frequent muscle cramps. Physical examination is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/minute, and blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg. Laboratory testing reveals the findings shown below. Abdominal CT scan shows a 3 cm mass in the tail of the pancreas. Which of the following can be used to control the patient's symptoms?

Laboratory Value
Result
Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL
Hematocrit
45%
Leukocyte count
5,000/mm3
Platelet count
300,000/mm3
Sodium
139 mEq/L
Chloride
96 mEq/L
Potassium
2.8 mEq/L
Calcium
8.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient presents with watery diarrhea and hypokalemia, which can lead to weakness and muscle cramps. CT reveals a pancreatic mass. In combination, these findings are most suggestive of a VIPoma. VIPomas are neuroendocrine tumors that secrete excessive vasoactive inhibitory peptide (VIP) and lead to WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria). Somatostatin analogs are the first-line option for symptomatic management.  

Somatostatin is a regulatory hormone that functions widely in the body. It is mainly produced from D-cells of the gut and pancreas, as well as the brain. It has a short half-life and exerts its effects in a paracrine fashion. Somatostatin has predominantly inhibitory effects that are most profound in the gut and endocrine system. The physiological effects of somatostatin are summarized in the table below.  

Long-acting somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide, lanreotide, seglitide, vapreotide) are used in the treatment of different diseases. These include acromegaly and various neuroendocrine tumors (e.g., insulinoma, VIPoma, glucagonoma, carcinoid tumor, gastrinoma). Additionally, somatostatin reduces splanchnic blood flow, increases intestinal transit time, and promotes intestinal absorption of water. Thus, somatostatin analogs can be used to treat acute variceal bleeding and secretory diarrhea.  

Early side effects of somatostatin analogs include gastrointestinal upset (e.g., nausea, diarrhea, abdominal cramps) and fat malabsorption. These side effects tend to self-resolve over time. Patients taking somatostatin analogs for longer periods are at increased risk of cholesterol gallstones, because of decreased gallbladder motility secondary to decreased cholecystokinin release.  



Option Analysis

❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor that is used to treat gastric hyperacidity and peptic ulcer disease. However, it is not indicated in patients with VIPoma as these patients already have decreased gastric acidity.
❌ Metoclopramide:
Incorrect: Metoclopramide is a dopamine agonist that is used to treat gastroparesis in patients with diabetes mellitus. In contrast, this patient has watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and a pancreatic tail mass on CT imaging. These findings are more suggestive of a VIPoma, which is not treated with metoclopramide.  
✅ Octreotide  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sulfasalazine:
Incorrect: Sulfasalazine is an immunosuppressive drug with anti-inflammatory effects. It is used frequently in patients with inflammatory bowel syndrome. However, this patient has watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and a pancreatic mass, making VIPoma the most likely diagnosis. Sulfasalazine has no role in VIPoma treatment
❌ Infliximab:
Incorrect: Infliximab is an anti-TNF monoclonal antibody that is used in the treatment of Crohn disease. It has no role in this patient, who most likely has a VIPoma.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by family members because of increasing confusion over the past two days. The patient also has experienced nausea as well as back and abdominal pain. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and amlodipine. Family history is significant for prostate cancer in the patient’s father. He has a 25-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows a disheveled and confused man. Lung fields are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and heart sounds are normal. A chest radiograph is obtained and is unremarkable. There are no focal neurological deficits. Laboratory results are shown below. In addition to normal saline, which of the following should be administered to this patient?  


Laboratory Value  Result
Complete Blood Count 
Hematocrit  42% 
 Leukocytes  8,000/mm3 
 Platelet  170,000/mm3 
Serum Chemistries 
Sodium  138 mEq/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Creatinine  2 mg/dL 
 Calcium  14.2 mg/dL 
 Glucose  138 mg/dL 
 Blood urea nitrogen   40 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient has symptomatic hypercalcemia, as evidenced by the history of confusion, abdominal pain, and back pain. Patients with hypercalcemia require saline hydration to restore intravascular volume and facilitate urine calcium excretion. Calcitonin, a peptide hormone, can be administered concurrently.  

Calcitonin works by directly inhibiting osteoclast activity, thereby decreasing bone breakdown. At the same time, calcitonin stimulates osteoblasts to build more bones. It also decreases the concentration of serum calcium and phosphate by increasing their excretion via the kidneys.  

There are two types of calcitonin, synthetic human calcitonin, and synthetic salmon calcitonin. Synthetic salmon calcitonin, also known as salcatonin, is more convenient due to its longer half-life and potency.    

Calcitonin can be administered by injection or intranasally. It is indicated in the treatment of postmenopausal and corticosteroid-induced osteoporosis, hypercalcemia, and Paget disease of the bone. Adverse effects of calcitonin use include flushing, dizziness, paresthesia, and gastrointestinal disturbances.  



Option Analysis

✅ Calcitonin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase renal tubule reabsorption of calcium, leading to an increase in serum calcium levels and a decrease in urine calcium concentration. This patient’s symptoms are likely due to hypercalcemia, so thiazide diuretics should be avoided.  
❌ Lithium:
Incorrect: Patients receiving chronic lithium therapy often develop mild hypercalcemia. This side effect is most likely because of increased parathyroid hormone (PTH) secretion due to an increase in the set point at which calcium suppresses PTH release. Lithium is not indicated in the management of hypercalcemia.  
❌ Insulin:
Incorrect: Insulin is effective in driving potassium into the cells and can be used to treat hyperkalemia, but not hypercalcemia.  
❌ Glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Glucocorticoids are effective in managing hypercalcemia secondary to granulomatous diseases such as sarcoidosis. In contrast, this patient does not have a history of sarcoidosis, and chest imaging is unremarkable. As a result, calcitonin would be more effective in managing hypercalcemia in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for a wellness checkup. The patient recently had a dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan that placed her at two standard deviations below the mean for bone density and is following up today to discuss the results. Past medical history is notable for asthma, anxiety, irritable bowel syndrome, and radial fracture that occurred 5-months ago following a ground-level fall. Current medications include clonazepam and albuterol. Vitals are within normal limits. The patient is started on raloxifene in addition to weight-bearing exercise and vitamins. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
This postmenopausal woman is started on raloxifene, a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), to treat postmenopausal osteoporosis.    

Raloxifene has a partial agonist effect on estrogen receptors in the bones. Therefore it is useful in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. In addition, it is an estrogen receptor antagonist in the endometrium and breast tissue. As a result, raloxifene can also be used to prevent breast cancer.      

Common side effects include hot flashes and an increased risk of venous thrombosis.   

 

Option Analysis

❌ Endometrial cancer:
Incorrect: Tamoxifen, another selective estrogen receptor modulator, has an agonist effect on the endometrial receptors, promoting endometrial hyperplasia and increasing the risk of endometrial cancer. In contrast, raloxifene is an agonist at estrogen receptors in the bone but an antagonist at receptors in the endometrium.  
❌ Breast cancer:
Incorrect: Selective estrogen receptor modulators such as raloxifene are effective in treating hormone-responsive breast cancer, where it acts as an antagonist to prevent receptor activation by endogenous estrogens. It does not increase the risk of developing breast cancer.  
❌ Osteonecrosis of jaw:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates are associated with osteonecrosis of the jaw. In contrast, raloxifene is not associated with this complication.   
✅ Deep vein thrombosis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Osteosarcoma:
Incorrect: The use of teriparatide, a parathyroid hormone analog, in patients with Paget disease of the bone can increase the risk of developing osteosarcoma. In contrast, raloxifene is not associated with osteosarcoma.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for a 20-pack smoking history and intravenous drug use. Temperature is 38.6°C (101.5°F), blood pressure is 98/69 mm Hg, pulse is 112/min, and respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air.  Physical examination is significant for scattered non-painful erythematous macules over the palms and soles, and a new grade 4/6 holosystolic murmur over the lower left sternal border radiating to the right lower sternal border. Lung auscultation is significant for decreased breath sounds at the lung base bilaterally. Laboratory evaluation shows a white blood cell count of 18,000/mm3 and a C-reactive protein of 50 mg/L. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Chest CT scan with IV contrast is shown below. Blood cultures are sent and IV fluids are initiated with adequate blood pressure response. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
 

Picture taken from openi

choices.text: Administer IV vancomycin and order a transesophageal echocardiogram
Administer IV vancomycin and consult cardiothoracic surgery
Discharge the patient on oral cephalexin
Order a transesophageal echocardiogram and wait for blood culture results before starting antibiotics

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of injection IV drug use, presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fever, Janeway lesions (scattered non-painful erythematous macules on the palms and soles), and a new-onset holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border radiating to the right lower sternal border (consistent with murmur of tricuspid regurgitation), suggestive of right-sided infective endocarditis. The presence of dyspnea, hemoptysis, tachycardia, tachypnea, and decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, and the CT scan findings of multiple peripheral alveolar infiltrates indicate septic pulmonary emboli which can be a complication of right-sided infective endocarditis. The most appropriate treatment once blood cultures are obtained is to start empiric antibiotics with vancomycin and order a transesophageal echocardiogram.

Acute management of an adult with infective endocarditis involves obtaining blood cultures, followed by initiation of empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics (to be tailored when blood culture results return). If clinical suspicion for IE is high, then a TEE can be ordered next. Transthoracic echocardiogram may be performed first in certain circumstances. The choice of antibiotic should be based on the most likely pathogens. For most patients, empiric therapy should cover methicillin-susceptible and resistant staphylococci, streptococci, and enterococci. Vancomycin is the appropriate initial therapy for most patients. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) should be performed, as it is more sensitive than transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) in detecting vegetation and abscesses. However, TTE may be the initial imaging in some circumstances. Early (before completion of antibiotic course) surgical management may also be indicated for certain conditions including heart failure secondary to valvular destruction, persistent bacteremia, large vegetations/persistent septic emboli, difficult-to-eradicate organisms like fungi or multidrug-resistant bacteria, or extension of infection causing abscess, fistula, or heart block.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Administer IV vancomycin and order a transesophageal echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer IV vancomycin and consult cardiothoracic surgery:
Incorrect: While cardiothoracic surgery may need to be consulted based on the finding of the TEE, it is crucial to first perform a transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate for complications of infective endocarditis.  
❌ Administer IV vancomycin and heparin:
Incorrect: Although IV antibiotics are indicated, heparin is not. This patient’s findings point towards septic pulmonary emboli, a common complication of right-sided infective endocarditis.  
❌ Discharge the patient on oral cephalexin:
Incorrect: Infective endocarditis is a potentially life-threatening infection that requires hospitalization and intravenous antibiotics. Oral antibiotics are insufficient for managing this condition.  
❌ Order a transesophageal echocardiogram and wait for blood culture results before starting antibiotics:
Incorrect: Waiting for blood culture results before initiating antibiotic therapy may be appropriate for some stable patients without an acute presentation, but would not be appropriate for this patient.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man without significant past medical history presents to the emergency department for evaluation of fatigue, night sweats, and fever for the past week.He has not had a cough, chest pain, or dysuria. Social history is significant for intravenous drug use for the past year. Temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg, pulse is 96/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. On examination, the patient appears lethargic. Cardiac examination reveals a holosystolic murmur heard at the lower left sternal border that radiates to the right lower sternal border. Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin of 10.4 g/dL, WBC count of 16,400/mm<sup>3</sup>, and CRP of 25 mg/L. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be found on the physical examination?

choices.text: Tender purplish nodules on the fingertips
Rhonchi over the left lower lung base

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of intravenous drug use presents with fever, night sweats, and a new holosystolic murmur at the lower left sternal border. This clinical presentation is suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). The presence of Osler nodes is a classic finding in patients with infective endocarditis. Osler nodes are small, tender, purple-pink nodules with a pale center typically found on the distal fingers and toes. They are caused by small-immune complex-mediated vasculitis.

Infective endocarditis (IE) refers to inflammation of the heart's endocardium secondary to infection. Pathogens can adhere to the intracardiac surfaces, leading to the formation of vegetation on heart valves, as well as on the septa, mural endocardium, or implanted electronic devices.

Certain populations are at an increased risk for IE including patients with underlying structural heart disease, patients with prosthetic heart valves, congenital heart disease, or a history of previous IE. Patients who inject drugs are also at high risk due to repeated injection of nonsterile substances. Other risk factors include immunosuppression, the presence of intracardiac devices, and invasive dental/surgical procedures.

The clinical presentation of IE can be varied and is often nonspecific. Patients may present with fever, fatigue, night sweats, weight loss, and other systemic symptoms, which may be persistent or intermittent. A more specific sign of IE is auscultation of a new or changed cardiac murmur. In some cases, IE can result in embolic phenomena, causing symptoms related to stroke, pulmonary embolism, or infarction in other organs. Physical examination may reveal Osler nodes (painful subcutaneous nodules on the fingers and toes), Janeway lesions (hemorrhagic non-painful erythematous macules on the palms and soles), and splinter hemorrhages under the nails. These signs are not always present, and their absence does not rule out the diagnosis. A high degree of clinical suspicion is needed, and definitive diagnosis typically requires an echocardiographic showing vegetation with positive blood cultures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Tender purplish nodules on the fingertips:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Petechiae over the hard palate:
Incorrect: Petechiae can be seen on the conjunctiva and skin in infective endocarditis due to septicemia and disseminated intravascular coagulation. They are not usually found on the hard palate. This finding is most often associated with streptococcal pharyngitis.  
❌ Costovertebral angle tenderness:
Incorrect: This finding is indicative of pyelonephritis. The absence of dysuria and the presence of a new-onset right-sided heart murmur in a patient with a history of intravenous drug use is suggestive of infective endocarditis.  
❌ Rhonchi over the left lower lung base:
Incorrect: This finding is typically seen in patients with lobar pneumonia. The presence of a new-onset murmur in a patient with a history of intravenous drug use is suggestive of infective endocarditis.  
❌ Tender cervical lymphadenopathy:
Incorrect: Although cervical lymphadenopathy is often seen with systemic infections, it is not specific for infective endocarditis. It is more often associated with systemic viral infections such as EBV and HIV, and with localized infections or inflammation in the head and neck including strep pharyngitis.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and an erythematous rash over the palms and soles. Past medical history is significant for mitral valve prolapse. The patient has not traveled recently. She is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.8°F), blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has several small erythematous non-tender macules over the palmar surface over the hands and on the plantar surface of the feet, and several reddish-brown lesions under the nail beds. Cardiac auscultation is significant for 4/6 late systolic murmur with mid systolic click best heard over the apex, which is a change from prior murmur 2/6. Blood cultures are drawn and a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is performed which does not show vegetation. Which of the following is the best next step in the evaluation?

choices.text: Await blood culture results before further evaluation
Obtain a chest CT scan with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and a rash on the palms and soles. The physical examination reveals Janeway lesions and splinter hemorrhages, which are indicative of infective endocarditis (IE) and a change in the murmur related to mitral valve prolapse. Although the transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) did not reveal vegetation, suspicion for IE should remain high and a TEE should be ordered. TTE has a lower sensitivity than transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE) for diagnosing IE.

The diagnostic workup for infective endocarditis (IE) involves a combination of clinical, microbiological, and imaging evaluations. The Modified Duke criteria can then be used to determine the likelihood of endocarditis. There are two major criteria and five minor criteria in the Modified Duke Criteria.
 

The major criteria in the Modified Duke Criteria include positive blood cultures with organisms that typically cause IE, such as Staphylococci, Streptococci, HACEK group organisms, and Coxiella burnetti, and evidence of endocardial involvement on echocardiography such as vegetation, abscess, or dehiscence of the prosthetic valve(s). TTE is typically the initial imaging modality of choice. However, in certain scenarios like infection of a prosthetic valve, paravalvular abscess, or a high clinical suspicion of IE, a TEE may be favored due to its superior sensitivity.

The minor criteria in the Modified Duke Criteria include predisposing heart conditions, intravenous drug use, and fever >38.0°C. Additional minor criteria include vascular phenomena such as mycotic aneurysm, intracranial or conjunctival hemorrhages, major arterial emboli, septic infarcts, and Janeway lesions; immunological phenomena such as Roth spots, Osler nodes, glomerulonephritis, or positive rheumatoid; and microbiological evidence that does not meet major criteria.

A diagnosis of IE is established if the patient has 2 major criteria, 1 major and 3 minor criteria, or 5 minor criteria. If the Modified Duke Criteria are not met, alternative diagnoses should be considered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Obtain a transesophageal echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Await blood culture results before further evaluation:
Incorrect: Given the strong clinical suspicion for IE in this patient with a history of mitral valve prolapse and a change in the nature of her murmur, transesophageal echocardiography should be ordered now and not when blood culture results return.  
❌ Obtain a chest CT scan with IV contrast:
Incorrect: A chest CT scan can identify complications or an alternative diagnosis in suspected infective endocarditis, but it does not visualize heart structures as precisely as a TEE, which is indicated in this case.  
❌ Obtain Rickettsia serology:
Incorrect: Rickettsia serology would be appropriate to order for a patient with suspected tick-borne disease like Rocky Mountain spotted fever. Although patients with Rocky Mountain spotted fever present with fever, and a rash that involves the palms and soles, this patient has additional clinical findings that make infective endocarditis more likely.  
❌ Obtain rapid plasma reagin test:
Incorrect: A rapid plasma reagin test is used to screen for syphilis. Secondary syphilis may present with a rash that involves the palms and soles; however, the presence of fever, splinter hemorrhages, and a changed murmur in a patient with a history of mitral valve prolapse, along with the absence of history of signs and symptoms suggestive of primary syphilis makes the diagnosis of infective endocarditis more likely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 1-week history of fever, fatigue, and night sweats. He has not had a sore throat, cough, diarrhea, or weight loss. The patient has a history of intravenous drug use and admits to sharing needles. Temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), blood pressure is 107/71 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border that radiates to the right lower sternal border. Reddish brown lesions are noted under the nail beds. Laboratory evaluation is significant for leukocytosis and an elevated CRP. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Blood cultures are drawn and results are pending. A transesophageal echocardiogram shows vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Admit to the hospital and administer IV vancomycin
Admit to the hospital and administer IV nafcillin
Refer for emergent valve replacement surgery
Discharge home on oral ciprofloxacin and rifampin
Admit to the hospital and administer IV amphotericin B

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of intravenous drug use, presents with fever, splinter hemorrhages, and a holosystolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border radiating to the right lower sternal border (consistent with tricuspid regurgitation) along with findings of leukocytosis and an elevated CRP most likely has right-sided infective endocarditis (IE). The diagnosis is confirmed by the detection of vegetation on the tricuspid valve via transesophageal echocardiography (TEE). Empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics should be initiated and should cover methicillin-susceptible staphylococci, MRSA, Streptococci, and Enterococci. The patient should be admitted to the hospital and started on IV vancomycin.

The choice of empirical antibiotics for IE should be based on the suspected causative organism, which is typically dependent on patient risk factors. Patients who inject drugs are often infected with S. aureus (including MRSA), making vancomycin an appropriate antibiotic choice. Once culture and sensitivity results are available, antibiotics can be tailored to target the specific causative organism. Typical treatment duration is 4-6 months. Early surgical management (before completion of the antibiotic course) may be indicated for certain conditions such as heart failure secondary to valvular destruction, persistent bacteremia despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, large vegetations/persistent septic emboli, a difficult-to-eradicate organism such as fungi or multi-drug resistant bacteria, and extension of infection as evidenced by the presence of an abscess, fistula, or heart block.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Admit to the hospital and administer IV vancomycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Admit to the hospital and administer IV nafcillin:
Incorrect: Nafcillin, a penicillinase-resistant penicillin, is used to treat methicillin-sensitive staphylococcus aureus. While staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of infective endocarditis in patients who inject IV drugs, empiric therapy should cover MRSA in these patients.  
❌ Refer for emergent valve replacement surgery:
Incorrect: Surgical valve replacement is necessary only in specific cases of infective endocarditis, such as heart failure secondary to valvular destruction, persistent bacteremia despite appropriate antibiotic therapy, large vegetations/persistent septic emboli, difficult-to-eradicate organisms, or extension of infection as evidenced by the presence of an abscess, fistula, or heart block.  
❌ Discharge home on oral ciprofloxacin and rifampin:
Incorrect: Oral antibiotics and discharge are not appropriate. Patients diagnosed with infective endocarditis should be admitted to the hospital for intravenous antibiotics and monitoring.  
❌ Admit to the hospital and administer IV amphotericin B:
Incorrect: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication that is not used as part of the initial empiric treatment of infective endocarditis. This patient should have empiric antibiotics that cover for the most likely organisms, including MRSA in this case.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of weight loss, heat intolerance, and increased irritability. Her family and coworkers have noted changes in her eyes, describing them as looking like they are “popping out”. Past medical history is unremarkable. Social history is significant for a 6-pack-year smoking history. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 148/78 mmHg, pulse is 112/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The thyroid is enlarged, nodular, and non-tender, and her eyes appear prominent with mild lid lag. Laboratory tests reveal a low TSH level and elevated free T4 and T3 levels. Which of the following is the best next step in the evaluation?

choices.text: Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid

questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic findings of primary hyperthyroidism such as weight loss, heat intolerance, irritability, and laboratory evaluation showing low TSH, and elevated T3 and T4. In addition, the presence of characteristic ophthalmic findings is consistent with Graves disease as the underlying etiology. Given that the patient has a nodular thyroid on examination thyroid uptake scan is indicated to confirm the diagnosis of Graves and distinguish it from toxic adenoma and toxic multinodular goiter.

A thyroid uptake scan is the most appropriate next step, as it not only confirms the hyperthyroid state but also provides additional information to distinguish Graves disease from other causes of hyperthyroidism. In Graves disease, this scan will demonstrate diffusely increased, homogeneous radiotracer uptake throughout the enlarged thyroid gland. This increased uptake reflects the underlying autoimmune stimulation of the thyroid by TSH receptor antibodies associated with Graves disease. In contrast, with solitary hyperfunctioning nodules (toxic adenoma), the scan will demonstrate focal increased uptake limited to a single nodule ("hot nodule") with suppressed uptake in the rest of the thyroid, and with toxic multinodular goiters the scan will show multiple areas of focal increased and suppressed uptake. Additionally, TSH receptor antibodies [thyrotropin receptor antibodies (TRAb)], should be checked and are typically elevated in Graves disease.

Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid uptake scan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if on a thyroid uptake scan a non-functioning nodule suspicious for thyroid cancer was found.  
❌ Thyroid ultrasound:
Incorrect: An ultrasound would be appropriate in patients without a nodular thyroid and without detectable antibodies to assess for blood flow to determine if Graves or thyroiditis is more likely.  
❌ Anti-thyroglobulin antibodies (anti-TGB) levels:
Incorrect: Anti-TGB levels are frequently elevated in patients with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, an autoimmune disorder that leads to hypothyroidism. However, this patient has clinical and laboratory findings suggestive of Graves disease, which is characterized by elevated anti-TSH receptor antibodies.  
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: This would be appropriate if there were suspicion of a pituitary adenoma causing secondary hyperthyroidism which is characterized by an elevated TSH. Given this patient's clinical presentation and low TSH on laboratory evaluation, primary hyperthyroidism due to Graves disease is more likely.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to unintentional weight loss, diarrhea, excessive sweating, and occasional diplopia. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 152/78 mmHg, pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is diffusely enlarged without nodules and non-tender, and her eyes exhibit significant proptosis with restrictive extraocular movements. Laboratory tests reveal a decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level, elevated free thyroxine (T4) level, and positive thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Refer the patient for radioactive iodine ablation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with classical symptoms of hyperthyroidism and a non-nodular thyroid in addition to positive thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin, consistent with the diagnosis of Graves disease. Her ocular findings of proptosis and restricted extraocular movements with occasional diplopia are suggestive of moderate Graves ophthalmopathy, which is an indication for thyroidectomy.

Treatment options for Graves disease include antithyroid drugs, radioactive iodine ablation, and thyroidectomy. The choice of treatment depends on the patient's symptoms, the severity of the disease, patient preferences, the presence of contraindications to therapy, and the presence of certain features like ophthalmopathy. Antithyroid medications like methimazole or propylthiouracil (PTU) inhibit the synthesis of thyroid hormones, providing a non-invasive, reversible treatment option. However, there is a high relapse rate with these medications once the medication is discontinued.

Radioactive iodine ablation offers a permanent solution by destroying the overactive thyroid tissue but often results in hypothyroidism, necessitating lifelong thyroid hormone replacement. Radioactive iodine treatment is contraindicated in pregnant or breastfeeding women and in patients with Graves' ophthalmopathy, as it can exacerbate the condition.

Surgery (total or subtotal thyroidectomy) is typically reserved for patients with large goiters causing compressive symptoms, suspicion of malignancy, and moderate or severe ophthalmopathy. It's also considered for those who are pregnant or cannot tolerate other treatment options. However, surgery carries risks, such as injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerves and parathyroid glands.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Refer for thyroidectomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer propylthiouracil (PTU):
Incorrect: Propylthiouracil (PTU) is an antithyroid drug used in the treatment of hyperthyroidism. It is usually indicated in patients with mild hyperthyroidism, no orbitopathy, and a high likelihood of remission. In this patient with moderate ophthalmopathy, thyroidectomy is preferred.  
❌ Administer oral glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Although oral glucocorticoids can be used in the management of Graves ophthalmopathy, they do not address the underlying hyperthyroidism and are usually used in combination with other therapies in patients with mild orbitopathy.  
❌ Refer the patient for radioactive iodine ablation:
Incorrect: Radioactive iodine ablation is a common treatment for Graves disease but is contraindicated in patients with moderate to severe ophthalmopathy as it can worsen eye symptoms.  
❌ Selenium:
Incorrect: Selenium can be used in patients with mild orbitopathy in parts of the world where there is deficiency.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the clinic due to fatigue, paresthesias in the hands and feet, and intermittent abdominal cramps for the past two months. His past medical history is significant for uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He hasn’t been seen by primary care in over 2 years and takes no medications. Vitals are significant for blood pressure of 170/90. Physical examination is significant for spasms of the left hand when the blood pressure cuff is inflated above the systolic blood pressure for 3 minutes. Laboratory evaluation is significant for creatinine of 2.6 mg/dL (previously 1.7 mg/dL). Which of the following is most likely to be seen on further blood work analysis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of uncontrolled diabetes mellitus, HTN, and kidney disease presents with fatigue, intermittent cramps, and carpopedal spasm with inflation of the blood pressure cuff (positive Trousseau sign). This clinical presentation is consistent with the diagnosis of hypocalcemia secondary to chronic kidney disease.  

Important causes of hypocalcemia include hypomagnesemia, impaired vitamin D conversion, hypoparathyroidism, and secondary hyperparathyroidism. When evaluating patients with hypocalcemia, magnesium should be checked first. If it is not the cause of hypocalcemia, then additional lab work including a basic metabolic panel, serum PTH and 25-hydroxy vitamin D (inactive form of Vitamin D) should be checked. If the serum creatinine is elevated, then the active form of vitamin D or 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D, should be checked. If CKD is the cause of hypocalcemia, then 1,25 hydroxy vitamin D level will be low and the PTH level will be increased in response to the low calcium level.     

Hypocalcemia in CKD arises from two primary mechanisms: decreased production of 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D and hyperphosphatemia. CKD impairs the kidney's ability to convert 25-hydroxyvitamin D to its active form, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D in response to parathyroid hormone (PTH). This active form of vitamin D is necessary for intestinal absorption of calcium. As levels of active vitamin D drop, less calcium is absorbed from the gut, leading to hypocalcemia. CKD also reduces the kidney's ability to excrete phosphate, leading to hyperphosphatemia. Elevated phosphate levels can also precipitate calcium, further lowering serum calcium levels. The decrease in serum calcium stimulates PTH secretion in an attempt to restore calcium homeostasis.  

Option Analysis

✅  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D  Decreased  Increased  Increased  Decreased :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D   Decreased  Increased  Increased  Normal:
Incorrect: Decreased calcium, increased phosphate, increased PTH, and normal 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D reflects hyperphosphatemia. Patients with CKD may have hyperphosphatemia, typically accompanied by decreased 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels due to impaired renal conversion.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH  Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D  Decreased  Increased  Decreased    Normal:
Incorrect: Decreased calcium, increased phosphate, decreased PTH, and normal 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D levels suggest a diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism. However, this patient with CKD likely has hypocalcemia secondary to chronic kidney disease.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH  Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D  Decreased  Decreased  Increased  Decreased :
Incorrect: Decreased calcium and phosphate with increased PTH suggest secondary hyperparathyroidism due to Vitamin D deficiency. However, the patient's elevated creatinine in the setting of type 2 DM and HTN makes chronic kidney disease a more likely cause of his hypocalcemia.
❌  Serum Calcium  Serum Phosphate  Serum PTH  Serum 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D Increased  Decreased  Increased  Normal:
Incorrect: Increased calcium, decreased phosphate, and increased PTH suggest primary hyperparathyroidism, which does not align with the patient's presentation of hypocalcemia and kidney disease.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for routine follow up. The patient does not take any medications. The patient has chronic diarrhea for which no cause has yet been identified despite evaluation that the patient and patient’s mother have requested. Temperature is 36.7 °C (98.0 °F), heart rate is 98/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is thin and has dry lips. Laboratory studies obtained at the last visit are listed below. Which of the following conditions would be most consistent with these findings?  

 Laboratory study  Result
 Serum potassium  3.0 mEq/L 
 TSH  1.2 microunits/mL 
 Urine potassium:creatinine  1.1
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic, unexplained diarrhea, mild hypokalemia, and evidence of mild volume depletion. The urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio is < 1.5, signifying extrarenal potassium wasting. The only answer choice that meets this criterion is surreptitious laxative use, which would also explain the patient’s chronic diarrhea.   

There are many potential causes of hypokalemia. Often, this can be elicited from the history and presentation (e.g. decreased potassium intake, recent GI illness, diuretic use). If the cause is not obvious, additional workup should be obtained. Evaluation should start with a serum magnesium level to rule out hypomagnesemia. From there, patients can be evaluated for potential causes of transcellular potassium shifts. This should include reviewing medications (e.g. theophylline, beta agonists, insulin) or evaluating for conditions like hyperthyroidism, which may be accompanied by symptoms (e.g. heat intolerance, palpitations) and a low TSH.    

If these causes are ruled out, the next step is to obtain urine studies in order to calculate the urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio. If it is ≤ 1.5, extrarenal potassium wasting is most likely, which can be caused by laxative overuse, other causes of severe diarrhea, and excessive sweating. If the ratio is > 1.5, then a condition that causes renal potassium wasting is more likely. In patients with hypertension or evidence of hypervolemia, consider diseases affecting mineralocorticoid activity, such as Cushing syndrome, hyperaldosteronism, and congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Otherwise, the next step is to check the patient’s acid-base status. Metabolic acidosis is associated with renal tubular acidosis and acetazolamide use. Metabolic alkalosis is associated with Bartter and Gitelman syndrome as well as diuretics.   

Option Analysis

✅ Surreptitious laxative use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hyperthyroidism:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism can cause hypokalemia through transcellular potassium shifts. However, this would be associated with a low TSH. This patient’s TSH is normal.  
❌ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia can cause hypokalemia due to increased mineralocorticoid activity. However, the urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio would be > 1.5.   
❌ Gitelman syndrome:
Incorrect: Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition that results in renal potassium wasting. The urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio would be > 1.5.  
❌ Bartter syndrome:
Incorrect: Bartter syndrome causes hypokalemia through renal potassium wasting. The urine potassium-to-creatinine ratio would be > 1.5.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic for a follow-up appointment. After their last visit, the patient underwent pulmonary function testing due to progressive dyspnea on exertion and cough. The patient’s FEV1 is 78% and FEV1/FVC is 65%. The patient has smoked two packs of cigarettes per day since age 14. The patient has experienced significant anxiety, headaches, and insomnia when attempting to quit in the past. Today, the patient vocalizes a readiness to quit. In addition to nicotine replacement therapy, which of the following interventions is most likely to improve the patient’s chances of quitting?
questions.solution:
This patient has developed COPD as a consequence of his tobacco use disorder. The patient is currently motivated to quit and would benefit from combination therapy with pharmacotherapy and behavioral therapy.

Tobacco use disorder is a condition that develops with continued tobacco use, resulting from nicotine dependence. When assessing a patient, it is important to evaluate their readiness to quit. For those who are not ready, motivational smoking cessation counseling and close follow-up are important initial steps. Patients who are ready to quit benefit from motivational counseling and follow-up but will also be more open to additional measures. This includes a combination of cognitive behavioral therapy and pharmacotherapy, which has shown to be more effective than either used alone.

Cognitive behavioral therapy can teach patients to recognize and avoid potential triggers and guide patients in the application of coping mechanisms and problem-solving skills to resist cravings. First-line medications for smoking cessation include nicotine replacement therapy (e.g. patch, gum), varenicline (a partial nicotine agonist), and bupropion (a dopamine/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor). The choice of medications will depend on the patient’s history and preferences.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Cognitive behavioral therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ No additional intervention:
Incorrect: A combination of motivational counseling, cognitive behavioral therapy, and pharmacotherapy has been shown to be more effective for tobacco cessation management than pharmacotherapy alone.  
❌ Acupuncture:
Incorrect: Acupuncture has been trialed in some smoking cessation programs. However, it has not demonstrated long-term improvement in rates of abstinence.  
❌ Hypnotherapy:
Incorrect: Hypnotherapy has been tried in some smoking cessation programs. There is insufficient evidence to support its use.  
❌ Sertraline:
Incorrect: Antidepressants have been used for tobacco cessation management. However, bupropion (a dopamine/norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor) is recommended over sertraline.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of chronic back pain. The patient has been experiencing worsening back pain over the past five months which is what brought them into the clinic. The patient has not experienced any sensory changes or bowel or bladder loss of control. She has no difficulty walking. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, obesity, and osteoporosis. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination is notable for anterior pelvic tilt, and increased curvature of the lumbar spine without abnormalities in the rest of the spine. The patient has full range of motion of the lumbar spine without pain. A radiograph is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes this patient’s findings?  


Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of worsening chronic back pain and is found to have an anterior pelvic tilt and excessive curvature of the lumbar spine on physical examination. Furthermore, radiography demonstrates excessive lumbar lordosis or an increase in inward curvature of the lumbar vertebrae.  

The spine's normal curvature typically follows four normal curvatures, which can be seen on a lateral view radiograph. These include thoracic and sacral kyphosis. Kyphosis is an increased front to back curve of the spine giving a convex curve in the spine (i.e., convexity towards the back of the spine). in those areas. There is also a normal cervical and lumbar lordosis giving a gently concave curve in those areas (i.e, concavity towards the back of the spine). Two common spinal abnormalities include excessive thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis and excessive lumbar lordosis.  

Excessive kyphosis typically occurs in the thoracic region and leads to a hunchback appearance. This process can be postural or due to vertebral compression fractures from osteoporosis, osteoarthritis, or spondylolisthesis. Additional etiologies include genetic disorders such as Scheuermann kyphosis, osteogenesis imperfecta, or metabolic or congenital disabilities like spina bifida.  

Excessive lumbar lordosis results in the presence of an anterior pelvic tilt or swayback posture on physical examination. It is most often due to poor posture, obesity, weak hamstrings, tight hip flexors, or osteoporosis. Like excessive kyphosis, excessive lumbar lordosis is also associated with several genetic disorders, including Ehlers-Danlos syndrome and achondroplasia. It can lead to lumbar pain and if untreated, excessive lumbar lordosis may result in slippage of intervertebral discs, radiculopathy, and spondylolisthesis.

Option Analysis

✅ Excessive lumbar lordosis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Excessive thoracolumbar kyphosis:
Incorrect: Thoracolumbar kyphosis refers to excessive thoracic/lumbar convexity seen in the sagittal plane.. This finding is  not present in this patient’s radiograph or examination. Patients with thoracic or thoracolumbar kyphosis have exaggerated forward rounding of the upper back on physical exam  
❌ Scoliosis:
Incorrect: Scoliosis refers to an abnormal curvature of the spine in the coronal plane, resulting in lateral displacement of the spine. It is difficult to evaluate for scoliosis on a lateral spinal radiograph, however this patient does not have abnormal lateral curvature of the spine on physical examination.  
❌ Spondylolisthesis:
Incorrect: Spondylosis refers to an anatomic defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis. Spondylosis may progress to spondylolisthesis, characterized by anterior displacement of the vertebral body. This patient’s radiograph does not demonstrate spondylolisthesis.  
❌ Vertebral body compression fracture:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of osteoporosis, the radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of a compression fracture. It shows excessive curvature of the lumbar spine.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man comes to the dermatology clinic for evaluation of a skin lesion. He does not have pain, itching, or discharge from the lesion. He states that it has been present since birth, and he has not noted any significant changes in its appearance. Past medical history includes testicular cancer treated with orchiectomy five years ago. Family history is unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits.  Physical examination shows a 0.5 cm, single, well-demarcated reddish-brown papule inferior to the left breast. Both breasts and axilla appear normal. Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of this patient’s presentation?  


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis
Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery
Failed involution of the mammary ridge

questions.solution:
The most common congenital breast condition in males and females is polythelia (supernumerary nipples), which results from the mammary ridge's failure to involution. The most common site for accessory nipples lies just inferior to the normal breast. Accessory nipples are usually asymptomatic, and excision is not required.  

Another related condition is polymastia (supernumerary breasts). This condition refers to more petite than usual breasts that consist of only a rudimentary nipple and areola (often mistaken for a mole). Supernumerary breasts can appear anywhere along a line that extends from the axilla to the groin along the milk line (location of embryonic mammary crest cells from which the breasts develop). The most common site for polymastia is the lower axilla.  



Option Analysis

❌ Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis:
Incorrect: Obliteration of the milk line during embryogenesis can result in athelia, for example, the absence of a nipple or amastia (i.e. absence of breast tissue). This patient’s presentation is consistent with an accessory nipple.  
❌ Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery:
Incorrect: Inflammation of the sebaceous glands of Montgomery presents with tender, palpable abscesses over the periphery of the areola. This patient’s breast examination is unremarkable.  
❌ Abnormal response to gonadal hormones:
Incorrect: Abnormal response to gonadal hormones results in spontaneous overgrowth of breast tissue. Overgrowth may be unilateral or symmetric (more common) and begins around puberty. This patient’s breasts appear normal.  
✅ Failed involution of the mammary ridge  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes:
Incorrect: Benign melanocytic nevi result from the clonal proliferation of benign melanocytes. They are usually small or medium-sized, solitary, and may occur anywhere on the skin. This patient’s examination findings are suggestive of an accessory nipple.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for febrile neutropenia and started on cefepime. The patient is currently receiving chemotherapy for colon cancer. Initial workup including urinalysis, chest radiograph, and nasal viral swab did not reveal a source of infection. On day two of hospitalization, the patient's blood culture from the chest wall port demonstrates growth of Staphylococcus aureus with sensitivities pending, and results from the other blood culture are pending. On rounds, the patient reports persistent chills throughout the night. Temperature is 38.2 °C (100.8 °F), pulse is 96/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 130/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical examination, there is no erythema or purulence at the right chest wall port. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient who is actively receiving chemotherapy is being treated with empiric antibiotics with cefepime for neutropenic fever. Antibiotics should be tailored to the culture and sensitivities results. For this patient, one blood culture is pending and the one from the port has grown out S. Aureus with sensitivities still pending, therefore vancomycin should be added because S. Aureus could be methicillin-resistant S. Aureus (MRSA).

Patients with neutropenic fever should have a thorough history performed if possible and a thorough physical examination to search for a source of infection. Blood cultures should be sent from two sources including any central lines or ports. Patients with a confirmed source of infection should receive tailored antibiotic therapy. Patients without a confirmed source are considered to have a fever of unknown origin and should continue to receive treatment with an antipseudomonal beta-lactam.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Add vancomycin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Continue cefepime only:
Incorrect: Patients with neutropenic fever are at high risk for Gram-negative bacteremia and require empiric antibiotics that cover Pseudomonas (such as cefepime). However, this would not be appropriate coverage for potentially methicillin-resistant (MRSA) S. Aureus and vancomycin should be started.  
❌ Add ampicillin-sulbactam:
Incorrect: While cefepime covers Pseudomonas, ampicillin-sulbactam does not cover for possible methicillin-resistant S. aureus.  
❌ Discontinue antibiotics:
Incorrect: This patient is still febrile and has been on antibiotics for <72 hours with a culture that is positive for S. Aureus and awaiting sensitivities. Discontinuing antibiotics is not appropriate.  
❌ Add voriconazole:
Incorrect: This patient’s S. aureus bacteremia is likely the source of persistent fever. Adding the antifungal agent voriconazole will not treat this bacteremia and would not be necessary without evidence of fungal infection.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe angioedema. Several attempts are made to intubate without success, and the decision is made to perform an emergent cricothyroidotomy. After identifying the appropriate anatomic landmarks and prepping the patient with betadine, the physician begins the procedure by making a midline vertical incision below the thyroid cartilage and above the cricoid cartilage. Which of the following structures is at risk of injury if the vertical incision is extended too far inferiorly?
questions.solution:
The thyroid ima artery is an uncommon variant of blood supply to the inferior aspect of the thyroid gland. It arises from the brachiocephalic trunk, right common carotid artery, or aortic arch. It ascends on the anterior surface of the trachea to the isthmus of the thyroid gland and supplies blood to the thyroid gland, trachea, parathyroid glands, and thymus.

Due to its location and course, it can be injured during head and neck procedures such as cricothyroidotomy, thyroidectomy, or tracheostomy. When injured, it can be a source of brisk and potentially difficult to control bleeding as the cut vessel often retracts below the manubrium.  

Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid ima artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: The common carotid artery is at risk of injury if the incision is extended too far laterally, not inferiorly. This vessel is at risk of injury by placing a central venous catheter in the neck.  
❌ Thyroid lobe:
Incorrect: The lobes of the thyroid lie lateral to the trachea and are at risk of injury if an incision is extended too far laterally.  
❌ Vocal cords:
Incorrect: The vocal cords are at risk of injury if the incision is extended too far superiorly, not inferiorly.  
❌ Internal jugular vein:
Incorrect: The internal jugular veins, like the internal carotid arteries, lie lateral to the trachea and are at risk of injury should an incision be extended too far laterally.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman comes to the office with a complaint of blurry vision for the past few days. The patient also reports intermittent headaches and poor sleep. Review of systems reveals constipation and the sensation of bladder fullness. The patient lives alone and her son visits her occasionally. The patient does not report any recent trauma or infections. Past medical history is significant for chronic migraine headaches, hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include simvastatin, lisinopril, sumatriptan and over-the-counter diphenhydramine for insomnia. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a well-appearing woman with flushed cheeks and dilated pupils. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The patient’s blurred vision is most likely a side effect related to diphenhydramine use.  Diphenhydramine is an H1 receptor antagonist. First and second generation H1 receptor antagonists are primarily indicated in the treatment of allergic reactions, such as urticaria, angioedema, and allergic rhinitis.  However, first-generation H1 blockers are associated with multiple side effects, which are important to keep in mind as they can be taken advantage of in the treatment of other conditions or result in unwanted adverse effects. As demonstrated in this patient, the sedative properties of first-generation H1 antihistamines (e.g. diphenhydramine or hydroxyzine) are helpful in treating insomnia, but other adverse effects such as blurred vision can also occur.

Common side effects of first-generation H1 blockers can be subdivided into antihistaminic effects, such as sedation, increased appetite, and weight gain; antimuscarinic effects, or atropine-like side effects, such as dilated pupils, blurry vision, and dry mouth; and anti-α-adrenergic effects, like orthostatic hypotension and dizziness.

Second-generation H1 blockers (e.g., cetirizine, loratadine or fexofenadine) have far less lipid solubility, and are therefore less likely to cause cognitive side effects. Moreover, antimuscarinic side effects also tend to be less severe in second-generation H1 blockers.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Add propranolol for migraine prophylaxis:
Incorrect: Although migraine prophylaxis with propranolol could be considered in this patient, discontinuing unnecessary medications takes priority.  
❌ Decrease the dose of lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril does affect vision or level of consciousness. Moreover, the patient’s blood pressure is within normal limits.  
✅ Discontinue diphenhydramine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Recommend cystography:
Incorrect: This patient’s urinary retention is most likely due to the anticholinergic side effects of diphenhydramine and cystography is not recommended as the next best step in management.  
❌ Head CT scan:
Incorrect: Obtaining a head CT scan in a patient with chronic headaches is inappropriate.

questions.text: A 35-year-old taxi driver presents to the office because of itchy, watery eyes and excessive sneezing that have become more severe with the change of seasons. The patient has taken an over-the-counter medication in the past with moderate relief of the symptoms, but it made the patient very drowsy. Past medical history is significant for eczema. Family history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a prominent nasal crease. The nasal turbinates are boggy and bluish-gray. There is copious watery nasal mucus. The patient asks the physician to switch to a medication that will not impair his ability to drive. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sneezing, rhinorrhea and watery eyes, consistent with allergic rhinitis. The patient should be treated with a second-generation H1 receptor blocker such as cetirizine, loratadine or fexofenadine, to avoid sedation. These drugs have far less lipid solubility than first generation H1 blockers, resulting in less cognitive side effects. In addition, the antimuscarinic side effects also tend to be less severe, so second generation H1 blockers are preferable to first-generation H1 blockers in the treatment of allergic disease.

On the contrary, first-generation H1 blockers such as diphenhydramine or hydroxyzine, have high lipid solubility and can easily cross the blood-brain barrier to cause cognitive side effects like sedation. Other side effects include increased appetite, and weight gain; antimuscarinic effects (e.g. dilated pupils, blurry vision, and dry mouth); and anti-α-adrenergic effects (e.g. orthostatic hypotension and dizziness).
 

Option Analysis

❌ Chlorpheniramine:
Incorrect: Chlorpheniramine is a first-generation antihistamine. It is more likely to cause sedation and drowsiness in this patient, as it is lipophilic and easily crosses the blood-brain barrier.  
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine is a first-generation antihistamine. It is more likely to cause sedation and drowsiness in this patient as it is lipophilic and easily crosses the blood-brain barrier.  
❌ Hydroxyzine:
Incorrect: Hydroxyzine is a first-generation antihistamine. It is more likely to cause sedation and drowsiness in this patient as it is lipophilic and easily crosses the blood-brain barrier.  
✅ Loratadine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Promethazine:
Incorrect:  Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine. It is more likely to cause sedation and drowsiness in this patient as it is lipophilic and easily crosses the blood-brain barrier.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to a rural urgent care center. He is severely dehydrated and has been experiencing four days of violent watery diarrhea. He has not seen blood in the stool. The patient recently started taking antibiotics for cellulitis of the left leg. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 112/75 mmHg, and pulse is 87/min. Physical examination reveals dry mucosal membranes. There is no focal tenderness in the abdomen. PCR of a stool sample reveals Clostridium difficile toxin B. The patient is told to stop taking the antibiotic and is provided with intravenous fluids. The urgent care center does not carry fidaxomicin or vancomycin. Which of the following most accurately characterizes the mechanism of action of the next best drug to treat this patient’s diarrhea?

choices.text: Formation of toxic metabolites that directly damage pathogenic DNA
Binding and disabling of the 30s ribosomal subunit

questions.solution:
This patient suffers from Clostridium difficile diarrhea, as evidenced by the history of persistent watery diarrhea and positive PCR for toxin B. The best drug of choice in this situation is fidaxomicin or vancomycin. The next best drug is metronidazole in resource-poor settings where these antibiotics are not available.

Metronidazole is a bactericidal antibiotic that functions by generating free radicals that damage DNA and cause it to fragment. Without the DNA as a template, the invading pathogens will be unable to synthesize new nucleic acids, which will lead to cell death. Metronidazole is relatively nontoxic to humans since, to function, the medication needs to be activated by a protein called ferredoxin. Ferredoxin is found in anaerobic bacteria and protozoans but not in humans or aerobic bacteria.

The medication can treat many anaerobic infections (e.g., Clostridium difficile, Bacteroides species) and protozoal infections (e.g., Giardia lamblia, Entamoeba histolytica). It can also be used as surgical prophylaxis, especially for colorectal surgeries, and as part of Helicobacter pylori treatment.

Common side effects of metronidazole therapy include gastrointestinal irritation (e.g., decreased appetite, nausea, stomach cramps), a metallic taste in the mouth, and a disulfiram-like reaction if the patient consumes alcohol after taking the drug. Patients taking high doses or on chronic therapy may also experience neurological symptoms such as confusion, seizures, and peripheral neuropathy.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of cell wall synthesis:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of beta-lactams. In contrast, the second-line agent for treating Clostridium difficile infection is metronidazole, which works by forming free radicals that damage bacterial DNA.  
✅ Formation of toxic metabolites that directly damage pathogenic DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Binding and disabling of the 30s ribosomal subunit:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of tetracyclines and aminoglycosides. In contrast, the second-line agent for treating Clostridium difficile infection is metronidazole, which works by forming free radicals that damage bacterial DNA.  
❌ Binding and disabling RNA polymerase:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of rifamycins, such as rifampin and rifabutin. Rifamycins are used to treat infections caused by pathogens such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, Mycobacterium leprae, and Neisseria meningitidis. However, they are not used in the treatment of Clostridium difficile diarrhea.  
❌ Direct inhibition folate synthesis:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of sulfonamides. These medications are not used in the treatment of Clostridium difficile diarrhea.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the office because of a week of intermittent high fevers, chills, and sweats. The patient recently returned to the United States after visiting his relatives in Ghana. Past medical history is unremarkable, and he does not take any medications. Temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mmHg. Physical examination shows scleral icterus. The spleen is palpated 2 cm below the left costal margin. Hemoglobin concentration is 10 g/dL. A peripheral blood smear is shown below. After further evaluation, the patient is started on an antiparasitic drug that is metabolized in the food vacuoles of the parasite to form toxic free radicals. Which medication was this patient most likely prescribed?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents with high fevers, chills, anemia, and splenomegaly after visiting Ghana (where malaria is endemic). Peripheral blood smear reveals banana-shaped organisms. These findings suggest infection by Plasmodium falciparum, and he is started on artemisinin.

Artemisinin derivatives are a new class of antimalarials that include artemisinin, artesunate, and dihydroartemisinin. These medications are blood schizonticides that build up in the food vacuoles of the Plasmodium, where they bind to iron found in heme and generate free radicals that damage parasite proteins. Artemisinins are especially useful since they are effective against all Plasmodium species, including the strains resistant to chloroquine and other quinoline derivatives. Their effectiveness is so high that they are considered the first-choice agent for treating chloroquine-resistant malaria. However, they are not effective for prophylaxis since they have only a few hours short half-life.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Chloroquine:
Incorrect: Chloroquine accumulates in the food vacuoles of Plasmodium and prevents the polymerization of heme, a hemoglobin breakdown product, into hemozoin. Intracellular accumulation of heme is toxic to the parasite. However, chloroquine does not lead to the formation of toxic free radicals.  
❌ Proguanil:
Incorrect: Proguanil is bioactivated to cycloguanil, a selective inhibitor of protozoan dihydrofolate reductase. It does not lead to the formation of toxic free radicals.  
❌ Quinine:
Incorrect: Quinine complexes with double-stranded DNA prevent strand separation, which blocks DNA replication and RNA transcription. It is not involved in the formation of toxic free radicals.  
✅ Artemisinin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Primaquine:
Incorrect: Primaquine forms quinoline-quinone metabolites, electron-transferring redox compounds that act as cellular oxidants. The drug is a tissue schizonticide and limits malaria transmission by acting as a gametocide.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise, and fatigue for the past 7-days. The patient recently returned from a 2-week trip to the Dominican Republic. She was prescribed antimalarial chemoprophylaxis but forgot to take it. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies and “chronic joint pain”. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva. Laboratory evaluation shows mild anemia and thrombocytopenia. Peripheral blood smear findings are shown below. After a complete evaluation, the patient is started on hydroxychloroquine. Which of the following findings can also be managed with the medication?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid
Proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joint stiffness
Intensely pruritic papules and pustules on the extensor surface of extremities
Well-defined erythematous plaque with silvery scales
Fluctuating and fatigable proximal muscle weakness

questions.solution:
This patient presents with high fevers, chills, anemia, and splenomegaly after visiting the Dominican Republic (where malaria is endemic). Peripheral blood smear reveals banana-shaped organisms. These findings are concerning for Plasmodium falciparum infection, and the patient is started on hydroxychloroquine.

Other therapeutic indications of hydroxychloroquine include:
 
  •  Treatment of chronic discoid erythematosus and systemic lupus erythematosus in adults 
  •  Treatment of acute and chronic rheumatoid arthritis in adults 
  •  Dominant skin, nasal mucosal, and sinus sarcoidosis
  •  Antiphospholipid syndrome 

Option Analysis

❌ Negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid:
Incorrect: Gouty arthritis presents negatively birefringent crystals in synovial fluid. Treatment options include glucocorticoids, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, and colchicine. Hydroxychloroquine is not effective in the management of gouty arthritis.  
✅ Proximal interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joint stiffness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intensely pruritic papules and pustules on the extensor surface of extremities:
Incorrect: Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with intensely pruritic papules and pustules on the extensor surface of the extremities. The condition is associated with underlying celiac disease and is managed with a gluten-free diet and dapsone. Hydroxychloroquine is ineffective in managing dermatitis herpetiformis.  
❌ Well-defined erythematous plaque with silvery scales:
Incorrect: Psoriasis presents with well-defined erythematous plaques with silvery scales. Common treatment options include emollients, corticosteroids, and topical vitamin D analogs. Hydroxychloroquine is not effective in the management of psoriasis.  
❌ Fluctuating and fatigable proximal muscle weakness:
Incorrect: Myasthenia gravis presents with fluctuating and fatigable proximal muscle weakness. Treatment options include pyridostigmine, azathioprine, and corticosteroids. Hydroxychloroquine is not effective in the management of myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of left flank pain radiating to the groin. The pain started two hours ago, is sharp, and is rated by the patient as a 10/10. The patient has hematuria but no dysuria or urgency. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows no costovertebral angle tenderness. Plain radiograph of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 4 mm calcified density at the level of the lower left sacrum, just above the level of the vesicoureteric junction. This patient’s groin pain is most likely referred from the involvement of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with flank pain radiating to the groin and radiographic evidence of an opacity in the pelvis, along the course of ureter, is consistent with ureteric colic/calculus.    

A ureteric calculus is the presence of a solid stone in the urinary tract, formed from minerals within the urine. These can obstruct urinary flow, causing renal colic (an acute and severe loin pain) and haematuria. There are three locations where the ureters are at their narrowest and, therefore, where a stone is more likely to become stuck: 
  •  Ureteropelvic junction 
  •  Pelvic brim 
  •  Where the ureter enters the bladder 
Nervous supply to the ureters is delivered via the renal, testicular/ovarian, and hypogastric plexuses. Sensory fibers from the ureters enter the spinal cord at T11-L2 with ureteric pain referred to those dermatomal areas. 
  •  Pain from upper ureteral stones tends to radiate to the flank and lumbar areas.  
  •  Mid-ureteral calculi cause pain that radiates anteriorly and caudally.  
  •  Distal ureteral stones cause pain that tends to radiate into the groin or testicle in the male or labia majora in the female because the pain is referred from the ilioinguinal (L1) or genitofemoral nerves (L1-L2). 


Option Analysis

❌ Subcostal :
Incorrect: The subcostal nerve is the anterior division of the twelfth thoracic nerve. It communicates with the iliohypogastric nerve and gives a branch to the pyramidalis muscle. It also gives off a lateral cutaneous branch that supplies sensory innervation to the skin over the hip. Its involvement would not cause groin pain.  
❌ Iliohypogastric :
Incorrect: The iliohypogastric nerve originates from the lumbar plexus and supplies sensation to skin over the lateral gluteal and hypogastric regions and motor to the internal oblique and transverse abdominal muscles. It’s involvement would not cause groin pain seen in this patient.  
✅ Ilioinguinal :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sciatic :
Incorrect: Sciatic nerve pain typically affects one or more regions in the low back, thigh, leg, and foot but not the groin.  
❌ Pelvic splanchnic:
Incorrect: Pelvic splanchnic nerves are splanchnic nerves that arise from sacral spinal nerves S2, S3,  and S4 to provide parasympathetic innervation to the hindgut, urinary bladder, and sphincter.
