Incorrect: Cocaine is a central nervous system stimulant and a local anesthetic. Central nervous system effects are mediated primarily through presynaptic norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin reuptake blockade.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the office after noticing bright red blood in her sputum this morning. The patient has had a fever, chest pain, and productive cough for the last 3 days. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and chronic myelogenous leukemia. She underwent a hematopoietic stem cell transplantation 8 weeks ago, which was complicated by acute graft-versus-host disease and prolonged neutropenia. Family history is noncontributory. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Lung auscultation reveals left-sided crackles. A complete blood profile shows a hematocrit of 25% and a leukocyte count of 1,400/mm<sup>3</sup>. A CT scan of the chest reveals several nodular lesions with surrounding ground-glass opacities in the left upper lobe. A combination of voriconazole and caspofungin is started. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of caspofungin?

choices.text: Conversion to 5-fluorouracil and subsequent inhibition of nucleic acid biosynthesis
Interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis
Binds ergosterol to form membrane pores that allow leakage electrolytes
Prevents cell wall synthesis by inhibiting beta-1,3-D-glucan synthase
Inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase

questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain, fever, and hemoptysis in combination with a history of immunosuppression and the classic “halo sign” on chest imaging. These findings are suggestive of invasive aspergillosis. Patients are usually treated with a combination of intravenous voriconazole and an echinocandin (e.g., caspofungin, anidulafungin, micafungin).

Echinocandins are antifungal medications that non-competitively bind and inhibit beta-1,3-D-glucan synthase, thereby preventing cell wall synthesis and repair. The cell wall gradually deforms until it ruptures, causing the fungal cell to die.

Echinocandis are only available via the intravenous route since they are not well absorbed through the gastrointestinal tract.

Echinocandins are used to treat fungal infections resistant to the more common antifungal medications like amphotericin-B and the azoles. Common indications include mucocutaneous candidiasis, disseminated candidiasis, and invasive aspergillosis.

Adverse effects include hepatotoxicity, gastrointestinal upset, as well as facial flushing and rash due to histamine release. It is generally approved for use in children and the elderly, but not in pregnant or lactating women.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Conversion to 5-fluorouracil and subsequent inhibition of nucleic acid biosynthesis:
Incorrect: Flucytosine is an antifungal agent that is converted to the antimetabolite 5-fluorouracil by cytosine deaminase in fungal cells, where it inhibits DNA synthesis. Flucytosine is usually used in combination with amphotericin B or an azole for treatment of severe systemic infections, such as candidiasis and cryptococcal meningitis. In contrast, caspofungin works via a different mechanism of action.  
❌ Interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis:
Incorrect: Griseofulvin interferes with fungal microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It deposits in keratin-containing tissues (e.g. nails) and is used to treat superficial fungal infections.  
❌ Binds ergosterol to form membrane pores that allow leakage electrolytes:
Incorrect: Nystatin and amphotericin B bind ergosterol in fungal cell membranes to form membrane pores that allow for the leakage of electrolytes. In contrast, caspofungin works via a different mechanism of action.  
✅ Prevents cell wall synthesis by inhibiting beta-1,3-D-glucan synthase:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase:
Incorrect: Terbinafine inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, thereby decreasing the synthesis of ergosterol from squalene and increasing cellular membrane permeability. It is typically used in the management of dermatophyte infections, especially onychomycosis. It is not indicated in the treatment of invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man is brought by ambulance to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. The patient resides in an assisted living facility and has been refusing his medications throughout the week due to feeling unwell, which was presumed to be due to an upper respiratory illness. The patient has a past medical history of coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypertension. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, pulse is 122/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. The patient appears ill, is responsive only to pain, and is unable to provide a clinical history. Fingerstick blood glucose is >600 mg/dL and venous pH is 7.42. Serum osmolality is 390 mOsm/kg. Which of the following additional features is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Development of symptoms over days to weeks

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with altered mental status, hypotension, elevated glucose, and increased osmolality likely has hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS). Patients with HHS tend to develop symptoms over days to weeks, which include polyuria, polydipsia, and weight loss. This is in contrast to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) which often develops rapidly within 24 hours in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus.

HHS is a potentially life-threatening complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Patients at risk for HHS are those with inadequate glycemic control, advanced age, and multiple comorbidities. It is typically triggered in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus by precipitating factors, such as illness or infection. The diagnosis of HHS requires lab workup that demonstrates an elevated blood glucose and serum osmolality and the absence of metabolic acidosis and ketonuria.  

Option Analysis

✅ Development of symptoms over days to weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ketonuria:
Incorrect: Ketonuria is typically not present in patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), which helps to distinguish it from diabetic ketoacidosis.  
❌ Absolute insulin deficiency:
Incorrect: Absolute insulin deficiency is characteristic of diabetic type 1 where patients can develop diabetic ketoacidosis. Patients with insulin resistance with diabetes mellitus type 2 are more likely to develop hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state.  
❌ Metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: In contrast to diabetic ketoacidosis, patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state do not develop metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Evidence of mild dehydration:
Incorrect: Patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state are often severely dehydrated with volume deficits that can approach 8-9 liters due to osmotic diuresis.

questions.text: An 83-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. The patient's partner reports that they found him unresponsive that morning and reports the patient has been urinating constantly over the past two weeks and complaining of increased thirst and fatigue. The patient’s partner states that he has been non-adherent with his medications. The patient has a past medical history of peripheral vascular disease, atrial fibrillation, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), blood pressure is 97/60 mmHg, pulse is 123/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears ill and is unable to provide a clinical history. Physical examination demonstrates dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, and delayed capillary refill. Fingerstick blood glucose is >600 mg/dL and serum osmolality is 360 mOsm/kg. A serum arterial blood gas, complete metabolic panel, and urinalysis are pending. Which of the following additional diagnostic findings is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) including history of DM, blood glucose >600 mg/dL, elevated serum osmolality, and physical examination findings and history suggestive of profound dehydration and altered mental status. Of the findings listed, a normal pH >7.3 is most likely to be present on arterial blood gas.

HHS is a life-threatening complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus, usually triggered by a precipitating factor, such as illness or infection. The diagnosis of HHS requires lab workup that demonstrates an elevated blood glucose and elevated serum osmolality, as well as the absence of metabolic acidosis and ketonuria.

Patients with HHS will often have a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus with inadequate glycemic control, precipitating infection, advanced age, or multiple comorbidities. Patients develop osmotic diuresis and slowly lose free water until symptoms develop, which can include fatigue, polyuria, polydipsia, altered mental status, and seizures.

On physical examination, patients may have evidence of focal neurologic deficits mimicking a stroke as well as evidence of profound dehydration (e.g. dry mucous membranes, decreased skin turgor, poor capillary refill). All patients with suspected HHS should have serum pH, CMP, serum osmolality, and urinalysis obtained to assist in making the diagnosis. In contrast to patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, patients with HHS will demonstrate a pH>7.3, few to no ketones on urinalysis, and the absence of metabolic acidosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ pH > 7.3:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Non-anion gap metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect:  In patients with diabetic ketoacidosis, an elevated anion-gap metabolic acidosis is seen. Patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS) do not have metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Significant ketonuria:
Incorrect: Profound ketonuria is seen in patients with diabetic ketoacidosis but not typically in patients with hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state (HHS), although mild ketonuria can be present in severe cases of hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state.  
❌ Elevated anion-gap metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: An elevated anion-gap metabolic acidosis is present in the setting of diabetic ketoacidosis due to the presence of ketones in the blood.  
❌ Calcium oxalate crystals on urinalysis:
Incorrect: Calcium oxalate crystals on urinalysis suggests a diagnosis of ethylene glycol toxicity, which presents with altered mental status and renal failure in patients who have ingested ethylene glycol, a chemical typically found in antifreeze.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department with crushing substernal chest pain. He is found to have an inferior wall myocardial infarction per ECG criteria, and the cardiac catheterization lab is activated. Before transferring, this patient is treated with aspirin and clopidogrel since the sum of their anti-platelet effects together is more significant than their individual effects. Which of the following best describes this type of pharmacodynamic medication interaction?
questions.solution:
Pharmacokinetic and pharmacodynamic medication interactions are the foundation for multiple medical treatments and adverse medication effects. An interaction between two or more drugs that causes the total effect of the drugs to be greater than the sum of the individual effects of each drug is referred to as synergism. Several significant interactions should be memorized for the USMLE and are outlined in the table above.    

Moreover, phase I metabolism of a drug, which is usually performed by the cytochrome P450 superfamily of mixed-function oxidases, can be affected by genetic and environmental factors. A common environmental influence is a drug-drug interaction in which a drug's induction or inhibition of a cytochrome enzyme alters the metabolism of another drug that is a substrate for that enzyme (e.g. warfarin).   

Option Analysis

✅ Synergistic:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Potentiation:
Incorrect: Potentiation is similar to synergism; however, a key difference is that one of the medications does not exert a therapeutic effect or has a completely different effect that enhances the principal medication.   
❌ Tachyphylactic :
Incorrect: Tachyphylactic refers to an acute decrease in response to a medication with repeated doses.   
❌ Permissive:
Incorrect: Permissive refers to the fact that for a medication to exert its full therapeutic effect, it must be in the presence of additional medication.   
❌ Antagonism:
Incorrect: Antagonism means that the effect of two substances together is less than the sum of their individual effects.

questions.text: A group of researchers is studying a novel medication used to treat hypertension. They are attempting to understand its pharmacokinetic profile better. In particular, they investigate the drug’s primary route of excretion from the body. Which of the following organs is this medication’s most likely route of excretion from the body?
questions.solution:
Elimination refers to the irreversible loss of drugs from the body and occurs via two processes: metabolism or excretion. Metabolism refers to the build-up and breakdown of substances by enzymatic conversion of one chemical entity to another. In contrast, excretion eliminates drug or drug metabolites from the body. In some cases, certain medications do not undergo any metabolism (e.g. lithium) and do not exert their effects until they are excreted via the kidneys.    

In general, most medications are excreted through urination via the kidneys. In the kidneys, some medications or their metabolites are directly filtered through the glomerulus, while others are secreted in the proximal convoluted tubule. Ultimately, these drugs and metabolites travel to the distal convoluted tubule where polar, water-soluble molecules are excreted. A portion of non-soluble molecules is passively diffused back into peritubular circulation.    

Additional routes of excretion include the hepatobiliary system, lungs, and to a lesser extent, bodily secretions such as sweat or milk. Of note, medications excreted via the lungs are limited to volatile gasses such as nitrous oxide and halothane.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Kidneys:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hepatobiliary system:
Incorrect: Multiple medications are processed and excreted through the hepatobiliary system, including those processed by the CYP-450 enzyme system. However, the kidneys remain the most common route of drug excretion from the body.  
❌ Lungs:
Incorrect: Volatile anesthetics, such as those used during surgery (e.g., halothane, nitric oxide), are excreted via the lungs. However, the kidneys remain the most common route of drug excretion from the body.  
❌ Skin:
Incorrect: The skin is not a standard route of drug excretion. However, trace quantities of specific drug metabolites can be found in sweat.  
❌ Gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: The gastrointestinal tract (e.g., small intestine, large intestine) is not a common route of drug excretion. However, an example of a drug excreted primarily via this route is rifampicin.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found confused at home with scattered pill bottles at the bedside. Past medical history is notable for depression, anxiety, and peripheral neuropathy. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), respirations are 22/min, pulse is 109/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mmHg.  Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes, mydriasis, and urinary retention. An electrocardiogram demonstrates QT prolongation. A medication overdose is suspected, and the patient is empirically administered ammonium chloride to enhance renal drug excretion. Which of the following medications did this patient most likely ingest?
questions.solution:
This patient presents clinical features concerning tricyclic antidepressant overdose, including antimuscarinic toxidrome findings and QT prolongation on an electrocardiogram. Given that these medications are weak bases, patients presenting with overdose are often treated with ammonium chloride, which enhances renal excretion of these substances.    

Several medications are considered weak bases, including tricyclic antidepressants and amphetamines, among many others. Historically, an adjunct to overdose treatment with these medications involves administering ammonium chloride, which has been shown to reduce total body pH. The drug molecules are weak bases and will exist primarily in protonated charged form. The charged molecules are less likely to induce toxicity by crossing the blood-brain barrier and have enhanced elimination in the urine. The latter phenomenon is because charged particles have a more challenging time back-diffusing across the renal epithelium into the systemic circulation.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  



Option Analysis

✅ Amitriptyline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate (not ammonium chloride) can be administered to alkalize the urine, cause aspirin to deprotonate, and trap the polarized drug molecules in the renal tubules. These changes can increase aspirin elimination via urine.  
❌ Phenobarbital:
Incorrect: Phenobarbital is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in the setting of an overdose to increaelimination via urine.  
❌ Methotrexate:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in the setting of an overdose to increase drug elimination via urine.  
❌ Cephalexin:
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate, not ammonium chloride, can be administered in case of an overdose to increase drug elimination via urine.

questions.text:
A 66-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of acute onset right flank pain, hematuria, and vomiting for the past 10 hours. The patient has a past medical history of obesity, hypertension, and diabetes. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 155/75 mm Hg, heart rate is 111/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable. Physical exam reveals right-sided flank tenderness. He is started on IV normal saline, IV ketorolac, and ondansetron.  A CBC and BMP are pending. Urinalysis findings are shown below. A non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis shows a 6.5 mm obstructing stone in the mid-ureter on the right side. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Laboratory value
Result
Urinalysis

Color
Clear
Specific gravity  
1.013  
Glucose
Negative
Blood
Large
Leukocyte esterase  
Negative
Nitrites
Negative
Leukocytes
1-2/hpf  
Erythrocytes
25-50/hpf  
Bacteria
None seen  
Dysmorphic RBCs  
Absent
Casts
none
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings consistent with nephrolithiasis which is confirmed with CT-imaging. Given the size of the stone, the best next step in management is to obtain a urologic consultation. Renal stones that are ≥ 6 mm are unlikely to pass spontaneously. These stones typically require endoscopic removal or extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.

Patients with suspected nephrolithiasis should have a non-contrast helical CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to confirm the diagnosis, characterize the size and location of the stone, and determine if hydronephrosis is present. Stones that are <6 mm in size may pass spontaneously. Patients can be sent home on pain medication and instructed to increase fluid intake and strain their urine to collect any stones that pass. They can be prescribed alpha-blockers, like tamsulosin, which can help relax the ureteral smooth muscle and facilitate stone passage. Stones that are ≥ 6 mm in size require urologic consultation for endoscopic removal or extracorporeal lithotripsy.

Regardless of the management strategy, the stone type should be assessed, either from the stone fragments obtained during a urologic procedure or from stones collected in a calculi strainer. 24-hour urine collection should be sent for urinary pH, calcium, oxalate, citrate, uric acid, and phosphorus levels. The information from these studies is used to determine which measures should be taken to prevent future stones. Regardless of the type of stone, all patients with stones should be encouraged to drink enough fluid to dilute urine and maintain a urine output of at least 2.5 liters in 24 hours. In general, a low-sodium diet that is high in fruits and vegetables is recommended to prevent stones. Specific dietary recommendations and medications should be tailored to the type of stones found.  

Option Analysis

✅ Urologic consultation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Trial of spontaneous passage:
Incorrect: Renal stones that are ≥ 6 mm are unlikely to pass spontaneously. This patient requires urologic consultation for endoscopic removal or extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.  
❌ 24-hour urinary studies:
Incorrect:  24-hour urinary studies are indicated when the renal stone has spontaneously passed or after removal of stone fragments from surgical intervention. This patient has evidence of a large renal stone that is unlikely to pass spontaneously requiring urologic consultation for endoscopic removal or extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy.  
❌ Administration of tamsulosin:
Incorrect: Tamsulosin may be provided to patients with confirmed nephrolithiasis unless otherwise contraindicated. However, the best next step in management for this patient is to consult urology given the size of the renal stone.  
❌ Administer potassium citrate:
Incorrect: Potassium citrate is indicated to prevent recurrent stones in patients with uric acid stones. This would be prescribed if 24-hour urine studies and urine microscopy are consistent with  uric acid stones.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic with fatigue and headaches for five months. She struggles with having enough energy to teach her preschool students and has noticed numbness in her feet for the past four weeks. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 83/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and blood pressure is 123/74 mmHg. On physical examination, she appears pale with mild conjunctival pallor. Strength is 5/5 in all extremities with decreased sensation to light touch in both feet. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Initial laboratory studies reveal a normal basic metabolic panel and thyroid stimulating hormone. Results from a complete blood count and additional studies are shown below. Which of the following additional clinical elements is most likely to be present?  

Laboratory value
Result
Hemoglobin
10.6 g/dL  
Hematocrit
32%  
Mean corpuscular volume  
102 fL  
Reticulocyte count  
1.0%  
Peripheral blood smear  
Macrocytosis and hypersegmented neutrophils
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of chronic fatigue, headache, and peripheral neuropathy and has evidence of macrocytosis (i.e. mean corpuscular volume greater than 100 fL) with hypersegmented neutrophils consistent with megaloblastic anemia (likely secondary to vitamin B12 deficiency). This disease is commonly seen in patients on a vegan diet who do not take supplemental vitamin B12.

A thorough and focused history is essential for guiding further assessment and management of patients presenting with anemia. Inquiring about medical history, alcohol use, medications, and dietary practices is important. If macrocytosis is discovered, then a reticulocyte count, vitamin B12 level, folate level, and a peripheral smear should be obtained. With megaloblastic processes, red blood cell precursors become larger due to defective RNA and DNA synthesis and ineffective hematopoiesis. The reticulocyte count will be inappropriately low for the degree of anemia. Hypersegmented neutrophils seen on peripheral smears are another important diagnostic feature of megaloblastic anemias.

Vitamin B12 deficiency is commonly the cause of macrocytic anemia in countries with readily available access to folate-supplemented food. Vitamin B12 deficiency can develop in individuals who follow a vegan or strict vegetarian diet as well as those with poor nutritional intake or malabsorption (such as in pernicious anemia). Other causes of megaloblastic anemia include deficiency of folate or copper, heavy alcohol use, and medications that interfere with DNA synthesis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vegan diet:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ NSAID use:
Incorrect: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can induce gastrointestinal mucosal injury, resulting in blood loss and eventually microcytic, iron deficiency anemia.  This patient’s macrocytic anemia is likely due to vitamin B12 deficiency from following a vegan diet.  
❌ Heavy menstruation:
Incorrect: Women who experience menstrual cycles with heavy bleeding are at increased risk for developing iron deficiency anemia, which results in microcytic and hypochromic RBCs. This patient has evidence of macrocytic anemia.  
❌ Environmental lead exposure:
Incorrect: Lead poisoning can cause microcytic anemia with basophilic stippling of RBCs. While it can present with fatigue and headaches, this patient has evidence of macrocytic anemia.  
❌ Recent viral infection:
Incorrect: Parvovirus B19 infection can cause a normocytic, pure red cell aplasia with low reticulocyte count. This patient's anemia is macrocytic and she does not have associated symptoms like arthralgias that can be seen with Parvovirus infection.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with a history of sickle cell disease (SCD) presents to the emergency department with sudden onset right-sided weakness and difficulty speaking for the past 2 hours. She has a history of multiple painful episodes from SCD. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), heart rate is 85/min, blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Neurological examination reveals expressive aphasia, right-sided hemiparesis, 4+ reflexes in the right arm and leg, and a positive Babinski on the right. Cardiovascular, respiratory, and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Hemoglobin is 8 g/dL. After a simple red blood cell transfusion, MRI confirms an ischemic stroke. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate intravenous hydration with hypotonic saline

questions.solution:
This patient with sickle cell disease (SCD) presents with clinical features and MRI findings consistent with an acute ischemic stroke. Immediate exchange transfusion should be performed.      

Exchange transfusion is a type of apheresis where blood is removed from the patient and depleted of RBCs, then it is reconstituted with donor RBCs and retransfused. The primary mechanism of stroke in SCD is vaso-occlusion of cerebral vessels caused by sickled erythrocytes. This process is particularly dangerous because once the sickling process begins, it can propagate quickly, leading to extensive ischemia and infarction. Immediate exchange transfusion is the most effective management to rapidly reduce the proportion of sickled cells, restore blood flow to ischemic areas, and limit extension of the stroke. This method is preferred over simple transfusions alone to avoid increasing the blood viscosity which could exacerbate the vaso-occlusion.    

Patients with SCD and an ischemic stroke should also be treated with isotonic fluids, and simple transfusions can be used as a temporizing measure for patients with low hemoglobin levels. Oxygen should be provided to maintain oxygen saturation > 95% and supportive care should be provided. Empiric antibiotics should be given if there is a fever or evidence of infection.  

Option Analysis

✅ Perform exchange transfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiate intravenous hydration with hypotonic saline:
Incorrect: IV hydration with isotonic fluids (ie normal saline) should be given to patients with SCD and acute stroke. Hypotonic saline could potentially worsen cerebral edema.
❌ Administer tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) :
Incorrect: Patients with SCD and acute ischemic stroke should be considered for intravenous tPA, though the evidence is limited. The exchange catheter should be placed and exchange transfusion should be initiated regardless of whether or not reperfusion is performed.
❌ Perform head CT:
Incorrect: MRI is the preferred imaging in suspected acute stroke in patients with SCD if it is available and can be done rapidly; however if it is not rapidly available or is contraindicated, CT should be performed. This patient had an MRI already that confirmed the diagnosis of ischemic stroke.
❌ Administer hydroxyurea :
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea is used as a long-term treatment in patients with SCD to reduce the frequency of pain episodes and acute chest syndrome. It is not used for the treatment of acute stroke.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to his primary care physician because of abdominal and chest discomfort for two months. The patient states that the pain is worse with swallowing. Past medical history includes HIV. The patient has not been consistent with taking his highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART therapy). Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 125/70 mmHg, pulse is 92/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The oropharynx has evidence of scrapable white plaques over the tongue and posterior pharynx. Abdominal examination is benign. The patient is referred to gastroenterology for endoscopy with biopsies. Which of the following features on histopathology is most likely to be present?

choices.text: Nonciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of esophagitis. Given his history of untreated HIV and physical examination findings of scrapable white plaques in the oropharynx, he most likely has esophageal candidiasis. Histopathology from esophageal biopsies taken during upper gastrointestinal endoscopy would show the presence of yeast forms or pseudohyphae. He should be treated with antifungal agents if the EGD confirms the diagnosis of esophageal candidiasis.  

Upper abdominal pain, chest discomfort, and odynophagia may be present in patients with esophagitis. Dysphagia is considered an alarm feature and an upper endoscopy with biopsies should be performed. EGD can help differentiate between reflux esophagitis, eosinophilic esophagitis, esophageal candidiasis, viral esophagitis, and radiation-induced esophagitis as seen in the table below. Pill-induced esophagitis can be diagnosed clinically.  



Option Analysis

✅ Pseudohyphae:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlarged, multinucleated cells :
Incorrect: Enlarged, multi-nucleated cells are often seen on histopathology in patients with viral esophagitis. While this patient is immunocompromised, the presence of scrapable white plaques is more consistent with esophageal candidiasis. 
❌ Epithelial necrosis:
Incorrect: Epithelial necrosis can be seen on histopathology in patients with radiation-induced esophagitis. Superficial erosions, bleeding, ulcers, and strictures may be seen on endoscopy. This patient has no risk factors for radiation-induced esophagitis. 
❌ Eosinophils in the squamous epithelium :
Incorrect: Eosinophils seen in the squamous epithelium on histopathology is suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis. It typically occurs in patients with atopic conditions (e.g. asthma, allergic rhinitis) due to chronic inflammation of the esophagus caused by antigen sensitization.
❌ Nonciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells:
Incorrect: Metaplastic columnar epithelium is seen on histopathology in patients with Barrett’s esophagus. The stratified squamous epithelium that normally lines the distal esophagus is replaced with metaplastic columnar epithelium. This patient does not have a history of long-standing gastroesophageal reflux.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with voice hoarseness, weight gain, and fatigue. She reports a weight gain of 11 kg (24 lb) during the past six months with no changes to her diet or activity level. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 43/min, and blood pressure is 115/95 mmHg. A palpable, smooth, rubbery, non-tender neck mass is noted on physical examination. The patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Laboratory studies show a TSH of 11.1 mIU/L, a free T4 of 0.75 mIU/L, and the presence of anti-TPO and anti-Tg antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with compressive symptoms of a goiter (voice hoarseness), fatigue, and weight gain. She has an elevated TSH, low free T4, and the presence of antithyroid antibodies; therefore, can be diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Symptoms of Hashimoto thyroiditis include fatigue, weight gain, depression, dry skin, and cold intolerance. Physical examination findings consist of bradycardia, delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes, peripheral edema, palpable (non-tender) smooth goiter, and diastolic hypertension. An elevated TSH, low free T4, and detection of autoantibodies (anti-TPO and anti-Tg) can be used to confirm the diagnosis of Hashimoto thyroiditis. The presence of either anti-TPO or anti-Tg antibodies is sufficient to make the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hashimoto thyroiditis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hashitoxicosis:
Incorrect: Hashitoxicosis is a rare phase of hyperthyroidism that can occur during the initial stages of Hashimoto thyroiditis and results from the acute destruction of thyroid cells by autoantibodies. Patients will typically present with signs and symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism (eg, tachycardia, heat intolerance, weight loss, etc.) which is then followed by hypothyroidism.  
❌ Addison disease:
Incorrect: Addison disease typically presents with hyperpigmentation, weakness, fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and orthostatic hypotension.  
❌ Nonthyroidal illness:
Incorrect: Patients recovering from a nonthyroidal illness can have transient elevations in TSH. This patient with anti-TPO and anti-Tg antibodies can be diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis.  
❌ Graves disease:
Incorrect: Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism and presents with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, eye pain, and heat intolerance.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department with malaise, nausea, and abdominal discomfort. She took several acetaminophen tablets over the past week to manage menstrual pain but is unsure of the exact amount or timing. Her past medical history is significant for dysmenorrhea and migraine headaches. She takes no regular medications and does not smoke or drink alcohol. Temperature is 36.2°C (97.2°F), blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, pulse is 76/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing woman with mild tenderness in the right upper abdominal quadrant. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?  

Test
Result
Hemoglobin
11.4 g/dL
Leukocyte count  
11,000/mm3  
Platelet count  
300,000/mm3  
Sodium
142 mEq/L  
Potassium
4.3 mEq/L  
Chloride
101 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate
24 mEq/L  
BUN
15 mg/dL  
Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL  
AST
750 U/L  
ALT
650 U/L  
PT
12 seconds  
INR
1.0  
Acetaminophen level  
Undetectable

choices.text: Monitor liver function tests every 4 hours

questions.solution:
The patient who has been ingesting acetaminophen and presents with malaise, nausea, and abdominal discomfort, along with substantially elevated AST and ALT levels, likely has acetaminophen hepatotoxicity despite the initial undetectable acetaminophen level. Immediate administration of N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is essential for managing this toxicity.

For patients presenting after 24 hours or an unknown duration post-ingestion, management is guided by acetaminophen (APAP) levels and liver function enzymes. If APAP levels are undetectable and liver enzymes (AST and ALT) are within the normal range, an alternative diagnosis should be considered. However, even if APAP is not present in the bloodstream, elevated AST and ALT levels can indicate acetaminophen toxicity in the right clinical context. In such instances, the immediate course of action is to initiate management with NAC which acts as an antidote, replenishing glutathione stores, thus preventing further liver damage.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer N-acetylcysteine (NAC)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Discharge with outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: Discharging the patient without addressing the potential acetaminophen toxicity is not appropriate. The elevated liver enzymes suggest ongoing liver injury, which requires immediate intervention rather than outpatient monitoring.  
❌ Monitor liver function tests every 4 hours:
Incorrect: While it is essential to keep track of liver function levels in suspected acetaminophen toxicity, monitoring won't prevent the progression of liver damage. Immediate intervention with NAC is necessary.  
❌ Perform gastric lavage:
Incorrect: Gastric lavage aims to prevent further absorption of ingested toxins and is most effective if performed within 4 hours of ingestion. Given the patient's uncertainty about the timing of ingestion and the presence of liver injury, NAC should be administered to prevent further liver damage.  
❌ Consult liver transplant team:
Incorrect: Liver transplantation is considered for patients with acetaminophen toxicity who display signs of liver failure and have unfavorable prognostic indicators. This patient does not have advanced features, such as markedly elevated PT/INR and metabolic acidosis. The immediate treatment priority is to start NAC therapy.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with three days of fever, chills, back pain, and dysuria. The patient is diagnosed with pyelonephritis and started on an intravenous (IV) antibiotic. The plasma concentration of this IV antibiotic is graphed over time. After two days the patient is switched to an oral antibiotic, and the plasma concentration of the oral antibiotic is also graphed over time. Which of the following could be used to calculate the bioavailability of this antibiotic?

choices.text: Total amount of drug ingested / plasma drug concentration
Plasma drug concentration / total amount of drug ingested
Total amount of drug ingested  x  plasma drug concentration
Area under the curve (AUC) for oral drug / AUC for IV medication
AUC for IV medication / AUC for oral medication

questions.solution:
Bioavailability refers to the proportion of a medication that reaches circulation and can be determined by graphing the plasma concentration of a medication over time for both IV and oral forms. The area under the curve (AUC) of the oral medication is divided by the AUC for the IV medication to determine the bioavailability. It can be expressed as a fraction of 1, or as a percentage.  

Since intravenous (IV) medications are delivered directly into the bloodstream, their bioavailability is said to be 1, or 100%. Ingested medications have varying amounts of bioavailability, thus making IV medications more effective in many cases. Some oral medications have such high bioavailability that they are almost equivalent to IV doses. As a medication passes through the GI tract, some of it may be delivered to the liver and partially metabolized, leaving less medication available for delivery to target tissues. This is referred to as the first-pass effect. In addition, the medication needs to diffuse across cellular membranes, further lowering bioavailability.  

Option Analysis

❌ Total amount of drug ingested / plasma drug concentration:
Incorrect: This represents the volume of distribution which indicates the degree a drug is distributed throughout body tissues (e.g., predominantly in plasma or distributed throughout most tissues).
❌ Plasma drug concentration / total amount of drug ingested:
Incorrect: This would be the inverse of the volume of distribution and does not represent bioavailability.
❌ Total amount of drug ingested  x  plasma drug concentration:
Incorrect: This would not provide any useful information to this patient. If the total amount of drug ingested were instead divided by plasma concentration, this would yield the volume of distribution. 
✅ Area under the curve (AUC) for oral drug / AUC for IV medication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ AUC for IV medication / AUC for oral medication:
Incorrect: If the numerator and denominator were reversed, this would be the correct calculation for bioavailability.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 1-day history of abdominal pain, fatigue, and pallor. He reports that he recently developed a cough and congestion and used the remainder of his girlfriend’s antibiotics which helped with his symptoms. He recalls that his mother and younger brother occasionally have had “yellow eyes” when they have had infections. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On exam, the conjunctivae are pale, and the sclerae have a slight yellowish tint. Abdominal examination is significant for diffuse abdominal tenderness, and mild splenomegaly. Laboratory evaluation is shown below. Peripheral blood smear shows Heinz bodies and Coombs test is negative. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause for this patient’s presentation?  

Laboratory test
Results
Hemoglobin (Hb)  
9.2 g/dL  
Hematocrit (Hct)  
26%  
White Blood Cells (WBC)  
7,500/mm3   
Platelets (Plt)  
300,000/mm3
Reticulocyte Count  
10%  
Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)  
88 fL
Total Bilirubin  
2.9 mg/dL
Unconjugated Bilirubin  
2.5 mg/dL
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  
360 U/L

choices.text: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency in red blood cells
Intrinsic defect in red blood cell membrane proteins
Warm autoantibody-mediated destruction of red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute hemolytic anemia, evident from his fatigue and pallor. The recent upper respiratory illness combined with use of an unknown antibiotic likely triggered oxidative stress-induced hemolysis in this patient with underlying glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

G6PD deficiency, which is an X-linked recessive disorder, is the most common enzymatic disorder of red blood cells. G6PD plays a pivotal role in the pentose phosphate pathway, which protects red blood cells from oxidative damage by producing reduced glutathione. A deficiency in G6PD makes red blood cells more susceptible to oxidative stress. Consequently, certain triggers, like infections, certain medications (eg sulfa drugs, antimalarials), certain foods like fava beans, and alcohol can precipitate acute hemolysis in affected individuals. Patients with G6PD deficiency may remain asymptomatic until exposed to these triggers. When hemolysis occurs, symptoms can be rapid in onset and may include fatigue, pallor, jaundice (due to the breakdown of hemoglobin), abdominal pain, and hemoglobinuria, leading to dark urine. The physical exam may show pallor, jaundice, and splenomegaly due to increased RBC turnover.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency in red blood cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intrinsic defect in red blood cell membrane proteins:
Incorrect: Hereditary spherocytosis is characterized by an intrinsic defect in RBC membrane proteins. However, this condition can result in acute or chronic hemolytic anemia and spherocytes on peripheral smear.  
❌ Warm autoantibody-mediated destruction of red blood cells:
Incorrect: Warm autoantibody-mediated hemolytic anemia (the most common form of autoimmune hemolytic anemia) can lead to jaundice and anemia, but the Coombs test would be positive and spherocytes would typically be seen on peripheral smear.  
❌ Decreased hepatic UDP-glucuronosyltransferase activity:
Incorrect: This is suggestive of Gilbert's syndrome, a benign condition that can result in intermittent jaundice, particularly during times of stress or fasting. However, it does not cause acute hemolytic anemia.  
❌ Decreased ADAMTS13 activity:
Incorrect: A deficiency in ADAMTS13 results in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). While patients with TTP can present with acute hemolytic anemia, they often present with a constellation of findings including thrombocytopenia, neurological abnormalities, renal dysfunction, and fever.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 1-week history of fatigue, pallor, dizziness, headaches, and episodes of fever with chills that occur every 48-72 hours. He reports intermittent yellow discoloration of his skin. He recently returned from a research trip to Malawi. His family history is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), heart rate is 105/min, blood pressure is 125/78 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. The patient appears pale. Examination reveals jaundice and mild splenomegaly. Cardiovascular examination reveals tachycardia. Pulmonary and neurologic examinations are unremarkable. Initial laboratory tests are shown below. Which of the following blood smear findings would be expected in this patient?  

Laboratory test
Results
Hemoglobin (Hb)  
9.2 g/dL
Hematocrit (Hct)  
26%
White Blood Cells (WBC)  
11,500/mm3
Platelets (Plt)  
400,000/mm3   
Reticulocyte Count  
9%  
Mean Corpuscular Volume (MCV)  
88 fL
Total Bilirubin  
3.4 mg/dL  
Unconjugated Bilirubin  
3.1 mg/dL  
Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)  
220 U/L  
Haptoglobin
10 mg/dL (Reference value 50-220 mg/dL)
questions.solution:
Taken fromWikimedia Commons
The patient's presentation of cyclical fever with chills, headaches, history of recent travel abroad to a malaria-endemic region; anemia with hemolysis evidenced by jaundice, elevated reticulocyte, indirect hyperbilirubinemia, increased LDH, and decreased haptoglobin is highly suggestive of malaria. The pathognomonic finding on blood smear is the presence of intraerythrocytic ring-form structures. These are young trophozoites of the Plasmodium parasite, often referred to as "ring forms" due to their appearance.

Malaria, caused by the Plasmodium species, is an infectious disease transmitted via the bite of the female Anopheles mosquito. This leads to RBC lysis and subsequent hemolysis. Patients with malaria typically have episodes of fever with chills, with a pattern that can vary based on the Plasmodium species but often involves cycles where the individual will feel well for a period, followed by sudden and intense shaking, fevers, and diaphoresis. Other symptoms include fatigue, pallor, dizziness, headache, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea.  

Option Analysis

✅ Presence of intraerythrocytic ring-form structures:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Presence of intraerythrocytic "Maltese cross" structures:
Incorrect: This finding is indicative of Babesiosis, a parasitic infection transmitted by ticks typically seen in temperate zones including the Northeast and upper Midwest regions of the United States. The "Maltese cross" formation represents the tetrads of Babesia parasites within the red cells. The clinical presentation can be similar to malaria with fevers and hemolysis, but this patient's travel history and cyclical fevers align more closely with malaria.  
❌ Predominance of spherocytes:
Incorrect: A blood smear with a predominance of spherocytes is characteristic of hereditary spherocytosis and also can be seen in autoimmune hemolytic anemia. The presence of cyclical fevers, headaches, and travel history to a malaria-endemic region, makes malaria more likely.  
❌ Presence of sickled RBCs:
Incorrect: Sickled red blood cells are a defining trait of sickle cell disease (SCD). This genetic disorder prompts red cells to assume a sickle shape under conditions of low oxygen, leading to occlusion of small vessels and painful crises. SCD does not exhibit the cyclical fever pattern associated with malaria, making it an unlikely diagnosis in this patient.  
❌ Presence of bite cells:
Incorrect: Bit cells can be seen during hemolytic episodes in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. Oxidative stress induces hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies, and the spleen's macrophages "bite" these inclusions out, leading to the characteristic "bite" cell appearance. While this patient does exhibit symptoms of hemolysis, the cyclical fever pattern and travel history make malaria more likely.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a past medical history of thyroidectomy for thyroid cancer is brought to the emergency department due to palpitations, profuse sweating, and headaches. The patient’s brother had a similar episode last year and subsequently underwent surgery for a neuroendocrine tumor. Temperature is 37.7 ºC (99.9 ºF), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is alert and oriented. She is anxious with a fine tremor of the hands. The patient’s skin is warm and moist. Laboratory tests are in progress and a point-of-care glucose is 125 mg/dL. A 12-lead ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of thyroid cancer and a family history consistent with a pheochromocytoma, presents with palpitations, sweating, hypertension, and tachycardia suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2). In the acute setting with patients experiencing a catecholamine surge from a suspected pheochromocytoma, the immediate goals are to establish adequate monitoring, stabilize the patient, and prevent complications. Continuous cardiac monitoring (telemetry) is crucial due to the risk of tachyarrhythmias and other cardiac complications that can arise from catecholamine excess.

MEN2 is a rare hereditary disorder characterized by the occurrence of multiple endocrine tumors, such as medullary thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma. It is further subdivided into MEN2A and MEN2B based on additional features. MEN2A is associated with hypercalcemia from primary hyperparathyroidism as a result of hyperplasia or adenomas of the parathyroid glands. In MEN2B, patients may develop mucosal neuromas or intestinal ganglioneuromas.

Patients with pheochromocytoma may present with paroxysms of anxiety, diaphoresis, headache, hypertension, and tachycardia. An ABCDE assessment should be performed to assess hemodynamic and respiratory stability. IV access should be obtained and continuous cardiac/vital sign monitoring should be initiated. This includes blood pressure, heart rate, and pulse oximetry. If blood pressure control is required the first-line pharmacologic treatment for  pheochromocytoma-induced hypertensive crisis is an alpha-adrenergic blocker (e.g. phentolamine) to prevent vasoconstriction. Only after adequate alpha-blockade should beta-blockers be administered.  

Option Analysis

✅ Continuous cardiac monitoring:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous metoprolol:
Incorrect: Although beta-blockers like metoprolol are part of the medical management for pheochromocytoma, they should not be used without adequate alpha-adrenergic blockade provided first.  
❌ CT abdomen and pelvis:
Incorrect: A CT scan may eventually be indicated to locate the pheochromocytoma, but it is not the immediate next step. This patient should first be stabilized and adequate monitoring should be established.  
❌ Intravenous normal saline:
Incorrect: Intravenous fluids would be appropriate if the patient were hypotensive or volume-depleted, but this is not indicated in the current presentation.  
❌ Endotracheal intubation:
Incorrect:  Endotracheal intubation is critical in the management of patients with respiratory failure or for patients who are unable to protect their airways. There is no indication that this patient is in respiratory distress or has altered mental status.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic to follow up on her glycemic control. She was recently diagnosed with diabetes mellitus; however, she has not been able to achieve satisfactory glucose control with the current dose of metformin. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and non-transfusion-dependent beta-thalassemia. She was diagnosed with beta-thalassemia in childhood; she occasionally requires blood transfusions which have been required more frequently lately. Medications include metformin, olmesartan, and occasional ibuprofen for joint pain. Temperature is 36.8oC (98.24 F), heart rate is 90 bpm, and blood pressure is 130/90. The patient has conjunctival pallor. Cardiac auscultation reveals an S3 gallop. Pulmonary exam reveals crackles at the bases bilaterally. The lower border of the liver is felt 5 cm below the costal margin. Hand examination reveals tenderness over the bilateral metacarpophalangeal joints without swelling. Lower extremity exam is significant for 2+ pitting edema over the feet bilaterally. Basic metabolic panel is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value   Results 
 Hemoglobin   9.5 g/dl 
 Mean corpuscular volume  66 μm3 
 AST  251 U/L 
 ALT  311 U/L 
 Albumin  2.1 g/dl 
 Iron  253 mcg/dL 
 Ferritin  452 ng/mL (normal: 12 to 300 nanograms per milliliter (ng/mL)  
 Transferrin saturation  66% (normal: 20-50%)
questions.solution:
The combination of diabetes, arthropathy, cardiomyopathy, impaired liver function, and history of beta-thalassemia strongly point to secondary hemochromatosis. Most patients with beta thalassemia will develop iron overload at some point in their lives. Even though secondary hemochromatosis is likely in this patient with beta-thalassemia, genetic testing should be performed to definitively rule out primary hemochromatosis before treatment is initiated.  

Diagnosis of primary hemochromatosis is based on the detection of abnormally high serum ferritin levels (≥300 μg/L) with elevated transferrin saturation levels ( ≥50%). Patients with an abnormal iron profile and signs, symptoms, and physical exam findings consistent with hemochromatosis should have testing for HFE gene mutation to determine if hemochromatosis is primary or secondary.  

Causes of secondary hemochromatosis include chronic liver disease (alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, and HCV infection), iron-loading anemia as seen in this patient (thalassemia or sickle cell disease), and excess iron supplements (parenteral or oral iron supplementation). Treatment of secondary hemochromatosis involves addressing the underlying condition and using chelating agents and, at times, phlebotomy.

Option Analysis

✅ Genetic testing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Phlebotomy:
Incorrect: Phlebotomy is often indicated in patients with either primary or secondary hemochromatosis; however, treatment for hemochromatosis should be done only after establishing the diagnosis and performing HFE gene mutation testing to differentiate between primary vs secondary disease.
❌ Iron chelation:
Incorrect: Iron chelation is indicated in patients with either primary or secondary hemochromatosis, especially in patients with anemia and poor venous access and in patients with end-organ damage (heart failure, liver cell failure). However, the diagnosis of hemochromatosis needs to be established first, and HFE gene mutation testing should be done to definitively rule out primary disease in this case.
❌ Dietary restrictions:
Incorrect: Dietary restriction of iron supplements, vitamin C supplements (because vitamin C enhances iron absorption), and alcohol is an essential step in managing iron overload from hemochromatosis; however, these steps should be initiated after establishing the diagnosis and determining if it is primary or secondary hemochromatosis.
❌ Right upper quadrant ultrasound:
Incorrect: Ultrasound should be performed, however, it will add little value for diagnosing hemochromatosis and differentiating primary from secondary etiologies.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with end-stage liver disease secondary to chronic hepatitis C infection undergoes liver transplantation. The liver was received from the patient’s daughter. The patient had no complications in the perioperative period and is subsequently started on tacrolimus to decrease the likelihood of transplant rejection.  Which of the following best describes the mechanism by which tacrolimus reduces transplant rejection?
questions.solution:
This patient underwent hepatic transplantation and was given tacrolimus to prevent organ rejection. Tacrolimus is a calcineurin inhibitor that is used to prevent organ rejection in transplant patients. It can also be used in some autoimmune disorders.  

Tacrolimus exerts its immunosuppressive properties by binding to a protein called FK-binding protein and then inhibiting calcineurin. This suppresses the activation of the Nuclear Factor of Activated T cells (NFAT), which in turn leads to decreased IL-2 production. The lack of IL-2 impairs the proliferation and differentiation of T lymphocytes, which are the main cells responsible for transplant rejection.  

As with cyclosporine, tacrolimus also has vasoconstrictive properties that can lead to nephrotoxicity and hypertension. Neurotoxicity (e.g. convulsions) is more commonly associated with tacrolimus than cyclosporine. On the other hand, tacrolimus is not associated with gingival hyperplasia or hirsutism. Other side effects of tacrolimus include hyperuricemia, hyperlipidemia,  and hyperglycemia.  



Option Analysis

❌ Decreases intracellular response to interleukin-2 (IL-2):
Incorrect: Sirolimus decreases the intracellular response to IL-2 by binding to and inhibiting mTOR, inhibiting T cell growth and proliferation in response to IL-2 receptor activation. This patient is receiving tacrolimus.
✅ Inhibits Interleukin-2 (IL-2) production:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Blocks interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor:
Incorrect: Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody against IL-2 receptors. It binds to and blocks IL-2 receptors, thereby preventing the action of IL-2 in promoting T cell immune response.
❌ Inhibits purine synthesis:
Incorrect: Azathioprine is an antimetabolite that gets converted to 6-mercaptopurine, which inhibits the synthesis of purine bases. This impairs nucleotide synthesis and immune cell proliferation.
❌ Inhibits pyrimidine synthesis:
Incorrect: Methotrexate exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting the synthesis of pyrimidine bases. This impairs immune cell division and proliferation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the gastroenterology clinic to discuss recent hepatitis C virus (HCV) laboratory results. Past medical history is significant for well-controlled HIV and prior intravenous drug use for 5 years. Current medications include bictegravir-emtricitabine-tenofovir and melatonin. Laboratory studies from last week show a positive anti-HCV antibody and significantly elevated levels of HCV RNA. After discussion of the indications and side effects of HCV treatment, the patient is started on ribavirin. Which of the following medications can also be added to this patient’s treatment of HCV?
questions.solution:
This patient has chronic hepatitis C infection. One of the approved treatment regimens for hepatitis C virus infection is the combination of ribavirin and interferon-alpha; however, the use of interferons has fallen out of favor due to their side effect profile.  

Interferons are cytokines involved in regulating the immune response. Interferons are crucial in fighting viral infections, and also have immunomodulatory effects and tumor suppression effects. Interferons increase the expression of MHC I which activates CD8+ T cells. They also increase the expression of MHC II receptors. Additionally, interferons activate B cells causing more antibody production and recruit macrophages and natural killer cells. Natural killer cells in particular help in fighting cancer cells and also virally-infected cells. Finally, interferons also inhibit various steps in the viral replication cycle and can have anti-proliferative effects by inducing apoptosis.    

Interferon-alpha is used in multiple disease processes such as chronic hepatitis B and C virus infection, hairy cell leukemia, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. Interferon-beta can be used in the management of multiple sclerosis. Interferon-gamma can be used in the management of chronic granulomatous disease.  

Side effects of interferons include nausea and vomiting, and flu-like symptoms (fever, myalgia, and fatigue). In addition, some patients may experience autoimmune reactions.  

Option Analysis

✅ Recombinant interferon-alpha:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recombinant interferon-beta:
Incorrect: Interferon-beta is not used in the management of hepatitis C virus infection. It is used in the treatment of multiple sclerosis.
❌ Infliximab:
Incorrect: Infliximab is a monoclonal antibody against tumor necrosis factor-alpha, and is used in many disorders such as psoriatic arthritis and ulcerative colitis. It has no role in the management of hepatitis C virus infection. 
❌ Aldesleukin:
Incorrect: Aldesleukin, a recombinant interleukin-2 that has been used for the management of renal cell carcinoma and melanoma. It is not used in the management of hepatitis C virus infection.
❌ Recombinant Interferon-gamma :
Incorrect: Recombinant interferon-gamma is used in the management of chronic granulomatous disease, but is not used in the treatment of hepatitis C virus infection.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening fatigue and abdominal pain. His symptoms started several months ago but have worsened to the point where he feels like he cannot function at work. He states, “I am having so much trouble sleeping; maybe I am depressed.” Their past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism, for which he takes levothyroxine. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or recreational substances. Temperature is 37.0°C, blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Laboratory testing is shown below. Physical examination is notable for skin hyperpigmentation. Which medications are most appropriate for treating this patient’s clinical condition?  

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Sodium  130 mEq/L 
 Potassium  5.1 mEq/L 
 Chloride  100 mEq/L 
 Bicarbonate  26 mEq/L 
 Thyroid stimulating hormone  3.2 µU/mL 
 Free T4  10 µg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of hypothyroidism presents with chronic fatigue, non-specific abdominal pain, and hyperpigmentation. Laboratory testing is notable for hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and normal thyroid function tests. These findings are consistent with primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease). The most appropriate treatment for this condition is fludrocortisone, which has significant mineralocorticoid activity.    

Mineralocorticoids are a class of corticosteroids that primarily influence salt and water balance. Physiologically, the primary mineralocorticoid in the human body is aldosterone. The primary synthetic mineralocorticoid in use is fludrocortisone, which is recombinant aldosterone. Additional medications such as hydrocortisone or prednisone have some mineralocorticoid activity. However, they also possess glucocorticoid activity, making them less potent agents in treating hypoaldosteronism.  

Mineralocorticoids work by mimicking the effects of aldosterone via increasing the retention of sodium and water and excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions into the cortical collecting tubule of the kidney. They are used primarily in the treatment of hypoaldosteronism but are also utilized in the treatment of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Adverse side effects include hypokalemia, hypertension, and weight gain due to water retention.

Option Analysis

✅ Fludricortisone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Spironolactone :
Incorrect: Spironolactone carries anti-mineralocorticoid effects, which would make this patient’s primary hyperaldosteronism worse. 
❌ Prednisone :
Incorrect: Prednisone has some mineralocorticoid activity. However, it is primarily a glucocorticoid. In contrast, fludrocortisone is a more appropriate treatment for this patient’s primary hypoaldosteronism.
❌ Liothyronine:
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of hypothyroidism, his thyroid function tests are within normal limits. As a result, it is unlikely that his current symptoms are secondary to hypothyroidism.
❌ Metyrapone:
Incorrect: Metyrapone is a pyridine derivative and a glucocorticoid synthesis inhibitor. The medication is used to aid in diagnosing, not treating, primary adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine check-up. During the evaluation, the patient is found to have a blood pressure of 158/94 mmHg. At a follow-up visit two weeks later, his blood pressure is 163/71 mmHg. He does not consume alcohol, tobacco, or recreational substances. Past medical history is unremarkable. Initial labs from this second office visit are demonstrated below. Based on this information, treatment for this patient’s condition would most likely involve a medication that acts via which of the following mechanisms?  

 Laboratory Value  Result 
 Serum Chemistry 
 Sodium   147 mEq/L 
 Potassium   2.9 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.1 mg/dL 
 Bicarbonate   36 g/dL 
 Calcium   8.6 mg/dL 
 Glucose  84 mg/dL 
 Serum Blood Gas  
           pH               7.57 
           pCO2             44 mm Hg 
            Po2             100 mm Hg 
           HCO3-              36 mEq/L

choices.text: Inhibition of the Na+ and Cl- transporter

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypertension in the setting of metabolic alkalosis (pH 7.57 with a concomitant increase in bicarbonate), hypernatremia, and hypokalemia. These findings are suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism. This condition is characterized by excessive aldosterone production, resulting in sodium and water retention and hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis secondary to the excretion of potassium and hydrogen ions into the urine. Treatment of primary hyperaldosteronism involves aldosterone receptor antagonists, such as spironolactone and eplerenone.  

Primary hyperaldosteronism is often due to an aldosterone-secreting adenoma (Conn syndrome), especially in young and otherwise healthy patients. Secondary hyperaldosteronism can be due to etiologies, including renovascular hypertension, renin-producing juxtaglomerular cell tumor, and edematous states such as heart failure.    

Regardless, medical therapy aims to normalize the serum potassium level and blood pressure and reverse the effects of hyperaldosteronism on the heart. Thus, therapy should be targeted at antagonizing mineralocorticoid receptors using medications. These medications will ultimately prevent additional sodium reabsorption and hydrogen ion and potassium wasting.  

The primary side effect of these medications is hyperkalemia, which can cause dangerous arrhythmias. Spironolactone can also cause antiandrogen effects, resulting in gynecomastia and decreased sex drive.

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of the Na+ and Cl- transporter:
Incorrect: Thiazides (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide, chlorthalidone) are diuretics that act by inhibiting the Na+ and Cl- transporter in the distal convoluted tubule. Although this group of diuretics is indicated for treating patients with essential hypertension, this patient’s hypokalemia is a contraindication to using these medications.
✅ Antagonism of mineralocorticoid receptors:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of carbonic anhydrase:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide is a medication that acts by inhibiting carbonic anhydrase. It can be used as a diuretic, antiepileptic, and for the treatment of glaucoma. However, this medication can cause hypokalemia. Administering acetazolamide to this patient would likely worsen his hypokalemia. 
❌ Inhibition of the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter:
Incorrect: Furosemide is a loop diuretic that acts on the Na+-K+-2Cl- symporter in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. This medication is widely used in patients with hypertension. However, this patient’s laboratory findings of hypernatremia, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis are more concerning for hyperaldosteronism, which can be better treated with an aldosterone receptor antagonist.
❌ Inhibition of the angiotensin-converting enzyme :
Incorrect: Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor that decreases angiotensin II and consequently decreases the glomerular filtration rate and prevents constriction of efferent arterioles. This patient's metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia suggest hyperaldosteronism as the etiology of his hypertension. Hence, an aldosterone receptor inhibitor would be more effective than an ACE inhibitor.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with four weeks of difficulty breathing and a dry cough. The patient has not seen a physician in several years and does not take any medication. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), blood pressure is 136/84 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, pulse is 96/min, and SpO2 is 88% on room air. On physical examination, the patient has increased respiratory efforts but is not in distress. Cardiac sounds are unremarkable on auscultation but abnormal lung sounds are present. There is no clubbing of the fingers. Chest radiograph shows multiple reticulonodular opacities. You suspect the patient has underlying pneumoconiosis. Which of the following historical or physical examination features would be most helpful for supporting the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with shortness of breath and hypoxia as well as chest imaging showing reticulonodular opacities. This raises concern for pneumoconiosis, which is a group of lung diseases related to prolonged occupational (environmental) exposure to inhaled mineral dust. Inhaled particles cause chronic lung inflammation with subsequent scarring and fibrosis. The most common types include asbestosis, silicosis, coal worker pneumoconiosis, berylliosis and hard metal pneumoconiosis.    

Patients with pneumoconiosis eventually develop dyspnea (especially on exertion) and dry cough and may also have hypoxia. There will be a history of significant occupational/environmental exposure to inhaled minerals, so a thorough social history is very important. Patients will generally have fine inspiratory crackles on auscultation and may also have wheezing. Clubbing is not common, but can be present in severe long-standing disease. Diagnosis is confirmed with a history of exposure to metal dust, pulmonary function tests (restrictive pattern with reduced diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO)), and computed tomography (CT) chest findings (usually reticulonodular opacities) and/or bronchoalveolar lavage.  

Option Analysis

✅ Environmental exposure to inorganic material:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: The risk of developing pneumoconiosis may be increased by smoking cigarettes, but environmental exposures and not tobacco use cause pneumoconiosis. Therefore, history of tobacco use would not be a supporting factor in the diagnosis of pneumoconiosis.
❌ Family history of lung disease:
Incorrect: Family history is helpful when diagnosing chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to alpha-1-antitrypsin deficiency, but pneumoconiosis is caused by environmental triggers and is not hereditary. Therefore, family history would be noncontributory in this case.
❌ Presence of wheezes:
Incorrect: Wheezes indicate narrowed airways with resultant turbulent airflow. Wheezes can be heard in patients with pneumoconiosis, but they may also be present in many other lung conditions, and even in congestive heart failure. They do not indicate a specific lung pathology.
❌ Presence of rales:
Incorrect: Rales (crackles) can be present in patients with pneumoconiosis, but they can also be  present with volume overload (e.g. congestive heart failure) and interstitial lung disease. They do not indicate a specific lung pathology.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for evaluation of weakness and muscle cramps. The patient has intentionally lost 25 lbs (11.3 kg) in the past 3 months. She has a history of obesity and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. BMI is 36 kg/m2. She appears weak, but is able to respond to questions appropriately. Physical examination reveals dry mucous membranes and diminished skin turgor. Her neck appears supple. She has multiple abrasions on her hands. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. Initial laboratory evaluation is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this patient?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum Chemistry

Sodium
125 mEq/L
Potassium
3.0 mEq/L  
Chloride
84 mEq/L  
Bicarbonate
40 mEq/L  
Serum Osmolality  
270 mOsm/kg  
Urine Chemistry  

Urine sodium  
15 mEq/L  
Urine chloride  
3 mEq/L  
Urine osmolality  
560 mOsm/kg
questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms of weakness and muscle cramps with physical examination findings of dry mucous membranes, tachycardia, borderline low blood pressure, and serum sodium of 125 mEq/L are concerning for hypovolemic hyponatremia. Given her intentional weight loss of 25 lbs in 3 months, metabolic alkalosis, urine sodium < 20 mEq/L, and abrasions on her hands, surreptitious vomiting is the most likely cause of hyponatremia.

For patients with hyponatremia, a focused history and examination should assess for symptoms of cerebral edema, which usually presents as headache, nausea, vomiting and/or confusion. If any of these are present, patients should be treated emergently with boluses of hypertonic saline. Assessment of volume status can usually guide the clinician towards the probable cause of hyponatremia and differentiate between hypovolemic, euvolemic or hypervolemic hyponatremia.

Laboratory evaluation can further narrow down the differential diagnosis. For patients with hypovolemia, the body typically responds by secreting antidiuretic hormone (ADH), which stimulates reabsorption of free water in the kidneys, causing urine osmolality to rise. However, in patients with non-renal sodium loss (e.g. vomiting) the urine sodium levels are < 20 mEq/L, as seen in this case.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Surreptitious vomiting:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diuretic use:
Incorrect: This patient has hypovolemia with metabolic alkalosis which can occur in patients with ongoing diuretic use. These patients would also have loss of sodium in the urine leading to a urine sodium of > 20 mEq/L. This patient’s urine sodium is 15 mEq/L, and thus surreptitious vomiting is more likely the cause of hyponatremia.  
❌ Mineralocorticoid deficiency:
Incorrect: This patient has hypovolemia with metabolic alkalosis which can occur in patients with mineralocorticoid deficiency. However, loss of sodium in the urine typically leads to a urine sodium of > 20 mEq/L with mineralocorticoid deficiency. This patient’s urine sodium is 15 mEq/L and thus surreptitious vomiting is more likely the cause of hyponatremia.  
❌ Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH):
Incorrect: Patients with SIADH are usually euvolemic, and excessive reabsorption of free water leads to an elevated concentration of sodium in the urine (urine sodium > 20 mEq/L). This patient appears hypovolemic on examination and has a urine sodium of 15 mEq/L, making hypovolemic hyponatremia from surreptitious vomiting more likely.  
❌ Primary polydipsia:
Incorrect: Excessive water intake in patients with primary polydipsia can cause urine sodium to decline < 20 mEq/L. However, patients with primary polydipsia typically appear euvolemic on examination. This patient more than likely has hypovolemic hyponatremia from surreptitious vomiting.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic for an annual visit. He has a chronic cough but no other complaints. Review of systems is significant for 20 lbs (9 kg) unintentional weight loss over the past 6 months. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, hyperlipidemia, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and diabetes mellitus type 2. He takes valsartan, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin and metformin. He is a current smoker with a 55 pack-year history. He does not drink alcohol or use recreational drugs. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. BMI is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination shows moist mucous membranes without lower extremity edema. Cardiac examination is unremarkable. Routine labs show a serum sodium of 126 mEq/dL. Results from laboratory testing are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s hyponatremia?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum

Blood urea nitrogen  
9 mg/dL
Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL  
Osmolality
257 mOsm/kg H2O  
Cortisol, 8AM  
15.1 mcg/dL (normal)  
ACTH, 8AM  
40 pmol/L (normal)  
TSH
3 mIU/L  
Urine

Osmolality
420 mOsm/kg  
Sodium
45 mEq/L
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic euvolemic hyponatremia and significant weight loss with normal adrenal and thyroid function, suggesting syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH). An occult lung malignancy with paraneoplastic syndrome is the most likely cause of hyponatremia in this patient.

Initial diagnostic workup for hyponatremia involves evaluating serum osmolality. If the serum osmolality is <280 mOsm/kg, a diagnosis of true hyponatremia can be established. Assessment of volume status can further narrow down the differential diagnoses for causes of hyponatremia.

This patient appears euvolemic on examination, with a urine sodium of > 20mEq and urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg. In the absence of hypothyroidism or secondary adrenal insufficiency, these values indicate an abnormally high ADH. This will cause continuous reabsorption of water through ADH-stimulated aquaporin-2 channels in the collecting duct and lead to further increases of sodium in the urine and urine osmolality. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) from paraneoplastic syndrome caused by small cell lung cancer can lead to hyponatremia, and this patient should be further evaluated with chest imaging.
 

Option Analysis
