❌ Low dietary solute intake:
Incorrect: Low dietary solute intake can result in a relative increase in free water in the extracellular fluid and hyponatremia. The kidneys respond by increasing the reabsorption of filtered sodium, which results in a urine sodium < 20 mEq/L. Urine osmolality typically declines to < 100 mOsm/kg. This patient’s urine sodium is 45 mEq/L and urine osmolality is 420 mOsm/kg. Given his history and physical examination, SIADH from a lung malignancy is more likely.  
❌ Mineralocorticoid deficiency:
Incorrect: Patients with mineralocorticoid deficiency develop hyponatremia, concomitant hypovolemia and metabolic alkalosis and will typically have low blood pressure and hypokalemia. These signs and symptoms are absent in this patient, and he is euvolemic. Given his history and physical examination, SIADH from a lung malignancy is more likely.  
✅ Occult lung malignancy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Surreptitious vomiting:
Incorrect: Surreptitious vomiting usually results in hypovolemic hyponatremia and urine sodium < 20 mEq/L. This patient appears euvolemic on exam with a urine sodium >20 mEq/L.  
❌ Heart failure:
Incorrect: Patients with heart failure and hyponatremia usually appear hypervolemic on exam and have a urine sodium below 20 mEq/L. This patient is euvolemic with a urine sodium of 45 mEq/L. Given his history and physical examination, SIADH from a lung malignancy is more likely.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to worsening fever and night sweats over several days. The patient has also had worsening back pain and unintentional weight loss of 22 lbs. (10 kg) over the past few months. Past medical history is significant for untreated HIV. She does not use tobacco, alcohol or recreational drugs. She frequently travels to South Asia to visit family. Temperature is 38.9 ºC (102.0 ºF),  pulse is 96/min, blood pressure is 145/89 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and SpO<sub>2</sub> is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears cachectic and ill, but she is in no acute distress. Cardiac exam is within normal limits. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation. There is point tenderness over several lumbar spinous processes. There is decreased sensation in both lower extremities. A chest radiograph shows no abnormalities. MRI of the thoracic and lumbar spine shows destruction of the L2-L3 vertebral bodies and intervertebral discs. Interferon-gamma release assay is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiation of rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol

questions.solution:
This patient with untreated HIV presents with fever, night sweats, unintentional weight loss, and lumbar back pain. On physical examination, she has point tenderness, over the spinous processes, and MRI shows L2-L3 vertebral body and disc destruction which is concerning for spinal tuberculosis (Pott disease). Patients with suspected tuberculosis of the spine should undergo tissue sampling of the bony lesions with CT-guided lumbar spine biopsy to provide tissue for microscopy and culture to establish the diagnosis.

Pott disease is a form of extrapulmonary tuberculosis. Patients with extrapulmonary tuberculosis typically present with systemic symptoms (fever, night sweats, unintentional weight loss) and manifestations of the particular type of disease they have. Patients with chronic non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy may have tuberculous lymphadenitis. Tuberculous pleural effusions can occur, and the pleural effusions will be exudative with elevated adenosine deaminase (ADA) and lymphocyte predominance. Patients with spinal tuberculosis present with point tenderness of the spine at the involved levels and neurologic deficits. Patients with tuberculous meningitis present with headaches, nuchal rigidity, and neurologic deficits. Tuberculous pericarditis can cause symptoms of pericarditis and an exudative pericardial effusion with lymphocyte predominance. Tuberculous peritonitis can cause ascites with a low serum-ascites albumin gradient, low glucose, and lymphocyte predominance. Patients with genitourinary tuberculosis can have sterile pyuria with urinary tract granulomas and bladder wall thickening.  

Option Analysis

✅ CT guided lumbar spine biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum adenosine deaminase (ADA) testing:
Incorrect: An elevated ADA level in pleural fluid can support the diagnosis of tuberculosis pleural effusions but alone it is not diagnostic of tuberculosis infection, and serum ADA levels are not diagnostic and are not performed.  
❌ CT imaging of the chest:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal chest radiograph and no respiratory symptoms or hypoxia to suggest lung disease. This patient has back pain and neurologic deficits. Therefore, lumbar spine biopsy should be performed to obtain a tissue diagnosis.  
❌ Initiation of rifampin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide and ethambutol:
Incorrect: This would be an appropriate first-line treatment regimen for pulmonary tuberculosis or extrapulmonary tuberculosis without drug resistance. However, diagnostic testing for spinal tuberculosis should be done first before starting treatment.  
❌ Tuberculin skin test:
Incorrect: This test can be used to screen for prior tuberculosis (TB) exposure or suspected latent infection. However, it can cause false positives, is subject to interpretation error, and requires further confirmatory testing. Therefore, it is not used in the inpatient setting. Additionally, this patient has a positive interferon-gamma release assay. At this point, tissue is needed to establish the diagnosis through microscopy and culture.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to a syncopal episode that occurred at home while gardening. According to the patient, he stood up from gardening, immediately felt light-headed, and fell to the ground. The patient’s spouse reports that he awoke immediately following the fall and seemed slightly disoriented, but was able to answer questions appropriately. He did not hit his head and there was no shaking movement of the limbs during the incident. The patient had a recent gastrointestinal illness with vomiting and diarrhea that ended this morning. He has a past medical history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. Medications include aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, and losartan. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, and respirations are 20/min. His blood pressure is 132/84 mmHg while seated and drops to 102/62 mmHg after standing for two minutes. His heart rate increases from 68/min while seated to 82/min upon standing. The patient is awake, alert, and oriented, with normal speech. Dry mucous membranes are noted. Heart and lung examinations are normal. Strength is 5/5 in the upper and lower extremities, and gait is normal. ECG shows normal sinus rhythm. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with typical symptoms of orthostatic hypotension, including light-headedness and syncope upon standing. This older patient may have autonomic dysfunction that may have been further exacerbated by fluid depletion (e.g. dry mucous membranes) from his recent gastrointestinal illness, leading to orthostatic hypotension. Fluid replacement is the best next step in management.

Syncope, defined as a transient, self-limited loss of consciousness, is caused by a temporary decrease in cerebral blood flow. Based on the underlying cause, syncope can be categorized into several types. These include cardiogenic syncope caused by heart-related issues; reflex-mediated syncope triggered by various stimuli like neck pressure; syncope due to orthostatic hypotension; and neurologic syncope, which is associated with neurological conditions. If a patient presents with a chief concern suggesting syncope, an ABCDE assessment should be performed to determine if they are unstable or stable, followed by a systematic investigation to determine the most likely cause. The normal physiologic response to standing up with blood pooling in the legs is an increase in heart rate and constriction of blood vessels. This is blunted by orthostatic hypotension resulting in decreased cerebral blood flow and syncope. Etiologies of orthostatic hypotension include medications (e.g., vasodilators, inotropic/chronotropic blockade, diuretics), autonomic dysfunction (e.g., advanced age, neurodegenerative disease), and hypovolemia (e.g., fluid restriction, GI losses, fever).

Orthostatic hypotension is a common cause of syncope, particularly in older adults. Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a decrease in systolic blood pressure of at least 20 mmHg or a decrease in diastolic blood pressure of 10 mmHg within 2-5 minutes of standing. Treatment depends largely on the underlying etiology but can include modifying postural transition, such as rising slowly when standing, increasing fluid and salt intake, or discontinuing/decreasing the dose of causative medications. This patient should receive intravenous fluids, as he appears clinically hypovolemic. Consideration could be given to lowering the dose of his beta-blocker or discontinuing the medication, as it is likely to be a contributing factor.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous fluids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Increase dosage of losartan:
Incorrect: Increasing the dosage of antihypertensives (e.g. losartan) in a patient with orthostatic hypotension could further exacerbate the patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Cardiology consult for pacemaker placement:
Incorrect: Pacemaker placement is not indicated in this scenario as the patient’s history, symptoms, and ECG findings are consistent with orthostatic hypotension, and not with bradyarrhythmia or heart block that would warrant such an intervention.  
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: An MRI of the brain is not indicated in this scenario, as this patient’s history and physical examination are more consistent with orthostatic hypotension than an acute stroke or other brain pathology.  
❌ Transthoracic echocardiography:
Incorrect: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is typically used to assess structural cardiac abnormalities. While TTE is important in evaluating certain causes of syncope, it is not indicated in this case where the clinical presentation is most consistent with orthostatic hypotension.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for follow-up. The patient was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis three years ago and is currently taking infliximab. Recently, the patient has been experiencing a tingling sensation in her hands and feet. In addition, she had an episode of eye pain and vision loss that resolved spontaneously. The physician decides to switch this patient to a new medication. Which of the following is the most appropriate option?
questions.solution:
This patient with rheumatoid arthritis is most likely experiencing demyelinating side effects from infliximab use. Anti-TNF agents are well-known to cause demyelinating syndromes including transverse myelitis (most likely responsible for tingling and weakness in this patient’s hands and feet) and optic neuritis (eye pain and loss of vision like this patient). Patients with severe side effects from TNF inhibitors should be switched to another class of medications.

Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits interleukin-12/23 and can be used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis, especially in patients who do not respond to TNF inhibitors or are intolerant to them (like this patient). It can also be used in the treatment of psoriasis and Crohn’s disease.

Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that works by binding to and inhibiting IL-12/23. IL-12 is an inflammatory mediator that is implicated in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis, Crohn’s disease, and psoriasis, as well as other inflammatory disorders. It activates T-cells and induces the differentiation of T-helper cells.  In addition, it also helps in the formation of granulomatous inflammatory response along with other cytokines (e.g., Interferon-Gamma, Tumor Necrosis factor). Therefore, ustekinumab inhibits T-cell-mediated inflammatory response and decreases joint damage in rheumatoid arthritis. In Crohn’s disease, ustekinumab decreases granuloma formation and reduces bowel wall thickening.  

Option Analysis

✅ Ustekinumab:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adalimumab:
Incorrect: Adalimumab is an anti-TNF monoclonal antibody like infliximab, and it shares the same side effects. Since this patient is not tolerating TNF antagonists, another class of drug should be used.  
❌ Certolizumab:
Incorrect: Certolizumab is also a TNF antagonist, and should be avoided in this patient since she is having severe side effects from another medication in this class.  
❌ Naproxen:
Incorrect: Naproxen is an NSAID. It is used in rheumatoid arthritis patients to alleviate the pain and stiffness, but it does not slow the joint destruction; therefore, it is not an appropriate alternative for infliximab.  
❌ Corticosteroids:
Incorrect: Like NSAIDs, steroids do not alter disease progression in rheumatoid arthritis and are only used to alleviate the pain and stiffness.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a fever, cough, and a lump in his neck for the past 3-months. The neck mass is non-tender, has not grown in size, and is not associated with any skin changes. The patient has experienced a 3 kg (7 lb) weight loss in the past 3-months and a significant decrease in appetite. He does not consume tobacco, alcohol, or recreational substances. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mmHg. Physical examination reveals non-tender cervical lymphadenopathy and pallor. A chest radiograph reveals a mediastinal mass. Biopsy reveals specimens containing Reed-Sternberg cells. The patient is initiated on a chemotherapeutic regimen involving a drug that prevents polymerization of microtubules. Which of the following side effects is associated with this agent?

choices.text: Prolonged fever, sore throat, and bleeding gums
Sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo

questions.solution:
This patient presents with cervical lymphadenopathy, weight loss, and decreased appetite. Imaging reveals a mediastinal mass and biopsy reveals Reed-Sternberg cells, which are suggestive of Hodgkin lymphoma. He was most likely started on a vinca alkaloid chemotherapeutic, which can cause an increased risk of bleeding from the gums.

Vinca alkaloids (e.g., vincristine, vinblastine) are microtubule inhibitors indicated in the treatment of a variety of solid organ tumors, Hodgkin lymphoma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma. These medications inhibit microtubule polymerization by binding to ꞵ-tubulin and inhibiting mitotic spindle formation.

Vinca alkaloids inhibit DNA replication in the M phase of the cell cycle. Rapidly dividing somatic cells (e.g., gastrointestinal tract, oral cavity, bone marrow, hair follicles) are particularly susceptible to the effects of vinca alkaloids.

Vinblastine, in particular, can cause profound myelosuppression resulting in symptoms that indicate a decrease in all cell lines. Patients can present with fatigue, pallor from anemia, fever from leukopenia, and bleeding from mucous membranes as a result of thrombocytopenia. Vinblastine has been found to be less neurotoxic as compared to vincristine, possibly due to differences in affinity to neural tissue.

In contrast, vincristine can cause peripheral neuropathy and autonomic dysfunction. Moreover, this medication can cause sensory peripheral neuropathy, areflexia, and orthostatic hypotension.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Blood in urine:
Incorrect: Hematuria is an adverse effect encountered in the use of the alkylating agent cyclophosphamide. Cyclophosphamide is a nitrogen mustard that creates interstrand cross-links between adjacent guanine molecules, resulting in DNA damage. Although it is used in the treatment of lymphoma, it does not bind to tubulin and does not play a role in the inhibition of microtubule polymerisation.  
✅ Prolonged fever, sore throat, and bleeding gums:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Nonproductive chronic cough:
Incorrect: A nonproductive cough following the use of an antineoplastic agent may signify pulmonary fibrosis in conjunction with an abnormal pulmonary function test. This adverse effect is encountered in the use of bleomycin and busulfan. Bleomycin causes DNA damage by inducing free radical formation. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that induces DNA damage by creating cross-links. Neither medication inhibits the polymerization of microtubules.  
❌ Convulsions, dizziness, and ataxia:
Incorrect: Neurologic symptoms indicative of CNS toxicity may develop following the use of nitrosoureas, such as carmustine. These agents cross the blood-brain barrier and create DNA cross-links in malignant brain tumor cells. However, they are not the therapeutic agents preferred in the treatment of Hodgkin lymphoma.  
❌ Sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and vertigo:
Incorrect: Ototoxicity is an adverse effect encountered with the use of platinum-containing compounds such as cisplatin. These agents are non-cell cycle specific and induce DNA damage by creating cross-links between adjacent guanine molecules.

questions.text: A 71-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with a three-week history of frequent severe, throbbing headaches on the left side of his head. He also reports feeling fatigued and has experienced a 6 lb (2.7 kg) unintentional weight loss over the past month. He says he feels weak and tired in the mornings and cannot raise his arms to brush his hair. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation in the left temporal region of the head. Laboratory findings are significant for a markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). Which of the following physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient given the likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with unilateral headaches in association with weight loss and fatigue as well as an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) most likely has temporal arteritis. Furthermore, the patient has symptoms suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica (e.g. morning stiffness, proximal muscle weakness): a diagnosis frequently associated with temporal arteritis.    

Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis, is an inflammatory vasculitis of medium and large arteries. In temporal arteritis, there is inflammation and thickening of the vessel wall, which eventually can result in ischemia and complications, such as vision loss. As the name suggests, the temporal artery is the most common vessel involved; however, intracranial and extracranial vessels can be affected as well, especially the vertebrobasilar arterial system. More remote sites of vascular involvement include the aorta and its proximal branches, like the carotid, subclavian, axillary, and brachial arteries.  

The greatest risk factor for developing temporal arteritis is aging. The disease almost never occurs before the age of 50, and its incidence rises steadily thereafter. It peaks between the ages of 70 to 79 with over 80 percent of patients older than 70 years of age. Patients typically report a new-onset localized headache, described as unilateral pain in the temporal region that worsens over time. These symptoms are often associated with scalp pain and tenderness as well as systemic symptoms like fatigue, malaise, fever, and unintentional weight loss. In more severe cases, patients may notice symptoms suggestive of ischemia, including sudden vision changes ranging from diplopia to complete vision loss. There may also be pain with chewing, known as jaw claudication. Patients may have signs and symptoms of polymyalgia rheumatica, including neck, shoulder, and hip pain and stiffness.  

Physical examination may reveal abnormalities in the temporal artery, including tenderness, ropiness, nodularity, and altered pulse quality due to occlusive vasculitis occuring within the vessel, while fundoscopic examination can reveal optic disc pallor and edema. If the vessels of the ophthalmic artery are affected, patients will present with visual symptoms, such as amaurosis fugax. Laboratory values are nonspecific but will often reveal signs of systemic inflammation like elevated inflammatory markers (e.g. ESR, CRP), thrombocytosis, and normocytic anemia. Diagnosis is confirmed with biopsy showing transmural inflammation, multinucleated giant cells, and mononuclear infiltrate.



Option Analysis

❌ Proptosis:
Incorrect: Proptosis, or bulging of the eyes, is not typically associated with temporal arteritis. Proptosis may be seen in patients with Graves' ophthalmopathy or thyroid eye disease. Vision loss can be seen in temporal arteritis and results from arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION).
❌ Absent corneal reflex:
Incorrect: Absent corneal reflex refers to the lack of a response when the cornea is touched, indicating damage to the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V). This patient’s presentation is classic for temporal arteritis, which can cause severe headaches and visual disturbances due to involvement of the arteries supplying the optic nerve, but it does not directly affect the corneal reflex. 
❌ Bounding left temporal artery pulse:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is classic for temporal arteritis, which typically presents with decreased or absent pulses in the temporal arteries, not increased pulses. 
✅ Enlarged left temporal artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Nuchal rigidity:
Incorrect: Nuchal rigidity is a physical examination finding associated with meningitis. Meningitis typically presents more acutely (over a span of days) as opposed to this patient’s subacute presentation of several weeks. Furthermore, patients typically present with fevers and other historical findings (e.g. photophobia).

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with a history of frequent severe, throbbing headaches on the right side. She also describes a recent episode of sudden vision loss in her right eye. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation of bilateral temporal regions of her head with decreased temporal artery pulsation on the right. Fundoscopic examination reveals swelling and pallor of the optic disc in the right eye. Laboratory findings are shown below. Ophthalmology is consulted. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 White blood cell count  11,500/mm3 
 Hemoglobin  11.5 g/dL 
 Mean corpuscular volume  88 μm3 
 Platelet count  510,000/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate  80 mm/h 
 C-reactive protein  25 mg/L

choices.text: Surgical revascularization of the affected artery
Neurosurgical consultation for optic nerve decompression
Confirmation of the diagnosis with biopsy prior to starting corticosteroids
Initiation of antiplatelet therapy to improve blood flow

questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe, throbbing right-sided headaches; sudden vision loss in the right eye; and tenderness of bilateral temporal regions with decreased temporal artery pulsation on the right side. She also has pallor of the optic disc, which indicates temporal arteritis with vision changes.    

Temporal arteritis, also known as giant cell arteritis, is an inflammatory vasculitis of medium and large arteries; which eventually can result in ischemia and complications, such as vision loss.   

In cases of suspected temporal arteritis, especially when associated with visual symptoms, prompt treatment is crucial to prevent irreversible complications, such as ischemic optic neuropathy and permanent blindness. High-dose corticosteroids, such as prednisone, are the mainstay of treatment as they effectively suppress the inflammatory process in the temporal arteries, reducing the risk of vascular complications. Initiating intravenous corticosteroid therapy promptly is essential to mitigate inflammation, preserve vision, and prevent further visual impairment in patients with temporal arteritis and visual changes. These patients should also have an urgent ophthalmology consult.    

Patients presenting with temporal arteritis without visual symptoms can be started on oral steroids, typically prednisone. An outpatient ophthalmology consultation should be scheduled as soon as possible to assess the optic nerve. In either case, it is crucial to start steroids early to prevent complications.    

Diagnostic confirmation is done with a temporal artery biopsy, ideally performed within 2 to 4 weeks of initiating steroids, as early treatment can alter biopsy findings. Biopsy classically reveals transmural inflammation with multinucleated giant cells, mononuclear infiltrate, and disruption of the internal elastic lamina in affected arteries. However, false negative rates with biopsy are high, due to the discontinuous character of the histopathologic changes (skip lesions) and the fact that glucocorticoid treatment may reduce the sensitivity of temporal artery biopsy. Therefore, if clinical suspicion remains high despite a negative biopsy, a contralateral biopsy can be performed; or imaging, such as a color duplex ultrasound of the temporal artery or an MRI with contrast of the cranial vessels, may be helpful for establishing a diagnosis.    

Lastly, all patients should have a rheumatology consult to determine if steroid-sparing agents, such as an interleukin-6 inhibitor (e.g. tocilizumab), or a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (e.g. methotrexate or abatacept) should be added.  



Option Analysis

✅ Immediate initiation of high-dose corticosteroids :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgical revascularization of the affected artery:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of severe temporal arteritis, for which the primary treatment is high-dose corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly visual impairment due to ischemic optic neuropathy. Surgical revascularization of the affected temporal artery is not recommended treatment for temporal arteritis.
❌ Neurosurgical consultation for optic nerve decompression:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of severe temporal arteritis. Optic nerve decompression is not a primary or established intervention for temporal arteritis and does not address the underlying inflammatory process in the temporal arteries.
❌ Confirmation of the diagnosis with biopsy prior to starting corticosteroids:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of severe temporal arteritis, which, especially in cases with visual symptoms, requires urgent intervention to prevent irreversible complications like permanent blindness. Delaying treatment with glucocorticoids to confirm the diagnosis can lead to progressive damage of the optic nerve and is not recommended. Biopsy can be performed within two weeks of starting glucocorticoids. 
❌ Initiation of antiplatelet therapy to improve blood flow:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is characteristic of temporal arteritis, which is primarily an inflammatory disorder. Therefore, the mainstay of treatment is high-dose corticosteroids to suppress inflammation and prevent complications, especially visual impairment due to ischemic optic neuropathy. Antiplatelet therapy can be added to prevent cardiovascular events, but it does not address the underlying inflammatory process.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic due to persistent fatigue. The patient mentions occasional bone pain and muscle weakness which she initially attributed to aging. She has attempted to stay active and has been trying to maintain a diet rich in calcium due to a family history of osteoporosis. On physical examination, the patient appears well-nourished with no significant abnormal findings. Laboratory studies are listed below. What is the most likely direct cause of this patient’s current condition?  

Laboratory study
Result
Serum calcium
8.1 mg/dL  
Serum phosphate  
5.2 mg/dL  
Glomerular filtration rate (GFR)  
19 mL/min/1.73 m2  
Parathyroid hormone (PTH)  
168 pg/mL
questions.solution:
This patient’s history, symptoms, (fatigue, bone pain, weakness) and laboratory values are consistent with secondary hyperparathyroidism. This patient has Stage 4 severe chronic kidney disease based on her glomerular filtration rate, causing chronic hypocalcemia leading to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone. Chronic kidney disease is the most likely direct cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism in this patient.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by the excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands in response to chronic hypocalcemia. This is in contrast to primary hyperparathyroidism, where the excess PTH secretion is due to intrinsic abnormalities of the parathyroid glands themselves, such as adenomas or hyperplasia. The patient’s history and laboratory studies can help differentiate between these two conditions. Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by an elevated PTH level accompanied by high serum calcium and often normal or low phosphate levels. Secondary hyperparathyroidism typically presents with an elevated PTH level, low or normal serum calcium, and high phosphate levels.

The most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism is chronic kidney disease, where impaired renal function leads to phosphate retention, reduced synthesis of active vitamin D, and subsequent decrease in calcium absorption from the GI tract. Malabsorption syndromes, like celiac disease or gastric bypass surgery, can also impair the absorption of calcium and vitamin D. Additionally, severe dietary deficiencies, or the use of certain medications (e.g., bisphosphonates, anticonvulsants, loop diuretics) that affect calcium and vitamin D homeostasis, can also lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic kidney disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: While diabetes can lead to kidney disease, which in turn may cause secondary hyperparathyroidism, it is not a direct causative factor for the condition.  
❌ High calcium diet:
Incorrect: In patients without underlying disorders, a diet high in calcium would typically reduce the risk of hyperparathyroidism by providing adequate calcium, which can suppress parathyroid hormone secretion. In this patient, a calcium-rich diet is not causing hyperparathyroidism, chronic kidney disease is the underlying cause.  
❌ Family history of osteoporosis:
Incorrect: While a family history of osteoporosis may indicate a predisposition to bone density issues, it does not directly relate to this patient’s secondary hyperparathyroidism from chronic kidney disease.  
❌ Active lifestyle:
Incorrect: An active lifestyle would not cause secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman with a history of sickle cell disease is admitted for transfusion of three units of packed red blood cells. Approximately two hours post-transfusion, she begins experiencing shortness of breath and orthopnea. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), heart rate is 102/min, blood pressure is 175/95 mmHg, respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Physical examination reveals rales halfway up the bilateral lung fields, jugular venous distension, and 3+ pitting edema in the bilateral lower extremities. Chest X-ray is significant for an enlarged cardiac silhouette and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Which of the following should be done next to help confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of fluid overload and chest X-ray findings of an enlarged cardiac silhouette and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. In the context of a recent blood transfusion, this clinical presentation is suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis. It can evaluate cardiac function and volume status.

TACO typically occurs when the volume of transfused blood products overloads the patient's cardiovascular system, leading to fluid overload and pulmonary edema. Risk factors include a history of heart failure or renal insufficiency. A diagnosis of TACO can be made in patients with signs and symptoms suggestive of volume overload following a blood transfusion with findings of an elevated BNP, cardiogenic pulmonary edema on chest X-ray (Kerley B lines, bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, peribronchial cuffing), and signs of left ventricular dysfunction and volume overload on TTE.  

Option Analysis

✅ Transthoracic echocardiogram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of intravenous (IV) furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Furosemide should improve her symptoms; however, transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) is needed for definitive diagnosis.  
❌ Administration of high-dose corticosteroids:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Corticosteroids do not address the fluid overload and cardiac strain that occurs in patients with TACO. Therefore, administration of high dose corticosteroids will not lead to clinical improvement, nor will it help determine the underlying condition.  
❌ CT angiography of the chest:
Incorrect: CT angiography is indicated for patients with suspected pulmonary embolism. This patient's presentation and signs of fluid overload and an enlarged cardiac silhouette following a transfusion is more suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO); this requires transthoracic echocardiogram to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Electrocardiogram (ECG):
Incorrect: An electrocardiogram (ECG) should be performed to rule out cardiac ischemia. However, this patient's clinical presentation, including hypertension, rales, peripheral edema, and an enlarged cardiac silhouette, points to transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) rather than a primary cardiac event. Transthoracic echocardiogram should be performed to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of chronic anemia is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of shortness of breath and chest tightness that developed 30 minutes after receiving a packed red blood cell transfusion. His past medical history includes hypertension and chronic kidney disease stage 3. His regular medications include lisinopril and amlodipine. On examination, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 160/95 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals bilateral rales at the lung bases and distended jugular veins. Electrocardiogram (ECG) is significant for sinus tachycardia and voltage criteria for left ventricular hypertrophy. Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin level of 10.2 g/dL, creatinine of 3.2 mg/dL, and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP). Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. An echocardiogram is pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of chronic anemia and chronic kidney disease presents with sudden onset respiratory distress, hypertension, signs of volume overload, and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) after receiving a blood transfusion. These findings are suggestive of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). The best next step in management is to administer IV furosemide.

TACO typically occurs when the volume of transfused blood products overwhelms the patient's cardiovascular system, leading to fluid overload and respiratory distress from pulmonary edema. Patients with underlying conditions like hypertension and chronic kidney disease are at increased risk for developing TACO with blood transfusions.

Treatment includes immediately stopping the blood transfusion if it is still in progress and intravenous furosemide. Furosemide reduces circulating blood volume and pulmonary congestion, which improves respiratory distress and oxygenation. This intervention is critical for managing the patient's acute symptoms and mitigating respiratory compromise. Supportive care, including supplemental oxygen and close monitoring of hemodynamic status, is also indicated.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous (IV) furosemide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemodialysis:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Although the patient has chronic kidney disease, immediate hemodialysis is not indicated in the absence of severe fluid overload unresponsive to diuretics, life-threatening electrolyte disturbances, or uremic complications. Initial management should focus on diuretic therapy.  
❌ Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation:
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). While severe respiratory distress may require intubation, initial therapy should target fluid overload. Intubation should be considered if the patient does not respond to initial medical management with diuretics or if their respiratory status worsens.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) metoprolol  :
Incorrect: This patient likely has transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). IV metoprolol, a beta-blocker, is not appropriate in the acute setting. It can reduce the heart rate and blood pressure but would not address the underlying condition of volume overload.  
❌ Intravenous (IV) enalapril:
Incorrect: IV enalapril is used for managing hypertensive emergencies. It is used in the acute management of transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO) where the main goal of treatment is to reduce excess fluid rapidly with diuretics like furosemide.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman comes to the emergency department complaining of chest pain and shortness of breath. Her symptoms began three hours ago. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and alcoholic liver disease. Upon arrival, her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 102/min, blood pressure is 142/75 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 21/min. Swelling and erythema is observed in the right lower extremity. The liver is palpated 2 centimeters below the right costal margin. There is no evidence of jaundice, scleral icterus, or abdominal ascites. Pulmonary CT angiography is ordered and reveals a pulmonary embolism in the left lung. The patient is started on the appropriate anticoagulant therapy. Two days later, the patient develops nausea, abdominal pain, and hematochezia. Laboratory testing is shown below. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Hemoglobin
11.0 g/dL
Hematocrit
33%
Leukocyte Count  
8,700/mm3
Platelet Count  
170,000/mm3  
Partial thromboplastin time  (activated)  
105 seconds
Prothrombin time  
14 seconds

choices.text: Intravenous infusion of prothrombin complex concentrate
Administration of cationic peptide that inactivates drug molecules
Transfusion with packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
This patient was initially diagnosed with a pulmonary embolism and started on heparin. She subsequently developed gastrointestinal bleeding and laboratory testing revealed an elevated activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) due to heparin overdose. Of note, a normal aPTT is 30-40 seconds and when a patient is on heparin, their aPTT should be 50-90 seconds.

The next best step in management would be to administer protamine sulfate. Protamine is a positively charged molecule (cation) that can bind to negatively charged heparin (anion), rapidly inactivating its anticoagulant activity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Intravenous infusion of prothrombin complex concentrate:
Incorrect: Prothrombin complex concentrate consists of factors II, VII, IX, and X. It can be administered to treat warfarin overdose. However, this patient has an elevated activated partial thromboplastin time but normal prothrombin time, which makes heparin overdose more likely. Prothrombin complex concentrate is not used in the treatment of heparin overdose.  
❌ Intravenous infusion of somatostatin analog:
Incorrect: Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is used to treat acute variceal bleeding, which typically presents with hematemesis. Patients usually have concurrent signs of portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, engorged paraumbilical veins). In contrast, this patient lacks these physical exam findings, making variceal bleeding an unlikely etiology of her symptoms.  
✅ Administration of cationic peptide that inactivates drug molecules:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform lower gastrointestinal tract endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient has symptoms of gastrointestinal tract bleeding likely due to anticoagulant overdose. The first step in management would be to reverse the anticoagulant medication. In contrast, endoscopy should be held off for at least 4-6 hours after the last heparin dose. This is because blood thinners can increase the risk of bleeding during or after the procedure.  
❌ Transfusion with packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: This patient has anemia due to gastrointestinal tract bleeding. Patients are generally transfused only when their hemoglobin is below 7 g/dL.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider to evaluate excessive sweating, anxiety, and weight loss despite an increased appetite. Her past medical history is notable for a toxic thyroid adenoma, for which she has been prescribed multiple medications. However, the patient reports that her symptoms have been poorly controlled. In the office, her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 127/76 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for mild eyelid retraction, and a non-tender, solitary nodule is palpated in the left thyroid lobe. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. The physician recommends that the patient undergo treatment that will improve her condition but may cause side effects of hypothyroidism, xerostomia, and sialadenitis. Which of the following best describes this treatment option’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Removal of autoantibodies from the bloodstream

questions.solution:
This patient has a toxic adenoma, causing symptoms of hyperthyroidism that are refractory to medical management. The patient is started on a radioactive iodine treatment regimen called radioiodine ablation therapy. The isotope of iodine that is used is I131. It is taken orally and eventually gets taken up by the thyroid. Over a few weeks, the radioactive isotope collects in the colloid and emits beta radiation that causes permanent damage to the thyroid.

Radioiodine ablation therapy can provide definitive treatment for hyperthyroidism caused by Graves disease, toxic multinodular goiter, and toxic adenoma. Since the thyroid is permanently destroyed, the patient will need to take thyroid hormone replacements like levothyroxine to prevent hypothyroidism. Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and is secreted in breast milk. Hence, it is contraindicated in pregnant or breastfeeding individuals. Finally, as far as side effects go, radioactive iodide can cause radiation-induced thyroiditis, increased risk of neoplasia, hematopoietic suppression, exacerbation of Graves ophthalmopathy, salivary, and lacrimal toxicity. Salivary and lacrimal toxicity arise since the radioactive iodine can also be uptaken by these glands and cause tissue damage.  

Option Analysis

❌ Non-selective blockade of beta-receptors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of non-selective beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol). Side effects may include bradycardia, fatigue, bronchoconstriction/asthma exacerbation, and weight gain. However, this medication class would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.  
✅ Radiation-induced thyroid gland destruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of thyroid peroxidase:
Incorrect: Thionamides (e.g., methimazole, propylthiouracil) block thyroid hormone production by inhibiting thyroid peroxidase. Side effects include agranulocytosis, hepatotoxicity, aplastic anemia, and skin rash. However, thionamides would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.  
❌ Promotion of lymphocyte apoptosis:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are immunosuppressants that function via several mechanisms of action. One involves promoting the apoptosis of lymphocytes, monocytes, and other immune cells. The medication treats Graves ophthalmopathy and thyroid storm, but not toxic adenoma. Side effects include hyperglycemia, skin atrophy, weight gain, and increased infection risk.  
❌ Removal of autoantibodies from the bloodstream:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of plasmapheresis. It is occasionally used in the management of severe Graves disease. However, plasmapheresis would not be useful in treating a toxic adenoma, given that autoantibodies do not mediate the condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office for the evaluation of a penile ulcer. The lesion is painless and began as a papule three days ago and developed an ulceration yesterday. Past medical history is noncontributory, and he takes no medication. Family history is noncontributory. The patient is sexually active with multiple partners and does not use condoms. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a 1.2 cm ulcer close to glans penis with raised indurated margins and a nonexudative base. There are several bilateral enlarged inguinal lymph nodes that are nontender, firm, and rubbery. There are no surrounding vesicles or lesions. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the first-line treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Inhibition of peptidoglycan formation by binding D-Ala-D-Ala
Inhibition of initiation complex through binding of the 30S subunit

questions.solution:
This patient most likely developed a genital ulcer after unprotected sexual intercourse, raising suspicion of sexually transmitted disease. A solitary, painless ulcer with raised, indurated margins and a clean base is indicative of primary syphilis; the ulcer is termed as a chancre. Chancres are caused by Treponema pallidum, a Gram-negative spirochete. A single dose of penicillin G benzathine is standard therapy for most patients with primary syphilis.    

Penicillin is a β-lactam antibiotic that consists of a thiazolidine ring connected to a β-lactam ring which is attached to a side chain. This structure of the β-lactam closely resembles the D-ala-D-ala residue.    

Penicillin is a bactericidal (kills bacteria) drug that act to inhibit cell wall synthesis by the following steps:  

  1.  Binds to penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) located in the bacterial cytoplasmic membrane 
  2.  Inhibits the transpeptidation reaction that cross-links the linear peptidoglycan chain constituents of the cell wall 
  3.  Activates the autolytic enzymes that cause lesions in the bacterial cell wall 

Option Analysis

❌ Inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase:
Incorrect: Sulfonamides inhibit dihydropteroate synthase, thus inhibiting folate synthesis. Although they are effective against various Gram-positive and Gram-negative organisms, as well as Chlamydia and Nocardia species, they are not used in the treatment of syphilitic chancre. 
❌ Inhibition of DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Fluoroquinolones inhibit prokaryotic enzymes topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV.  They are very effective against Gram-negative bacteria, such as Enterobacteriaceae, Haemophilus, Legionella, Neisseria, Moraxella, and even Pseudomonas species, but not spirochetes.
❌ Inhibition of peptidoglycan formation by binding D-Ala-D-Ala:
Incorrect: Vancomycin inhibits cell wall peptidoglycan formation by binding D-Ala-D-Ala portion of cell wall precursors. It is effective against Gram-positive organisms for serious, multidrug-resistant organisms, including MRSA, S epidermidis, sensitive Enterococcus species, and Clostridium difficile.
❌ Inhibition of initiation complex through binding of the 30S subunit:
Incorrect: Aminoglycosides (e.g. gentamicin, amikacin, tobramycin) are bactericidal antimicrobial agents that inhibit protein synthesis by blocking the formation of the initiation complex, misreading of mRNA, and inhibiting translocation. They are effective against severe Gram-negative rod infections and are not indicated in first-line treatment of primary syphilis. 
✅ Block transpeptidase cross-linking of peptidoglycan:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of years of chronic low back pain that improves with exercise and worsens with rest. He reports morning stiffness in the lower back that lasts for over two hours. On physical examination, the patient has decreased chest expansion and limited spinal mobility. Laboratory findings include an elevated ESR and C-reactive protein. X-ray of the spine reveals a “bamboo spine.” Which of the following additional X-ray findings would be expected with this patient's likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of chronic low back pain with reduced spinal range of motion, along with sacroiliac joint tenderness and the x-ray finding of a “bamboo spine” is consistent with ankylosing spondylitis. This diagnosis is further supported by the presence of elevated inflammatory markers. An additional radiologic finding associated with ankylosing spondylitis is fusion of the sacroiliac joints.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic, inflammatory condition that primarily affects the spinal and sacroiliac joints. Plain films can show bony changes that result from the disease. Sacroiliitis may be the first radiological finding seen in patients. It is diagnosed by finding loss of definition in the articular surfaces of the sacroiliac joints with erosions and subchondral sclerosis. Eventually, the joint space may disappear completely.

In the spine, vertebral bodies may appear “squared” from periosteal proliferation of new bone. Additionally, syndesmophytes (vertical bony growths) can be seen as ossification of the annulus fibrosis occurs. These syndesmophytes cause fusion of the vertebral bodies, limiting the spine’s range of motion and producing the unique “bamboo spine.”

In addition to x-rays, laboratory studies are often performed during the workup for ankylosing spondylitis. Inflammatory markers such as ESR and CRP are usually elevated. Patients may also be positive for HLA-B27. Additional studies should be sent to rule out other autoimmune and inflammatory conditions that affect the joints (depending on the clinical presentation), such as antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factor, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies, Lyme serology, and joint fluid analysis.

Erosions and subchondral sclerosis of the sacroiliac joints in ankylosing spondylitis  
 Image courtesy of Eva M. Escobedo, MD; B. J. Manaster, MD, PhD, FACR. STATdx. © Elsevier 2023. Image reused with permission.  
“Shiny corners” and complete syndesmophytes contribute to squaring of the vertebral bodies in ankylosing spondylitis.
 
 Image courtesy of Eva M. Escobedo, MD; B. J. Manaster, MD, PhD, FACR. STATdx. © Elsevier 2023. Image reused with permission.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fusion of the sacroiliac joints:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Widening of the intervertebral foramina:
Incorrect: Widening of the intervertebral foramina is not associated with ankylosing spondylitis. This finding can be seen in conditions like neurofibromatosis, where nerve sheath tumors cause expansion of the neural foramina.  
❌ Enlargement of the vertebral bodies:
Incorrect: Enlargement or ballooning of the vertebral bodies can be seen in Paget disease of bone where there is abnormal bone remodeling. It is not typically associated with ankylosing spondylitis.  
❌ Displacement of the intervertebral discs:
Incorrect: Disc displacement and herniation are more commonly associated with degenerative disc disease or traumatic injury. This is not a typical finding in patients with ankylosing spondylitis.  
❌ Widening of the sacroiliac joints:
Incorrect: Widening of the sacroiliac joints is not associated with ankylosing spondylitis, fusion is more often seen.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to progressive pain, redness, and swelling of the left foot for the past week, and 2 days of fevers and chills. Four weeks ago, the patient was diagnosed with a diabetic foot ulcer on the plantar surface at the base of the first left toe. Past medical history is significant for poorly controlled diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 38.8°C (101.9°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 93/68 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. Physical examination reveals an erythematous, swollen left foot with an open 2 ½ cm ulcer on the plantar surface at the base of the left toe. The foot is warm to the touch, and there is tenderness to palpation at the site of the ulcer and purulent discharge is present. Bone is felt when probing the ulcer with a sterile surgical probe. Laboratory evaluation is significant for a white blood cell (WBC) count of 18,000/μL, C-reactive protein (CRP) of 120 mg/L, and an elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level of 350 U/L. Intravenous fluids are initiated and blood and wound cultures are sent. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: MRI of the foot and intravenous clindamycin

questions.solution:
This patient with DM and a diabetic foot ulcer presents with progressive pain, redness, and swelling at the site of a prior ulcer. On a physical exam he has a positive probe-to-bone test, and signs of systemic infection and sepsis. The most likely diagnosis is acute osteomyelitis from a diabetic foot ulcer. Management should include hemodynamic stabilization and broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics that cover streptococci, MRSA, aerobic gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes. An appropriate regimen would be vancomycin, metronidazole, and cefepime.

The initial step in the acute management of an unstable patient with acute osteomyelitis is stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation; obtaining IV access; and initiating IV fluids. Once blood and wound cultures are obtained, broad-spectrum antibiotics should be started. The empiric antibiotic regimen for osteomyelitis from diabetic foot ulcers should be based on the severity of the infection and the likelihood of resistant organisms. For patients with systemic toxicity or limb-threatening infections, antibiotics should cover streptococci, MRSA, aerobic gram-negative bacilli, and anaerobes. Diagnostic imaging, typically with X-ray and MRI, should be performed after empiric antibiotics are started. Surgery should be consulted for possible debridement. A prolonged course of targeted antibiotics should be guided by culture and sensitivity results.  

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous vancomycin, metronidazole, and cefepime:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral amoxicillin-clavulanate and outpatient follow-up:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of sepsis due to acute osteomyelitis from a diabetic foot ulcer. Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and inpatient care are necessary due to the severity of the condition.  
❌ Immediate surgical debridement:
Incorrect: While surgical debridement may be required in the management of osteomyelitis in patients with diabetic foot ulcers, it is not the immediate priority in this case. The patient should first be stabilized and treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics.  
❌ Bone biopsy and intravenous ceftriaxone:
Incorrect: This patient has signs of sepsis due to acute osteomyelitis. A bone biopsy is used to definitively diagnose osteomyelitis, but this patient with hemodynamic instability and sepsis should first be started on empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics. Ceftriaxone alone is not broad enough coverage for this patient.  
❌ MRI of the foot and intravenous clindamycin:
Incorrect: While MRI can provide detailed information regarding the extent of osteomyelitis, it should not delay the initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. Furthermore, empiric clindamycin alone is not sufficient.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the office for a routine health maintenance examination. The patient reports episodes of cough, wheezing, and breathlessness during his workout sessions that improve with rest. The rest of the systemic review is unremarkable. Past medical history is noncontributory. Family history is significant for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease in the patient’s grandparent. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows equal breath sounds bilaterally on auscultation. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Suggest patient to warm-up well before exercise
Start the patient on oral prednisone twice daily
Start inhaled albuterol 10 minutes before exercise

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms are consistent with exercise-induced asthma (EIA) and he requires pre-treatment (10-20 minutes prior to exercise) with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (SABA) i.e.-albuterol to prevent symptomatic bronchoconstriction.

SABA (e.g., albuterol and terbutaline) has a duration of action of 3-6 hours. They have a rapid onset of bronchodilation (5 minutes) and are used as needed for symptom relief in patients with acute asthma exacerbation. They are also useful in preventing EIA if taken prior to exercise (as in this patient). SABA can also be used in high doses by a nebulizer or via a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) with a spacer.

Long-acting β2-agonists (LABA), (e.g., salmeterol and formoterol), have a duration of action over 12 hours and are given twice daily by inhalation or maintenance therapy for patients with asthma and/or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). LABA are usually prescribed with inhaled corticosteroids (ICS) and should not be given as a monotherapy as they do not control the underlying inflammation.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Start inhaled salmeterol twice daily:
Incorrect: Salmeterol is a long-acting beta agonist (LABA). When used as a monotherapy, it is associated with increased asthma-related mortality. It is not recommended in exercise-induced asthma.  
❌ Suggest patient to warm-up well before exercise:
Incorrect: The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of exercise-induced asthma and he should receive appropriate management to prevent complications.  
❌ Start the patient on oral prednisone twice daily:
Incorrect: A course of oral corticosteroid (usually prednisone or prednisolone 30-45 mg once daily for 5-10 days) is used to treat acute exacerbations of asthma. It is not indicated in exercise-induced asthma.  
✅ Start inhaled albuterol 10 minutes before exercise:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Start inhaled beclomethasone daily:
Incorrect: Low-dose steroid inhalers such as beclomethasone, may be indicated in athletes with daily activity and for the treatment of persistent asthma. It requires treatment for up to four weeks before it will have maximum benefit. This patient should initially be started on a pre-exercise short-acting beta-agonist.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman came to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and chest tightness for the past hour. The patient appears tachypneic but is able to speak full sentences. Past medical history is significant for seasonal allergies. Family history is significant for asthma in the patient’s mother. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows diffuse wheezing on pulmonary auscultation bilaterally. After further evaluation, treatment with an inhaled medication is begun. The patient reports improvement in symptoms after 10 minutes which was evident by increased flow rate on spirometry. Which of the following is the most common adverse effect of the inhaled therapy that was most likely administered in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with acute shortness of breath and chest tightness is consistent with airway bronchoconstriction, most likely due to an asthma attack. Administration of a bronchodilator, most likely a beta-2 (β2)-agonist (e.g.-albuterol) improved her symptoms.

β2-agonists are bronchodilators that relax the airway smooth muscle cells. It activates the enzyme adenylyl cyclase leading to increased cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) production that ultimately causes relaxation of the smooth muscle by reducing the concentration of intracellular calcium (Ca+2) ions. β2-agonists are mainstays of reliever or rescue therapy for asthma patients. Major side effects are caused by increased sympathetic stimulation and include tachycardia, palpitations, muscle tremors, restlessness, and insomnia. There is a slight fall in plasma potassium due to increased uptake by skeletal muscle cells, but this effect does not usually cause any clinical problems due to the significantly small dose.  

Option Analysis

❌ Myelosuppression:
Incorrect: Steroid-sparing therapy such as methotrexate can be used in patients with severe asthma to reduce the requirement for oral corticosteroids. Myelosuppression is the major side effect of methotrexate therapy.  
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: For severe asthma and COPD, muscarinic antagonists are often given with long-acting beta-agonists as this combination produces an additive effect, leading to stronger and longer-lasting bronchodilation. Side effects of muscarinic antagonists include tachycardia, dry mouth, urinary retention, and pupil dilation.  
✅ Palpitations:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Oral thrush:
Incorrect: Use of inhaled corticosteroids can cause oral thrush. It is not the first-line treatment for an acute asthma attack.  
❌ Drug-drug interactions:
Incorrect: Theophylline has been used for bronchodilation previously, but its use is limited due to narrow therapeutic index and adverse effects (e.g., cardiotoxicity, neurotoxicity). It is metabolized by cytochrome P-450 and is involved in significant drug-drug interactions.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of worsening shortness of breath and dry cough. The patient reports exertional shortness of breath for the past few days to the extent that he is now unable to perform his daily activities. He does not have chest pain but reports noticing whitish sputum with cough. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Family history is significant for lung cancer in the patient’s father. He has a 40-pack-year smoking history. BMI is 33 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 135/75 mmHg. Pulmonary auscultation reveals decreased breath sounds with scattered wheezes bilaterally. Medication is prescribed to counter the increase in mucus secretion, smooth muscle contraction, and bronchoconstriction in the airways. Which of the following is the most likely agent?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The mainstays of treatment are bronchodilators, especially antimuscarinic agents.

Muscarinic receptors are located primarily on autonomic effector cells (including the  heart, vascular endothelium, smooth muscle, presynaptic nerve terminals, and exocrine glands). It includes:
  
  • M1 receptors: mediates higher cognitive functions, stimulates the enteric nervous system 
  • M2 receptors: decreases heart rate and contractility of atria 
  • M3 receptors: increases exocrine gland secretions (e.g., lacrimal, sweat, salivary, gastric acid, airway secretions), decreases gut peristalsis, increases bladder contraction, bronchoconstriction, increased pupillary sphincter muscle contraction (miosis), ciliary muscle contraction (accommodation), increases insulin release and causes endothelium-mediated vasodilation 
Antimuscarinic medications used in the management of COPD bind to M3 muscarinic receptors on the tracheal and bronchial smooth muscles, blocking acetylcholine binding, consequently leading to less smooth muscle constriction. These medications also decrease mucous secretions from airway glands.  

Option Analysis

❌ Alpha-1 (α-1) adrenergic antagonist  :
Incorrect: α-1 adrenergic antagonists are primarily used in the management of benign prostatic hyperplasia, hypertension, and post-traumatic stress disorder (prazosin). It is not useful in the management of COPD.  
❌ Alpha-2 (α-2) adrenergic agonist:
Incorrect:  Clonidine and ɑ-methyldopa are α-2 adrenergic agonist used in the management of hypertension.  It does not help with COPD.  
❌ Beta-1 (β-1) adrenergic antagonist:
Incorrect: β-1 adrenergic antagonist may exacerbate pulmonary symptoms in patients with COPD via bronchoconstriction.  
❌ Muscarinic-2 (M2) cholinergic antagonist:
Incorrect: M2 cholinergic antagonist, would cause an increase in heart rate and contractility. It is not indicated in COPD.  
✅ Muscarinic-3 (M3) cholinergic antagonist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son after he was found confused on the floor of his apartment. The patient is lethargic but responsive and reports nausea, vomiting, and generalized weakness. Past medical history is significant for hypertension, diabetes mellitus type 2, and chronic kidney disease. Temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 140/75 mmHg. Laboratory results and ECG are shown below. The patient is immediately started on intravenous calcium gluconate. Administration of which of the following additional agents is indicated in this patient?  

Laboratory value  
Result
Serum chemistry  

Sodium
142 mEq/L
Potassium
7.5 mEq/L  
Chloride
95 mEq/L  
Creatinine
4.5 mg/dL  
BUN
49


Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with hyperkalemia (serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L and peaked T waves on ECG). Emergent treatment with intravenous calcium gluconate is indicated in this patient to stabilize the cardiac myocytes and prevent arrhythmias. Intravenous insulin with glucose and/or inhaled beta-2 agonists are used to transiently shift potassium into the cells and lower serum potassium levels.

Inhaled beta-adrenergic agonists (e.g. albuterol) shift potassium intracellularly by stimulating the Na+/K+ ATPase. It can also stimulate the release of insulin, which further promotes intracellular shifts of potassium. A significantly higher dose of nebulizer is required as compared to the dose used for the treatment of asthma or COPD. It is indicated as a 3rd line medication for hyperkalemia and should be avoided in patients with coronary artery disease due to the risk of tachycardia-induced angina.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lisinopril:
Incorrect: Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor that decreases the excretion of potassium by decreasing aldosterone secretion. Its administration will further increase serum potassium levels.  
✅ Albuterol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-adrenergic blocker that interferes with Β2 mediated intracellular potassium uptake. It is not indicated for the management of hyperkalemia.  
❌ Digitalis:
Incorrect: Digitalis is an inotropic agent which inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase to block intracellular uptake of potassium. Its administration may further increase serum potassium levels, among other side effects.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin should be avoided in this patient with chronic kidney disease. It will decrease renal perfusion and may cause further accumulation of serum potassium.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of painful swelling and erythema on his right leg. The patient reports that he suffered minor cuts a few days ago while he was cleaning his garage. A review of systems is otherwise unremarkable. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily. He does not consume alcohol or use recreational drugs. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min and blood pressure is 130/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows an indurated lesion surrounded by minor lacerations which are draining a purulent exudate. Complete blood profile shows a leukocyte count of 14,000 /mm3. Empiric antibiotic treatment is started after obtaining a sample of discharge for culture and sensitivity. Results of the culture reveal gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of resistance to methicillin in this bacteria?

choices.text: Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps
Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase
Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase
Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with painful erythematous swelling on right leg draining purulent exudate is most likely suffering from cellulitis. Gram-positive cocci in clusters that are resistant to methicillin is consistent with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infection.  

Resistance to methicillin and other β-lactams is due to one of the following mechanisms: 
  • Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP) altering its affinity for β-lactams (basis of methicillin resistance in staphylococci and of penicillin resistance in pneumococci and most resistant enterococci) 
  •  Inactivation of antibiotics by β-lactamase (penicillinases) is the most common mechanism of resistance of  staphylococci and many Gram-negative organisms 
  • Impaired penetration of drug to target PBPs, which is only in Gram-negative species because of the impermeable outer membrane of their cell wall 
  •  Efflux pump that efficiently transports some β-lactam antibiotics from the periplasm back across the cell wall outer membrane

Option Analysis

❌ Increased efflux of the drug out of bacteria by plasmid-encoded transport pumps:
Incorrect: Decreased uptake or Increased efflux of the drug out of bacterial cells by plasmid-encoded transport pumps is the mechanism of resistance of tetracyclines.
❌ Chromosomal mutation in bacterial DNA gyrase:
Incorrect: Resistance to quinolones is due primarily to chromosomal-encoded mutations that modify the bacterial DNA gyrase.
✅ Mutation in penicillin-binding protein (PBP):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decreased activity of bacterial catalase peroxidase:
Incorrect: Decreased activity of bacterial catalase-peroxidase is the mechanism of mycobacterial resistance to isoniazid. Mycobacterial catalase-peroxidase activity is required to synthesize the active metabolite of isoniazid that inhibits the growth of M. tuberculosis.
❌ Replacement of alanine with lactate in peptidoglycan:
Incorrect: Resistance to vancomycin is caused by a change in the peptide component of peptidoglycan from D-alanyl-D-alanine, which is the normal binding site for vancomycin, to D-alanine-D-lactate, to which the drug does not bind.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man undergoes elective coronary artery bypass grafting. Postoperative course is complicated by acute renal failure, pulmonary edema, and atrial fibrillation. An attempt to extubate the patient on the fourth postoperative day fails. The patient develops a temperature of 38.3°C (100.9 F) on the following day. Complete blood profile shows a leukocyte count of 16,000/mm3. Chest x-ray shows dense infiltrates in the upper and middle right lobes of the lungs. Lower respiratory tract samples are obtained. Gram stain is shown below. Culture on McConkey agar shows oxidase-positive organisms that do not ferment lactose. Treatment with piperacillin is initiated. Adding tazobactam to this treatment regimen would serve which of the following purposes?



Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Facilitate piperacillin binding to the bacterial cells
Decrease piperacillin cleavage by bacterial cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation is consistent with ventilator-associated pneumonia, which is a type of nosocomial pneumonia that develops ≧ 48 hours after endotracheal intubation. The most commonly implicated organisms include Gram-negative bacilli (e.g., Pseudomonas aeruginosa, Escherichia coli) and Gram-positive cocci (e.g. methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). This patient is infected with Gram-negative rods that are oxidase-positive and lactose non-fermenting, making P. aeruginosa the most likely pathogen.    

Certain bacterial strains, such as P. aeruginosa, produce the beta-lactamase enzymes that hydrolyze the beta-lactam ring of the penicillins, resulting in the loss of its antibacterial activity. The addition of a β-lactamase inhibitor (e.g., clavulanic acid, sulbactam, tazobactam) can protect hydrolyzable penicillins from inactivation by these enzymes. An inhibitor extends the spectrum of its companion β-lactam provided that the inactivity against a particular organism is due to destruction by a β-lactamase and that the inhibitor is active against the β-lactamase that is produced. They are available only in fixed combinations with specific penicillins and cephalosporins, for example, ampicillin-sulbactam, amoxicillin-clavulanate, and piperacillin-tazobactam.  

Option Analysis

❌ Facilitate piperacillin binding to the bacterial cells:
Incorrect: Penicillin-binding proteins in bacterial cells are responsible for bacterial binding of the antibiotic. Beta-lactamase inhibitors do not affect this function.
✅ Decrease piperacillin cleavage by bacterial cells:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Decrease renal clearance of piperacillin:
Incorrect: Clearance of both piperacillin and tazobactam are directly proportional to renal function. Moreover, probenecid can decrease the renal excretion of penicillins by inhibiting tubular organic acid secretion.
❌ Act synergistically with piperacillin:
Incorrect: Piperacillin–tazobactam often demonstrates synergy against P. aeruginosa in combination with an aminoglycoside.
❌ Slow liver metabolism of piperacillin:
Incorrect: Tazobactam has no effect on the biotransformation of piperacillin.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with shortness of breath that developed earlier in the day. She is currently being treated for colon cancer and had a partial colectomy one week ago. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 121/min, respirations are 26/min, blood pressure is 97/60 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals an elderly female in profound respiratory distress. A CT-angiogram of the chest is performed and shown below. Shortly after that, the patient suffers a cardiac arrest. Which of the following best describes the medication's mechanism of action that would be most effective in treating her condition?


Image reproduced from Radiopedia.

choices.text: Aid in the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin
Inhibit platelet aggregation by irreversibly blocking the ADP (P2Y12) receptor

questions.solution:
This patient presents an acute saddle pulmonary embolism with evidence of hemodynamic instability and cardiac arrest. A tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) should be administered in this setting. The medication works by aiding in the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin.  

Usually, when a blood clot is no longer needed, the body dissolves the blood clot through a process called fibrinolysis, which is the gradual degradation of the fibrin mesh. The enzyme tPA converts a circulating protein produced by the liver called plasminogen into its active form called plasmin. Plasmin then cuts the fibrin into smaller pieces, thus allowing the trapped red blood cells and platelets to float away and allowing the clot to dissolve. Typically, healthy endothelial cells release only tiny amounts of tPA, but when exposed to coagulation factors (mainly factor X and thrombin), they start making large amounts of tPA.   

By understanding this process, pharmacologists developed recombinant forms of tPA such as alteplase (tPA), reteplase (rPA), streptokinase, and tenecteplase. Under conditions such as cardiac arrest due to massive pulmonary embolism, early myocardial infarction, and early ischemic stroke, these medications can be administered to dissolve the thrombus and improve patient recovery.

Option Analysis

✅ Aid in the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Inhibit platelet aggregation by irreversibly blocking the ADP (P2Y12) receptor :
Incorrect: ADP receptor inhibitors such as clopidogrel are potent antiplatelet medications and are more commonly used in the setting of myocardial infarction or after coronary artery stenting. They are not used in the setting of venous thromboembolism.
❌ Direct inhibition of factor Xa :
Incorrect: Factor Xa inhibitors such as apixaban or rivaroxaban are often used in maintenance therapy for those with pulmonary emboli. However, this patient is unstable and requires thrombolytics for resuscitation.
❌ Activation of antithrombin:
Incorrect: Heparin is commonly used in the treatment of acute pulmonary embolism. However, this patient is unstable and requires thrombolytics for resuscitation.
❌ Irreversible COX-1 inhibition:
Incorrect: Aspirin is not used in the treatment of acute pulmonary embolism.

questions.text:
A 20 year-old woman presents to an outpatient clinic for evaluation of shortness of breath. The patient has had intermittent shortness of breath and coughing at night for the past year. She wakes up from sleep due to coughing around 1-2 times per month. Moreover, the patient has been skipping gym classes after noticing that physical exercise exacerbates her symptoms. The patient is asymptomatic today. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within limits. On physical examination, the lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Heart sounds are normal. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is performed and the results are shown below. Which of the following medications will be most helpful in diagnosing this patient’s underlying condition?  

Value
Result
FEV1
88% of predicted
FEV1/FVC ratio
84%
Diffusion capacity of carbon monoxide
96%
questions.solution:
The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of asthma. Upon exposure to inhaled methacholine, patients with asthma have hypersensitive airways and experience far more significant bronchoconstriction (when compared to the general population). As a result, direct cholinomimetic methacholine can assist in the workup of this condition.

Other direct-acting cholinomimetics include bethanechol, pilocarpine, and carbachol.
