Bethanechol can be given to stimulate intestinal motility in patients with ileus or to stimulate bladder contractility and emptying in patients with urinary retention. Pilocarpine can be used to treat glaucoma. When given topically on the eye, pilocarpine stimulates ciliary muscle contraction, thereby increasing aqueous humor outflow and decreasing intraocular pressure. Pilocarpine can also stimulate the lacrimal and salivary glands in patients with Sjögren syndrome. Moreover, it stimulates sweat glands and can be used for collecting sweat samples to assist in cystic fibrosis screening. Finally, carbachol can also be used to treat glaucoma.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Ipratropium:
Incorrect: Ipratropium is a muscarinic antagonist that can be used in the treatment of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. However, it is not used in the diagnosis of these conditions.  
❌ Theophylline:
Incorrect: Theophylline is a phosphodiesterase-3 inhibitor that can be used in the treatment of asthma. However, it is not used for diagnostic purposes.  
❌ Bethanechol:
Incorrect: Bethanechol is a direct cholinergic agonist that can be used for the treatment of iatrogenic urinary retention. It is not used for the diagnosis of asthma.  
✅ Methacholine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Physostigmine:
Incorrect: Physostigmine is used for the treatment of glaucoma, atropine overdose, and nightshade poisoning. It does not aid in the diagnosis of asthma.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents to the gastroenterologist’s office for a routine visit. He describes occasional straining during defecation and has bowel movements about 3 times per week. He is a recent immigrant to the United States from Venezuela. He was hospitalized there several times for a heart block. After evaluation by a cardiologist, an appointment is scheduled for a screening colonoscopy.  Which medication should be given in preparation for this patient’s colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
Magnesium sulfate is a multifaceted drug used for asthma, preeclampsia/eclampsia, hypomagnesemia, cardiac arrhythmias, and constipation. In the context of constipation,  magnesium sulfate, like most osmotic laxatives, is a salt which directly draws water into the intestinal lumen due to osmotic effect. As opposed to other laxatives, osmotic laxatives evacuate the entire bowel contents which makes them ideal for bowel preparation prior to surgery or colonoscopy. Adverse effects of osmotic laxatives include diarrhea and electrolyte abnormalities.

Magnesium sulfate is available in several different formulations; the IV formulation of magnesium sulfate is used for asthma, preeclampsia/eclampsia, electrolyte replacement, among others. IV magnesium sulfate must be used cautiously in patients with mild to severe heart blocks. Although this patient may have a heart block, magnesium sulfate for bowel prep is taken orally and is not contraindicated.  

Option Analysis

❌ Bran:
Incorrect: Bran is a bulk-forming laxative. The bulk-forming laxatives absorb water, distend the intestinal wall and promote peristalsis. They are not appropriate agents for preparation for colonoscopy (“bowel prep”).  
❌ Glycerin:
Incorrect: Glycerin is an emollient laxative. It acts as a surfactant in order to lessen the surface tension of water and soften the stool. While it will soften stool, it does not promote significant stool evacuation and is not an appropriate agent for bowel prep.  
❌ Lubiprostone:
Incorrect: Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator, which draws chloride into the lumen, and creates an osmotic gradient, drawing water into the lumen. Lubiprostone is approved for the treatment of chronic constipation and IBS-C, the constipation subtype of irritable bowel syndrome. It does not promote significant stool evacuation and is not an appropriate agent for bowel prep.  
❌ Docusate:
Incorrect: Docusate is a widely utilized emollient laxative, though its effectiveness has been called into question in recent years. It has no direct impact on bowel motility, does not promote significant stool evacuation, and is not an appropriate agent for bowel prep.  
✅ Magnesium sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department because of new-onset blurry vision with "flashing lights." The symptoms began approximately 4 days ago and have progressively worsened. The patient reports occasional floaters which are more severe in the left eye. Past medical history is significant for advanced HIV infection. The patient’s last CD4+ count was 39 cells/mm3 a year ago. He was previously started on antiretroviral therapy, but he has not consistently taken his medications over the past year because he has struggled with funds for the copays. Fundoscopic examination of the left eye is shown below. Treatment with which of the following medications is indicated in this patient?  


Reproduced fromWikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with progressive visual impairment (blurry vision, floaters, and flashing lights), in combination with fundoscopic findings of yellow-white fluffy retinal lesions, is consistent with cytomegalovirus (CMV) retinitis. Treatment with anti-CMV antivirals should be initiated. Among the options listed, cidofovir is the only medication with activity against CMV, though it is usually reserved as a 3rd line medication (after valganciclovir, ganciclovir, or foscarnet) due to severe nephrotoxicity.  

Cidofovir is a nucleotide analog which is exclusively phosphorylated by cellular kinases to the active diphosphate form, which directly binds to and inhibits viral DNA polymerases. It does not require phosphorylation by viral kinase; therefore, its activity is maintained against thymidine kinase-deficient or altered strains of CMV. Cidofovir is indicated for the treatment of acyclovir-resistant HSV infections. It is also used for the prophylaxis and treatment of resistant CMV infections in immunocompromised individuals.  

The main side effect of cidofovir is nephrotoxicity. Therefore, it is usually given along with probenecid and IV saline to decrease toxicity.

Option Analysis

❌ Bevacizumab:
Incorrect: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF). It is indicated in the management of proliferative diabetic retinopathy, which presents as hemorrhages and macular edema on fundoscopy. Yellow-white fluffy retinal lesions in this patient are suggestive of CMV retinitis.
❌ Timolol:
Incorrect: Timolol is a beta-blocker that is indicated in the management of glaucoma by decreasing aqueous humor production. Glaucoma presents with elevated intraocular pressure and optic disc atrophy with characteristic cupping i.e. thinning of the outer rim of the optic nerve head. Yellow-white fluffy retinal lesions in this patient are suggestive of CMV retinitis.
✅ Cidofovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Amphotericin B:
Incorrect: Amphotericin B is indicated in the management of Candida endophthalmitis. Fundoscopy usually shows focal, white, mound-like lesions on the retina. This patient’s fundoscopic findings are suggestive of CMV retinitis.
❌ Penicillin G:
Incorrect: Penicillin G is sometimes indicated in the management of ocular retinitis, which presents as ground-glass lesions with significant vitreal inflammation. This patient’s fundoscopic findings are suggestive of CMV retinitis.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man admitted to the inpatient unit is found to have an acute reduction in urine output over the last 24 hours. He was diagnosed with cryptococcal meningitis one week ago and was initiated on a treatment regimen involving amphotericin B and flucytosine. His medical history includes AIDS and IgA nephropathy. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Mucous membranes appear moist. Laboratory findings are demonstrated below. Which of the following is the target of the pharmacological agent responsible for this patient’s condition?

 Laboratory value  Result 
 Serum chemistry 
 Sodium   135 mEq/L 
 Potassium   3.0 mEq/L 
 Chloride   95 mEq/L 
 Creatinine   1.9 mg/dL 
 Mg  2.0 g/dL 
 BUN  30
questions.solution:
This patient with recent treatment for cryptococcal meningitis, presents with evidence of acute kidney injury, hypokalemia, and hypomagnesemia consistent with amphotericin B induced nephrotoxicity.   Amphotericin B is a polyene antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol–a key component of the fungal cell membrane–creating “micropores”, increasing cellular permeability. It is fungicidal at high doses and fungistatic at lower concentrations and clinically indicated in the treatment of invasive aspergillosis, cryptococcal meningitis, invasive candidiasis, blastomycosis, histoplasmosis and leishmaniasis.  

Amphotericin B is available in both conventional and liposomal formulations and is only administered intravenously. Lipid-based formulations are considerably less nephrotoxic and preferred in patients at increased risk of developing acute kidney injury.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fungal cell membrane :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fungal cell wall :
Incorrect: Echinocandins like caspofungin inhibit beta-glucan synthesis (a component of the fungal cell wall). The most common adverse effects associated with echinocandins include gastrointestinal disturbance. 
❌ Microtubules :
Incorrect: Griseofulvin is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It interferes with microtubule function and disrupts mitosis. It does not adversely affect kidney function or cause electrolyte abnormalities. 
❌ Lanosterol synthesis :
Incorrect: Terbinafine is used in the treatment of superficial fungal infections. It inhibits the fungal enzyme squalene epoxidase, which is involved in lanosterol synthesis. Terbinafine use can cause gastrointestinal disturbance.
❌ Nucleic acid synthesis :
Incorrect: Flucytosine is an antifungal agent that inhibits DNA and RNA synthesis by converting 5- flucytosine to 5-fluorouracil. Although it is a component of the treatment regimen for cryptococcal meningitis, it does not cause acute kidney injury. Adverse effects encountered with flucytosine use include bone marrow suppression and gastrointestinal disturbance.

questions.text: During a tumor board meeting, the oncology team is asked to review the clinical therapy for a 63-year-old man who had a recently resected colonic tumor. Gross pathology shows that the tumor was large and nearly completely obstructing the colonic lumen. A recent PET scan conducted on this patient shows distant metastases which have penetrated the liver. The oncology team proposes starting the patient on the FOLFOX chemotherapy regimen. Before initiating therapy, the team proposes using a medication that will prime the patient’s immune system by increasing the immune visibility of the tumor. The patient is treated with cetuximab and is found to have little effect on metastatic tumor populations on imaging. A biopsy of the metastatic liver deposits is taken. A mutation in which of the following receptors is most likely?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a patient with a newly diagnosed stage IV colon cancer with metastases to the liver. Standard treatment for stage IV colon cancers includes either FOLFOX (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, and Oxaliplatin) or FOLFIRI (Folinic acid, Fluorouracil, irinotecan) chemotherapy regimens. Before starting either of these chemotherapy regimens, it is now common to “prime” the patient’s immune system with targeted monoclonal antibodies, which help the patient’s immune system increase the immune visibility of tumor cells.    

Approximately 60-80% of cancer cells in colorectal tumors overexpress the EGFR receptor. Both  Cetuximab and Panitumumab are monoclonal antibody therapies targeted against the EGFR receptor used in the treatment of stage IV colorectal cancer and some head and neck tumors. Panitumumab is a human monoclonal antibody, whereas Cetuximab is a chimeric mouse monoclonal antibody. Both Cetuximab and Panitumumab have similar side effects, including rash, elevated LFTs, and diarrhea. Neither therapy is more efficacious in the treatment of colorectal cancer. A key difference between the two drugs is the role that cetuximab plays in immunological priming. Cetuximab has been shown to increase ADCC and other immunostimulatory activities such as cell maturation, T-cell recruitment to the tumor, increased antigen presentation, and cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. On the other hand, Panitumumab notably does not engage in cytotoxic NK T-cell priming. It does, however, engage in immune cytotoxicity at a much lower extent via neutrophil-driven ADCC. While it remains to be seen which of these drugs are superior in clinical efficacy, it’s clear that cetuximab has robust effects in modulating immune cytotoxic effects in cancer cells.   

Option Analysis

❌ VEGF:
Incorrect: This patient initially received cetuximab, which targets EGFR. A mutation in EGFR is most likely the cause of the tumor’s non-responsiveness to treatment.
❌ HER2:
Incorrect: Mutations in HER2 occur in breast cancers, not colorectal cancers. 
❌ CD20 :
Incorrect: CD20 is a pan-B-Cell marker useful in diagnosing and treating leukemia. 
❌ KIT:
Incorrect: Mutations in KIT are common in gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs)
✅ EGFR:
Correct: See main explanation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of compensated cirrhosis due to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis presents to the emergency department with two days of worsening abdominal pain that comes and goes abruptly. The pain is most pronounced in the right upper quadrant. He notes an increase in fatigue and abdominal girth. He has not had any recent alcohol intake, changes in medications, or history of similar episodes. Temperature is 37℃ (98.6℉), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. There is scleral icterus. The abdomen is tender to palpation diffusely with a positive fluid wave and splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal thrombocytopenia, elevated bilirubin, and mild transaminitis consistent with known cirrhosis. A doppler ultrasound reveals hyperechoic material in the portal vein with impaired blood flow. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with compensated cirrhosis presents with symptoms suggestive of portal vein thrombosis (PVT), confirmed by doppler ultrasound showing hyperechoic material and impaired blood flow in the portal vein. The best next step in management is therapeutic anticoagulation with low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).    

PVT refers to thrombosis within the portal vein that results in partial or complete vascular obstruction. This condition is commonly associated with cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, and can result in multiple complications, including esophageal and gastric varices, as well as cavernous transformation, pylephlebitis, and mesenteric ischemia.    

If a patient presents with findings suggestive of PVT, the first step is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine if the patient is unstable or stable. If the patient is unstable, airway, breathing, and circulation should be managed. Next, IV access and continuous vital sign monitoring, including blood pressure, heart rate, and pulse oximetry should be obtained. Unstable patients should be assessed for severe complications of portal vein thrombosis, like variceal bleeding or mesenteric infarction. For variceal bleeding, an endoscopy should be performed with variceal banding or sclerotherapy. In the case of mesenteric infarction, surgical consultation is necessary.

Option Analysis

❌ Paracentesis:
Incorrect: Paracentesis, although useful in assessing new-onset ascites and for diagnosing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, does not directly address the thrombotic event in the portal vein. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) should be started in this patient. 
✅ Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH):
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Apixaban:
Incorrect: Apixaban is a direct oral anticoagulant and reports have indicated decreased efficacy when used to treat portal vein thrombosis (PVT) in patients with cirrhosis. More research is needed before recommendations regarding its use can be made.
❌ Surgical thrombectomy:
Incorrect: Surgical thrombectomy may be used for patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) and intestinal infarction who are undergoing surgery for intestinal infarction where thrombectomy can be performed during laparotomy. Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) should be started in this patient. 
❌ Systemic thrombolytic therapy:
Incorrect: Systemic thrombolytic therapy is not appropriate management for acute portal vein thrombosis since it can lead to bleeding, especially in patients with cirrhosis. However, several studies have demonstrated some success with catheter-based thrombolysis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of progressively worsening right upper quadrant pain, fever, and chills. He was treated 5 days ago with antibiotics for diverticulitis. At first, he had improvement of the initial left lower quadrant pain, but he then developed right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fevers, and chills. He has no personal or family history of a hypercoagulable state. His medical history is significant for hypertension, managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 39℃ (100.4℉), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals abdominal tenderness in the right upper quadrant and guarding, without rebound tenderness. Laboratory tests show leukocytosis, normal transaminases, and normal INR. A bedside Doppler ultrasound reveals hyperechoic material in the portal vein with impaired blood flow from partial occlusion. What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient, who has recently been treated for diverticulitis, presents with diffuse abdominal pain, fevers, chills, and right upper quadrant tenderness. Doppler ultrasound shows hyperechoic material in the portal vein with impaired blood flow from partial occlusion. These findings are consistent with septic thrombophlebitis of the portal vein, or pylephlebitis, which is a rare complication of intra-abdominal infections. The best next step in management is to perform a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis to look for the source of infection.    

Patients with portal vein thrombosis (PVT) can be asymptomatic or present with nonspecific signs and symptoms. They may present with acute abdominal pain or progressively worsening abdominal pain. The abdominal pain may be associated with nausea or vomiting. Many of the clinical findings that patients present with will be related to the underlying cause of PVT (e.g. spider angioma, ascites, variceal hemorrhage in cirrhosis). Risk factors such as cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, recent abdominal surgery, and hypercoagulable state (including inherited thrombophilias or use of oral contraceptives) should raise the index of suspicion.  

On physical examination, patients with PVT may have abdominal tenderness typically without guarding. Guarding may be secondary to intra-abdominal infection. Patients with pylephlebitis may have a tender liver and fever. Patients with PVT may have signs of chronic liver disease (e.g. jaundice, ascites, spider angiomata). In severe cases, signs of systemic illness such as fever or hypotension may be present. 

Option Analysis

❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) abdomen/pelvis:
Incorrect: MRI abdomen/pelvis would not be helpful in the acute setting to diagnose an intraabdominal infection. 
❌ Abdominal radiograph:
Incorrect: An abdominal x-ray would not help diagnose suspected diverticulitis. 
❌ Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography:
Incorrect: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is not indicated, as it is primarily used for evaluation of biliary or pancreatic ductal pathologies. 
✅ Computed tomography (CT) abdomen/pelvis :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: An upper endoscopy is not appropriate for evaluation of suspected diverticulitis and associated complications.

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for fever and confusion. Her partner states that she has been “acting differently” over the past 24 hours. The patient has not had nausea, vomiting, constipation or diarrhea. Medical history is significant for cirrhosis due to chronic alcohol use. Medications include spironolactone and furosemide. The patient also has an umbilical hernia that has not been repaired. Temperature is 38.0 ℃ (100.4 ℉), pulse is 102/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 102/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient is unable to perform a timed connect-the-numbers test. Bowel sounds are decreased. Abdominal examination shows moderate ascites with diffuse tenderness to palpation. There is no rigidity or rebound tenderness. A bulge in the umbilicus is mildly tender and reducible without overlying skin changes. Creatinine is 1.1 mg/dL (baseline 1.0 mg/dL). Urinalysis shows no hematuria and a bland urine sediment. Abdominal radiograph shows dilated loops of small and large bowels with air in the colon. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s current condition?

choices.text: Atrophy of the mammillary bodies in the hypothalamus
Leakage of pancreatic enzymes causing increased vascular permeability

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cirrhosis presents with fever and confusion. She has abdominal tenderness, evidence of an ileus and ascites on physical exam. The most likely diagnosis is spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) which is caused by bacterial translocation from the gut.   

SBP is a common and serious complication in patients with cirrhosis and ascites. SBP primarily develops due to bacterial translocation, where gut bacteria (e.g., E. coli, Klebsiella) penetrate the intestinal wall and enter the mesenteric lymph nodes before migrating to and infecting the ascitic fluid. Factors contributing to bacterial translocation in cirrhosis include intestinal bacterial overgrowth, increased intestinal permeability, and impaired host immune defense mechanisms. Once bacteria enter the ascitic fluid, they can multiply rapidly due to the low opsonic activity in the ascitic fluid, leading to an inflammatory response and the clinical manifestations of SBP.    

The signs and symptoms of SBP are subtle compared with those typically seen in patients with bacterial peritonitis in the absence of ascites. By separating the visceral from the parietal peritoneal surfaces, the ascites prevent the development of a rigid abdomen. SBP should be suspected in any patient with cirrhosis and ascites who presents with symptoms suggestive of infection (e.g., fever, abdominal pain) or hepatic decompensation (e.g., worsening encephalopathy or renal function). Subtle changes in mental status are frequently overlooked as signs of SBP. The Timed Connect-The-Numbers Test is a diagnostic aid that can help detect subtle changes in mental status in patients with cirrhosis and suspected encephalopathy. Other signs and symptoms of SBP include diarrhea, paralytic ileus, hypotension, hypothermia; and laboratory abnormalities such as leukocytosis, metabolic acidosis, and elevated blood urea nitrogen.   

Option Analysis

❌ Atrophy of the mammillary bodies in the hypothalamus:
Incorrect: Atrophy of the mamillary bodies is associated with chronic thiamine deficiency and leads to Wernicke encephalopathy, which presents with confusion, ataxia, and ocular abnormalities. It is not associated with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis and does not cause fever, ascites, and abdominal tenderness.
❌ Leakage of pancreatic enzymes causing increased vascular permeability:
Incorrect: Leakage of pancreatic enzymes and the resultant increase in vascular permeability are characteristic of pancreatitis, which can lead to ascites. This patient’s ascites are more likely related to underlying cirrhosis, and her fever, confusion, and abdominal tenderness are likely caused by spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
❌ Bowel incarceration and strangulation:
Incorrect: Bowel incarceration and strangulation can be a complication of a hernia. However, this patient’s umbilical hernia is reducible with only mild tenderness. Her symptoms and exam findings are more suggestive of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.
❌ Hepatorenal syndrome:
Incorrect: This patient has normal renal function and urinalysis and therefore does not have hepatorenal syndrome.
✅ Bacterial translocation from the gut:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man with alcohol-induced cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain and swelling. The patient reports increasing abdominal girth over the past two weeks and worsening abdominal pain for the past three days. He has not had any recent trauma, fevers, or changes in bowel habits. He mentions that he has been forgetting things for the past 2 days. He has no known allergies and takes no medication. Temperature is 37.0℃ (98.6℉), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, blood pressure is 122/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On examination, the abdomen is distended with a fluid wave and mild diffuse tenderness, without rebound or guarding. There is no jaundice or peripheral edema. A paracentesis is performed. Which of the following tests for the ascitic fluid would be most helpful for determining the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cirrhosis presents with abdominal distension and pain and has a fluid wave and abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. The most likely diagnosis is spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) and a diagnostic paracentesis should be performed. Cell count with differential showing polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) count ≥ 250 cells/μL with culture results showing a monomicrobial infection confirms the diagnosis SPB.  

SBP should be suspected in patients with cirrhosis and ascites who present with fever, abdominal pain, or altered mental status. The diagnosis of SBP is made with ascitic fluid analysis. The diagnostic paracentesis should be performed before antibiotics are started. An ascitic fluid polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) count ≥ 250 cells/μL indicates SBP, and empiric antibiotics should be started while culture results are pending. Culture results can be used to confirm the diagnosis and tailor antibiotics. The serum-ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) can be calculated to help determine the source of the ascites. A gradient ≥ 1.1 indicates that the actitic fluid is from portal hypertension.

Option Analysis

❌ Cytology:
Incorrect: While cytology can be useful for diagnosing malignant ascites, cytology is not typically part of the evaluation of the ascitic fluid when spontaneous bacterial peritonitis is suspected. The cell count with differential is the most helpful study for diagnosing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
❌ Glucose:
Incorrect: A low glucose level can be seen in secondary bacterial peritonitis (from an intraabdominal source of infection) or from tuberculous peritonitis. The glucose level is not used to diagnose spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The cell count with the differential showing a polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) count ≥ 250 cells/μL with culture results showing a monomicrobial infection confirms the diagnosis SPB. 
❌ Amylase:
Incorrect: Ascitic fluid amylase is measured when pancreatitis and pancreatic ascites are suspected. It is not used to diagnose spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The cell count with the differential showing a polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) count ≥ 250 cells/μL with culture results showing a monomicrobial infection confirms the diagnosis SPB. 
✅ Cell count with differential:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lactate dehydrogenase:
Incorrect: An elevated ascitic fluid LDH level can indicate secondary bacterial peritonitis (from an intraabdominal source of infection) or malignancy-related ascites. However, it is not a diagnostic test for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). The cell count with the differential showing a polymorphonuclear leukocyte (PMN) count ≥ 250 cells/μL with culture results showing a monomicrobial infection confirms the diagnosis SPB.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the college campus health clinic with a two-week history of dysuria, penile discharge, and posterior scrotal pain. He has no other symptoms. He has had five different female sexual partners in the past three months and no male sexual partners. He inconsistently uses condoms. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 124/85 mmHg. Genitourinary examination reveals thick, greenish-yellow, purulent urethral discharge. He does not have costovertebral tenderness or abdominopelvic tenderness. There is no joint pain or swelling. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Rash on the hands and feet

questions.solution:
This 20-year-old man with a history of multiple recent sexual partners presents with a two-week history of dysuria, purulent urethral discharge, and posterior scrotal pain. He has a combination of lower urinary symptoms (urethritis) and symptoms consistent with epididymitis which is most commonly caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection or chlamydial infection. Unilateral testicular swelling and tenderness would likely be seen on physical examination in patients with epididymitis from sexually transmitted infections.

Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause of urethritis. Biologically male patients with urethritis may present with dysuria and/or urethral discharge; however, many male patients with urethritis from N. gonorrhoeae are asymptomatic. Patients with acute epididymitis commonly present with acute scrotal pain, unilateral testicular swelling, and tenderness, and they may have painful ejaculations.

In biologically female patients, the most common site of infection with N. gonorrhoeae is the cervix. Most patients with cervicitis from N. gonorrhoeae are asymptomatic; however, symptoms may include mucopurulent vaginal discharge, vaginal pruritis, and vaginal spotting. Patients also may have urethritis which is also typically asymptomatic. Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can result from cervicitis secondary to N. gonorrhoeae infections which can lead to ectopic pregnancy, infertility, and chronic pelvic pain. Patients with PID typically present with pelvic/abdominal pain, abnormal vaginal bleeding, dyspareunia and cervical motion tenderness on exam.

Extragenital infection with N. gonorrhoeae can occur and can result in proctitis (most commonly in males who have sex with males), pharyngitis (in patients who have exposure from oral sex), and conjunctivitis. Disseminated infection can result in two syndromes: septic arthritis or the triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis and polyarthralgias.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Unilateral testicular swelling:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Rash on the hands and feet:
Incorrect: Dermatitis may be seen with disseminated gonococcal infection.  This patient has none of the other findings associated with disseminated gonococcal infection, which include arthralgias, arthritis, and tenosynovitis, making rash an unlikely finding.  
❌ Purulent ocular discharge:
Incorrect: Purulent ocular discharge, erythema of the conjunctiva, and swelling of the eyelids are findings associated with conjunctivitis from N. gonorrhoeae infection. This is an unlikely finding in this patient who has no ocular complaints.  
❌ Painful bowel movements:
Incorrect: Painful bowel movements and other rectal symptoms can be seen in patients with proctitis from N. gonorrhoeae. This complication of N. gonorrhoeae infection is most commonly seen in males who have sex with males, which is not the case for this patient.  
❌ Right upper quadrant pain:
Incorrect: Right upper quadrant pain can be seen with perihepatitis or Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome (FHCS), which is a severe complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) from N. gonorrhoeae seen almost exclusively in biologically female patients. FHCS in males is extremely rare.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of severe headaches, which are worse in the morning and have been ongoing for the past month. They are 8/10 in severity and throbbing in quality. She has also experienced associated nausea and vomiting. Moreover, her ability to concentrate has declined, and she has experienced word-finding difficulty. Vital signs are within normal limits. Strength and sensation are intact in the upper and lower extremities. An MRI scan of the brain is obtained, which reveals a multicentric, hemorrhagic tumor in the right temporal lobe. She is prescribed an oral glucocorticoid to decrease cerebral edema associated with the mass. Which of the following glucocorticoids has the most prolonged duration of action?
questions.solution:
Glucocorticoids can be classified according to their duration of action. Of the answer choices listed, dexamethasone has the longest course of action. It can be administered orally, intravenously, or via inhalation. It is often used to treat inflammation, acute exacerbations of multiple sclerosis, cerebral edema (as in this clinical vignette), shock, allergic conditions, and multiple myeloma. It is very potent and can cause marked suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis. For this reason, it is also used in the dexamethasone suppression test, which assists in diagnosing Cushing syndrome.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hydrocortisone:
Incorrect: Hydrocortisone is a short-acting glucocorticoid that can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. It has the lowest potency among glucocorticoids. It can systemically treat acute adrenal insufficiency and topically treat skin rashes.
❌ Prednisone:
Incorrect: Prednisone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
❌ Prednisolone:
Incorrect: Prednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders. Moreover, since prednisolone is the biologically active form of prednisone, it is often used in patients with liver disease who cannot convert prednisone to prednisolone.
❌ Methylprednisolone:
Incorrect: Methylprednisolone is one of the intermediate-acting glucocorticoids. The intermediate-acting glucocorticoids include prednisone, prednisolone, and methylprednisolone. These can be given orally, intravenously, or intramuscularly. They are of intermediate potency and can be used to treat inflammatory conditions such as asthma and autoimmune disorders.
✅ Dexamethasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the clinic with voluminous watery diarrhea for the past five days. The patient has been unable to go to work since he has frequent urges to defecate and multiple bowel movements daily. He has also experienced nausea, bloating, and abdominal cramps. There has been no blood in the patient’s stool. He recently returned from a trip to Mexico. Vital signs are within normal limits. He is diagnosed with traveler’s diarrhea caused by Escherichia coli and is started on a three-day course of ciprofloxacin. Which of the following adverse effects is this patient at risk of developing?
questions.solution:
This patient was prescribed ciprofloxacin to treat traveler’s diarrhea caused by Escherichia coli.   

Fluoroquinolones are a class of bactericidal antibiotics that inhibit prokaryotic topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV. They are used in treating infections by Gram-negative rods in the urinary and gastrointestinal tracts, Pseudomonas, and some Gram-positive bacteria.    

Fluoroquinolones can cause tendon rupture and tendonitis, especially in individuals over 60 years old or those concurrently taking prednisone. The Achilles tendon is often affected, and patients can develop pain, swelling, or inflammation of the involved tendon. These side effects can develop anytime during treatment and up to six months post-treatment. Given this risk, fluoroquinolones should be avoided in athletes. Should tendon rupture or tendonitis develop, the fluoroquinolone should be discontinued, and the patient is switched to a different antibiotic.    

Moreover, fluoroquinolones are associated with gastrointestinal upset, rashes, headache, and dizziness. They can also cause cartilage damage. As a result, fluoroquinolones are contraindicated for use in pregnant women, nursing mothers, and children under 18 years old. Finally, they can cause QT prolongation, and ciprofloxacin, in particular, can inhibit cytochrome P450.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute cholestatic hepatitis:
Incorrect: This side effect concerns using macrolide antibiotics such as erythromycin. Acute cholestatic hepatitis may present with or without jaundice. It will resolve with medication withdrawal and does not lead to chronic liver disease. Acute cholestatic hepatitis is not associated with the use of fluoroquinolones. 
✅ Tendon rupture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Agranulocytosis:
Incorrect: This side effect is associated with medications such as clozapine, dapsone, and ganciclovir. Complete blood counts should be monitored regularly in patients taking these medications. Agranulocytosis is not associated with fluoroquinolones. 
❌ Drug-induced lupus:
Incorrect: This side effect is a concern with the use of minocycline. It is associated with the development of anti-histone antibodies. Patients with minocycline-induced lupus will present with fever, arthritis, rash, pneumonitis, and vasculitis. In contrast, fluoroquinolones are not associated with drug-induced lupus. 
❌ Interstitial nephritis:
Incorrect: This side effect is associated with using antibiotics such as penicillins, cephalosporins, rifampin, and sulfa drugs. It is not associated with fluoroquinolone use.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his son after being unresponsive on his bedroom floor with an empty pill bottle beside him. Past medical history is significant for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and major depressive disorder. His temperature is 37.7°C (100F), pulse is 35/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals cold and clammy extremities. Cardiopulmonary examination demonstrates bilateral wheezing. An ECG strip is shown below. Atropine and intravenous fluids are administered. After administering 3 mg atropine, Reevaluation shows no improvement in blood pressure and ECG. In addition to oxygenation, which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hypotension, first-degree heart block, and bilateral wheezing consistent with beta-blocker toxicity. Overdose of calcium channel blockers, digoxin, and cholinergic agents can present similar symptoms, but wheezing is atypical.    

Beta-adrenergic–blocking agents are widely used to treat hypertension, arrhythmias, angina pectoris, heart failure, migraine, and glaucoma. Presentation of beta-blocker toxicity can be divided into:  
  •  Cardiac disturbances: first-degree heart block, hypotension, and bradycardia 
  •  Central nervous system toxicity: convulsions, coma, and respiratory arrest 
  •  Bronchospasm 
  •  Hypoglycemia and hyperkalemia 

Management includes administration of isotonic fluid boluses and atropine to treat hypotension and bradycardia. Resistant or profound hypotension and bradycardia require the administration of glucagon.  This medication increases intracellular cAMP and has effectively treated both beta and calcium channel blocker toxicity. Other therapies include epinephrine, high-dose insulin with glucose, and IV lipid emulsion therapy.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.  

Option Analysis

❌ Digoxin-specific antibody:
Incorrect: Digoxin-specific antibody serves as the antidote for digoxin toxicity which presents with fatigue, anorexia, nausea, blurred vision, disturbed color perception, and cardiac arrhythmias. Wheezing is atypical.
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone serves as the antidote for opioid overdose, which presents with depressed mental status, decreased respiratory rate, and bradycardia. 
❌ Methylene blue:
Incorrect: Methylene blue is the antidote for methemoglobinemia, usually caused by nitrites, dapsone, or benzocaine. The severity of symptoms depends on the percentage of hemoglobin oxidized to methemoglobin. It can present with dizziness, nausea, headache, dyspnea, and confusion. Hypotension and first-degree AV block are atypical. 
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Membrane-depressant effects (wide QRS interval) may respond to boluses of sodium bicarbonate for tricyclic antidepressant poisoning. This patient’s ECG is suggestive of first-degree AV block.
✅ Glucagon:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician with a fever and sore throat. The patient’s symptoms started two days ago. She was diagnosed with a partial seizure last month and was started on anti-epileptic medication. Temperature is 38°C (100.4 °F), blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, and pulse is 89 beats per minute. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following medications is this patient most likely taking?

 Erythrocyte count   5 million (cells/mcL) 
 Hemoglobin   13 (g/dL) 
 Mean corpuscular volume   80 (fL) 
 Leukocyte count   1500 (cells/mm3) 
 Absolute Neutrophil count   80 (cells/mm3) 
 Platelets count   200,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a fever, sore throat, and low absolute neutrophil count, indicative of agranulocytosis. This patient’s agranulocytosis likely resulted from the use of carbamazepine.  Other common side effects of carbamazepine include diplopia, ataxia, and stevens-johnson syndrome. Side effects of associated anti-epileptic medications are listed in the chart detailed below.



Option Analysis

✅ Carbamazepine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lamotrigine :
Incorrect: Lamotrigine’s side-effect profile include Stevens-Johnson syndrome and hemophagocytic  lymphohistiocytosis. Lamotrigine is not associated with agranulocytosis.   
❌ Levetiracetam :
Incorrect: Common side effects of levetiracetam include neuropsychiatric manifestations, headache, and drowsiness. Agranulocytosis is not associated with the use of this medication. 
❌ Gabapentin :
Incorrect: Gabapentin use can lead to sedation and ataxia, but it is not associated with agranulocytosis. 
❌ Vigabatrin :
Incorrect: Vigabatrin’s side effects include permanent vision loss but not agranulocytosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the clinic for evaluation of a chronic cough. The cough is non-productive and associated with dyspnea and fatigue. He denies fever, hemoptysis, or chest pain. His medical history included a hematopoietic stem cell transplant for acute myelogenous leukemia eight months ago. He received busulfan as a part of a conditioning regimen before the transplant. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 90%. There is no lower extremity edema. JVP is 3 cm of H20. Pulmonary examination reveals bibasilar rales. CT of the chest with contrast shows ground glass opacities in lower lung lobes. Pulmonary function testing shows a reduction in the diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide. Which of the following describes the mechanism of action of the agent responsible for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Induction of free radical formation and DNA damage
Purine analog that inhibits DNA polymerase

questions.solution:
This patient presents symptoms of a non-productive cough, dyspnea, and evidence of ground glass opacities on CT with a history of busulfan use. These findings are consistent with pulmonary fibrosis secondary to busulfan.    

Patients who undergo hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) can experience pulmonary toxicity from various etiologies, including post-transplant infections (e.g. CMV), heart failure, pulmonary thromboembolism, graft versus host disease, secondary malignancy, and antineoplastic therapy.    

Busulfan is primarily used as a myeloablative procedure as part of the conditioning regimen in preparation for an HSCT. Busulfan is an alkylating agent that induces DNA damage by creating interstrand cross-links.    

Patients with busulfan toxicity commonly present with a nonproductive cough and progressive dyspnea on exertion. This may accompany a low-grade fever, fatigue, and weight loss. In most cases, patients present with symptoms within one-year post-transplant. A restrictive pulmonary function pattern with a reduced DLCO, interstitial infiltrates, and ground glass opacities on CT scans are common. Other adverse effects caused by busulfan include severe myelosuppression and hyperpigmentation (busulfan tan).  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Induction of free radical formation and DNA damage :
Incorrect:  Bleomycin is an antitumor antibiotic that causes DNA damage by inducing free radical damage. Pulmonary fibrosis is one of the known adverse effects of bleomycin. This patient received busulfan. 
❌ Folate antagonist :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that inhibits tetrahydrofolate reductase. Methotrexate can cause lung injury with chronic low-dose therapy. This patient has not received methotrexate. 
✅ Cross-links DNA:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Inhibition of thymidylate synthase :
Incorrect: 5- fluorouracil inhibits thymidylate synthase and the conversion of dUMP to dTMP. Adverse effects include myelosuppression, diarrhea, and photosensitivity. 
❌ Purine analog that inhibits DNA polymerase :
Incorrect: Cladribine is a purine analog and an antimetabolite. It is active during the S phase of the cell cycle and inhibits DNA polymerase. Adverse effects include myelosuppression, nephrotoxicity, and neurotoxicity.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency room with incoherent speech. He is accompanied by his spouse, who states the patient has had a headache for two weeks and that he appeared confused this morning. His medical history includes atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and diabetes. His current medications include warfarin, lisinopril, and metformin. Family history is noncontributory. He returned from a trip to India a month ago. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 115/75 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Extraocular movements are within normal limits. His speech is intangible, but he can pick up a pen and copy a picture of a matchstick when prompted. Axial MRI scan reveals a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum. Following a biopsy, he is initiated on procarbazine, lomustine, and vincristine regimen. Which of the following adverse effects can be expected in this patient?

choices.text: Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination
Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction
Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor

questions.solution:
This patient presents with expressive motor aphasia, chronic headache, and an MRI revealing a butterfly-shaped intracranial mass crossing the corpus callosum consistent with glioblastoma multiforme.  

Procarbazine is a non-cell, cycle-specific alkylating agent indicated in treating Hodgkin lymphoma, glioblastoma multiforme, and other brain tumors. Its mechanism of action is not well defined. Myelosuppression is the most common, acute, dose-limiting toxicity of this agent. Resultant effects include depression of all cell lineages resulting in pallor secondary to anemia, bacterial infections due to leukopenia, and bleeding from mucous membranes due to thrombocytopenia. Granulocyte stimulating factors such as filgrastim are commonly administered in case of bone marrow suppression. Other adverse effects of procarbazine include pulmonary toxicity and secondary leukemia. Procarbazine has also been shown to induce mild reversible encephalopathy and neuropathy. 

Option Analysis

❌ Progressive dyspnea on exertion, S3 on cardiac examination:
Incorrect: These symptoms indicate a presentation suggestive of dilated cardiomyopathy. Cardiotoxicity is anticipated with the administration of doxorubicin and daunorubicin.
❌ Asymptomatic decrease in left ventricular ejection fraction:
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody instrumental in treating HER2-positive breast cancers. Reversible cardiotoxicity is a known complication of its use and manifests as a reduction in left ventricular ejection fraction. 
❌ Transaminitis :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can cause hepatotoxicity at all doses. Patients may present with transaminitis or fibrosis. Hepatotoxicity is not associated with procarbazine, vincristine, or lomustine use. 
✅ Bleeding from the gums, fever, and pallor :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Infertility :
Incorrect: Alkylating agents like cyclophosphamide are known to exert long-term effects on male and female fertility. Women on cyclophosphamide experience premature menopause and infertility, while men may have a reduction in sperm count. Infertility is not a known adverse effect of procarbazine, lomustine, or vincristine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the clinic to evaluate intermittent palpitations and lightheadedness since last night. He does not report syncope, chest pain, nausea, or vomiting. His past medical history includes asthma and GERD. Current medications include inhaled glucocorticoids and ranitidine. He drinks 4-5 beers and 4 cups of coffee daily. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. His father died at the age of 50 due to a cardiac condition. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 23/min, blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg, and SpO2 of 96%. Cardiopulmonary auscultation is otherwise unremarkable. Lead II telemetry is shown below. Vagal maneuvers are trialed, and IV adenosine is administered without termination of the arrhythmia. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as evidenced by both symptoms and ECG findings that include rapid, narrow, complex, regular tachycardia without discernable p-waves.

Verapamil and diltiazem are treatment options for paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia when refractory to vagal maneuvers or adenosine.
 


Pacemaker tissue depends on calcium currents to generate action potentials. Verapamil and diltiazem inhibit L-type calcium channels in pacemaker tissue, prolonging the effective refractory period of the AV node and slowing down the transmission of the electrical impulse through the AV node. Therefore, they are useful in treating supraventricular tachyarrhythmias dependent on conduction through the AV node.
 

In the presence of unstable vital signs, direct cardioversion is the preferred treatment of choice for PSVT.  The other indications for class IV antiarrhythmics include rate control for atrial fibrillation and atrial flutter, management of chronic stable angina, as well as multifocal atrial tachycardia.  

Option Analysis

❌ Lidocaine:
Incorrect: Lidocaine is a class Ib antiarrhythmic agent that blocks inactivated sodium channels. It is indicated in treating ventricular arrhythmias (wide complex), particularly those originating from ischemic tissue.  
✅ Diltiazem:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Direct cardioversion:
Incorrect: Direct cardioversion is indicated in hemodynamically unstable patients (hypotension, loss of consciousness, heart failure, altered mental status). In this patient with stable vital signs, an AV nodal blocking agent such as diltiazem would be the best next step in management.  
❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: In this patient with a history of asthma, administering nonselective beta-blockers could induce bronchospasm.  
❌ Ibutilide:
Incorrect: Ibutilide is a class III antiarrhythmic and a beta blocker. It is no longer recommended for the treatment of atrial flutter and fibrillation. It is not a treatment of choice for PSVT.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion. He is accompanied by his spouse, who states that he has appeared confused and lethargic since this morning. Since then, he has had three episodes of vomiting. He has also reported ýellow tinted vision. His medical history includes chronic systolic heart failure and hypertension. His current medications include hydrochlorothiazide, lisinopril, spironolactone, digoxin and metoprolol.  He was hospitalized two days ago for an episode of atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response, which was treated with metoprolol and an amiodarone drip. He does not smoke or use recreational drugs. He consumes 2-3 beers on the weekends. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 45/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 95/85 mmHg. Mucous membranes are moist. Fingerstick glucose is 110 mg/dL. ECG is shown below. Which of the following additional findings would you expect to find in the laboratory evaluation of this patient?
 
 By Jer5150 - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0,  Reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This patient presents gastrointestinal symptoms, vision abnormalities, altered mental status, and a history of digoxin intake. These findings, coupled with recent amiodarone administration, are consistent with acute digoxin toxicity. Medications like amiodarone, verapamil, quinidine, and spironolactone can induce digoxin toxicity by reducing the renal filtration of digoxin.
 

Arrhythmias are the most dangerous manifestation of acute digoxin toxicity. They may include atrial tachycardia with AV block, premature ventricular contractions, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation, complete heart block, Mobitz type II heart block, symptomatic bradycardia, and asystole.
 

Electrolyte imbalances often accompany digitalis toxicity as this medication inhibits the sodium potassium channel of cardiac myocytes. Hyperkalemia is the most commonly encountered electrolyte abnormality and is a significant predictor of mortality.

Acute management of digitalis toxicity involves the administration of antibody fragments that bind to and eliminate digoxin. If antibody fragments are not immediately available, atropine or temporary transvenous pacing can be used to treat symptomatic bradycardia.

Due to its vagomimetic actions, digoxin is considered an option for rate control in atrial arrhythmias. However, it is not the first line agent for atrial arrhythmias owing to its low therapeutic window and adverse cardiac effects.  Digoxin is an effective treatment of atrial fibrillation in patients with concomitant heart failure or hypotension due to its added inotropic actions and its negative chronotropic effects.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hypokalemia is a concern in the setting of chronic digoxin toxicity. Acute digitalis toxicity is more commonly associated with hyperkalemia due to sodium-potassium channel blockade.  
❌ Hypoglycemia:
Incorrect: Hypoglycemia can manifest with neuroglycopenic symptoms (confusion, altered mental status, dizziness) and autonomic symptoms (tremors, palpitations, diaphoresis). Complete heart block is not commonly encountered. Normal fingerstick glucose makes hypoglycemia unlikely.  
❌ Hyponatremia:
Incorrect: Symptoms of hyponatremia include headache, confusion, malaise, coma, and seizures. Complete heart block, visual abnormalities, and gastrointestinal disturbances indicate digitalis toxicity.  
✅ Hyperkalemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Wide anion metabolic acidosis:
Incorrect: A wide anion gap metabolic acidosis is encountered with ethylene glycol, ethanol, and salicylate poisoning. Although these toxidromes can present with gastrointestinal and neurologic disturbances, complete heart block makes digoxin toxicity a more likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion, dizziness and blurred vision. The patient’s medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder, and she does not take medication. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), heart rate is 108/min, respiratory rate is 24/min, blood pressure is 120/72 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, there are decreased breath sounds in the lungs bilaterally with no crackles or wheezes. Neurological examination is significant for decreased visual acuity and nystagmus. The patient’s laboratory studies are shown below. Based on the patient's presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following conditions should be included in the differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient’s laboratory studies reveal a non-compensated metabolic acidosis (low pH and bicarbonate, relatively normal PaCO2) with a high anion gap. Of the answer choices provided, only methanol intoxication would result in these laboratory findings.

Metabolic acidosis is a clinical disturbance characterized by a reduced blood pH (< 7.35) and decreased serum bicarbonate (HCO3-) level. This may or may not be associated with a compensatory decrease in partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PaCO2) due to increased respiratory rate as the body attempts to restore acid-base balance. An essential step in the evaluation of metabolic acidosis is calculating the anion gap, which is the difference between the primary measured cations (sodium) and the primary measured anions (chloride and bicarbonate). The anion gap is calculated using the formula: Na+ - Cl- - HCO3-. A normal anion gap is typically between 8 and 12 mEq/L.

An increased anion gap metabolic acidosis indicates the presence of unmeasured anions and is often due to the accumulation of organic acids. The mnemonic "MUDPILES" is a useful tool to remember the common causes of high anion gap metabolic acidosis. Identifying whether metabolic acidosis is a high anion gap or a normal anion gap is crucial in narrowing the differential diagnosis and guiding further clinical investigation and management.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Methanol intoxication:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Acetazolamide use:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide use can result in a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis via excess bicarbonate loss in urine. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: Diarrhea can cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis via excess bicarbonate loss in stool. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Renal tubular acidosis:
Incorrect: Renal tubular acidosis can cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.  
❌ Addison disease:
Incorrect: Addison disease, or primary adrenal insufficiency, can cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, this patient’s laboratory studies are consistent with a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman presents to the office for a routine visit. She is feeling well and is asymptomatic. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus. She takes metformin daily. Family history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and myocardial infarction in the patient’s father—review of systems is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Body mass index is 33 kg/m2. Physical examination is unremarkable. A lipid profile is obtained and the results are shown below. The patient is started on simvastatin. Which of the following best describes the effects of simvastatin on serum low-density lipoprotein, high-density lipoprotein, and triglyceride levels?  

Laboratory Value
Results
Total cholesterol
325 mg/dL
Low-density lipoproteins (LDL)
195 mg/dL
High-density lipoprotein (HDL)
35 mg/dL
Triglyceride (TG)
100 mg/dL
questions.solution:
This patient’s lipid profile exhibits elevated serum cholesterol and LDL levels. Statins, a class of lipid-lowering drugs, are the first-line agent in such cases since they significantly decrease LDL levels, increase HDL levels, and improve cardiovascular mortality.

Statins competitively inhibit the enzyme HMG-CoA reductase, which normally converts HMG-CoA to mevalonate (a cholesterol precursor). In turn, there is a decrease in hepatic cholesterol synthesis and an increase in LDL recycling via the up-regulation of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. The LDL receptors not only increase the uptake of LDL-cholesterol but also increase the uptake of VLDLs (the major carrier of TG) to a smaller extent, resulting in a moderate decrease in triglyceride levels. Furthermore, the liver increases its production of HDLs, which carry cholesterol back from the peripheral tissues to the liver.

The net effect is a significant reduction in LDL levels, a modest decrease in TG levels, and a modest increase in HDL levels.  

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ :
Incorrect: Bile acid resins (e.g. cholestyramine) tend to decrease LDL cholesterol by preventing bile acid reabsorption in the intestine. Bile acid resins also slightly increase HDL and triglyceride levels. In contrast, this patient was prescribed a statin.   
❌ :
Incorrect: These changes are observed with fish oil and marine omega-3 fatty acids. Such medications decrease the transport of free fatty acids to the liver and inhibit the activity of TG-synthesizing enzymes. They also slightly increase LDL levels. In contrast, this patient was prescribed a statin.   
❌ :
Incorrect: A major reduction in TG is seen with the use of fibrates. Fibrates act by upregulating lipoprotein lipase, increasing the clearance of serum triglycerides. This class of medication also activates PPAR-α to induce HDL synthesis.   
❌ :
Incorrect: This patient was started on a statin. Statins increase, as opposed to decrease, serum HDL levels.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for a routine visit. He is asymptomatic. He has a past medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus which is controlled by metformin. The patient eats a well-balanced diet consisting of vegetables, fruits, and fish. He engages in 90 minutes of physical exercise weekly. He does not smoke. The patient’s parent has diabetes mellitus. Temperature is 37 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 65/min, blood pressure is 124/76 mmHg, and respiratory rate is 13/min. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are shown below. Hemoglobin A1c is 6.2%. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Lipid panel

Total cholesterol
210 mg/dL (6.24 mmol/L)
HDL cholesterol
62 mg/dL (2.56 mmol/L)
LDL cholesterol
142 mg/dL (3.00 mmol/L)
Triglycerides
124 mg/dL (1.45 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
Diabetes mellitus significantly increases the risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, and statins effectively reduce this risk by lowering LDL cholesterol. For patients with diabetes who are ≥40 years of age and have an LDL-C <190 mg/Dl, a moderate intensity statin is recommended.

All patients with LDL-C ≥190 mg/dL should be treated with high-intensity statin therapy. The American Heart Association (AHA)/American College of Cardiology (ACC) guidelines on management of cholesterol and the American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommendations include starting a moderate-intensity statin for adults aged 40 to 75 years with diabetes mellitus, regardless of the calculated atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) risk. Despite the patient's healthy lifestyle, his type 2 diabetes places him at increased risk for ASCVD and is an indication for starting moderate-intensity statin therapy.  

Option Analysis

❌ Insulin therapy:
Incorrect: Insulin therapy is typically necessary for patients with uncontrolled diabetes. However, this patient’s diabetes is currently controlled with metformin and his HgA1C is within goal.  
❌ Calculate ASCVD risk assessment score:
Incorrect: Regardless of this patient’s calculated ASCVD risk, he should be started on moderate-intensity statin therapy since he has diabetes.  
❌ Omega-3 fatty acid supplementation:
Incorrect: Initiating omega-3 fatty acid supplements can be considered for patients with lipid abnormalities. However, it is not the primary intervention for lowering LDL-C and reducing cardiovascular risk in patients with diabetes.  
✅ Moderate-intensity statin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gemfibrozil:
Incorrect: Gemfibrozil, a fibrate, is not the primary treatment for reducing LDL-C cholesterol and lowering cardiovascular risk in patients with diabetes. Gemfibrozil can pose increased risks when used with statins, particularly in patients without severe hypertriglyceridemia.

questions.text:
A 61-year-old man presents to the primary care clinic to follow up after a recent urgent care visit where he was diagnosed with bacterial pneumonia. This is the third occurrence of bacterial pneumonia within the past year. Over the past few months, he has also been experiencing easy bruising and significant fatigue. Past medical history is significant for dyslipidemia and hypertension. Current medications include atorvastatin, cefpodoxime, doxycycline, and losartan. Vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, the patient is pale with conjunctival pallor and diffuse scattered petechiae and ecchymoses. Bloodwork is obtained, and the results are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory Test
Result
Sodium
141 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL
Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL
Calcium
9.1 mg/dL
White blood cells
3400/mm3
Hemoglobin
7.9 g/dL
Platelets
59,000/mm3
questions.solution:
This patient presents with fatigue, recurrent bacterial infections, and easy bruising. Complete blood count shows pancytopenia. Given this patient’s age and pancytopenia, myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) should be suspected. A bone marrow biopsy is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out other causes.

Patients presenting with cytopenias should be evaluated for secondary causes, such as nutritional deficiencies, consumptive processes, chronic diseases, or medication side effects. Anemia may be caused by iron deficiency, splenic sequestration, hemolysis, or chronic disease. Thrombocytopenia may be caused by certain medications or cirrhosis. Neutropenia may result from the use of certain medications or from HIV infection. Peripheral blood smear can provide evidence of abnormal or dysplastic cells in patients with MDS. A bone marrow biopsy is essential for making the diagnosis. It can assess which cell lineages are dysplastic and low and to what degree, evaluate for hypercellularity or hypocellularity, and for the presence of blasts. It can also provide a sample for cytogenetic analysis. This information is critical for classifying the disease and determining the optimal treatment strategy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Bone marrow biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Peripheral blood cytology:
Incorrect: While peripheral blood cytology can aid in diagnosing myelodysplastic syndromes and leukemia, bone marrow biopsy is used to confirm the diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).  
❌ Platelet function assay:
Incorrect: This test can be useful in patients with unexplained bleeding and/or thrombocytopenia, particularly if there is a high suspicion for a platelet disorder (e.g. Bernard-Soulier syndrome, Glanzmann thrombasthenia). However, this patient’s pancytopenia is not likely explained by a platelet-specific disorder and bone marrow biopsy should be performed.  
❌ Serum human leukocyte antigen (HLA) typing:
Incorrect: HLA typing is important in certain circumstances, such as when patients are receiving or donating bone marrow for bone marrow transplants. This patient does not yet have a confirmed diagnosis, so this test is not necessary at this time, and bone marrow biopsy is needed to make the diagnosis of myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).  
❌ Urine protein electrophoresis:
Incorrect: This test would be appropriate if multiple myeloma were suspected. This patient has pancytopenia but normal calcium and renal function, making multiple myeloma less likely. This patient likely has myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS) and requires bone marrow biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents to the primary care office due to 6 weeks of joint pain in both hands. She has joint stiffness lasting 1 hour in the mornings and the pain and stiffness worsens with prolonged inactivity. The patient has also recently developed fatigue and malaise, but she has no fever or weight loss. She has no past medical history and does not take any medication. She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational substances and is not currently sexually active. She works as a high school principal. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, multiple proximal interphalangeal joints and metacarpophalangeal joints of both hands are edematous and tender to palpation. She has pain when she moves them and her grip is weak, secondary to pain. Initial complete blood work and basic metabolic panel are normal. Which of the following is most likely to be positive and confirm the underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 52-year-old patient presents with 6 weeks of polyarticular arthritis affecting the small joints of the hands bilaterally and is associated with morning stiffness and fatigue. Given the finding of synovitis of the hands and no other signs to indicate other autoimmune conditions or septic arthritis, the most likely diagnosis is RA, and a positive rheumatoid (RF) can help make the diagnosis.

Patients with rheumatoid arthritis typically present with symmetric inflammatory polyarthritis involving the peripheral joints, most often the hands and feet. They may also have constitutional symptoms like weight loss, fatigue, and malaise. Patients typically experience prolonged joint stiffness (> 30 minutes) in the morning or after prolonged inactivity, which is a hallmark of inflammatory arthritis. On physical examination, patients will have symmetric small joint swelling and synovitis involving the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints, and metatarsophalangeal joints. Boutonniere deformities ( finger flexed at the proximal interphalangeal joint (PIP) and hyperextended at the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP)) and swan-neck deformities (proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint hyperextension and flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint may be seen with long-standing diseases. Elevations of ESR and CRP are typically seen and can be used to monitor disease activity. Imaging can show erosions in chronic or severe disease. The presence of rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-CCP (anti-citrullinated peptide) antibodies can help make the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rheumatoid factor:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gonorrheal nucleic acid amplification testing:
Incorrect: This test can help in evaluating for disseminated gonococcal infection, which is unlikely in this patient who is not sexually active. Patients with disseminated gonococcal infection typically present with a vesiculopustular rash, migratory arthralgias, tenosynovitis, and arthritis.  
❌ Antinuclear antibody:
Incorrect: An antinuclear antibody (ANA) test should be ordered initially when SLE is suspected. Besides arthritis, this patient has none of the other features associated with SLE, such as malar rash, photosensitivity, alopecia, oral ulcers, and cytopenias.  
❌ Parvovirus B19 serology:
Incorrect: Adults with parvovirus can present with acute polyarthritis involving the bilateral hands. Parvovirus B19 may affect adults who have close contact with young children (e.g. daycare, and preschool teachers) where it can cause, fifth disease with the classic slapped cheek facial rash. This patient works with older children and has a more chronic cause of her arthritis.  
❌ Arthrocentesis:
Incorrect: Arthrocentesis should be performed when there is monoarticular arthritis to rule out septic arthritis, and it can help with diagnosing crystal arthritis. This patient with a subacute or chronic symmetric polyarthritis of the hands is more likely to have RA.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for evaluation of a painful rash that developed one day prior. The patient reports preceding symptoms of fever, malaise, and nausea. The rash began on her chest and face but now also involves the back and both arms, and she has new lesions in her mouth. The patient was started on sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim two weeks ago for treatment of a urinary tract infection. The patient has a past medical history of HIV and is currently on antiretroviral therapy. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 102/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is bilateral conjunctival erythema. There are multiple ulcerative lesions in the oropharynx. Skin exam shows multiple areas of dusky erythema, purpura, target lesions, and flaccid bullae overlying her arms, chest, and back. Once the patient is stabilized, which of the following is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge with primary care follow-up in two days

questions.solution:
This patient with a history of HIV presents with an extensive rash with mucocutaneous involvement and hemodynamic instability after being started on sulfamethoxazole. The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Patients with HIV are at increased risk of developing SJS/TEN. Patients with these conditions should be treated in an intensive care unit (ICU) and/or burn center.    

SJS and TEN are rare immune-mediated mucocutaneous conditions characterized by widespread blistering and sloughing of the skin. The exact cause of these conditions is not fully understood, but it is thought to involve type 4 hypersensitivity against certain antigens, including certain medications and pathogens. Frequently implicated drugs include anticonvulsants, sulfasalazine, sulfamethoxazole (as seen in this patient), allopurinol, and nevirapine.  

Many patients with SJS/TEN are critically ill and require stabilization of the airway, breathing, and circulation. The remainder of acute care includes wound care, fluid and electrolyte management, nutritional support, temperature management, pain control, and infection prevention along with surgical consultation. Due to extensive skin sloughing, these patients are at high risk for significant volume losses and temperature dysregulation, and they should receive appropriate fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion. Exposed tissue from skin sloughing predisposes them to infection, and they should receive appropriate biological dressings. Importantly, these patients should have their medication list examined and potential causative medications should be immediately discontinued. 

Option Analysis

✅ Transfer to a burn center :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Discharge on oral antibiotics:
Incorrect: Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are severe, potentially life-threatening conditions that require inpatient treatment, often in a specialized burn unit or burn center due to the risk of significant dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, infection, and other complications. Outpatient management with oral antibiotics would be inadequate.
❌ Admit to the medical floor:
Incorrect: Patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) should not be admitted to the general medical floor. These patients are at high risk for developing secondary infections, multi-organ failure, and critical illness. They should be admitted to an intensive care unit and/or burn center.
❌ Admit for 24-hour observation:
Incorrect: Patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are not appropriate candidates for 24-hour observation. These patients are at high risk of developing secondary infections, multi-organ failure, and critical illness.They should be admitted to an intensive care unit and/or burn center.
❌ Discharge with primary care follow-up in two days:
Incorrect: Patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are not appropriate candidates for discharge with primary care follow-up. These patients are at high risk of developing secondary infections, multi-organ failure, and critical illness. They should be admitted to an intensive care unit and/or burn center.

questions.text:
An 87-year-old woman presents to the emergency department from an assisted living facility for evaluation of a rash. The patient’s nurse from the facility reports the patient has had flu-like symptoms for the past two days and that today she noticed a desquamating truncal rash that progressed to involve all extremities. The patient has a past medical history of Alzheimer dementia, hypertension, diabetes, and recurrent urinary tract infections. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. Three weeks ago, she was treated with sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim after she developed a urinary tract infection that was resistant to ciprofloxacin. Temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), blood pressure is 97/60 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 94% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears ill and is unable to provide further clinical history. She has conjunctival erythema and oral lesions. Skin examination is notable for the findings shown below. Which of the following tests will lead to a definitive diagnosis?


 Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with prodromal symptoms, a desquamating rash, conjunctival erythema, and oral lesions following the initiation of sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim. The most likely diagnosis is Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) caused by sulfamethoxazole. While largely a clinical diagnosis, definitive diagnosis can be achieved via skin biopsy, which will reveal full-thickness necrolysis and separation of the epidermis at the dermo-epidermal junction.
