Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN) are rare immune-mediated mucocutaneous conditions characterized by widespread blistering and sloughing. Stevens-Johnson syndrome is diagnosed when the percent of body surface area affected is less than 10%. TEN is diagnosed when the percent of body surface area affected is more than 30%. SJS/TEN overlap is diagnosed when 10% to 30% of the body surface area is affected. The Wallace rule of nines can be used to estimate the amount of body surface area affected.  

Workup for patients with SJS/TEN should include a complete blood count (CBC), comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP), c-reactive protein (CRP), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), as well as blood cultures and a skin biopsy. Typically, patients demonstrate elevations in the white blood cell count and inflammatory markers, and they may have positive blood cultures if there is associated infection. The CMP may reveal electrolyte imbalances and elevated BUN and creatinine. CT chest imaging should also be considered for patients with pulmonary symptoms to assess for associated pneumonitis. Skin biopsy can rule out other conditions in the differential diagnosis, such as erythema multiforme, exanthematous drug eruptions, or staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome.  



Option Analysis

✅ Skin biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Antinuclear antibodies:
Incorrect: Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are associated with multiple immune mediated conditions. A positive ANA does not help to diagnose Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) chest:
Incorrect: A CT chest may reveal evidence of pneumonitis, suggestive of severe disease from Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). However, this does not definitively diagnose SJS/TEN. 
❌ Tzanck smear:
Incorrect: A tzank smear can be used to diagnose varicella-zoster or herpes simplex virus. Skin biopsy is the definitive diagnostic modality for patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)
❌ Lumbar puncture:
Incorrect: A lumbar puncture may be useful for diagnosing associated meningitis in patients with Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS)/toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN); however, it is not used to diagnose this condition. Skin biopsy is the definitive diagnostic modality for patients with SJS/TEN.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for an annual visit. Over the past year, the patient has unintentionally lost 15 lb. (kg). On her last visit last year, she weighed 151 lb., and she now weighs 136 lb. (kg). For the past few months, she has had palpitations and diarrhea. She has not had difficulty swallowing, abdominal pain, bloating, nausea, night sweats, or fever. She has no known medical history and takes no medication. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 106/min and regular, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 142/90 mmHg. There is no abdominal tenderness to palpation. Proximal muscle strength is 4 out of 5 in the upper and lower extremities bilaterally; distal extremities show 5/5 strength. Which of the following diagnostic tests would most likely confirm the underlying cause of this patient’s weight loss?

choices.text: Complete metabolic panel and iron studies

questions.solution:
This patient presents with unintentional weight loss, palpitations, and diarrhea. Physical examination is significant for tachycardia and proximal muscle weakness. Thyroid studies will show hyperthyroidism from Graves' disease as the cause of this patient’s unintentional weight loss.   

Underlying medical conditions can be a cause of unintentional weight loss. They can lead to increased metabolic demand, impaired caloric intake, or impaired absorption.    

Patients can have gastrointestinal causes of unintentional weight loss. If dysphagia, nausea, or early satiety are present, then upper endoscopy with biopsy may be ordered to further evaluate. If bloating and diarrhea are the most prominent symptoms, then patients may have malabsorption and should have a metabolic panel, iron studies, vitamin B12 level, celiac disease autoantibodies checked, and possible upper endoscopy with biopsy. Patients with dysphagia, oral pain, or poorly fitting dentures may require a swallow study and evaluation by a speech-language pathologist.    

Malignancy can be suspected as the cause of unintentional weight loss in patients with fever, night sweats, lymphadenopathy, or a newly palpable or visualized mass. Further workups may include a biopsy of a mass or the bone marrow, and other studies. Autoimmune diseases should be suspected in patients with persistent fever, rash, and/or joint pain and swelling. The workup may include serum autoantibody testing, imaging, or tissue biopsy. Advanced heart or lung disease and chronic infection can also lead to unintentional weight loss and should be worked up as appropriate for the condition. Endocrinologic conditions such as diabetes mellitus (e.g., polydipsia, polyuria) or hyperthyroidism (e.g., frequent bowel movements, heat intolerance, palpitations) should be assessed by testing hemoglobin A1c and thyroid studies (TSH, free T4), respectively.   

Option Analysis

✅ Thyroid studies :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy, or esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD), is useful for evaluating weight loss in patients with suspected gastrointestinal causes. This patient’s signs and symptoms are more suggestive of hyperthyroidism. 
❌ Bone marrow biopsy:
Incorrect: Bone marrow biopsy may be warranted in patients with unintentional weight loss and features concerning malignancy. This patient does not yet have a complete blood count, which would be needed first to determine if there is an indication for bone marrow biopsy. Thyroid studies would most likely reveal the underlying cause of weight loss. 
❌ Complete metabolic panel and iron studies:
Incorrect: Complete metabolic panel with iron studies could be useful in assessing gastrointestinal causes of weight loss (e.g., malabsorption). This patient’s signs and symptoms are more suggestive of hyperthyroidism. 
❌ Positron emission tomography imaging:
Incorrect: PET imaging can be used to assess areas of increased glucose tracer uptake which may represent malignancy. Without basic tests such as complete blood count or a diagnosis of malignancy, PET imaging would be inappropriate.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old woman presents to the emergency department because of two days of abdominal pain, nausea, malaise, and increased thirst. Symptoms were initially intermittent at onset but are now constant. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not currently take any medications. Temperature is 37.6 ºC (99.7 ºF), pulse is 120/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/66 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient appears uncomfortable. Mucous membranes are dry, and there is decreased skin turgor. There is mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness to palpation without rebound or guarding. Laboratory results are shown below. The patient is given one liter of 0.9% saline. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management? 

 Serum Laboratory Test     Result   
 Sodium     124 mEq/L    
 Chloride     96 mEq/L    
 Potassium     5.5 mEq/L    
 Bicarbonate     14 mEq/L    
 Glucose     500 mg/dL    
 Beta-hydroxybutyrate     5 mmol/L (normal < 0.5 mmol/L)
questions.solution:
This patient with abdominal pain, nausea, and polydipsia presents with an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis with severe hyperglycemia and ketosis. Together, these findings indicate diabetic ketoacidosis, and the most appropriate treatment is an insulin infusion and IV fluid hydration (0.9% saline in this case).

Metabolic acidosis refers to an increase in hydrogen ions and a decrease in bicarbonate concentration in the blood due to a metabolic cause. Metabolic acidosis can be classified as non- (or normal) anion gap or elevated (or high) anion gap. The anion gap is calculated by subtracting the concentrations of serum chloride and bicarbonate from serum sodium (AG = Na - Cl - HCO3).

Patients presenting acutely with metabolic acidosis can be extremely ill. They are often tachypneic as the body tries to compensate by inducing a relative respiratory alkalosis. An ABCDE assessment is crucial at the time of presentation. Intravenous fluid resuscitation is indicated for most patients presenting with acute metabolic acidosis. Once stabilized, the underlying issues causing metabolic acidosis should be addressed to prevent decompensation. Severe, untreated metabolic acidosis can lead to cardiac arrest.

Life-threatening causes of metabolic acidosis include toxic ingestion (e.g., ethylene glycol, methanol, isoniazid, salicylates), septic shock with resultant lactic acidosis, severe acute kidney injury, and diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). Patients with DKA are typically volume-depleted, requiring aggressive IV fluid resuscitation. Insulin infusion is crucial for stopping the production of ketones and the resultant acidosis. Once the patient’s anion gap is closed, they can be transitioned to subcutaneous insulin for continued management of hyperglycemia.   

Option Analysis

✅ Insulin infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 0.45% saline infusion:
Incorrect: Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis should receive IV fluid hydration with 0.9% or 0.45% saline based upon the corrected sodium level (i.e., when accounting for hyperglycemia). This patient is hypovolemic and the corrected sodium level of 132 is still below the normal reference range, so 0.9% saline is more appropriate. 
❌ Oral sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Administration of oral sodium bicarbonate can help treat patients with chronic metabolic acidosis from chronic kidney disease. Bicarbonate administration is not necessary for this patient. 
❌ Subcutaneous insulin:
Incorrect: Diabetic ketoacidosis can be managed with subcutaneous insulin in mild cases if an insulin infusion is not feasible. However, insulin infusion is the safest and most reliable method of insulin delivery. 
❌ Oral sodium polystyrene sulfonate:
Incorrect: Gastrointestinal potassium binders are the cornerstone of treatment of hyperkalemia. This patient has mild hyperkalemia which will resolve after initiation of an insulin infusion, so a potassium binder is not necessary in this case.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department to be evaluated for abdominal pain, vomiting, and frequent urination over the last 24 hours. Over the past several days, he has been much more thirsty than usual and has experienced severe fatigue. He has no burning with urination. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or other recreational drugs and has not recently taken any supplements. He has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 99/62 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary exam is within normal limits. Abdominal exam reveals mild diffuse abdominal tenderness without rebound or guarding. Neurological exam is nonfocal. Basic metabolic panel is obtained and shows sodium 128 mEq/L, chloride 91 mEq/L, and bicarbonate 14 mEq/L. Which of the following additional historical or physical examination findings is likely to be present given the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with abdominal pain, vomiting, polyuria, and polydipsia and is found to have an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis. Together, this patient’s symptoms and elevated anion gap are highly suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. This typically occurs in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM), who often have a family history of type 1 DM or other autoimmune diseases.

Patients with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) usually present with signs of hyperglycemia (polyuria, polydipsia), fatigue, and GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain). Altered mental status can occur but is more common in a hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state. Since DKA is more common in type 1 diabetes mellitus, patients may have a family history of type 1 diabetes mellitus or a personal or family history of other autoimmune diseases.

On physical examination, patients will be uncomfortable-appearing and may have altered mentation. They are usually tachypneic as the body tries to compensate for metabolic acidosis by inducing a relative respiratory alkalosis. The mucous membranes are typically very dry as patients can be extremely volume-depleted. Generalized abdominal tenderness is common. Tachycardia and hypotension are also common due to the severe volume depletion which is often seen.   

Option Analysis

✅ Family history of type 1 diabetes:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acetazolamide use:
Incorrect: Acetazolamide can lead to metabolic acidosis due to increased urinary bicarbonate wasting. This causes a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis; however, this patient has an elevated anion gap. 
❌ Recent weight gain:
Incorrect: This patient likely has new-onset type 1 diabetes mellitus presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis. New type 1 diabetes mellitus is typically associated with weight loss and not weight gain. 
❌ Decreased visual acuity:
Incorrect: Decreased visual acuity can occur in patients with methanol toxicity and can eventually lead to blindness. This could cause this patient’s elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis. However, the clinical presentation of abdominal pain, polyuria, and polydipsia is more suggestive of diabetic ketoacidosis. Symptoms that suggest methanol toxicity include neurologic symptoms like those seen with alcohol intoxication, such as disinhibition, ataxia, drowsiness, and seizures. 
❌ History of kidney stones:
Incorrect: Recurrent kidney stones in a patient with metabolic acidosis could indicate renal tubular acidosis. This would, however, cause a non-anion gap metabolic acidosis, and this patient has an elevated anion gap.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol use is admitted to the hospital for management of severe pancreatitis diagnosed three days ago. Despite initial treatment, he has worsening respiratory symptoms. Past medical history is significant for chronic alcohol use and 2 prior episodes of pancreatitis. Temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), heart rate is 115/min, respiratory rate is 28/min, blood pressure is 92/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 86% on room air, which improves to 90% with 6 liters of supplemental oxygen via nasal cannula. The patient appears to be in distress and is using accessory muscles to breathe. Physical examination reveals decreased skin turgor, dry mucous membranes, and abdominal tenderness with guarding in the epigastric region and without distension or fluid waves. Chest auscultation reveals bilateral crackles in the lower lung fields. There is no lower extremity edema. Laboratory tests indicate persistent elevation of amylase and lipase. Chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following can be used to establish the most likely diagnosis in this patient? 



Image courtesy of STATdx

choices.text: CT scan of the chest with IV contrast

questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of chronic alcohol use, presents with worsening respiratory symptoms in the context of severe pancreatitis. His clinical picture, including marked hypoxemia (oxygen saturation of 86% on room air, minimally responsive to supplemental oxygen), respiratory distress, bilateral crackles in the lower lung fields, and diffuse bilateral infiltrates on chest X-ray strongly suggests acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300, assessed by arterial blood glass (ABG) analysis and estimated FiO2 in non-intubated patients, is necessary to make the diagnosis of ARDS in this patient.        

ARDS is characterized by rapid onset of severe inflammatory lung injury leading to increased pulmonary vascular permeability and alveolar damage. Patients typically present with rapid onset of severe respiratory distress, often following a precipitating event such as sepsis, trauma, pneumonia, or pancreatitis. Clinically, patients exhibit marked hypoxemia, dyspnea, tachypnea, cyanosis, and use of accessory muscles for breathing. Physical examination is significant for bilateral diffuse crackles on lung auscultation in the absence of signs of volume overload such as pitting lower extremity edema and jugular venous distention. Imaging, including chest x-ray or CT, will show bilateral pulmonary opacities, and a PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300 in non-intubated patients will be calculated. The diagnosis of ARDS can be made clinically in patients who meet all the criteria listed below.   



Option Analysis

✅ Arterial blood gas analysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ CT scan of the chest with IV contrast:
Incorrect: This patient likely has acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A CT scan with IV contrast can provide detailed images of lung pathology but is not necessary for diagnosing ARDS. The diagnosis of ARDS can be made clinically, based on agreed-upon diagnostic criteria that include a PaO2/FiO2 of ≤ 300 in non-intubated patients and PaO2 can be determined from arterial blood gas analysis. 
❌ Transthoracic echocardiogram :
Incorrect: For patients with suspected ARDS, it should be determined that respiratory distress is not from cardiac failure or volume overload. In this patient who has no prior history of coronary artery disease or other cardiac dysfunction and has evidence of dehydration on exam, and onset of symptoms within 1 week of severe pancreatitis, ARDS is the likely cause of respiratory distress. A PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 is necessary to make the diagnosis.  
❌ B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) level:
Incorrect: BNP testing is useful for distinguishing between cardiac and pulmonary causes of respiratory failure. However, the absence of volume overload in this patient without a history of cardiac dysfunction and the onset of symptoms within 1 week of severe pancreatitis is more indicative of ARDS than other causes of respiratory distress. A PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 is needed to make the diagnosis in this patient and PaO2 can be determined from arterial blood gas analysis. 
❌ Sputum culture:
Incorrect: While a sputum culture can identify causative pathogens in respiratory infections when that is the inciting event of ARDS, it is not necessary to make the diagnosis of ARDS. In the context of severe pancreatitis, ARDS is primarily caused by an inflammatory response in the lungs, often secondary to systemic factors, rather than a direct result of lung infection. A PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 300 is needed to make the diagnosis of ARDS in this patient and PaO2 can be determined from arterial blood gas analysis.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman with a history of type 2 diabetes and hypertension is brought to the emergency department for severe shortness of breath. She has been experiencing a worsening cough and fever over the past 5 days. Temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F), heart rate is 110/min, blood pressure is 89/54 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 28/min, and oxygen saturation is 89% on 60% FiO2 via a non-rebreather mask. Physical examination reveals bilateral crackles on lung auscultation. There is no jugular venous distension and no lower extremity edema. Chest X-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. Results from the laboratory evaluation are shown below. A bedside echocardiogram reveals normal left ventricular systolic function and preserved ejection fraction. Arterial blood gas and FiO2 are used to calculate a PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300. Arterial blood gas analysis is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient? 

 Complete Blood Count    
 Hemoglobin (Hb)     12.5 g/dL   
 White Blood Cells (WBC)     17,000/µL   
 Platelets     400,000/µL   
 General Chemistry    
 Sodium     140 mEq/L    
 Potassium     4.2 mEq/L    
 Chloride     102 mEq/L    
 CRP     40 mg/L
questions.solution:
The patient's presentation of respiratory distress in the setting of 5 days of a worsening cough, fever, hemodynamic instability, hypoxemia, leukocytosis on laboratory evaluation, and diffuse bilateral opacities on chest x-ray, strongly suggests acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to sepsis (likely from a severe pulmonary infection such as pneumonia). The arterial blood gas (ABG) in patients with ARDS typically shows a combination of hypoxemia and respiratory acidosis due to impaired gas exchange and lung mechanics. The expected ABG pattern in ARDS includes a low pH (acidemia) (ie 7.15), low PaO2 (hypoxemia) (ie 58), and elevated PaCO2 (hypercapnia) (ie 48) as seen in answer A. For this patient, low bicarbonate (HCO3-) level (19) suggests a concomitant metabolic acidosis from sepsis due to lactic acid production from tissue hypoperfusion.        

A clinical diagnosis of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) can be made based on agreed-upon criteria. ARDS can be diagnosed in patients like this one with a clinical insult or new or worsening symptoms within 1 week of presentation, bilateral pulmonary opacities on imaging (not explained by effusions, collapse, or nodules), and respiratory failure evidenced by a PaO2/FiO2 ratio ≤ 300 that is not fully attributable to cardiac failure or fluid overload.        

PaO2/FiO2 is determined based on estimated FiO2 in non-intubated patients and ventilator settings in intubated patients and ABG and is used to stratify patients based on the severity of ARDS. This stratification can then be used to guide management. Patients can be diagnosed with mild (>200 mmHg but ≤300 mmHg), moderate (>100 mmHg but ≤200 mmHg) or severe (≤ 100 mmHg) disease.    

Option Analysis

✅  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.15     58     48     19    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.55   602124:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed clinically with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This ABG pattern indicates primary respiratory alkalosis with hypoxemia, which is more consistent with conditions like pulmonary embolism. In ARDS, patients are expected to have respiratory acidosis, hypercapnia, and metabolic acidosis. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.4 703724:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed clinically with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). A normal ABG pattern like this one would not be expected based on this patient's severe symptoms and clinical, imaging and laboratory findings. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.36554530:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed clinically with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This ABG is consistent with respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation, more indicative of chronic respiratory conditions. 
❌  pH     PaO2 (mmHg)     PaCO2 (mmHg)     HCO3- (mmHg)     7.44602521:
Incorrect: This patient can be diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This ABG pattern is consistent with chronic pulmonary embolism, characterized by hypoxemia, respiratory alkalosis, and compensated metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man with a history of hypertension is admitted to the intensive care unit for management of pneumonia and subsequent acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He was intubated and mechanically ventilated due to worsening hypoxemia. His initial ventilator settings were set to a tidal volume of 6 mL/kg of predicted body weight, with a positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cm H2O. Temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), heart rate is 102/min, respiratory rate is set at 12 breaths/min on the ventilator, blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 88% on FiO2 of 50%. The patient is put in a prone position. Lung auscultation reveals bilateral crackles. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows pH 7.3, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, PaO2 55 mm Hg, and HCO3- 24 mEq/L. PaO2/FiO2 ratio=110. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Increase positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 cm H2O
Switch the patient to a supine position

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) secondary to pneumonia. Based on PaO2/FiO2 ratio=110 he can be diagnosed with moderate disease. The best step to improve oxygenation in this patient is to increase the positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 cm H2O. The patient's current oxygen saturation (88%) and PaO2 (55 mm Hg) indicate inadequate oxygenation, necessitating adjustments in ventilator settings.        

Increasing PEEP is a key strategy to improve oxygenation in ARDS. It helps to recruit collapsed alveoli, improve functional residual capacity, and reduce intrapulmonary shunting, thereby enhancing oxygenation. A careful increase in PEEP can improve gas exchange without significantly raising the risk of barotrauma.        

For hypoxemia (PaO2 < 60 mm Hg), increasing PEEP is recommended to improve oxygenation before escalating FiO2, due to the risks associated with oxygen toxicity. Hyperoxia (PaO2 > 90 mm Hg) warrants decreasing FiO2 to avoid similar toxicities. On the ventilation side, if the patient is acidotic (PaCO2 high and pH < 7.25), increasing the respiratory rate (RR) is advised, and as a last resort, increasing tidal volume (Vt) may be considered. Conversely, if PaCO2 is low and pH > 7.45, reducing Vt or RR is recommended, and sedation may be deepened to decrease metabolic demand and respiratory drive. Throughout the management, ensuring lung-protective ventilation to prevent alveolar overdistension is critical. This is assessed by measuring plateau pressure (Pplat) with an inspiratory hold, aiming for a goal Pplat ≤ 30 cm H2O.        

For patients with moderate severity, ARDS-prone positioning and increased levels of PEEP may be used. In addition to ventilator management, all patients with ARDS should receive supportive care, potentially medications like diuretics, and severity should be assessed regularly to determine the need for other measures like neuromuscular agents to induce paralysis and ECMO for severe disease.   

Option Analysis

✅ Increase positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) to 8 cm H2O:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Increase FiO2 to 80%:
Incorrect: Escalating FiO2 to 80% is not the first-line approach for moderate hypoxemia in ARDS. High FiO2 levels can increase the risk of oxygen toxicity. The primary strategy should be to optimize PEEP to improve oxygenation while minimizing potential oxygen-related lung injury. 
❌ Increase tidal volume to 8 mL/kg:
Incorrect: Increasing tidal volume to 8 mL/kg is generally avoided in ARDS due to the risk of volutrauma and should only be considered as a last resort for severe refractory hypercapnia, which this patient does not currently exhibit. 
❌ Increase respiratory rate to 16 breaths/min:
Incorrect: Adjusting the respiratory rate is not the first step in addressing hypoxemia in patients with moderate ARDS. It is considered when addressing ventilation issues, particularly hypercapnia. In this patient with ARDS and acceptable PaCO2 levels, the priority is to optimize oxygenation through PEEP adjustments rather than altering respiratory rate. 
❌ Switch the patient to a supine position:
Incorrect: Prone positioning is recommended in moderate ARDS to improve oxygenation as it decreases the amount of weight and compression on the lungs, allowing more air to get to the alveoli, which has already been implemented for this patient. Reverting to supine positioning is contrary to the recommended practice for severe hypoxemia in ARDS and could potentially worsen V/Q mismatch and oxygenation.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of opioid use disorder presents to the emergency department in withdrawal. The patient states that she needs help with her opioid use and has repeatedly attempted to stop using, but has been unable to do so due to side effects from withdrawal. The patient reports that she has been using heroin daily for several months, in escalating doses. The patient reports she recently lost her job and significant other due to her ongoing use. Her last use was approximately 24 hours ago. The patient has no other significant past medical history and does not take any medication daily. Vital signs show tachycardia but are otherwise within normal limits. The patient vomits before the start of the examination. Physical examination reveals mydriasis and piloerection. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. Which of the following should be administered next?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with several clinical features of opioid use disorder including desire and unsuccessful attempts to quit, negative impact on work, continued use despite interpersonal problems caused by use, tolerance, and withdrawal. The patient exhibits characteristics of physical dependence and can be classified as having moderate to severe opioid use disorder. Buprenorphine, a partial opioid agonist, can be safely started during withdrawal and continued as medication for opioid use disorder.        

All patients with opioid use disorders should be considered for pharmacologic treatment. They should also be offered appropriate psychosocial counseling, and any associated medical conditions should be treated (e.g. opioid-induced constipation). Counseling can consist of recovery programs, individualized or group support (e.g. narcotics anonymous), as well as cognitive behavioral therapy. All patients should be provided with overdose prevention education.        

Pharmacologic therapy for opioid use disorder includes either opioid agonists (methadone and buprenorphine) or the opioid antagonist naltrexone. Methadone is a long-acting opioid agonist that is most often used for patients taking high daily doses of opioids with higher levels of physical dependence. It can also be used in patients who have been unsuccessful on buprenorphine. Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist that ameliorates withdrawal symptoms and suppresses cravings. Hospitalized patients with opioid use disorders can start medication treatment with buprenorphine once they are experiencing withdrawal symptoms. It can then be continued. Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist. It can precipitate withdrawal in patients who are actively using opioids. Therefore, patients who will be using it for ongoing medication treatment should first have medically supervised withdrawal before starting it. Giving it to patients in active withdrawal can worsen withdrawal symptoms.       

Regional poison control centers in the United States are available around the clock for consultation on patients with known or suspected poisoning, and those who may be critically ill, require admission, or have clinical pictures that are unclear (1-800-222-1222).   

Option Analysis

✅ Buprenorphine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is a fast-acting opioid antagonist that can reverse and block the effects of opioids. It is used in cases of opioid overdose. Administering naloxone to this patient would likely worsen the withdrawal symptoms she is experiencing.  
❌ Naltrexone:
Incorrect: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used as part of the treatment plan for opioid and alcohol use disorders. It prevents opioid intoxication and physical dependence. Administration during acute withdrawal may worsen withdrawal symptoms.  
❌ Buspirone:
Incorrect: Buspirone is a partial 5-HT1A receptor agonist. It is used to treat anxiety disorders.It is not utilized as pharmacologic management in opioid use disorders. 
❌ Pimozide:
Incorrect: Pimozide is a first generation antipsychotic medication. It is used to treat Tourette syndrome. It is not utilized as part of the pharmacologic management of opioid use disorders.

questions.text: A 31-year-old man presents to the clinic for evaluation of diarrhea and low-grade fevers over the past five weeks. The patient has been having 3-4 episodes of bloody diarrhea every day. Abdominal cramping and bloody diarrhea have persisted despite eliminating dairy and gluten products from his diet. The diarrhea is preceded by intense crampy abdominal pain that is relieved with bowel movements. The patient has no history of recent travel and only eats food he prepares. In addition, the patient has measured oral temperatures up to 100.4°F at home. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, and blood pressure is 116/74 mmHg. Physical examination shows mild tenderness to palpation throughout the abdomen without rebound or guarding. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Rectal examination shows perianal skin tags. Serum transaminases and bilirubin are normal. Which of the following additional physical examination findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration

questions.solution:
This patient's presentation, including several weeks of bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramping, and low-grade fevers, is suggestive of an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), most likely Crohn disease. Erythema nodosum is a type of panniculitis characterized by tender red nodules, usually found on the anterior aspects of the legs. It is considered an extraintestinal manifestation of IBD and is associated with both Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis.

When evaluating a patient with fever, a detailed history and physical examination are essential for determining the underlying etiology. The history should include the fever's characteristics; associated symptoms, including chills, cough, or rash; and any recent travel or exposures as these can hint at infectious, inflammatory, or neoplastic causes. Past medical and medication histories are essential to identify predispositions and potential drug-induced fevers. During the physical examination, vital signs and focused assessments of the skin, lymph nodes, joints, and abdomen are vital for pinpointing signs of specific conditions. Findings such as skin rashes, lymphadenopathy, or hepatosplenomegaly can direct clinicians toward further workup to determine the etiology of the fever.   

Option Analysis

❌ Dermatitis herpetiformis:
Incorrect: Dermatitis herpetiformis is associated with celiac disease. Although celiac disease and inflammatory bowel disease may present similarly, there are a few key distinctions. The presence of bloody diarrhea and perianal skin tags in this patient indicates Crohn disease. In addition, dermatitis herpetiformis usually resolves when patients with celiac disease completely eliminate gluten; this patient’s symptoms have persisted despite eliminating gluten. 
✅ Erythema nodosum:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Widespread skin excoriations:
Incorrect: Conditions that result in elevated bilirubin can lead to pruritus and subsequent excoriations. Crohn disease is associated with primary sclerosing cholangitis, which can present with elevated bilirubin, hepatomegaly, and eventually cirrhosis. However, this patient’s bilirubin is noted to be normal; therefore, pruritus and excoriations would not be expected. 
❌ Pain in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration:
Incorrect: Murphy sign, or pain and discomfort in the right upper quadrant on deep inspiration when the examiner’s hands palpate below the liver edge, is an indication of acute cholecystitis. This patient’s more subacute presentation of diarrhea and fever and the presence of perianal is more consistent with Crohn disease. 
❌ Hyporeflexia of bilateral lower extremities:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barré syndrome can present as lower extremity weakness or paralysis, which is often preceded by a respiratory or gastrointestinal viral illness. This patient’s presentation is more consistent with inflammatory bowel disease (specifically, Crohn disease with bloody diarrhea, perianal skin tags, and fever).

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the primary care office for daily chest pain and vomiting for the past two months. Symptoms are worse at night and have occurred on most days of the week for the last two months especially after he eats a late dinner. The patient smokes a pack of cigarettes per day and drinks five or six beers daily. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 88/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 138/84 mmHg. BMI is 31. On examination, there is mild tenderness to palpation in the epigastric area. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) reveals inflammation at the gastroesophageal junction. Which of the following additional findings is most likely found on examination?
questions.solution:
This patient with chest pain, chronic vomiting, and epigastric tenderness, with EGD showing inflammation at the gastroesophageal junction, can be diagnosed with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Patients with GERD may experience dental erosions due to the effects of stomach acid on the tooth enamel. This patient has several risk factors for GERD including smoking, excessive alcohol use, and obesity.

Several abdominal and non-abdominal causes can cause chronic vomiting. Obtaining a detailed history and physical examination is important to help narrow down the most likely cause of the symptoms but also to evaluate for other coexisting issues. Patients with GERD may experience symptoms such as “heartburn”, chest pain, a sour or bitter taste in the mouth, sore throat, globus sensation, cough, or hoarseness. The physical examination may be normal or may reveal dental erosions (see image below), halitosis, wheezing, or epigastric abdominal tenderness.
 
   

Maxillary occlusal view of severe tooth erosion caused by endogenous acid in a patient with GERD by Dr. A. Dickinson is licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution-Share Alike 4.0 International license. Reproduced from WikiCommons 

Option Analysis

✅ Dental erosions:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Palpable abdominal mass:
Incorrect: A palpable abdominal mass may be present in patients with chronic vomiting caused by an obstructing abdominal mass. This patient’s findings are consistent with gastroesophageal reflux which may be associated with dental erosions.  
❌ Anal fissure:
Incorrect: Anal fissures can be associated with inflammatory bowel disease or constipation-prevalent irritable bowel disease. This patient’s symptoms and findings are consistent with gastroesophageal reflux which can be associated with dental erosions.  
❌ Papilledema:
Incorrect: Papilledema, or optic disc swelling, is associated with elevated intracranial pressure, which can cause chronic vomiting.  However, this patient’s history and clinical exam findings are more suggestive of an abdominal cause of chronic vomiting rather than a neurologic cause.  
❌ Orthostatic hypotension:
Incorrect: Orthostatic hypotension may be seen in patients with chronic vomiting that is caused by adrenal insufficiency.  This patient’s findings are more consistent with gastroesophageal reflux as the cause of his chronic vomiting.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for a follow-up of hypertension. The patient has had elevated blood pressure measurements on several occasions. The patient feels well and does not report any symptoms. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for coronary artery disease in the patient’s father. He does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs. Temperature is 36.8 C (98.2 F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/98 mmHg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is started on a drug that acts on the segment of the nephron labeled “A” below. Which of the following best describes the normal function of this segment of nephron?

choices.text: Major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption
Pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney
Reabsorbs calcium under the control of parathyroid hormone
Primary site of acidification of the urine and is controlled by aldosterone
Passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium

questions.solution:
The segment of the nephron labeled A is the distal convoluted tubule (DCT). It is affected by thiazide diuretics (e.g. hydrochlorothiazide). This segment of the nephron reabsorbs sodium and chloride via the Na+/Cl– carrier on the apical surface of the tubule and is responsible for 5% of filtered sodium reabsorption. The cotransporter moves Na+ in the direction of its concentration gradient and uses that energy to move a chloride against its concentration gradient. Once inside, chloride leaves via Cl- channels on the basolateral surface into the interstitium, down its concentration gradient. It is impermeable to H2O and makes urine fully dilute (hypotonic).

There are also Ca++ channels on the apical surface and Na+/Ca++ channels on the basolateral surface of the tubule cells. Ca++ ions can diffuse across the apical surface into the tubule cells, down their concentration gradient, and then move across the basolateral surface into the interstitium against their concentration gradient as 1 Na+ moves from the interstitium into the tubule cells. Calcium reabsorption is regulated by the parathyroid hormone (PTH). Moreover, the Na+/K+ ATPase on the basolateral surface keeps the intracellular Na+ level low, and that allows more Na+ to flow into the tubule, down its concentration gradient on the basolateral surface through the Na+/Ca++ channels, and on the apical surface through the Na+/Cl- cotransporter.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption :
Incorrect: The proximal convoluted tubule (PCT) carries out isosmotic reabsorption of amino acids, glucose, and numerous ions. It is the major site for sodium chloride and sodium bicarbonate reabsorption. The proximal tubule is responsible for 60–70% of the total reabsorption of sodium. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
❌ Pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney :
Incorrect: The thick ascending loop of Henle has a Na-K-2Cl symporter which pumps sodium, potassium, and chloride out of the lumen into the interstitium of the kidney. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
✅ Reabsorbs calcium under the control of parathyroid hormone :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Primary site of acidification of the urine and is controlled by aldosterone :
Incorrect: The collecting duct is the final segment of the nephron and is the last tubular site of sodium reabsorption that is controlled by aldosterone. It is also the primary site of acidification of the urine and the last site of potassium excretion. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule. 
❌ Passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium :
Incorrect: The descending limb of loop of Henle passively reabsorbs H2O via medullary hypertonicity and is impermeable to sodium. The segment marked A is the distal convoluted tubule.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for several hours of severe low back pain. The patient was sitting on her couch and bent down to the floor to retrieve her phone when she heard a crack coming from her back and experienced excruciating pain. The pain worsens with standing, walking, and lying on her back. She has not had any recent falls, lower extremity weakness, or loss of sensation in the extremities. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals midline tenderness with palpation and percussion of the lumbar spine. Laboratory results are shown below. Based on the diagnosis, her case team decides to start her on a medication that targets proteasomes. Which of the following medications is the best initial therapy for this patient?
 
 Hemoglobin     8.2 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     26%    
 Glucose     88 mg/dl    
 Calcium     13 mg/dl    
 Sodium     135 mmol/L    
 Chloride     101mmol/L    
 Potassium     3.5 mmol/L    
 Magnesium     2.7 mg/dl    
 BUN     10 mg/dl    
 Creatinine     1.5 mg/dl
questions.solution:
This patient has recently suffered from a spontaneous fracture of her lumbar vertebrae. Laboratory results show hypercalcemia, anemia, and chronic kidney disease. These features suggest that this patient is suffering from multiple myeloma. A therapeutic intervention that targets proteasomal degradation is bortezomib. 

The proteasome is a central component of protein degradation machinery in eukaryotic cells. It is present in both transformed and normal cells, which depend on the proteasome for cell proliferation. Three proteasomal inhibitors currently in therapeutic use include bortezomib, carfilzomib, and ixazomib. Proteasome inhibitors have become a staple in treating multiple myeloma and some types of lymphomas. Solid tumors have been shown to develop resistance to these medications over time, which is why they are selectively used in these scenarios. Neurotoxicity, fatigue, gastrointestinal effects, and modest cytopenias are common side effects of proteasome inhibitor therapy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Bortezomib :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Gentamicin :
Incorrect: Gentamicin is a protein synthesis inhibitor. This patient is suffering from multiple myeloma, not an infection.  
❌ Metronidazole :
Incorrect: Metronidazole is a DNA synthesis inhibitor. This patient is suffering from multiple myeloma, not an infection.  
❌ Hydroxyurea :
Incorrect: Hydroxyurea inhibits ribonucleotide reductase used to treat melanoma and treatment-resistant CML. It does not affect proteasomes.  
❌ Methotrexate :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist which binds to the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR); it does not affect proteasomes.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is taken for endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) following surveillance for an enlarged lymph node incidentally detected on CT imaging. Following identification and aspiration of an enlarged lymph node, atypical cells were identified during intraoperative pathology consultation. A partial pulmonary lobectomy was done, removing the lower lobe of the right lung where the lymph nodes were harvested. Molecular pathology revealed that this patient had non-small cell lung cancer with mutations in the EGFR gene. Which of the following is an appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is suffering from a non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), with mutations in the EGFR gene. An appropriate first-line therapeutic agent would be a medication that targets the mutant EGFR gene in this scenario. 

Erlotinib is a reversible first-generation receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) inhibitor that acts on the endothelial growth factor receptor (EGFR), a member of the ErbB receptor family. It is currently used to treat NSCLC and pancreatic cancers, which have been shown to have mutant EGFR activity. EGFR helps in angiogenesis, differentiation, and proliferation of cells, and therefore, RTK inhibitors like erlotinib prevent phosphorylation of their substrate, preventing downstream signaling from being propagated. Side effects are mild and include rash, pruritus, diarrhea, anorexia, and fatigue.    

Option Analysis

❌ Gemcitabine :
Incorrect: Gemcitabine is a nucleoside analog that works to prevent DNA replication. It is not first-line therapy for the treatment of EGFR mutant lung cancers.  
✅ Erlotinib :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Trastuzumab  :
Incorrect: Trastuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that binds to HER2 receptors in breast and gastric cancers. It is not first-line therapy for the treatment of EGFR mutant lung cancers.  
❌ Bortezomib :
Incorrect: Bortezomib is a drug that inhibits proteasomes. It is not first-line therapy for the treatment of EGFR mutant lung cancers. It is not first-line therapy for the treatment of EGFR mutant lung cancers.  
❌ Methotrexate :
Incorrect: Methotrexate is a folic acid antagonist which binds to the enzyme dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR). It is not first-line therapy for the treatment of EGFR mutant lung cancers.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of balance issues, headache, and nausea for the past 4 days. The patient endorses a sensation of objects moving around him. The patient was diagnosed with infective endocarditis one week ago and has been receiving penicillin G and gentamicin. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and hypertension. Other medications include furosemide, metformin, atorvastatin, aspirin, and metoprolol. Vitals are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination is normal. Air conduction is better than bone conduction with Renne testing, and sound is heard better in the left ear with Weber testing. Rapid movement of the head away from a fixed target induces a horizontal eye saccade with redirection towards the target. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient receiving gentamicin for the treatment of infective endocarditis presents with new-onset hearing loss, imbalance, and sensations of objects moving around him (oscillopsia). This presentation is consistent with aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicity likely exacerbated by coadministration with furosemide (another ototoxic drug). Other risk factors for aminoglycoside-induced ototoxicity include bacteremia, as well as hepatic, or renal impairment.

Irreversible vestibular and auditory dysfunction can follow aminoglycoside administration. Presentation varies and includes clinical features such as:

  •  High-pitched tinnitus (usually the first symptom of cochlear toxicity)  
  •  Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and loss of high-frequency range (outside the conversational range)  
  •  Imbalance and oscillopsia   
  •  A positive head thrust test (impaired vestibulo-ocular reflex)  

Management of aminoglycoside-induced vestibular toxicity includes immediate discontinuation of the offending medication. Associated renal toxicity is typically reversible and presents in the form of acute tubular necrosis (ATN). It is common in elderly patients receiving aminoglycosides as well as in those concurrently receiving amphotericin B, cephalosporins, or vancomycin.

Option Analysis

❌ Meniere disease :
Incorrect: Meniere disease is caused by increased endolymphatic volume/pressure in the labyrinthine system. It presents with a triad of episodic vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing loss. Acute onset of vestibular dysfunction, rather than episodic dysfunction, makes this diagnosis unlikely. 
✅ Medication-induced ototoxicity :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Cholesteatoma :
Incorrect: Cholesteatomas are erosive expansile masses of squamous cell debris in the middle ear visible on the otoscopy. This condition typically presents with recurrent otorrhea and asymmetric conductive hearing loss (bone conduction> air conduction in the affected ear). 
❌ Otosclerosis :
Incorrect: Otosclerosis results from ossification of the ossicles and presents with conductive hearing loss (bone conduction> air conduction) rather than sensorineural hearing loss. 
❌ Presbycusis :
Incorrect: Presbycusis is common in the elderly (age > 75 years) and presents with bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man presents to the primary care office for a rash. He has had an itchy patch of skin on his right arm for six weeks which has not improved with over-the-counter steroid cream. He has not had a fever and has not been in contact with any new materials or outdoor plants. He is not currently being treated for any chronic medical conditions. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, and blood pressure is 120/78 mmHg. On examination, the patient is awake and alert and in no distress. Ear, nose, and throat examinations are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary exam reveals no abnormalities. A skin rash is seen on the right elbow as pictured below. Pinpoint bleeding is noted when a small area of the rash is removed. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with this patient’s underlying condition? 



Image by Li X, Li J, Wang L, Niu X, Hou R, Liu R, Hao Z, Wang C, Yin G, Zhang K - Blood cancer journal (2015) was cropped from original, licensed under CC BY 4.0, reproduced from Open-i

choices.text: Prodrome of malaise     Dermatomal pattern     Hyperalgesia of affected area
Recent medication use     Erythematous papules with a dusky center     Widespread location
Flexor surfaces affected     History of food allergies     History of asthma

questions.solution:
This patient’s persistent, pruritic skin rash as pictured is concerning for psoriasis, a chronic immune-mediated condition that causes inflammation of the skin. Erythematous plaques covered by silvery-white scales are classic for psoriasis and are typically found on extensor surfaces. The rash is usually worse in the winter and better in the summer and may be associated with painful inflammation of the joints leading to sausage-shaped swelling of the fingers and toes, known as dactylitis. Removal of scales from a psoriatic plaque will often cause pin-point bleeding (Auspitz sign).        

The diagnostic workup of common skin rashes can be approached by first determining which of three main categories of rashes is present: cutaneous adverse medication reaction, infectious etiology, or inflammatory/autoimmune etiology. Features such as recent medication exposures, risk factors for infection, rash appearance, and associated features help narrow the differential. In this case, a localized rash, not associated with recent medication use, rules out cutaneous adverse medication rash. The absence of features suggestive of folliculitis (pustules over hair follicles, recent sweating or hot tub use), scabies (severe itching, worse at night, with serpiginous burrows and papules), shingles (vesicles in a dermatomal pattern with local hyperalgesia), tinea corporis (annular/ovoid itchy patches with a scaly edge and possible central clearing) and the lack of classic features of other common skin infections such as Lyme disease make an infectious cause unlikely.          

When adverse medication rash and infectious etiology have been ruled out, an inflammatory/autoimmune cause should be considered. Classic diagnostic features of conditions such as atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, acne vulgaris, rosacea, and psoriasis should be looked for, as the diagnosis of these conditions is primarily clinical. Skin testing or biopsy may be useful if a clinical diagnosis cannot be made or if patients fail to respond to empiric treatments.   

Option Analysis

✅  Extensor surfaces affected     Dactylitis     Rash worse in winter    :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌  Prodrome of malaise     Dermatomal pattern     Hyperalgesia of affected area    :
Incorrect: A vesicular rash in a dermatomal pattern with hyperalgesia of the affected area is classic for the rash of herpes zoster (shingles); a prodrome of malaise or fever may precede the skin lesions. This patient’s scaly rash on an erythematous base is classic for psoriasis.  
❌  Recent medication use     Erythematous papules with a dusky center     Widespread location    :
Incorrect: A widespread rash presenting as erythematous papules with a dusky center after recent medication use is classic for erythema multiforme, a cutaneous adverse medication reaction. This patient’s rash is consistent with psoriasis, which can be worsened by certain medications, but does not share the other classic findings of erythema multiforme. 
❌  Telangiectasias     Rhinophyma     Dryness of eyes    :
Incorrect: While psoriasis can affect the eyes, telangiectasias and the presence of rhinophyma are characteristic of rosacea. 
❌  Flexor surfaces affected     History of food allergies     History of asthma    :
Incorrect: Involvement of flexor surfaces and a history of food allergies and asthma are commonly seen with atopic dermatitis. This patient’s lesion is more characteristic of psoriasis, presenting as an erythematous plaque with silvery scale.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents to the student health clinic at his college for an itchy rash on his right thigh. He first noticed a reddish area on his upper thigh three weeks ago, and two new lesions have appeared distally in the last five days. He says the rash is similar to eczematous rashes he has had in the past. He has not had a fever, chills, or malaise. Past medical history is significant for asthma and eczema. He is on the school wrestling team, and they are currently in-season, practicing 5 days per week. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 60/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On physical exam, he is in no distress. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Skin examination reveals multiple annular raised patches with sharp erythematous margins on the right anterior thigh. The remaining skin surfaces are clear. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient’s pruritic, well-demarcated, erythematous, annular skin rash is tinea corporis and nummular eczema. The history of asthma and eczema favors an inflammatory/autoimmune process (atopic dermatitis), while his participation in wrestling increases his chance of having a fungal infection.  Given the lack of a clear clinical picture, the best next step is to perform a potassium hydroxide (KOH) test on a skin scraping to confirm whether fungal elements are present.        

Skin rashes can present a diagnostic challenge given the large differential and the variable and overlapping presenting features of different skin rashes. A helpful initial approach is to first consider whether the rash could be caused by medication. If no recent medications were used, a careful history and physical examination can help determine whether an infectious or an inflammatory/autoimmune etiology is more likely.        

Often, a diagnosis can be made clinically with common skin rashes. However, laboratory testing and, if necessary, a skin biopsy can help in cases of atypical, severe, or overlapping conditions. Tinea corporis and nummular eczema are two conditions that can present with overlapping features on physical examination. A classic history of eczema, or atopic dermatitis, includes the “atopic triad” of atopic dermatitis, allergic rhinitis, and asthma. Patients with itchy, dry, erythematous patches on flexor surfaces, with these historic features can be diagnosed with eczema (atopic dermatitis). If the classic atopic history is absent, and itchy, raised, erythematous rings are present in a patient with frequent skin-to-skin contact with others, or with close contact with an infected individual, then tinea corporis can be diagnosed clinically. When the clinical picture is unclear, further testing with a KOH test can determine if fungal elements are present to guide treatment.       

Option Analysis

✅ Potassium hydroxide test:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test:
Incorrect: Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of vesicular fluid is commonly used to confirm herpes zoster (shingles) by testing for the varicella-zoster virus. This patient’s presentation is consistent with tinea corporis; while tinea can be confirmed by PCR, potassium hydroxide (KOH) testing is a much faster and more cost-effective way to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Bacterial culture:
Incorrect: Bacterial culture is useful for determining the etiology of infections that contain a purulent fluid-filled structure such as a pustule or abscess. This patient has solid, raised skin lesions and a bacterial culture of intact skin will not help make the diagnosis.  
❌ Skin biopsy:
Incorrect: Skin biopsy would provide a definitive diagnosis in cases of tinea corporis; however, it is invasive, costly, risks scarring, and is not an appropriate first step in an otherwise straightforward case. This patient’s history and physical examination are classic for tinea corporis, but eczema is also possible, therefore a potassium hydroxide (KOH) test is the appropriate initial test.  
❌ Treatment with topical steroids :
Incorrect: Treatment with topical steroids is appropriate in straightforward cases of eczema; however, this patient has a history of eczema but also has factors concerning for an acute fungal infection (tinea corporis). A potassium hydroxide (KOH) test would help determine the cause of the current rash and guide treatment since steroid use could potentially make a fungal infection worse.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes and peripheral vascular disease presents to the emergency department with a three-week history of persistent lower back pain. The pain is described as constant, worse at night, and it does not improve with over-the-counter analgesics. Six weeks ago, the patient underwent a lumbar epidural corticosteroid injection for treatment of left lower extremity radicular pain. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 94/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, blood pressure is 146/94 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. There is spinal tenderness to palpation, erythema, and swelling at L3 and L4. The pain worsens with hyperextension or flexion of the spine. There are no neurological deficits. Laboratory results are shown below. Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) test results and blood and urine cultures are pending. A spinal X-ray shows degenerative changes but no acute pathology. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Hemoglobin      14 g/dL    
 Leukocyte count     13,100/mm3    
 Platelet count      450,000/mm3    
 Creatinine      0.9 mg/dL    
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)      77 mm/hr    
 C-reactive protein     15 mg/L

choices.text: Computed tomography (CT) of the lumbar spine
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine
18F–fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) and computed tomography
Lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint X-rays

questions.solution:
This patient presents with persistent lower back pain, fever, spinal tenderness erythema, swelling, elevated leukocyte count, markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and C-reactive protein (CRP) following a lumbar epidural corticosteroid injection. This clinical picture is concerning for a spinal infection such as osteomyelitis, and a lumbar spine MRI with and without contrast should be ordered for diagnosis after spinal X-ray and blood cultures are obtained. CT is a reasonable alternative diagnostic study that can be ordered if MRI is not available or contraindicated.        

When patients present with back pain, the history and physical exam and the presence or absence of alarm features can help determine whether further diagnostic workup with imaging is necessary. In patients who present with saddle anesthesia or loss of sensation around the buttocks, perineum, and inner thighs and absent or decreased anal sphincter tone, cauda equina syndrome should be suspected, and a spinal X-ray and MRI should be ordered. Patients with fever and risk factors for infectious causes of back pain should also have spinal X-ray and MRI. If patients have a history of cancer, unexplained weight loss, or night sweats, malignancy should be suspected. Imaging should be performed, which might show a vertebral tumor or metastatic lesions; then, biopsy should be obtained. Patients with spinal stenosis are typically elderly with back pain that is relieved by bending forward. Spinal X-ray or MRI will typically show signs of spinal stenosis. In patients with severe back pain and a history of osteoporosis or trauma, spinal fracture should be suspected; and X-ray, spine CT, and MRI should be ordered. Patients with signs of radiculopathy who have not responded to conservative management should have MRI imaging for suspected disc herniation. In patients with pain with movement and an inciting incident like lifting heavy objects, lumbar strain/sprain should be suspected; if no red flag findings are present, then imaging is not necessary.   

Option Analysis

❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: CT of the lumbar spine would be appropriate if the patient were unable to undergo MRI (e.g. due to hardware implantation). However, MRI allows for better visualization of the soft tissue structures of the lumbar spine and is, therefore, the preferred imaging modality when osteomyelitis is suspected. 
✅ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the lumbar spine:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ 18F–fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) and computed tomography:
Incorrect: 18F–FDG-PET/CT is a highly sensitive means of detecting vertebral osteomyelitis and can be considered in the diagnostic workup of complex spinal pathology when other studies are negative and suspicion for infection or malignancy remains high. The current gold standard in imaging of suspected vertebral osteomyelitis is MRI for its specificity and anatomic detail.  
❌ Lumbar spine and sacroiliac joint X-rays :
Incorrect: The patient's older age at presentation and history of recent spinal procedure that would predispose him to infection are more consistent with a spinal infection rather than ankylosing spondylitis, which typically presents in young males with inflammatory back pain and can be seen on imaging of the sacroiliac joints and spine. 
❌ Bone biopsy:
Incorrect: While a bone biopsy can confirm osteomyelitis and identify the causative organism, it is invasive and typically reserved for cases where the diagnosis remains unclear after imaging, or when there is inadequate response to empirical treatment with antibiotics. MRI should precede a biopsy in the diagnostic process for suspected spinal infections.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because of bilateral leg swelling and increased abdominal girth. The symptoms started around 2-weeks ago and have progressively worsened. Past medical history is notable for liver cirrhosis that has been well-managed with furosemide for the past 4-years. The patient has also taken over-the-counter ibuprofen for the past few weeks due to back strain. The patient has not made any changes to dietary sodium or fluid intake. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 87/min, respirations are 23/min, and blood pressure is 144/78 mmHg. Physical examination shows bilateral +2 pitting edema and moderate ascites. Laboratory evaluations reveal decreased fractional excretion of sodium. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of liver cirrhosis well-managed with furosemide developed worsening lower extremity edema and ascites over the past 2-weeks. These symptoms are likely due to recent ibuprofen use.       

Furosemide is a loop diuretic that inhibits the Na+/K+/2Cl- symporter in the ascending limb of the loop of Henle. Loop diuretics also increase the synthesis of prostaglandin in the afferent renal arterioles to increase renal blood flow (RBF), glomerular filtration rate (GFR), and NaCl excretion via the urine.        

In healthy patients, NSAIDs (e.g. ibuprofen) have minimal effect on renal perfusion due to low prostaglandin synthesis. However, in patients with intravascular volume depletion (e.g., cirrhosis, dehydration), the inhibition of prostaglandin synthesis by NSAIDs results in a markedly decreased RBF and GFR. These effects result in reduced delivery of fluids and electrolytes to the renal tubule, thereby causing water and salt retention as well as symptoms of volume overload in susceptible patients.    

Option Analysis

❌ Insufficient dose of furosemide:
Incorrect: This patient’s condition has been well-managed with furosemide for the past 4 years. The deterioration of his condition is most likely a result of reduced renal blood flow and glomerular filtration secondary to recent ibuprofen use. 
✅ Use of ibuprofen for pain:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Incompetent venous valves:
Incorrect: Varicose veins are dilated, tortuous, subcutaneous veins that result from incompetent venous valves in the lower extremity. No such veins were identified on physical examination. In contrast, the progressively worsening lower extremity edema and ascites in this patient is more suggestive of fluid retention secondary to NSAID administration. 
❌ Occlusion of the hepatic veins:
Incorrect: Budd-Chiari syndrome results from occlusion of the hepatic veins. Although it can present with abdominal ascites and lower extremity edema, patients typically also have abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and jaundice. The deterioration of this patient’s condition is more likely due to reduced renal blood flow and glomerular filtration secondary to ibuprofen intake. 
❌ Thrombosis of the deep veins :
Incorrect: Deep vein thrombosis usually presents with unilateral lower extremity pain, erythema, and tenderness. It does not present with ascites or bilateral lower extremity edema.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office for a routine follow-up. He does not have any active complaints at this visit. The patient last visited the emergency department five months ago to evaluate a skin rash and difficulty breathing following the ingestion of furosemide for hypertension. Past medical history is significant for type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin, atorvastatin, and lisinopril. Family history is noncontributory. He smokes two packs of cigarettes daily and does not consume alcohol or illicit drugs. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination is unremarkable. His home glucose measurement review shows his postprandial glucose levels are frequently elevated. Laboratory testing reveals hemoglobin HbA1c is 7.5%. A decision to add a hypoglycemic drug acts on pancreatic beta cells' K-ATP channel to release insulin at all blood glucose levels. Which of the following best describes the drug added to this patient’s medication regimen?
questions.solution:
This patient with inadequate glycemic control on metformin is most likely started on a meglitinide, a non-sulfonylurea insulin secretagogue. It binds to a different site on pancreatic beta cells than sulfonylurea. Still, it results in a similar effect, i.e., inhibition of potassium ATP channels in the pancreatic beta cells, leading to depolarization and calcium influx, with subsequent insulin release in the blood at all glucose levels.  



They have a rapid onset and shorter duration of action (approximately one hour) compared to sulfonylureas and are usually administered with meals to manage postprandial glucose levels. Common examples include repaglinide and nateglinide. As they are structurally different from sulfonylureas, this class of drugs can be used in patients with known sulfa allergies (such as this patient). Side effects include hypoglycemia and weight gain but are less severe than sulfonylureas. 

Option Analysis

❌ Glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist :
Incorrect: Glucagon-like peptide-1 agonist (e.g. exenatide) binds GLP-1 receptors and stimulates glucose-dependent insulin release from the pancreatic islets. It does not affect the K-ATP channel and only causes insulin release in response to elevated blood glucose levels. 
❌ Dipeptidyl peptidase four inhibitors :
Incorrect: Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) inhibitors (e.g. sitagliptin) inhibit DPP-4, an enzyme that deactivates glucagon-like peptide 1. Its inhibition results in the same effect as that of GLP-1 analogs, i.e. increased glucose-induced insulin release. Although it is used to manage postprandial blood glucose levels, it does not directly inhibit the K-ATP channel on pancreatic beta cells. 
❌ Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 inhibitor :
Incorrect: Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor (e.g. canagliflozin) acts on the renal tubule to prevent the reabsorption of glucose. Although it manages postprandial blood glucose levels, it does not affect insulin production by pancreatic beta cells. 
✅ Meglitinide :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Thiazolidinediones :
Incorrect: Thiazolidinediones (e.g. pioglitazone) are synthetic ligands that bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma receptors leading to increased insulin sensitivity (not release) by upregulating the transcription of insulin-responsive genes in peripheral tissues (e.g., adipose tissue, skeletal muscles, and liver).

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department for right eye pain and redness. She has had worsening pain in the right eye for four days, and she states the pain is worse at night. Her vision is blurry today, and there is a foreign body sensation in the eye. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 138/88 mmHg. On examination, the patient is in moderate distress, holding her hand over her right eye. Vision is 20/50 in the right eye and 20/25 in the left. There is diffuse injection of the conjunctiva of the right eye with photosensitivity and tearing. The pain worsens with extra-ocular movements. Pupils are equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. Inflamed scleral vessels are identified on slit lamp examination. Which of the following additional historical features is most likely to be present?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior scleritis, which is an inflammatory condition of the eye characterized by significant pain that is worse at night, redness, photosensitivity, and decreased visual acuity. The finding of inflamed scleral vessels on slit lamp examination supports the diagnosis. At least half of cases of scleritis are linked to an underlying autoimmune condition like rheumatoid arthritis.        

The history and physical examination of a patient with a red eye are aimed at determining whether red flag features are present and narrowing down the diagnosis. Red flag features indicate an immediate threat to vision. Red flag findings include severe pain, decreased visual acuity, photophobia, pupillary changes, increased intraocular pressure, anterior chamber inflammation, and corneal epithelial defects.    



Key features from the history can help narrow down the most probable cause. For example, scleritis commonly occurs in patients with an underlying autoimmune condition, while hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis is usually seen in patients who are sexually active or immunocompromised, or in neonates exposed during vaginal delivery. Patients with keratitis often have underlying autoimmune conditions or infections (i.e., herpes simplex virus). Keratoconjunctivitis sicca often occurs in patients with a history of Sjogren syndrome or in patients taking medications with a drying effect on the eyes (e.g., antihistamines, diuretics). Certain forms of angle-closure glaucoma are hereditary; therefore, a positive family history can signal an increased risk of this condition. Patients with conjunctivitis may have a history of recent exposure to chemical irritants, recent bacterial or upper respiratory infections, or seasonal allergies. Benign causes of a red eye can often be diagnosed clinically after a thorough history and physical examination. In cases where red flags are present, the history and physical will determine which additional tests are necessary in consultation with an ophthalmologist.

Option Analysis

✅ Rheumatoid arthritis :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Recent head trauma:
Incorrect: Head trauma can cause a variety of eye disorders, including globe rupture, subconjunctival hemorrhage, corneal abrasions, and glaucoma. However, this patient has scleritis, which is commonly associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis. 
❌ Multiple sexual partners:
Incorrect: Although bacterial infection, such as from a sexually transmitted infection, can lead to scleritis, this etiology represents only a small percentage of cases of scleritis and is typically associated with copious purulent discharge, which is absent in this case.  
❌ Sickle cell anemia:
Incorrect: Sickle cell anemia increases the risk of developing glaucoma. However, this patient has scleritis, which is frequently associated with autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.  
❌ Recent vomiting:
Incorrect: Increased intrathoracic pressure from actions like coughing, sneezing, vomiting, heavy lifting, or performing a Valsalva maneuver can lead to a subconjunctival hemorrhage. However, this has scleritis, which is often associated with autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents to the urgent care clinic for evaluation of pain in the left eye and a rash on the nose. He has had a left sided headache for two days, and today, a painful rash appeared on the left forehead and nose accompanied by pain and redness of the left eye. He has not been exposed to any new materials nor has he experienced recent facial or head trauma. The patient reports recently recovering from COVID-19 but has no chronic medical conditions. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respiratory rate is 18/min, blood pressure is 136/82 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Vision is 20/20 in the right eye and 20/50 in the left. Examination of the eyes reveals bulbar conjunctival injection diffusely in the left eye with photosensitivity. Pupils are round and reactive to light, and extraocular muscles are intact bilaterally. Painful, vesicular lesions are noted at the tip of the nose. Which of the following tests would help confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Slit lamp exam with Fluorescein staining

questions.solution:
This patient’s unilateral eye redness, photosensitivity, and decreased vision in the setting of a new-onset painful vesicular rash on the left forehead and at the tip of the nose (Hutchinson sign) is highly concerning for herpes zoster ophthalmicus. Herpes zoster ophthalmicus is a sight-threatening condition caused by herpes zoster involvement of the ophthalmic division of the fifth cranial nerve. Patients can have uveitis, episcleritis, and keratitis. Patients with epithelial or stromal keratitis are at risk for vision loss. Slit lamp exam with Fluorescein staining showing a dendritic pattern can confirm keratitis.       

Patients presenting with a red eye should first be characterized as either having a vision-threatening condition or a likely benign condition, based on the presence or absence of red flags. Benign conditions can usually be diagnosed clinically with a limited, office-based evaluation by a non-ophthalmologist clinician. Additional diagnostic workup and consultation with an ophthalmologist should be pursued when red flag features are present. A fundoscopic and slit lamp exam are standard for most emergent eye conditions. Goniometry will provide a diagnosis in acute angle-closure glaucoma, CT of the head is indicated in globe rupture, and fluorescein staining is essential to the workup of conditions such as keratitis and corneal injury. Laboratory testing for gonorrhea is indicated in suspected cases of hyperacute bacterial conjunctivitis.   

Option Analysis

✅ Slit lamp exam with Fluorescein staining :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
