The physician decides to initiate a medication that blocks glucose reabsorption in the proximal convoluted tubules. Initiation of this new medication will increase the risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
This patient with uncontrolled type II diabetes mellitus was likely prescribed an oral hypoglycemic medication that belongs to the class sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor (e.g., canagliflozin and dapagliflozin). These medications can increase the risk of developing urinary tract infections due to glycosuria.       
SGLT2 is the glucose transporter in the proximal renal tubule that accounts for 90% of all renal glucose absorption. When SGLT2 inhibitors inhibit this transporter, the kidney cannot reabsorb glucose.        

SGLT2 inhibitors are primarily indicated in patients who are intolerant to first-line therapies, have inadequate glucose control with metformin, or deny injection therapies. Significant adverse effects include:     
 
  •  Urinary tract infections (UTIs) and vulvovaginal candidiasis due to glycosuria which provides a medium for fungal and bacterial growth  
 
  •  Hypotension: Due to osmotic diuresis and intravascular volume contraction  
 
  •  Acute kidney injury (should be used with caution in older adults)  
 
  •  Weight loss: Due to an increase in renal glucose elimination  
 
  •  Hyperkalemia  
 
  •  Low bone mineral density  

  

Option Analysis

❌ Acute pancreatitis :
Incorrect: Acute pancreatitis is an uncommon but serious adverse effect of glucagon-like peptide-1(GLP-1) agonists. GLP-1 agonists (exenatide and liraglutide) are injectable hypoglycemic medications and cause glucose-dependent insulin secretion by binding its receptors on the pancreatic beta cells.  
❌ Heart failure :
Incorrect: Heart failure is an uncommon but significant adverse effect of thiazolidinediones (e.g. pioglitazone), synthetic ligands that bind to peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma receptors. They do not affect the renal tubules. 
✅ Urinary tract infection :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Vitamin B12 deficiency :
Incorrect: Metformin can induce vitamin B12 deficiency in the long term by decreasing its absorption in the intestine. It inhibits mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase (mGPD), inhibiting gluconeogenesis by blocking pyruvate carboxylase. It is not known to affect renal tubules. 
❌ Nasopharyngitis :
Incorrect: Dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP-4) inhibitors (e.g. sitagliptin) can predispose patients to nasopharyngitis. It acts by inhibiting DPP-4, an enzyme that deactivates glucagon-like peptide 1. Its inhibition results in increased glucose-induced insulin release.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department due to bilateral leg swelling. Three days ago, the patient developed a dull, achy pain and swelling in both calves. The swelling and pain have continued to worsen. The patient has had three lower extremity, and one upper extremity deep vein thromboses in the past. He does not currently take any medication. The patient does not use alcohol or tobacco, and he works as a waiter in a local restaurant. Temperature is 37.3 ºC (99.1 ºF), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 18/min and blood pressure is 141/86 mmHg. On physical examination, both legs are edematous with mild erythema and tenderness to palpation. Lower extremity venous ultrasound with Doppler shows bilateral deep vein thromboses below the knee. The patient is given a dose of subcutaneous enoxaparin. Bloodwork is subsequently obtained. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to perform as part of the workup?

choices.text: Protein C activity level in four months
Anticardiolipin antibody now and in three months, regardless of initial test results
Prothrombin activity level in four months

questions.solution:
This 43-year-old man with a history of multiple prior venous thromboses is diagnosed with bilateral lower extremity deep vein thromboses. Given his extensive history of thromboses, he should be tested for an underlying hypercoagulable disorder. Given the presence of the current clot and the dose of enoxaparin administered in the emergency department that will interfere with testing, this patient should wait before certain hypercoagulable testing is performed. Testing for Protein C activity level should be performed four weeks after completion of anticoagulation, which would be in 4 months (assuming 3 months of anticoagulation treatment).    

If a hypercoagulable disorder is suspected, patients should be tested for inherited hypercoagulable states, including mutations in factor V Leiden and prothrombin gene, and activity levels of protein C, protein S, and antithrombin. While genetic testing can be performed right away, functional assays will be inaccurate with acute thrombosis and current anticoagulation treatment. These studies (e.g., protein C and S) should be performed 4 weeks after completion of anticoagulation therapy. The patient should also be assessed for antiphospholipid antibodies, which include anti-cardiolipin, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein, and lupus anticoagulant. A positive antiphospholipid antibody result should be confirmed with a repeat test in 12 weeks.   

Option Analysis

✅ Protein C activity level in four months:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Prothrombin activity level now:
Incorrect: In patients with a suspected hypercoagulable disorder, testing for prothrombin G20210A gene mutation should be performed, but Prothrombin activity levels are not checked. 
❌ Anticardiolipin antibody now and in three months, regardless of initial test results:
Incorrect: An initial anticardiolipin antibody would be appropriate to check now as part of the hypercoagulable disorder workup. Antiphospholipid antibodies (anti-cardiolipin, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein, and lupus anticoagulant) should be repeated at 12 weeks only if they are positive on the initial screen. 
❌ Prothrombin activity level in four months:
Incorrect: In patients with suspected hypercoagulable disorders, testing for a prothrombin G20210A gene mutation should be performed, but Prothrombin activity levels are not checked. 
❌ Antinuclear antibody now:
Incorrect: Patients with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome may have an elevated ANA and can have associated SLE. However, testing for antiphospholipid antibody syndrome should be performed with anti-cardiolipin, anti-beta-2-glycoprotein, and lupus anticoagulant testing.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of diarrhea, runny nose, muscle aches, anxiety, and insomnia. He mentions these symptoms started about 16 hours after he stopped using oxycodone. He has been taking this medication recreationally for the past year. He has no other significant past medical history, takes no other medications, and does not drink alcohol or use other recreational drugs. Temperature is 99.8°F (37.7°C), blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respiratory rate is 16/min. The patient appears anxious and diaphoretic and is constantly moving in his seat and short when answering questions. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be observed?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of opioid withdrawal syndrome, including symptoms related to sympathetic and central nervous system arousal. These include mild hypertension, tachycardia, anxiety, irritability, and insomnia. Frequent yawning is also a common finding in patients with opioid withdrawal syndrome. 

Opioid withdrawal occurs when a person who has become physically dependent on opioids either drastically reduces or stops opioid consumption altogether. While opioid withdrawal syndrome is typically not life-threatening, it can cause significant distress and discomfort. Common symptoms include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, muscle aches, insomnia, anxiety, and agitation. Frequent yawning is particularly emblematic of opioid withdrawal, along with other signs of autonomic dysregulation, such as piloerection (goosebumps), tearing, sweating, and rhinorrhea. Vital signs can reveal evidence of sympathetic overactivity, such as tachycardia, elevated blood pressure, elevated body temperature.   

Option Analysis

✅ Frequent yawning :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dry skin :
Incorrect: Opioid withdrawal is more likely to cause sweating and piloerection, often referred to as "cold turkey" symptoms, rather than dry skin. 
❌ Constricted pupils :
Incorrect: Pupillary constriction (miosis) is a typical effect of opioid use, but not of opioid withdrawal. During withdrawal, patients typically exhibit dilated pupils (mydriasis). 
❌ Constipation :
Incorrect: Constipation is a common effect of opioid use due to reduced gastrointestinal (GI) motility. Conversely, opioid withdrawal can lead to diarrhea as normal GI function begins to resume. 
❌ Dry eyes :
Incorrect: Dry eyes are not typically associated with opioid withdrawal, which is more likely to cause excessive tearing along with other increased secretions (e.g., rhinorrhea).

questions.text: A 58-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of confusion, disorientation, and slurred speech. His partner reports that he has been increasingly forgetful over the past few weeks and has had difficulty with daily tasks. She also mentions that he has been more fatigued than usual, and his abdomen has become distended. The patient has a history of alcohol use disorder and has multiple glasses of vodka nightly. He was diagnosed with cirrhosis two years ago. He has not returned to the clinic for follow-up care or treatment. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, blood pressure is 128/70 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On examination, the patient is drowsy but awakens easily. He is oriented to person only. There is a bilateral scleral icterus. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light. Spider angiomas are present across the chest. Extraocular muscles are intact and there are no abnormalities in eye movement. Asterixis is present. The abdomen is distended with a positive fluid wave. There is no tenderness to palpation. There are no focal neurologic deficits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient who presents with lethargy, disorientation, slurred speech, and asterixis in the setting of cirrhosis with abdominal distension and possible spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP), likely has hepatic encephalopathy. He has signs of chronic liver disease, including jaundice and spider angioma. He also has findings consistent with ascites. This patient has a distended abdomen with a fluid wave and paracentesis should be performed to diagnose spontaneous bacterial peritonitis that may have precipitated hepatic encephalopathy. Findings of an elevated serum ammonia level would support the diagnosis of hepatic encephalopathy. 

The diagnostic workup for an adult with altered mental status (AMS) begins with a rapid assessment of vital signs and basic laboratory tests, including blood glucose, electrolytes, and arterial blood gas to quickly identify and correct life-threatening conditions such as hypoglycemia, hypoxia, or hypercapnia. Patients with Hypoglycemia typically present with confusion, diaphoresis, and tachycardia, and it is rapidly reversible with glucose administration. Patients with Hypoxia or hypercapnia, often seen in conjunction with respiratory disorders, may present with confusion, cyanosis, or lethargy, and low oxygen or elevated carbon dioxide levels on blood gas analysis can confirm the diagnosis. Toxins and medications can cause AMS, and symptoms will differ based on the substance ingested. detailed history, toxicology screen, and careful review of the patient’s medication list can help make the diagnosis. Patients suspected of having Central nervous system disorders, such as stroke or meningitis, require imaging and possibly lumbar puncture. Metabolic disorders like uremia or hepatic encephalopathy are diagnosed via a combination of laboratory abnormalities and clinical findings. The table below shows some of the common causes of AMS and their associated findings.   

Option Analysis

❌ Wernicke encephalopathy:
Incorrect: Wernicke encephalopathy is associated with thiamine deficiency and can be seen in patients with chronic alcohol use. Patients present with encephalopathy, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. This patient does not have ophthalmoplegia but does have signs of chronic liver disease, ascites, and encephalopathy which point to spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP) as a precipitant of hepatic encephalopathy. 
❌ Subdural hematoma:
Incorrect: Patients who have a subdural hematoma typically present with a history of head trauma, followed by gradual onset of headache, confusion, and focal neurological deficits. This patient has not experienced trauma and has no focal neurological findings, making a subdural hematoma unlikely.  
❌ Delirium tremens:
Incorrect: Delirium tremens is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal characterized by agitation, tremors, hallucinations, and autonomic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypertension). This patient does not exhibit these symptoms and has no history of recent alcohol cessation. 
✅ Hepatic encephalopathy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Dementia:
Incorrect: Dementia typically has a more gradual course. This patient has a subacute presentation of altered mental status more likely due to hypercalcemia due to lung malignancy.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the clinic for a routine examination. She reports regular menstrual cycles and has no significant medical history. She has no concerns now. Upon further questioning, she states that she has had three sexual partners in the last year and has not consistently used condoms. Her last sexual encounter was with a new partner three months ago. She has no known history of sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Her last Pap smear one year ago was normal. Physical examination is within normal limits. Which of the following STI screenings is recommended now?

choices.text: Chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and herpes simplex virus (HSV)
No screening is necessary at this visit

questions.solution:
The patient is a sexually active woman under the age of 25, making her eligible for routine yearly screening for chlamydia and gonorrhea, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) guidelines. These infections are common among young, sexually active individuals who are, in many cases, asymptomatic. This makes regular screening crucial to prevent complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease, infertility, and further transmission. Additionally, because this patient is sexually active with multiple partners and inconsistent condom use, she should be screened for HIV and syphilis as well. 

HIV screening is recommended for all individuals aged 13 to 64 at least once in their lifetime, with more frequent testing for those with risk factors. Given that this patient has multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use, annual HIV screening is appropriate. Syphilis screening is also recommended for individuals at higher risk of infection, including those with multiple sexual partners. While syphilis is less common than chlamydia and gonorrhea, it should still be screened for in high-risk populations.    

Option Analysis

❌ Chlamydia and syphilis:
Incorrect: Chlamydia and syphilis screening is necessary for this patient given her age and risk factors; however, this option is incomplete as it omits the additional necessary testing for gonorrhea and HIV that are recommended for this patient based on her sexual history.  
✅ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and syphilis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Chlamydia and gonorrhea:
Incorrect: This choice covers routine screening for STIs in young patients who are sexually active but misses the additional screenings for HIV and syphilis that are recommended for this patient given her risk factors.  
❌ Chlamydia, gonorrhea, HIV, and herpes simplex virus (HSV) :
Incorrect: For this patient, chlamydia, gonorrhea, and HIV screenings are recommended, but routine screening for HSV in asymptomatic individuals is not recommended. HSV testing is reserved for patients with symptoms suggestive of genital herpes, those with recent exposure or for patients specifically requesting testing. 
❌ No screening is necessary at this visit:
Incorrect: This option is incorrect because the patient falls within the recommended age group for routine yearly chlamydia and gonorrhea screening. And given her sexual history, she warrants screening for additional STIs, including HIV and syphilis.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of easy bruising and frequent nosebleeds over the past several months, and she reports progressively worsening heavy menstrual periods. Her mother and maternal uncle have a history of spontaneous bleeding. She has no significant past medical history and takes no prescribed medications. She has been taking glucosamine supplements for joint pain from running and doesn't take any other supplements or medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals scattered ecchymoses over the bilateral upper extremities. There is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s bleeding? 

 Laboratory Test Result     
 Hemoglobin 11.8 g/dL     
 White blood cell count 7,500 /µL     
 Platelets 140,000 /µL     
 Peripheral smear No schistocytes     
 Prothrombin time (PT) 12 seconds (normal 11-15 seconds)     
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 42 seconds (normal 25-40 seconds)     
 Fibrinogen 250 mg/dL     
 D-dimer 0.5 mg/L     
 Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL
questions.solution:
The patient presents with easy bruising, heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), and has a family history of spontaneous bleeding. Laboratory results show a slightly prolonged aPTT, with normal PT and mild thrombocytopenia. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is von Willebrand disease.

Von Willebrand disease (vWD) is the most common hereditary bleeding disorder. It is caused by the qualitative or quantitative deficiency of the pro-von Willebrand factor which helps maintain levels of factor VIII and helps with platelet adhesion and binding to endothelial components after a vascular injury. Von Willebrand disease leads to a decrease in factor VIII levels (and often a slightly prolonged aPTT). Common manifestations include menorrhagia, bleeding after minor procedures, and mucocutaneous bleeding.    

Option Analysis

✅ Von Willebrand disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hemophilia A carrier status:
Incorrect: Hemophilia A typically presents with deep tissue bleeding (hemarthroses or muscle hematoma), rather than mucocutaneous bleeding. Additionally, carriers do not exhibit symptoms unless they have extremely low factor VIII levels, which are unlikely given the normal PT and mildly elevated PTT. 
❌ Hemolytic uremic syndrome:
Incorrect: Hemolytic uremic syndrome typically occurs in children but can rarely be seen in adults. Patients present with thrombocytopenia, microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, and acute kidney injury. This patient has no evidence of microangioopathic hemolytic anemia or kidney injury.  
❌ Drug induced immune thrombocytopenia (DITP):
Incorrect: Drug induced thrombocytopenia (DITP) is thrombocytopenia due to drug-dependent platelet antibodies causing platelet destruction. Glucosamine supplements have not been associated with DITP, and this patient is not taking any other medications.  
❌ Disseminated intravascular coagulation:
Incorrect: Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) typically causes a prolonged PT and aPTT, low fibrinogen levels, elevated D-dimer, and evidence of both bleeding and thrombosis. This patient has a mildly prolonged aPTT, but lacks the other features characteristic of DIC.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after suddenly collapsing while out for a walk. Upon arrival, the patient is lightheaded and short of breath. An electrocardiogram obtained by emergency medical services en route is demonstrated below. The patient is given a medication that markedly prolongs the cardiac action potential repolarization. Which of the following best describes this medication's primary mechanism of action?
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Decrease in SA and AV nodal activity
Selective blockade of fast sodium channels
Increase in potassium efflux via blockade of the AV node

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a syncopal episode with ventricular tachycardia. She is given a medication that markedly prolongs repolarization of the ventricular action potential, which is consistent with the mechanism of action of class III antiarrhythmic medications.

Class III antiarrhythmic medications function primarily via blockade of potassium rectifier currents, which results in a prolonged phase three and marked prolongation of the ventricular action potential (AP) duration. An increase in the AP duration results in an increased effective refractory period, QT interval, and subsequent ability of the heart to react to reentrant tachycardias.

In addition to this primary mechanism, class III medications such as amiodarone and dronedarone also have some class I, II, and IV effects via the blockade of sodium channels, ꞵ-receptors, and calcium channels, respectively. Notably, amiodarone has the most potent effects, effectively treating arrhythmias.

Additional medications in this class include ibutilide, dofetilide, and sotalol.    

Option Analysis

✅ Blockade of potassium rectifier currents:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Decrease in SA and AV nodal activity:
Incorrect: ꞵ-blockers work via selective ꞵ-receptor blockade, decreasing intracellular cAMP and Ca2+ currents. These effects ultimately decrease the slope of phase four of the cardiac action potential.  
❌ Selective blockade of fast sodium channels:
Incorrect: Blockade of fast sodium channels is the mechanism of action of class I antiarrhythmic medications.  
❌ Blockade of voltage-dependent calcium channels:
Incorrect: Class IV antiarrhythmic medications work by inhibiting voltage-dependent calcium channels, decreasing conduction velocity, increasing the PR interval, and increasing the effective refractory period.  
❌ Increase in potassium efflux via blockade of the AV node:
Incorrect: Adenosine works via blockade of A1 adenosine receptors, which leads to increased potassium efflux and blocking of the AV note. This medication is not used to treat ventricular tachycardia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents to the emergency department with lightheadedness and dizziness. He feels his heart is “in that funny rhythm again.” Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 152/87 mmHg, and pulse is 138/min. An electrocardiogram from triage demonstrates atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The patient is given a medication that acts primarily on the phase of the cardiac action potential as designated in the figure below. Which medications were most likely used to treat this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with symptomatic atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. The patient is administered a medication that works on phase three of the cardiac action potential, consistent with the mechanism of action of class III antiarrhythmic medications. Of the medications listed, only ibutilide has class III activity.  

Class III antiarrhythmic medications function primarily via the blockade of potassium rectifier currents and exert the most significant effect on phase three of the cardiac action potential. The blocking of potassium rectifier currents by these medications results in an increased effective refractory period, QT interval, and ability of the heart to react to reentrant tachycardia. Notable medications in this class include amiodarone, ibutilide, dofetilide, and sotalol.   

Option Analysis

✅ Ibutilide:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Flecainide :
Incorrect: Flecainide is a class IC antiarrhythmic that works via strong sodium channel blockade, which decreases the slope of phase 0. It does not affect phase three of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Propafenone:
Incorrect: Propafenone, like flecainide, is a class IC antiarrhythmic that works via strong sodium channel blockade, which results in a decrease in the slope of phase 0. It does not have a meaningful effect on phase 3 of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is a class II medication that exerts its effects via ꞵ-receptor blockade. It does not affect phase three of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Ivabradine:
Incorrect: Ivabradine prolongs phase four of slow depolarization by inhibiting the “funny” sodium channel. The medication does not affect phase three of the cardiac action potential.

questions.text:
A 78-year-old man presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. According to the patient’s caretaker, he was found at the foot of his bed this morning. Past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease, hypertension, and atrial fibrillation. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), the pulse is 202/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg. Physical examination is significant for a pale man with profuse diaphoresis and rales bilaterally. The results of the initial electrocardiogram are shown below. He is given a medication that functions by blocking potassium rectifier currents. Which of the following graphs best represents the desired effects on the cardiac action potential after administering this medication? 
 

Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
This ill-appearing patient in respiratory distress presents with altered mental status. The electrocardiogram demonstrates wide-complex tachycardia, consistent with ventricular tachycardia. He was prescribed a class three antiarrhythmic medication, blocking potassium rectifiers. Choice A illustrates this medication's effects on the cardiac action potential. 

Class III antiarrhythmics block potassium rectifier currents, prolonging phase three of the action potential (AP) and AP duration. An increase in AP duration increases the effective refractory period it takes for the heart to reach phase four for another depolarization. Ultimately, these changes manifest with a prolonged QT interval on an electrocardiogram. 

In addition to this primary mechanism, class III medications also have some class I, II, and IV effects via the blockade of sodium channels, ꞵ-receptors, and calcium channels, respectively. Specifically, amiodarone and dronedarone have all of these properties, resulting in a mild decrease in the slope of phase zero, a decrease in the height of phase two, and a decrease in the slope of phase four.    

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Procainamide is a class IA antiarrhythmic drug used to treat cardiac arrhythmias, including atrial fibrillation. It depresses phase 0 and increases the duration of the action potential.  
❌ :
Incorrect: Mexiletine is a class Ib sodium channel blocker. The medication depresses phase 0 and shortens repolarization, thereby decreasing the duration of the action potential.  
❌ :
Incorrect: Flecainide and propafenone are class Ic sodium channel blockers that function by depressing phase 0. These medications have minimal effect on cardiac repolarization. As a result, they do not impact action potential duration. 
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ :
Incorrect: This graph demonstrates the effects of a class IV antiarrhythmic agent, such as diltiazem. These effects are mediated by calcium channel blockade, not sodium.

questions.text: Medication A is under study for the treatment of cardiac arrhythmias. Based on use in animal models, it is found that this medication increases action potential duration and effective refractory period with a subsequent increase in QT interval. The medication is found to increase liver function enzymes in animal models. Pre-administration (black) and post-administration (red) cardiac action potentials are demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes this medication's class(es) of antiarrhythmic properties?

choices.text: Classes I, II, III, and IV

questions.solution:
The medication increases the cardiac action potential (AP) duration, effective refractory period, and QT interval. It is also found to cause an increase in liver function tests. Based on the figure, the medication decreases the slope of phase 0, reduces the height of phase 2, prolongs phase 3, and decreases the slope of phase 4. Both medications possess class I, II, and IV activity. 

Like other class III antiarrhythmics, Amiodarone and dronedarone block potassium rectifier currents, resulting in prolongation of phase 3 and the AP duration, increase in the effective refractory period, and prolongation of the QT interval on an electrocardiogram.  

In addition to these class III effects, the drugs’ class I effects result in sodium channel blockade, class II effects result in ꞵ-blockade, and class IV effects result in decreased conduction velocity. These properties ultimately manifest with the changes observed in the figure above and make amiodarone and potent dronedarone antiarrhythmics used in treating both supraventricular and ventricular arrhythmias. 

In contrast, other class III antiarrhythmics (e.g., dofetilide, ibutilide) only demonstrate prolongation of phase 3.    

Option Analysis

❌ Class I :
Incorrect: Class I medications are predominantly sodium channel blockers, with class Ia exhibiting some potassium channel blocking effects. These medications do not have calcium channel-blocking effects and hence would not affect phase two of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Class II :
Incorrect: Class II medications such as metoprolol will predominantly affect pacemaker cells by decreasing the slope of phase 4 of the cardiac action potential. In contrast, this medication described in the question stem also involves phases zero, two, and three. 
❌ Class III :
Incorrect: Typical class III medications such as dofetilide and ibutilide have potassium channel-blocking effects but do not have notable sodium or calcium channel-blocking effects. As a result, class III medications do not typically affect phases zero and two of the cardiac action potential. 
❌ Class II, III :
Incorrect: Sotalol is generally classified as a class III antiarrhythmic medication, although it has some class two effects. It does not have significant calcium channel-blocking effects and would not affect phase two of the cardiac action potential. 
✅ Classes I, II, III, and IV:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of right shoulder pain for the past several weeks. The patient describes the pain as dull and generalized and has noted that the pain worsens with overhead movements. The patient experienced a fall while rock climbing several weeks ago during which he landed directly onto his right shoulder. He immediately felt pain in the anterior shoulder. The patient has no significant past medical history and does not take any medications daily. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination does not demonstrate obvious deformity, swelling, or warmth over the right shoulder. The patient has full range of motion of the right shoulder but notes worsening pain with abduction and elevation of the shoulder. The patient is asked to flex the shoulder, extend at the elbow, and internally rotate with the arm until the thumb is pointing downward. When the examiner pushes the arm to the floor while the patient resists, there is deep shoulder pain. When the patient’s arm is supinated and the examiner pushes down, there is no pain. An X-ray of the right shoulder is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 


Reproduced from: Wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of traumatic shoulder pain. He experiences pain in the anterior shoulder that worsens with overhead movements and a positive O’brien test, which is highly suggestive of a labral tear. The next best step is to obtain a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the shoulder to confirm the diagnosis radiographically.        

Shoulder pain is a common symptom with many underlying causes, including conditions affecting the joint, capsule, tendons, or bursa. When performing a history and physical examination for a patient with shoulder pain, the first step is to identify if the patient’s shoulder pain is due to trauma or infection.    

When a clear history of trauma is present, further diagnostic differentiation can often be achieved by a combination of physical examination maneuvers and imaging. For example, patients with a shoulder dislocation or AC separation will typically have an obvious deformity of the shoulder that may be detected by X-ray. Patients with a labral tear or rotator cuff pathology will exhibit pain with certain physical examination maneuvers like the O’brien test or the drop arm test. Patients with trauma and positive physical exam signs of labral tear or rotator cuff pathology should undergo additional imaging with MRI to confirm the diagnosis.    

Option Analysis

✅ Labral tear:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Acromioclavicular separation :
Incorrect: While a positive O’brien test as seen in this patient may indicate AC separation as well as labral pathology, there is no evidence of AC separation radiographically. Additionally, patients with AC separation often have a visible deformity on physical exam. 
❌ Anterior shoulder dislocation:
Incorrect: Patients with a shoulder dislocation typically have evidence of a severely limited range of motion at the shoulder. The shoulder typically appears “squared off.” Moreover, this patient's X-ray does not demonstrate a dislocation. 
❌ Osteoarthritis :
Incorrect: This patient has a normal X-ray without joint space narrowing or osteophyte formation that would be suggestive of arthritis. Moreover, osteoarthritis would be unlikely in this young, healthy patient.  
❌ Humeral head fracture:
Incorrect: This patient has a normal X-ray without evidence of fracture or dislocation despite this patient's history of direct trauma to the shoulder.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner for evaluation of altered mental status. His family reports worsening confusion over the past 24 hours, and the patient is now difficult to arouse. The patient has a history of cirrhosis due to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 110/min, respiratory rate is 22/min, blood pressure is 88/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 87% on room air. The patient appears stuporous and is unable to answer orientation questions or follow commands. The patient appears jaundiced. The abdomen is distended and tender with a positive fluid wave test. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of cirrhosis presents with altered mental status, ascites, and a tender abdomen. He is unstable and cannot protect his airway. Therefore, immediate stabilization with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation is necessary. The most likely diagnoses are either spontaneous bacterial peritonitis or spontaneous bacterial peritonitis with hepatic encephalopathy. Either way, stabilization is the priority before further diagnostic studies or treatments are performed.       

Many patients with hepatic encephalopathy present in a near comatose state. Thus, before addressing the underlying cause with treatments like lactulose or treating underlying infections, it is crucial to secure the airway and provide supplemental oxygen to maintain adequate oxygenation (oxygen saturation >90%) as part of the ABCDE (Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure) assessment.   

Option Analysis

✅ Endotracheal intubation :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) head without contrast:
Incorrect: A head CT scan may be necessary if there is suspicion for an alternative etiology of altered mental status, such as intracranial hemorrhage. However, this patient with cirrhosis and confusion and ascites most likely has hepatic encephalopathy. He is unstable; therefore, immediate stabilization takes precedence.  
❌ Lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is used for managing patients with hepatic encephalopathy. However, it should be administered after stabilizing the patient’s airway, breathing, and circulation. 
❌ Broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics would be necessary to treat a suspected spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, which may have precipitated hepatic encephalopathy in this patient. However, antibiotic administration should follow securing the airway and stabilizing the patient. 
❌ Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation:
Incorrect: Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation (e.g. BiPAP) is typically used for patients with respiratory distress who can protect their airway. Given the patient's stuporous state, noninvasive ventilation is inappropriate. It may result in aspiration or worsening respiratory failure. Invasive airway management (i.e. intubation) is required for this patient.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with gradually worsening mild chest discomfort, palpitations, and shortness of breath that started 2 days ago. He notes mild fatigue and has had a low-grade fever and cough that began 5 days ago. He has no significant past medical history and does not smoke tobacco or use alcohol or other recreational substances. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg, heart rate is 92 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Cardiac examination reveals a soft S3 gallop, but no murmurs or pericardial rub. Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally, and there is no jugular venous distention or peripheral edema. Laboratory results are shown below. An ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment changes and T-wave inversions in the lateral leads. Chest X-ray is unremarkable. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on transthoracic echocardiogram? 

 Laboratory value     Result    
 Cardiac troponins     1.5 ng/mL (normal <0.04)   
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)     77 mm/hr (normal <20 mm/hr)   
 C-reactive protein (CRP)     35 mg/L (normal <10 mg/L)

choices.text: Global hypokinesis with a mildly reduced ejection fraction
Apical ballooning with preserved basal function

questions.solution:
In patients with myocarditis, a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) can reveal global hypokinesis (reduced movement of the myocardium) or regional hypokinesis and reduced ejection fraction (typically between 40-50%). This finding reflects inflammation and injury to the myocardium caused by the underlying myocarditis. In patients like this one with mild myocarditis transthoracic echocardiogram may reveal global hypokinesis and mildly reduced ejection fraction.        

The diagnostic evaluation for suspected myocarditis involves the combination of clinical history and physical examination, laboratory testing, cardiac imaging, and potentially endomyocardial biopsy. Initial tests include ECG, which may show nonspecific ST-segment changes, and blood tests including cardiac troponin and inflammatory markers (e.g., CRP, ESR). Troponins and inflammatory markers are often elevated.       

Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) can usually reveal regional or global hypokinesis and reduced ejection fraction. For patients with mild myocarditis, these changes are typically subtle, while fulminant myocarditis presents with heart failure, marked reduction in ejection fraction and cardiac dysfunction, and signs of cardiogenic shock. Cardiac MRI may also be used to aid in making a diagnosis. Invasive testing with endomyocardial biopsy may be needed to confirm the diagnosis and assess severity.    

Option Analysis

✅ Global hypokinesis with a mildly reduced ejection fraction:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Apical ballooning with preserved basal function:
Incorrect: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as "broken heart syndrome," is characterized by apical ballooning with normal contraction of the basal segments of the heart. This condition is typically triggered by intense emotional or physical stress and may mimic acute coronary syndrome, with regional wall motion abnormalities. Global hypokinesis of myocarditis with a mildly reduced ejection fraction is more suggestive of myocarditis. 
❌ Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy is typically associated with chronic conditions like hypertension or aortic stenosis. Viral Myocarditis involves inflammation of the myocardium, that can lead to global hypokinesis and decreased ejection fraction. 
❌ Large pericardial effusion with tamponade:
Incorrect: A large pericardial effusion with tamponade is more often associated with pericarditis or malignancy. It can lead to life-threatening hemodynamic compromise (e.g., severe hypotension). This patient has more mild symptoms and a recent upper respiratory illness suggestive of myocarditis which can be associated with global hypokinesis and decreased ejection fraction. 
❌ Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction:
Incorrect: This finding is characteristic of hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM), where abnormal septal thickening causes obstruction of blood flow from the left ventricle. Patients can experience exertional chest pain, syncope, or sudden cardiac death. This patient's presentation and findings are more consistent with Myocarditis, which can lead to global hypokinesis and. Decreased ejection fraction.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department for evaluation of progressively worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, and palpitations over the last three days. She describes the chest pain as constant, dull, and non-radiating. She developed flu-like symptoms 3 days ago. Initially, she experienced shortness of breath with exertion, but she now struggles to breathe at rest. She appears to be in moderate respiratory distress. Temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), blood pressure is 85/60 mmHg, heart rate is 125 beats per minute, respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. On physical examination, there is jugular venous distension, bilateral rales on lung auscultation, and bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities. ECG shows nonspecific ST-segment changes and sinus tachycardia. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) reveals a severely reduced ejection fraction of 25% with global hypokinesis. The patient is started on supplemental oxygen and a dobutamine infusion. Which of the following is the best next step in management if the patient continues to have hypotension despite these initial measures?
questions.solution:
For patients with fulminant myocarditis and cardiogenic shock, initial supportive measures include respiratory and circulatory support. Patients may require intubation and mechanical ventilation. Inotropic agents like dobutamine should be given for circulatory support. When patients fail to respond to these measures, the next step is to initiate mechanical circulatory support (MCS), such as extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP). These interventions provide temporary support by improving cardiac output and oxygenation, allowing time for the heart to recover or until more definitive therapy (e.g., heart transplantation) can be considered.       

Treatment of myocarditis begins with supportive care, which includes oxygen therapy, management of fluid balance, and inotropic support to improve cardiac output in cases of heart failure. For patients who remain unstable despite the use of inotropic agents or for those with fulminant myocarditis, mechanical circulatory support (MCS), such as extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) or an intra-aortic balloon pump (IABP), may be necessary to maintain perfusion and support cardiac function during cardiac recovery. Immunosuppressive therapies like corticosteroids, cyclosporine, or azathioprine may be considered in certain cases. If the myocardium is severely damaged and unresponsive to treatment, heart transplantation may be necessary for survival in patients with irreversible cardiac failure.       

Option Analysis

✅ Mechanical circulatory support:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Oral prednisone:
Incorrect: This patient has fulminant myocarditis with cardiogenic shock. In critical cases, immediate respiratory and circulatory support with intravenous therapies and mechanical mechanisms may be required to stabilize the patient. This should be done before corticosteroids are given intravenously. 
❌ Heart transplantation :
Incorrect: Heart transplantation is a last resort option for patients with myocarditis who do not respond to intravenous inotropic agents and mechanical circulatory support. 
❌ Oral diuretics:
Incorrect: Oral diuretics are inadequate for treating fulminant myocarditis with cardiogenic shock. This patient requires emergent intravenous inotropic agents and mechanical circulatory support if there is inadequate response to inotropes to stabilize hemodynamics. 
❌ Pericardiocentesis:
Incorrect: Pericardiocentesis is indicated for patients presenting with cardiac tamponade or large pericardial effusions, neither of which are seen on this patient’s echocardiogram. This patient in cardiogenic shock from myocarditis should have intravenous inotropic agents and mechanical circulatory support if there is inadequate response to inotropes to stabilize hemodynamics.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman presents to the cardiology clinic for follow-up of recently diagnosed pulmonary hypertension. Six months ago, the patient began seeking medical care for progressive shortness of breath. Prior to this, she had not seen a physician for fifteen years and had no significant medical history. Outpatient computed tomography imaging of the chest was notable for pulmonary edema, and pulmonary function tests showed no abnormalities. An overnight sleep study showed an apnea-hypopnea index of 4. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated significant mitral regurgitation and elevated estimated mean pulmonary artery pressure, which was subsequently confirmed on right heart catheterization. Today, that patient’s vital signs are within normal limits. On physical examination, she is fatigued but otherwise appears well. Cardiac auscultation reveals a 4/6 systolic murmur, best heart at the apex and an S3. Crackles are heard on auscultation of the lungs bilaterally, and there is bilateral lower extremity edema to the knees. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
This 61-year-old woman presents for follow-up of pulmonary hypertension (PH). Outpatient workup showed no obstructive sleep apnea or pulmonary disease, and the patient’s age and lack of comorbidities makes group I PH very unlikely. Given this and the patient’s significant mitral regurgitation, she likely has group II PH due to left heart disease from mitral regurgitation. Surgery of the mitral valve with Transcatheter mitral valve repair is the most appropriate treatment now.   

Pulmonary hypertension (PH) refers to a mean pulmonary artery pressure >20 mmHg and is categorized into five groups (I, II, III, IV, and V) based on the underlying etiology. Group II PH is a common type and is due to left heart disease which may be the result of severe hypertension, heart failure, coronary artery disease, or severe valvulopathy, as seen in this patient. Like the other causes of PH, symptoms and manifestations can be managed with loop diuretics and, if necessary, supplemental oxygen. Most patients with PH will also benefit from cardiopulmonary rehabilitation. If symptoms are severe or persistent in patients with underlying valvular heart disease, valve repair or replacement may be necessary.   

Option Analysis

✅ Transcatheter mitral valve repair:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Epoprostenol:
Incorrect: Epoprostenol is a prostacyclin which can be used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension (group I). This patient likely has group II pulmonary hypertension due to left heart disease and would benefit more from addressing the underlying cause of heart failure. 
❌ Continuous positive airway pressure :
Incorrect: Nightly continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) is the mainstay for treatment of obstructive sleep apnea, which can lead to group III pulmonary hypertension in severe cases (due to hypoxia). This patient’s sleep study does not show obstructive sleep apnea (apnea-hypopnea index <5). 
❌ Metolazone:
Incorrect: While loop diuretics such as furosemide can be used to manage pulmonary hypertension, thiazide diuretics are not appropriate monotherapy. In addition, this patient does not have concomitant hypertension, which would be another indication for a thiazide diuretic. 
❌ Amlodipine:
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers can be used in some cases of pulmonary arterial hypertension (group I). This patient’s pulmonary hypertension is more likely related to left heart disease (group II), which should be managed by treating the underlying cause of heart failure.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of worsening shortness of breath for the past two months. She reports an increase in lower extremity swelling, abdominal fullness, and early satiety. The patient recalls an episode of chest pressure and discomfort approximately three months ago for which she did not seek treatment. Past medical history includes hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia; and she has been intermittently compliant with amlodipine, metformin, and atorvastatin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 156/74 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. The patient is in no acute distress and is resting comfortably on the examination table. Cardiopulmonary examination reveals a right-sided S3. She has notable jugular venous distention, 2+ pitting edema in the lower extremities bilaterally, and abdominal distention with a positive fluid wave. The lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. An electrocardiogram reveals normal sinus rhythm with Q-waves in the inferior leads. An echocardiogram is ordered and reveals impaired right ventricular (RV) wall motion and a reduced RV ejection fraction. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical findings consistent with right heart failure, including dyspnea, lower extremity edema, early satiety, a right sided S3, jugular venous distention, and ascites. The preceding episode of chest pain, along with findings of inferior Q-waves on ECG, and echocardiogram demonstrating right ventricular wall motion abnormalities suggest myocardial disease as the cause of right heart failure. This patient likely sustained an inferior myocardial infarction for which she did not seek treatment, resulting in right heart failure.        

Right heart failure occurs when the right side of the heart fails to adequately perfuse the pulmonary arterial circulation, resulting in elevated central venous pressure. In stable patients, this condition often presents with historical elements of chronic dyspnea, chest discomfort, fatigue, early satiety, or abdominal fullness. Physical examination may reveal jugular venous distention, hepatojugular reflux, bilateral lower extremity edema, or evidence of ascites (e.g. positive fluid wave). Cardiac exam will typically reveal a right ventricular heave, loud P2 (if caused by pulmonary hypertension), and right-sided S3. Importantly, there should be no evidence of pulmonary edema, unless concurrent left-sided heart failure is present.        

Diagnostic findings suggestive of right heart failure include an elevated BNP, evidence of congestive hepatopathy (including elevated AST, ALT, and bilirubin), and elevations in BUN and creatinine (due to cardiorenal syndrome). ECG may demonstrate right axis deviation, right atrial enlargement, and right ventricular hypertrophy. It may also provide clues to a prior inferior myocardial infarction with Q-waves). Chest X-ray may reveal a globular cardiac silhouette with rightward displacement. Additionally, echocardiogram may show evidence of RV dysfunction and right ventricular (RV) wall motion abnormalities and a reduced RV ejection fraction, indicating prior inferior myocardial infarction (as seen in this case). Additional testing, such as right-heart catheterization or a cardiac MRI, may be necessary.   

Option Analysis

✅ Myocardial disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Valvular disease:
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation is more consistent with an inferior MI, causing right heart failure. Tricuspid or pulmonic valve disease would be suspected if this patient had a typical murmur on examination and echocardiographic findings demonstrating regurgitation or stenosis of the affected valves. 
❌ Pulmonary hypertension:
Incorrect: Echocardiographic findings that would be expected with pulmonary hypertension include an elevated estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure, enlarged right atrium and ventricle, and signs of RV strain. Patients with pulmonary hypertension typically have a history of an associated risk factor (e.g. family history of pulmonary hypertension, chronic structural lung disease). This patient's history and findings are more consistent with an inferior MI as the cause of right heart failure. 
❌ Cardiac tamponade:
Incorrect: Patients with cardiac tamponade will generally be hemodynamically unstable. Echocardiographic findings would include a large pericardial effusion with right atrial and ventricular collapse during diastole. 
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Echocardiographic findings suggestive of pulmonary embolism include a hyperkinetic apex, D-sign, and RV strain. The findings in this vignette are more consistent with inferior myocardial infarction, causing right heart failure.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man presents to the primary care physician for evaluation of a painful, red, and swollen eyelids bilaterally for the past three days. The patient reports that he has a gritty sensation in both eyes and crusting along his eyelashes. He has no pain with eye movements or vision changes, and he has not had a fever. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no significant medical history. He drinks alcohol socially and does not use tobacco products. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for the findings shown in the image below, which are present on both eyes. Visual acuity is 20/20 bilaterally. There is no discharge or pain with extraocular eye movements. Which of the following is the best next step in management? 


Reproduced from Wikipedia

choices.text: Warm compresses, lid massage, and lid washing

questions.solution:
This patient presents with clinical features consistent with blepharitis, which is a chronic condition characterized by inflammation of the eyelid and associated eye irritation. First-line treatment includes warm compresses, lid massage, and lid washing.     

Patients with blepharitis typically present with chronic irritation of both eyes, a gritty or burning sensation in both eyes, tearing, and crusting or matting of the eyelashes in the morning. Examination may reveal eyelid swelling and erythema. The eyelid edges often appear pink or irritated and crusting of the lashes or lid margins may be visible. There may be diffuse conjunctival injection.   

Aside from orbital cellulitis, which requires aggressive treatment with intravenous antibiotics, most eyelid disorders including blepharitis, can be treated with supportive and symptomatic management. For example, most cases of hordeolum, chalazion, and blepharitis will often resolve with warm compresses alone and only require additional treatment if refractory to initial therapy. Good eyelid hygiene is also important, including washing the lid with diluted baby shampoo, removing scales and debris, and avoiding eye makeup. Lid massage can help empty the eyelid glands and improve secretion. For blepharitis, topical antibiotics and steroids are reserved for severe or refractory cases.    

Option Analysis

✅ Warm compresses, lid massage, and lid washing :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Botulinum toxin injection:
Incorrect: Botulinum toxin injection can be utilized for recurrent blepharospasm; however, it is not indicated in the management of uncomplicated blepharitis.  
❌ Oral amoxicillin-clavulanic acid:
Incorrect: Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is a first-line treatment for patients with peri-orbital or pre-septal cellulitis. This condition presents with pronounced swelling, tenderness and erythema of the peri-orbital soft tissues, and often fever—which are absent in this patient.  
❌ Steroid injection:
Incorrect: A steroid injection is appropriate for the treatment of a chalazion that is refractory to conservative therapy with warm compresses. It is not indicated in the management of blepharitis.  
❌ Check lipid panel :
Incorrect: A lipid panel would be appropriate in the evaluation of xanthelasma palpebrarum, a benign condition characterized by the development of soft, semisolid, yellow papules or plaques containing cholesterol that typically form over the eyelid. However, the exam findings for this patient are more consistent with blepharitis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of left leg pain and black discoloration of the left toes. The pain occurs with walking and resolves with rest. He first noticed a black discoloration of the toes two days ago and it has progressively worsened since then. He does not have any chest pain or shortness of breath. Past medical history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He does not take any medications. The patient’s father died of a myocardial infarction at 60 years of age. The patient has a 35-pack year smoking history and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. Temperature is 37.2 C (98.9 F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mmHg. Which of the following additional clinical findings will likely be observed on further evaluation?

choices.text: Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa
Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes
Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of intermittent leg pain and black discoloration of toes in the presence of multiple risk factors (smoking, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus), is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Further physical examination is likely to demonstrate diminished posterior tibial artery pulsations. 

Examination in patients with PAD commonly reveals diminished or absent pulses below the level of arterial stenosis as well as evidence of poor wound healing in the area(s) of poor perfusion. 

Pimenta's Point refers to an anatomical landmark to easily palpate the posterior tibial artery. This landmark is described by the midpoint on the imaginary line drawn between the bony prominences of the medial malleolus and the insertion of the Achilles tendon. Similar to posterior tibial artery pulsations, the dorsalis pedis pulse can also be decreased or absent in patients with PAD. This artery can be readily palpated lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon (or medially to the extensor digitorum longus tendon) on the dorsal surface of the foot distal to the dorsal most prominence of the navicular bone.       

Option Analysis

❌ Bruit on the auscultation of popliteal fossa :
Incorrect: A bruit of the popliteal fossa can be seen in patients with popliteal artery aneurysms. Patients typically present with edema and pain in the popliteal fossa. The aneurysm may compress adjacent nerves leading to referred pain overlying the medial aspect of the calf, ankle, or foot.  
✅ Diminished posterior tibial pulse :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray :
Incorrect: Osteophytes on lateral foot x-ray are suggestive of osteoarthritis. Osteophytic pain may not disappear following exercise and varies in intensity from day-to-day (usually worse in the morning or upon waking). 
❌ Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes :
Incorrect: Reproduction of pain with passive dorsiflexion of the toes can be seen in compartment syndrome. Patients present with severe pain that worsens with passive stretching of the affected muscles, paresthesias, as well as sensory or motor deficits. This patient’s intermittent leg pain is suggestive of peripheral arterial disease. 
❌ Lack of femoral vein compressibility on doppler ultrasound :
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound of the lower extremities is used for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Patients typically present with leg swelling, pain, warmth, and erythema in the presence of significant risk factors (e.g., history of immobilization or prolonged hospitalization, recent surgery, or trauma). This patient has multiple atherosclerotic risk factors and claudication.

questions.text: A 62-year-old previously healthy man is brought to the emergency department after experiencing chest pain that radiates down the left arm. Emergency medical services provide the patient with supplemental oxygen, aspirin, and sublingual nitroglycerin. On arrival, temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 136/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 100/72 mmHg. Oxygen saturation is 93% on 2L nasal cannula. The patient's initial electrocardiogram is shown below. He is subsequently started on medication with moderate sodium channel blockade. Which of the following best illustrates the effect this medication will have on the cardiac action potential?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response in the setting of a clinical history concerning acute coronary syndrome. He is subsequently given medication with a moderate effect on sodium channel blockade, which is consistent with the mechanism of action of class IA antiarrhythmic medications. Among the answer choices, choice A best characterizes the effects these medications have on the cardiac action potential.        

Only sodium channel blockers (class I antiarrhythmics) will affect the duration of the action potential (AP) by modulating phase 0 (as illustrated in the figure). Class Ia drugs block fast-acting sodium channels, slowing Phase 0 upswing, and increasing the AP duration. In addition, class IA drugs have some potassium channel blockade, resulting in further AP and refractory period prolongation. Class IB drugs shorten the AP and effective refractory period. Class IC drugs dramatically slow phase 0, but do not increase the AP duration.    

Option Analysis

✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ :
Incorrect: Mexiletine is a class Ib sodium channel blocker that functions by mildly depressing phase 0 and shortening repolarization, thereby decreasing the duration of the action potential. Mexiletine has weak (not moderate) sodium channel blockade properties.  
❌ :
Incorrect: Flecainide and propafenone are class Ic sodium channel blockers that function by depressing phase 0 with minimal effects on repolarization. Therefore, these medications do not have an effect on action potential duration. Class Ic medications have strong (not moderate) sodium channel blockade properties. 
❌ :
Incorrect: Sotalol is a non-selective adrenergic ꞵ-receptor blocker. It can also block potassium channels and can be used as a class III antiarrhythmic agent, with its main effects on phases 3 and 4. Sotalol does not cause sodium channel blockade. 
❌ :
Incorrect: This graph demonstrates the effects of a class IV antiarrhythmic agent such as diltiazem. These effects are mediated by calcium channel blockade, not sodium.
